bio_naissance_annee: The eldest son of Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham), born during Abraham's time.
bio_lieu_naissance: The Valley of Makkah (by Allah's command)
bio_descendance: From his descendants came the Seal of the Prophets, Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), and all the 'Adnāni Arab tribes.
texte_original: Chapter Twenty-Seven Ishmael (Isma'il) In this chapter, we discuss the eldest son of the Intimate Friend of the Most Merciful (Khalīl Ar-Raḥmān), who is Ishmael. I have mentioned during my discussion of Abraham the story of Hagar, that the King of Egypt gave her to Sarah, that Sarah presented her to Abraham, and that she bore Ishmael to him. I also mentioned what Al-Bukhari reported in his Sahih from the hadith of Ibn 'Abbās regarding the story of Abraham's arrival with Hagar and Ishmael in Makkah, the story of Zamzam, the upbringing of Ishmael, his learning of the Arabic language, his marriage to a woman from Jurhum, and then his divorce from her by the order of his father, the 'Khalil'. Then his marriage to another righteous woman from Jurhum, and his father's order to him to keep her and establish her. I also mentioned the story of Ishmael helping Abraham in building the Sacred House (the Kaaba). I have established the clear evidence that Ishmael is the one commanded to be sacrificed (Adh-Dhabīḥ), not Isaac, and that the description of Ishmael in the glad tidings of his birth was that of a 'forbearing boy' (*ghulām ḥalīm*), unlike the glad tidings of Isaac, who was described as a 'knowing boy' (*ghulām 'alīm*). And that Ishmael is older than Isaac, and that Abraham was not given the good news of Isaac until Ishmael had reached the age of walking and striving with his father (peace and blessings be upon them). I have also clarified that Allah placed among the descendants of Ishmael the Seal of the Prophets, the Master of the Messengers, the dazzling jewel, the radiant pearl, the one who holds the Praised Station (*Al-Maqām Al-Maḥmūd*) and the Visited Reservoir (*Al-Ḥawḍ Al-Mawrūd*), Muhammad. Allah, Blessed and Exalted is He, mentioned Ishmael in His Noble Book in several places with magnificent descriptions, as He says in Sūrat Al-Baqarah: ﴿And [mention] when Abraham was raising the foundations of the House and [with him] Ishmael, [saying], 'Our Lord, accept [this] from us. Indeed, You are the Hearing, the Knowing. Our Lord, and make us Muslims [in submission] to You and from our descendants a Muslim nation [in submission] to You. And show us our rites [of worship] and accept our repentance. Indeed, You are the Accepting of repentance, the Merciful'﴾ [Al-Baqarah: 127-128]. And He says in Sūrat Maryam: ﴿And mention in the Book Ishmael. Indeed, he was truthful in [his] promise, and he was a messenger and a prophet. And he used to enjoin on his people prayer and zakāh and was to his Lord acceptable.﴾ [Maryam: 54-55]. He also coupled him in the chain of Prophets and Messengers in places where He says: ﴿And remember Our servants, Abraham, Isaac and Jacob – those of capacity and vision. Indeed, We chose them for an exclusive quality: remembrance of the home [in the Hereafter]. And indeed, they are, in Our sight, among the chosen and outstanding. And mention Ishmael and Elisha and Dhū [al-] Kifl, and all were of the outstanding.﴾ [Ṣād: 45-48]. And Almighty says in Sūrat Al-Anbiyā': ﴿And Ishmael and Idrīs and Dhū [al-] Kifl; all were of the patient. And We admitted them into Our mercy. Indeed, they were of the righteous.﴾ [Al-Anbiyā': 85-86]. And Almighty says in Sūrat An-Nisā': ﴿Indeed, We have revealed to you as We revealed to Noah and the prophets after him. And We revealed to Abraham, Ishmael, Isaac, Jacob, the Descendants, Jesus, Job, Jonah, Aaron, and Solomon, and to David We gave the book [of Psalms].﴾ [An-Nisā': 163]. And Almighty says in Sūrat Al-Baqarah: ﴿Say, [O believers], 'We believe in Allah and what has been revealed to us and what was revealed to Abraham and Ishmael and Isaac and Jacob and the Descendants and what was given to Moses and Jesus and what was given to the prophets from their Lord. We make no distinction between any of them, and to Him we are Muslims.'﴾ [Al-Baqarah: 136]. And Almighty says in Sūrat Āl 'Imrān: ﴿Say, 'We believe in Allah and in what was sent down to us and what was sent down to Abraham, Ishmael, Isaac, Jacob, and the Descendants, and what was given to Moses and Jesus and the prophets from their Lord. We make no distinction between any of them, and to Him we are Muslims.'﴾ [Āl 'Imrān: 84]. And He absolved Abraham, Ishmael, Isaac, Jacob, and the Descendants from [the claim of] Judaism and Christianity, as He says: ﴿Or are you saying that Abraham and Ishmael and Isaac and Jacob and the Descendants were Jews or Christians? Say, 'Are you more knowing or is Allah?' And who is more unjust than one who conceals a testimony he has from Allah? And Allah is not unaware of what you do.﴾ [Al-Baqarah: 140]. Allah, Blessed and Exalted is He, mentioned in His Noble Book a stature for Ishmael below which high ranks fall short, when his father, the 'Khalil', informed him that he saw in a dream that he was sacrificing him. Ishmael immediately submitted, recognizing that the vision of Prophets is a revelation to which one must hasten to obey and execute the command, even if it meant his sacrifice. He offered his very self in compliance with Allah's command and obedience to Allah's Messenger, and all of humanity has not known a station like this. In this regard, Allah, Blessed and Exalted is He, says in Sūrat Aṣ-Ṣāffāt: ﴿And indeed, among his kind was Abraham, When he came to his Lord with a sound heart. When he said to his father and his people, 'What do you worship? Is it falsehood – [as] gods besides Allah – that you desire? Then what is your thought about the Lord of the worlds?' And he cast a glance at the stars And said, 'Indeed, I am sick.' So they turned away from him, retreating. Then he turned to their gods and said, 'Do you not eat? What is [wrong] with you that you do not speak?' And he turned upon them, striking [them] with [his] right hand. Then [the people] came toward him, hastening. He said, 'Do you worship that which you carve, While Allah created you and that which you do?' They said, 'Construct for him a furnace and throw him into the blazing fire.' So they intended a plot against him, but We made them the lowest. And [then] he said, 'Indeed, I am going to my Lord; He will guide me. My Lord, grant me [a child] from among the righteous.' So We gave him good tidings of a forbearing boy. And when he reached with him [the age of] striving, he said, 'O my son, indeed I have seen in a dream that I [must] sacrifice you, so look what you think.' He said, 'O my father, do what you are commanded. You will find me, if Allah wills, of the patient.' And when they had both submitted [to the command of Allah] – meaning, they submitted to Allah's command – and he put him down upon his forehead – meaning, he laid him down on his forehead so that Allah's command could be carried out on him – ﴿We called to him, 'O Abraham, You have fulfilled the vision.'﴾ – meaning, you have fulfilled what Allah commanded you to do – ﴿Indeed, We thus reward the doers of good. Indeed, this was the clear trial. And We ransomed him with a great sacrifice.﴾ [Aṣ-Ṣāffāt: 83-107]. There is no dispute among genealogists that all the 'Adnāni Arab tribes are from the progeny of Ishmael. As for the Qaḥṭāni tribes, the majority of scholars hold that they are not from the progeny of Ishmael, and the general opinion of scholars is that Khuzā'ah is from Qaḥṭān, as are the Aws and the Khazraj. It is reported in Sahih Al-Bukhari from the hadith of Salama ibn Al-Akwa' (may Allah be pleased with him) that he said: The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) passed by a group from Aslam who were competing in archery—meaning, they were shooting arrows for a competition. He said: 'Shoot, O Sons of Ishmael, for your father was an archer, and I am with the son of so-and-so' (referring to one of the two teams). He said: 'One of the two teams held back their hands.' So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: 'What is wrong with you that you do not shoot?' They said: 'O Messenger of Allah, [how can we] while you are with them?' He said: 'Shoot, and I am with all of you.' In another wording by Al-Bukhari from the hadith of Salama (may Allah be pleased with him), he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) came out to a group from Aslam who were competing in archery in the market. He said: 'Shoot, O Sons of Ishmael, for your father was an archer, and I am with the sons of so-and-so' (to one of the two teams). They held back their hands. He said: 'What is wrong with them?' They said: 'How can we shoot while you are with the sons of so-and-so?' He said: 'Shoot, and I am with all of you.' The tribe of Aslam belongs to Aslam ibn Afṣā ibn Ḥāritha ibn 'Amr ibn 'Āmir of Khuzā'ah. This poses no problem for those who claim that Qaḥṭān is from the progeny of Ishmael. As for the majority of scholars who hold that the Qaḥṭāni tribes are not from the progeny of Ishmael, they say that this hadith may be interpreted as Aslam being from the progeny of Ishmael through the mothers, not the fathers, because the Qaḥṭāni and 'Adnāni tribes intermingled through marriage, and there is no objection to such an attribution, just as all the sons of Fāṭima Az-Zahrā' are attributed to the Messenger of Allah. Until the next chapter, if Allah wills, and peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you.
source: Holy Quran, Sahih Al-Bukhari, and the exegesis cited in the preceding text

bio_naissance_annee: No specific birth date; born in Egypt during the reign of Pharaoh, a time when he was slaughtering the sons of the Children of Israel.
bio_lieu_naissance: Egypt (birth, upbringing, and mission), then Midian (Moses' exile), then Mount Tûr (receiving the Message).
bio_descendance: Musa and Harun are full brothers, both prophets and Messengers. Harun served as Musa's minister and assistant in the call to Pharaoh.
texte_original: Moses. We speak to you about the great Prophet of the Children of Israel, one of the Messengers of firm resolve, the one who spoke directly with God (Kalīm Allāh), Moses son of 'Imran, peace be upon him. 'Imran, the father of Moses, was from the lineage of Jacob, son of Isaac, son of Abraham, peace be upon them. He is not the 'Imran mentioned in Sūrah Āl 'Imrān (The Family of 'Imran), which is named after him, where God (Exalted is He) says: {Indeed, Allah chose Adam and Noah and the family of Abraham and the family of 'Imran over the worlds.} [Āl 'Imrān: 33]. That 'Imran is the father of Maryam (Mary), the mother of Jesus. God (Exalted is He) clarified this immediately after this verse, saying: {Descendants, one of the other; and Allah is Hearing and Knowing. [Mention] when the wife of 'Imran said, 'My Lord, indeed I have vowed to You what is in my womb, dedicated [to Your service], so accept this from me. Indeed, You are the Hearing, the Knowing.' But when she delivered her, she said, 'My Lord, indeed I have delivered a female.' And Allah was most knowing of what she delivered. 'And the male is not like the female. And I have named her Maryam, and I seek refuge for her in You and [for] her descendants from Satan, the expelled [from God's mercy].'} [Āl 'Imrān: 34-36]. Nearly two thousand years separate 'Imran, the father of Moses, and 'Imran, the father of Maryam. Allah (Blessed and Exalted is He) alluded to the situation prevalent in Egypt at the time of Moses' birth, as the oppression and tyranny of Pharaoh against the Children of Israel and his corruption on Earth had reached the utmost limits of arrogance. He had divided its people into factions, favoring some and oppressing others, namely the Children of Israel. He was slaying their sons and letting their women live, employing those who were oppressed in humiliation, various forms of degradation, and torment. Allah (Exalted is He) intended to confer favor upon those who had been oppressed on Earth among the Children of Israel, who were at that time confined in Egypt, to make them leaders of guidance, to grant them security, to establish them firmly in the land, and to make them the inheritors, while replacing their fear with safety. Hatred and resentment toward the Children of Israel had ignited in the hearts of Pharaoh, Haman, and their armies because of the premonition instilled in their minds that the end of their dominion and their destruction would occur at the hands of a man from the Children of Israel. Yet, caution cannot avert fate. Allah (Exalted is He) willed to show Pharaoh, Haman, and their armies from them what they were apprehensive of. [Al-Qasas: 6]. Thus, Moses was born in this suffocating atmosphere. His mother feared that Pharaoh would kill him, as Moses' birth coincided with one of the periods when Pharaoh carried out the slaughter of the male infants of the Children of Israel. So, Allah (Almighty) inspired Moses' mother: "Suckle him; but when you fear for him from Pharaoh killing him, fashion a solid box for him like a boat, place him in the box, and cast him into the Nile River. Banish fear from yourself, so neither fear nor grieve, for Allah (Exalted is He) will preserve him for you, return him to you, and your son will be one of the Messengers. " Some scholars said that the revelation here means an inspiration or a dream. I say there is no impediment to Allah (Blessed and Exalted is He) having sent an angel to her with this revelation, and that she believed in him and affirmed His promise. The angel's arrival with this advice does not necessitate that she was a prophetess. It is established in the two authentic collections of Al-Bukhārī and Muslim, from the Hadīth of Abū Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him), that he heard the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) say: "Allah wished to test three men from the Children of Israel: a leper, a bald man, and a blind man. So He sent an angel to them. The angel came to the leper and asked, 'What thing is most beloved to you?' He replied, 'A beautiful color and beautiful skin, and that the defect which has made people shun me be removed.' The angel wiped him, and his defect disappeared, and he was given a beautiful color. The angel then asked, 'What wealth is most beloved to you?' He replied, 'Camels,' or he said, 'Cows,' (the narrator was in doubt). He was given a pregnant she-camel, and the angel said, 'May Allah bless it for you.' Then he came to the bald man and asked, 'What thing is most beloved to you?' He replied, 'Beautiful hair, and that the defect which has made people shun me be removed.' The angel wiped him, and his defect disappeared, and he was given beautiful hair. The angel then asked, 'What wealth is most beloved to you?' He replied, 'Cows.' He was given a pregnant cow, and the angel said, 'May Allah bless it for you.' Then he came to the blind man and asked, 'What thing is most beloved to you?' He replied, 'That Allah restore my sight so I can see people.' The angel wiped him, and Allah restored his sight to him. The angel then asked, 'What wealth is most beloved to you?' He replied, 'Sheep.' He was given a lamb that had just given birth. The first two produced offspring, and the third one also gave birth. Thus, one had a valley of camels, another a valley of cows, and the third a valley of sheep. Then the angel came to the leper in his former appearance and condition. He said, 'I am a poor man whose means have been cut off during my journey, and I have no means of reaching my destination today except by God and then by you. I ask you, by the One Who gave you the beautiful color, the beautiful skin, and the wealth, a camel to help me in my journey.' He replied, 'The rights [upon this wealth] are many.' The angel said, 'I think I know you. Were you not a leper whom people shunned, and poor, and then Allah gave you [this]?' He replied, 'I inherited this wealth from my forefathers, generation after generation.' The angel said, 'If you are lying, may Allah turn you back to what you were.' Then he came to the bald man in his former appearance and condition, and said to him the same as he said to the first, and the man replied with the same answer. The angel said, 'If you are lying, may Allah turn you back to what you were.' Then he came to the blind man in his former appearance and condition. He said, 'I am a poor man and a traveler whose means have been cut off during my journey, and I have no means of reaching my destination today except by God and then by you. I ask you, by the One Who restored your sight to you, a sheep to help me in my journey.' The man said, 'I was blind, and Allah restored my sight to me. So take whatever you wish and leave whatever you wish. By Allah, I will not burden you today by demanding anything you take for the sake of Allah.' The angel said, 'Keep your wealth. You were merely being tested. Allah is pleased with you and displeased with your two companions.' This authentic Hadīth, agreed upon, proves that God may send an angel to one of His servants who is neither a Prophet nor a Messenger. Similarly, Muslim narrated in his Sahīh, from the Hadīth of Abū Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him), that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "A man set out to visit a brother of his in another village. Allah (Almighty) stationed an angel on his path. When the angel came to him, he asked, 'Where are you going?' He replied, 'I intend to visit a brother of mine in this village.' The angel asked, 'Do you have a favor that you want to gain from him?' He replied, 'No, except that I love him for the sake of Allah (Almighty).' The angel said, 'Then I am a messenger of Allah to you [to inform you] that Allah loves you as you have loved him for His sake.' This proves that Allah (Almighty) may send an angel to some people and address them without them being Prophets. Allah (Almighty) also sent angels to Maryam (Mary), as He says: {And [mention] when the angels said, 'O Maryam, indeed Allah has chosen you and purified you and chosen you above the women of the worlds. O Maryam, be devoutly obedient to your Lord and prostrate and bow with those who bow [in prayer].'} [Āl 'Imrān: 42-43]. Then He (Almighty) says: { [Mention] when the angels said, 'O Maryam, indeed Allah gives you good tidings of a word from Him, whose name will be the Messiah, Jesus, the son of Maryam - distinguished in this world and the Hereafter and among the nearest [to Allah]. He will speak to the people in the cradle and in maturity and will be of the righteous.'} [Āl 'Imrān: 45-46]. Maryam was not a prophetess, but a righteous, truthful woman from the devout ones. Regarding the birth of Moses, the description of the atmosphere in which he was born, Pharaoh's tyranny, his humiliation of the Children of Israel, and the inspiration to Moses' mother to cast him into the river with the promise of his return to her, Allah says: {We recite to you from the news of Moses and Pharaoh in truth for a people who believe. Indeed, Pharaoh was haughty in the land and made its people into factions, oppressing a sector among them, slaughtering their [male] sons and letting their women live. Indeed, he was of the corrupters. But We wanted to confer favor upon those who were oppressed in the land and make them leaders and make them the inheritors. And establish them in the land and show Pharaoh and Haman and their soldiers through them that which they had been fearing. And We inspired to the mother of Moses, 'Suckle him; but when you fear for him, cast him into the river and do not fear nor grieve. Indeed, We will return him to you and make him one of the Messengers.'} [Al-Qasas: 3-7]. And until the next chapter, God willing. Peace be upon you and the mercy and blessings of Allah. Chapter Forty-Five: Moses Continued 190. At the end of the previous chapter, I mentioned what Allah (Exalted is He) recounted about the birth of Moses and the inspiration of Allah (Almighty) to his mother: {Suckle him; but when you fear for him, cast him into the river and do not fear nor grieve. Indeed, We will return him to you and make him one of the Messengers.} [Al-Qasas: 7]. This revelation included two commands, two prohibitions, and two pieces of news. Allah (Blessed and Exalted is He) summarized this in Sūrah Ṭā-Hā, where He mentions His favor upon Moses, saying: {And We had already conferred favor upon you another time, when We inspired to your mother what was inspired} [Ṭā-Hā: 37-38], then He detailed that summarized revelation, saying: { 'Put him into the chest and cast it into the river, and the river will throw it onto the bank; an enemy to Me and an enemy to him will take him.' And I bestowed upon you love from Me that you might be brought up under My eye.} [Ṭā-Hā: 39]. Moses' mother did as Allah (Almighty) commanded her. She cast her child into the river after placing him in the chest (the Ark). Allah (Blessed and Exalted is He) mentioned that the river cast the chest containing Moses onto the bank, which is the river's shore, in front of the house of Pharaoh's family. {Then the family of Pharaoh picked him up} [Al-Qasas: 8]. They rejoiced in him because of the love that Allah had cast upon Moses in the heart of anyone who saw him. However, Pharaoh feared that he might be from the Children of Israel and considered killing him. His wife, Asiya, said: { 'Do not kill him; perhaps he may benefit us, or we may adopt him as a son.'} [Al-Qasas: 9]. They were unaware that they were picking up the one at whose hands their kingdom would be destroyed, and who would be an enemy and a sorrow for them. Thus, Allah ordained for him that his fiercest enemy should raise him, and that he should grow up in their house, just as the poet said: "And if Providence watches you with its eyes, sleep, for all fears are security. " Allah (Almighty) prepared for him the righteous woman Asiya, the wife of Pharaoh, the enemy of Allah and His Messengers, to oversee his upbringing. However, Allah (Exalted is He) prevented him from taking the breast of any woman other than his mother. Whenever they brought him a wet nurse, he refused to suckle from her breast. The condition of Moses' mother, with the intensity of her contained fear for him, reached a point where her heart became empty (of all but fear), as if she was about to disclose [her secret], had not Allah strengthened her heart, so that she would be among the believers. She told his sister to follow his trail and see what those who had picked him up would do with him, and to be careful not to let them know that she was his sister or that she was trying to find out anything about him. She was to look from a distance and in an oblique manner that would not reveal her preoccupation with him. His sister carried out her mother's instruction. They passed by her while searching for a wet nurse for him. She said, "I will guide you to a wet nurse whom he may accept. " So, they brought him to his mother, and he took her breast, and they rejoiced greatly. They began to take him back and forth to her. Her eye was comforted by him, and Allah (Almighty) relieved her of her grief over him. She learned that the promise of Allah was true, and that Allah is capable of all things, and that when He wills a matter, He prepares the means for it and removes the obstacles. Moses continued to live in Pharaoh's house as if he were their own child, surrounded by their affection, until he reached his full strength and maturity. Allah filled his heart with wisdom, understanding, and knowledge. In this is the strengthening of the heart of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and the believers, and that Allah (Almighty) grants victory to His allies, delivers them from tribulations, and saves them from harm. Concerning all of this, Allah (Blessed and Exalted is He) says in Sūrah Al-Qasas: {Then the family of Pharaoh picked him up [to be] to them an enemy and a grief. Indeed, Pharaoh, Haman and their soldiers were wrongdoers. And the wife of Pharaoh said, '[He will be] a comfort of the eye for me and for you. Do not kill him; perhaps he may benefit us, or we may adopt him as a son.' And they perceived not. And the heart of Moses' mother became empty [of all else]. She was about to disclose [the matter] concerning him had not We made [her heart] firm, that she might be among the believers. And she said to his sister, 'Follow him.' So she watched him from a distance while they perceived not. And We had prevented from him [all] wet nurses before, so she said, 'Shall I direct you to the people of a household who will be responsible for him for you while they are to him [internally] sincere?' So We restored him to his mother that her eyes might be comforted and that she might not grieve and that she might know that the promise of Allah is true. But most of them do not know. And when he attained his full strength and was [mentally] mature, We gave him judgment and knowledge. And thus do We reward the doers of good.} [Al-Qasas: 8-14]. And He (Almighty) says in Sūrah Ṭā-Hā: {When your sister went and said, 'Shall I direct you to one who will take care of him?' So We restored you to your mother that her eyes might be comforted and she might not grieve.} [Ṭā-Hā: 40]. In the saying of Allah (Almighty): {Then the family of Pharaoh picked him up [to be] to them an enemy and a grief}, the Lām in {to be to them an enemy and a grief} is the Lām of consequence. That is, they did not realize that the consequence of their picking him up would be for him to become an enemy and a grief to them. How often does a person perform an action for a certain purpose, only for its consequence to be the opposite of what he intended, because the entire matter belongs solely to Allah. The human, no matter how much he claims power and knowledge, is ignorant of the consequence of his affair. Haman was Pharaoh's minister (may Allah curse them both). Regarding Moses' upbringing in Pharaoh's house, Allah (Almighty) says in Sūrah Ash-Shu'arā (The Poets): { [Pharaoh] said, 'Did we not raise you among us as a child, and did you remain among us for years of your life?'} [Ash-Shu'arā: 18]. After Moses reached his full strength, maturity, and his intellect became complete, and Allah (Almighty) bestowed upon him wisdom, understanding, and knowledge, Allah intended to bring about an event at his hands that would prompt him to leave Egypt, flee from Pharaoh's family, and distance himself from their customs and traditions. Allah destined him to enter the center of the city at a moment of its people's inattention, either during their sleep or when they were occupied with their games and amusements, where the roads were almost empty of passersby. He found two men fighting, each seeking to harm the other. Moses knew that one was an Israelite and the other a Copt. It seemed to him that the Copt was stronger than the Israelite, and that is why the Israelite implored him and asked for his help. Moses (Exalted is He) intended to push the Copt away from the Israelite, so he struck him with his hand and shoved him with his clenched fist to repel him. Moses did not know that this single blow would kill him. Therefore, he felt intense remorse and attributed this evil to Satan, saying: { 'This is from the work of Satan. Indeed, he is a clear, misleading enemy.' He said, 'My Lord, indeed I have wronged myself, so forgive me,' and He forgave him. Indeed, He is the Forgiving, the Merciful.} [Al-Qasas: 15-16]. He resolved not to return to such an act and said: { 'My Lord, for the favor which You bestowed upon me, I will never be an ally to the criminals.'} [Al-Qasas: 17], meaning, a supporter of any criminal disbeliever. He then spent the morning {in the city, fearful and anticipating} [Al-Qasas: 18] what the killing of this Copt would lead to, and whether they would realize it was Moses and apprehend him for it. While he was thus on a road near the place where the Copt was killed, the same Israelite he had helped yesterday was calling out to him (imploring and asking for his aid) against another Copt. Moses (Exalted is He) responded to him by saying, "Indeed, you are clearly misguided [and a source of trouble]. " [Al-Qasas: 19]. When Moses gestured with his hand toward the Israelite, a gesture of anger, rebuking him for his bad behavior, the Israelite said: { 'O Moses, do you intend to kill me as you killed a soul yesterday? You only want to be a tyrant in the land and do not want to be of the reformers.'} [Al-Qasas: 19]. Moses then knew that the news would inevitably reach Pharaoh from this Copt, and that they would surely kill him. Indeed, the Copt informed Pharaoh's family that Moses was the one who had killed the Copt the day before, and they plotted to kill Moses. And until the next chapter, God willing. Peace be upon you and the mercy and blessings of Allah. Chapter Forty-Six: Moses Continued 199. I mentioned at the end of the previous chapter that the Copt informed Pharaoh's family that Moses was the one who killed the Copt, and that they plotted against him. Moses felt great grief, a severe trial, and an intense affliction. Allah (Almighty) disposed for Moses a man whose house was near Pharaoh's family, living with them in the outskirts of the city—as was the custom in ancient and modern times for the elite to reside in the outlying areas. This man knew their news and had a strong affection for Moses. He rushed to search for Moses until he found him inside the city, and he informed him that Pharaoh's notables were conspiring against Moses to kill him. He commanded him to quickly flee from Egypt to escape their evil and be saved from their plot. He explained that his motive for this was his love and sincere advice for him. Moses quickly left, heading towards Sinai, invoking his Lord to save him from the unjust people who were deciding to kill someone who did not deserve to be killed. He (Exalted is He) resolved to proceed {towards Madyan}, but he was unfamiliar with the route. He earnestly supplicated to Allah (Almighty) to guide him to its path, to grant him success in taking the intended road, and to direct him to the straight path. He continued his journey until he {arrived at the water of Madyan}, where he found a group of people watering their livestock. He found before this group of waterers two women holding back their sheep from the water, even though Moses saw the sheep in need of water. Moses asked the two women: { 'What is your circumstance?'} Why are you holding back your sheep from the water when they need it? {They said, 'We do not water until the shepherds depart; and our father is an old man who is very old'} and cannot attend to watering our sheep. Moses stepped forward and watered for them without asking for any payment. After watering their sheep, he withdrew to the shade of a nearby tree, sat under it, and secretly addressed his Lord: {He said, 'My Lord, indeed I am, for whatever good You would send down to me, in need.'} [Al-Qasas: 24]. Then one of the two women came to him, with shyness apparent on her face and in her walk. {She said, 'Indeed, my father invites you that he may reward you for having watered for us.'} [Al-Qasas: 25] and recompense this kindness with kindness. When Moses came to the old man and recounted to him his story with Pharaoh's family, {the old man said, 'Fear not. You have escaped from the unjust people.'} [Al-Qasas: 25]. One of the two women then asked her father to hire Moses to tend their sheep. She informed her father that he was the best to hire because he was strong and trustworthy, embodying the most important, best, and most reliable qualities of an employee. She seemed to have known this from observing him while he was watering the sheep, along with his lowered gaze and good demeanor. The old man said: { 'Indeed, I wish to wed you to one of these two daughters of mine on [the condition] that you serve me for eight years. But if you complete ten, it will be [as a favor] from you, and I do not want to make hardship for you. You will find me, if Allah wills, to be of the righteous.'} [Al-Qasas: 27]. Moses agreed to marry one of the two women, with the dowry being service for eight years, to be completed as ten if he wished. Undoubtedly, this was a high dowry, but it was part of Allah's wisdom and His preparation of Moses, so that this term would be the remaining period until Allah would send him as a Messenger, complete His favor upon him, and he would come to Mount Tur at the appointed time. Allah (Exalted is He) alludes to all of this in Sūrah Ṭā-Hā, clarifying the grief and sorrow that befell Moses after the killing of the Copt, the Israelite's call for help the next day, and his flight to the land of Madyan and his stay there as long as Allah willed, saying: {And you killed a soul, but We saved you from the distress, and We tried you with successive trials. And you remained some years among the people of Madyan. Then you came [here] at the decreed time, O Moses. And I produced you for Myself.} [Ṭā-Hā: 40-41]. And Allah (Exalted is He) says in Sūrah Al-Qasas: {And he entered the city at a time of [near] inattention by its people and found therein two men fighting: one from his faction and one from among his enemies. And the one from his faction called to him for help against the one from his enemy, so Moses struck him with his fist and eliminated him. [Moses] said, 'This is from the work of Satan. Indeed, he is a clear, misleading enemy.' He said, 'My Lord, indeed I have wronged myself, so forgive me,' and He forgave him. Indeed, He is the Forgiving, the Merciful. He said, 'My Lord, for the favor which You bestowed upon me, I will never be an ally to the criminals.' And he spent the morning in the city, fearful and anticipating [what might happen]. And suddenly the one who had sought his help the previous day cried out to him [again]. Moses said to him, 'Indeed, you are clearly misguided.' And when he wanted to strike the one who was an enemy to both of them, [the Israelite] said, 'O Moses, do you intend to kill me as you killed a soul yesterday? You only want to be a tyrant in the land and do not want to be of the reformers.' And a man came running from the farthest end of the city. He said, 'O Moses, indeed the assembly is conspiring against you to kill you, so depart; indeed, I am to you of the sincere advisors.' So he left it, fearful and anticipating [apprehension]. He said, 'My Lord, save me from the unjust people.' And when he directed his face toward Madyan, he said, 'Perhaps my Lord will guide me to the right path.' And when he came to the water of Madyan, he found there a crowd of people watering [their flocks], and he found aside from them two women keeping back [their flocks]. He said, 'What is your circumstance?' They said, 'We do not water until the shepherds depart; and our father is an old man who is very old.' So he watered [their flocks] for them; then he went back to the shade and said, 'My Lord, indeed I am, for whatever good You would send down to me, in need.' Then one of the two women came to him walking with shyness. She said, 'Indeed, my father invites you that he may reward you for having watered for us.' So when he came to him and related to him the story, the old man said, 'Fear not. You have escaped from the unjust people.' One of [the women] said, 'O my father, hire him. Indeed, the best of those you can hire is the strong and the trustworthy.' He said, 'Indeed, I wish to wed you to one of these two daughters of mine on [the condition] that you serve me for eight years. But if you complete ten, it will be [as a favor] from you, and I do not want to make hardship for you. You will find me, if Allah wills, to be of the righteous.' [Moses] said, 'That is [established] between me and you. Whichever of the two terms I complete, there is to be no injustice to me, and Allah is over what we say a Witness.'} [Al-Qasas: 15-28]. I mentioned in the story of Shu'ayb (Jethro) that he was not Moses' father-in-law, and that the old man who married his daughter to Moses in Madyan was a righteous man from the remnants of those who believed in Shu'ayb. I mentioned what indicates this from the Book of Allah (Blessed and Exalted is He) in this context. As for the Hadīth of Al-Futūn (The Trials) which is famous among people, and which An-Nasā'ī mentioned in the book of Tafsīr (Exegesis) from his Sunan, which includes the detailed story of Moses from beginning to end, An-Nasā'ī reported it, saying: "'Abdullāh ibn Muhammad narrated to us, Yazīd ibn Hārūn narrated to us, Asbagh ibn Zayd narrated to us, Al-Qāsim ibn Abī Ayyūb informed me, Sa'īd ibn Jubayr said: I asked 'Abdullāh ibn 'Abbās about the saying of Allah (Almighty) to Moses: {and We tried you with successive trials} [Ṭā-Hā: 40], and I asked him about what Al-Futūn were. He said: 'Wait until morning, O son of Jubayr, for it is a long narrative.' When morning came, I went to Ibn 'Abbās to fulfill the promise he had made regarding the Hadīth of Al-Futūn. He then narrated the Hadīth. Ibn Kathīr said in his history after narrating it: "Thus, Imam An-Nasā'ī narrated this Hadīth, and Ibn Jarīr and Ibn Abī Ḥātim also extracted it in their Tafsīr from the Hadīth of Yazīd ibn Hārūn. The most probable, and Allah knows best, is that it is Mawqūf (attributed to a Companion), and its being Marfū' (attributed to the Prophet) is questionable. Most of it is derived from the Isrā'īliyyāt (narratives from the People of the Book). " Then he said: "And there is doubt and oddity in some of what is in it. It is most likely from the speech of Ka'b Al-Ahbār, and I heard our Shaykh, Al-Ḥāfiz Abul-Ḥajjāj Al-Mizzī, say that. And Allah knows best. " And until the next chapter, God willing. Peace be upon you and the mercy and blessings of Allah. Chapter Forty-Seven: Moses Continued After Moses had completed the term he was obligated to, and fulfilled it in the most perfect manner, Allah inspired him to head with his family towards Egypt. He did not know that the decrees of bliss awaited him on the way, and that Allah (Exalted is He) would call him, speak to him, and converse secretly with him in the Sacred Valley of Ṭuwā. He traveled with his family and a flock of sheep, heading towards the land of Egypt. During his journey, a cold wind passed over them on a dark night, preventing them from continuing, as the cold intensified and he did not know the direction of the road. Suddenly, a fire appeared to him near which he saw a tree. He felt familiarity and joy because of this. He said to his family: { 'Stay here; indeed, I have perceived a fire.'} [Ṭā-Hā: 10]. I will go to it. Perhaps I will find someone there who can guide us to the straight path, or I will bring you a piece of the fire so that you may warm yourselves with it. It is evident that his wife did not see this fire, and that the fire was only manifested to Moses alone. It also appears that Moses did not know the name of the place where he saw the fire, nor did he realize that it was the Sacred Valley of Ṭuwā, and that he would find the greatest guidance there. As soon as Moses approached the fire, with his staff in his hand, {he was called from the bank of the valley on the right side} [Al-Qasas: 30], meaning from the side of the valley next to the mountain, on his right side, from the western direction, {in the blessed spot, from the tree} [Al-Qasas: 30]: { 'Blessed is He who is in the fire and [all] around it. And exalted is Allah, Lord of the worlds.'} [An-Naml: 8]. { 'Remove your sandals; indeed, you are in the sacred valley of Ṭuwā.'} [Ṭā-Hā: 12]. { 'O Moses, indeed it is I - Allah, the Exalted in Might, the Wise.'} [An-Naml: 9]. { 'Indeed, I am Allah; there is no deity except Me, so worship Me and establish prayer for My remembrance. Indeed, the Hour is coming - I nearly conceal it - so that every soul may be recompensed according to that for which it strives. So do not let whoever does not believe in it and follows his desire avert you from it, and you [thus] perish.'} [Ṭā-Hā: 14-16]. After Allah crowned Moses with the decrees of bliss, He, the All-Knowing, the All-Aware, asked him about what was in his hand, to give him comfort and to strengthen his heart, and to show him a miracle that would indicate that Allah (Almighty) would support him, give him victory, and grant the favorable outcome to him and to those who believed in him. He said to him: { 'And what is that in your right hand, O Moses?' He said, 'It is my staff.'} [Ṭā-Hā: 17-18]. Moses did not stop at this answer, but began to explain some of the benefits of his staff, to prolong the pleasure of the intimate conversation. He said: { 'I lean upon it, and I bring down leaves with it for my sheep.'} [Ṭā-Hā: 18]. Then he said: { 'And I have therein other uses.'} [Ṭā-Hā: 18]. Perhaps he hoped that He would ask him about these other purposes and intentions, thus increasing the pleasure and prolonging the intimate conversation. The lover desires that the voice of his Beloved should never cease, as the poet said: "And there is no good except hearing your speech, face-to-face, dictated to me, and I convey it. " And as another poet said: "And when I came to visit Sa'dā, among the modest white women, her companion wished, I saw the earth folded for me and the distant drew near, if only a finished story would be repeated. " And to Allah belongs the highest example. Allah (Exalted is He) commanded him to throw the staff on the ground. He threw it, and behold, {it was a serpent, moving rapidly} [Ṭā-Hā: 20] and moving on its belly with great speed, like a small snake. When Moses saw it trembling and moving quickly, he turned and fled without looking back due to intense fear. Then Allah called him: { 'O Moses, do not fear. Indeed, in My presence the messengers do not fear.} [An-Naml: 10]. And He said to him: { 'Seize it and do not fear. We will return it to its former state.'} [Ṭā-Hā: 21]. So he took it, and it returned to being a staff in his hand as it was the first time. Then Allah (Exalted is He) commanded him to insert his hand into his bosom, meaning the opening of his garment. He inserted it, and when he withdrew it, behold, it was white without any leprosy or sickness, even though Moses was dark-skinned (adam). This was another sign. Allah (Exalted is He) commanded him to go to Pharaoh the tyrant, who said to his people: { 'I am your Lord, the Most High.'} [An-Nāzi'āt: 24]. He was to demand from him and his people the sincere worship of Allah alone, and that he should release the Children of Israel to him and deliver them from the humiliating torment. He asked him to be gentle in inviting Pharaoh to Allah and to speak to him: { 'a gentle word; perhaps he may be reminded or fear.'} [Ṭā-Hā: 44]. Moses then asked his Lord to expand his breast, ease his affair, and untie a knot from his tongue so that they might understand his speech, and to send his brother Aaron with him to strengthen his resolve and share in his mission, because Aaron son of 'Imran was known for his eloquence among his people. Allah (Exalted is He) granted him all of that and explained to him that Allah's favor upon him was great, and that this was not the first favor. He reminded him of another favor at his birth, when He inspired his mother to cast him into the river for Pharaoh's family to pick him up and raise him in the lap of his enemy, who protected and cared for him, even though he was constantly slaying the sons of the Children of Israel. Moses mentioned that he feared Pharaoh might kill him for the Copt's death, so Allah reassured him and informed him that He would grant them authority so that Pharaoh would not be able to kill him. He said to him: { 'Fear not. Indeed, I am with you both; I hear and I see. So go to him and say, 'Indeed, we are the messengers of your Lord, so send with us the Children of Israel and do not torment them. We have come to you with a sign from your Lord, and peace will be upon whoever follows the guidance.'} [Ṭā-Hā: 46-47]. Allah (Blessed and Exalted is He) described Moses' arrival at the Sacred Valley of Ṭuwā, specified the place where the intimate conversation took place, and mentioned what Moses secretly said in various places in the Great Qur'an to strengthen the heart of the Messenger of Allah Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and to be a clear sign to the Arabs and non-Arabs that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah. Neither the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) nor any of his people knew these accurate and truthful accounts. He was the illiterate among the illiterate people. Muhammad was not on the western side when Allah decreed the matter to Moses, nor was he among the witnesses. Nor was he on the side of the Mount when Moses was called. But it is a mercy from Allah for the bearer of good tidings and the warner, and for those who believe in him until the Day of Resurrection. Concerning this, Allah (Blessed and Exalted is He) says in Sūrah Maryam (Mary): {And mention in the Book, Moses. Indeed, he was chosen, and he was a messenger and a prophet. And We called him from the side of the mount's right and brought him near in [private] conversation. And We bestowed upon him through Our mercy his brother Aaron as a prophet.} [Maryam: 51-53]. And He (Exalted is He) says in Sūrah Ṭā-Hā: {And has the story of Moses reached you? When he saw a fire and said to his family, 'Stay here; indeed, I have perceived a fire; perhaps I can bring you from it a burning ember or find at the fire some guidance.' And when he came to it, he was called, 'O Moses, Indeed, I am your Lord, so remove your sandals. Indeed, you are in the sacred valley of Ṭuwā. And I have chosen you, so listen to what is revealed [to you]. Indeed, I am Allah; there is no deity except Me, so worship Me and establish prayer for My remembrance. Indeed, the Hour is coming - I nearly conceal it - so that every soul may be recompensed according to that for which it strives. So do not let whoever does not believe in it and follows his desire avert you from it, and you [thus] perish. And what is that in your right hand, O Moses?' He said, 'It is my staff; I lean upon it, and I bring down leaves with it for my sheep, and I have therein other uses.' [Allah] said, 'Throw it down, O Moses.' So he threw it down, and thereupon it was a serpent, moving rapidly. [Allah] said, 'Seize it and do not fear. We will return it to its former state. And draw in your hand to your side; it will emerge white without disability - [that is] another sign - that We may show you [some] of Our greater signs. Go to Pharaoh. Indeed, he has transgressed.' [Moses] said, 'My Lord, expand for me my breast [with assurance], and ease for me my task, and untie the knot from my tongue that they may understand my speech. And appoint for me a minister from my family - Aaron, my brother. Increase thereby my strength and let him share my task that we may praise You much and remember You much. Indeed, You are of us ever Seeing.' [Allah] said, 'You have been granted your request, O Moses. And We had already conferred favor upon you another time'} [Ṭā-Hā: 9-37]. And until the next chapter, God willing. Peace be upon you and the mercy and blessings of Allah. Chapter Forty-Eight: Moses Continued 207. In this chapter, we continue what Allah (Exalted is He) mentioned in Sūrah Ṭā-Hā regarding the story of Moses' arrival at the Sacred Valley of Ṭuwā, Allah's intimate conversation with him, and His favor upon him, where He says: {And We had already conferred favor upon you another time, when We inspired to your mother what was inspired: 'Put him into the chest and cast it into the river, and the river will throw it onto the bank; an enemy to Me and an enemy to him will take him.' And I bestowed upon you love from Me that you might be brought up under My eye. When your sister went and said, 'Shall I direct you to one who will take care of him?' So We restored you to your mother that her eyes might be comforted and she might not grieve. And you killed a soul, but We saved you from the distress, and We tried you with successive trials. And you remained some years among the people of Madyan. Then you came [here] at the decreed time, O Moses. And I produced you for Myself. Go, you and your brother, with My signs and do not slacken in My remembrance. Go to Pharaoh. Indeed, he has transgressed. And speak to him with gentle speech that perhaps he may be reminded or fear.' They said, 'Our Lord, indeed we fear that he may hasten [punishment] upon us or that he may transgress.' He said, 'Fear not. Indeed, I am with you both; I hear and I see. So go to him and say, 'Indeed, we are the messengers of your Lord, so send with us the Children of Israel and do not torment them. We have come to you with a sign from your Lord, and peace will be upon whoever follows the guidance. Indeed, it has been revealed to us that the punishment will be upon whoever denies and turns away.'} [Ṭā-Hā: 37-48]. And He (Exalted is He) says in Sūrah Ash-Shu'arā (The Poets): {And [mention] when your Lord called Moses, [saying], 'Go to the wrongdoing people - The people of Pharaoh; will they not fear Allah?' He said, 'My Lord, indeed I fear that they will deny me, and that my breast will tighten and my tongue will not be fluent, so send [a messenger] to Aaron. And they have against me a [claim of] sin, so I fear that they will kill me.' [Allah] said, 'No, never! Go both of you with Our signs; indeed, We are with you, listening. Go to Pharaoh and say, 'We are the messenger of the Lord of the worlds, [commanding] that you send with us the Children of Israel.'} [Ash-Shu'arā: 10-17]. And He (Exalted is He) says in Sūrah An-Naml (The Ants): { [Mention] when Moses said to his family, 'Indeed, I have perceived a fire. I will bring you from there an account or bring you a burning branch so that you may warm yourselves.' But when he came to it, he was called, 'Blessed is He who is in the fire and [all] around it. And exalted is Allah, Lord of the worlds. O Moses, indeed it is I - Allah, the Exalted in Might, the Wise. And throw down your staff!' But when he saw it writhing as if it were a serpent, he turned in flight and did not return. [Allah said], 'O Moses, fear not. Indeed, in My presence the messengers do not fear. Except one who has wronged and then substituted good after evil, for indeed, I am Forgiving and Merciful. And put your hand into the opening of your garment; it will exit white without disability [as a sign] among nine signs [going] to Pharaoh and his people. Indeed, they have been a defiantly disobedient people.'} [An-Naml: 7-12]. And He (Almighty) says in Sūrah Al-Qasas: {And when Moses had completed the term and was traveling with his family, he perceived from the direction of Mount Ṭūr a fire. He said to his family, 'Remain [here]; indeed, I have perceived a fire; perhaps I will bring you from there information or a burning branch of fire that you may warm yourselves.' But when he came to it, he was called from the bank of the valley on the right side in the blessed spot, from the tree, 'O Moses, indeed it is I - Allah, Lord of the worlds.' And [he was told], 'Throw down your staff.' But when he saw it movement as if it were a serpent, he turned in flight and did not return. [Allah said], 'O Moses, approach and fear not. Indeed, you are of the secure. Insert your hand into the opening of your garment; it will come out white without disability, and draw in your arm to yourself [to guard] against fear. These two are proofs from your Lord to Pharaoh and his establishment. Indeed, they have been a defiantly disobedient people.' He said, 'My Lord, indeed I killed from among them a soul, and I fear that they will kill me. And my brother Aaron is more eloquent than me in speech, so send him with me as a helper to confirm me. Indeed, I fear that they will deny me.' [Allah] said, 'We will strengthen your arm through your brother and grant you both supremacy so they will not reach you. [It will be] by Our signs; you two and those who follow you will be the predominant.'} [Al-Qasas: 29-35]. And He says in Sūrah An-Nāzi'āt (Those Who Drag Forth): {Has there come to you the story of Moses? When his Lord called to him in the sacred valley of Ṭuwā, 'Go to Pharaoh. Indeed, he has transgressed. And say to him, 'Would you [like to] purify yourself, and that I guide you to your Lord so you would fear [Him]?'} [An-Nāzi'āt: 15-19]. And His saying (Exalted is He): {Then you came [here] at the decreed time, O Moses.} [Ṭā-Hā: 40]. That is, your journey from the land of Madyan to the land of Egypt so that your Lord could call you and converse secretly with you in the Sacred Valley was a predestined matter decreed by Allah. He moved you, directed you, and inspired you to seek refuge in the blessed spot according to what Allah had decreed in eternity and predestined before the creation of the heavens and the earth. Everything with Him is by measure. And He is {Knower of the unseen and the witnessed, the Grand, the Exalted.} [Ar-Ra'd: 9]. And His saying (Exalted is He): {Except one who has wronged and then substituted good after evil, for indeed, I am Forgiving and Merciful} [An-Naml: 11]. The exception here is disjunctive, meaning 'but,' and the sentence is parenthetical to explain the favor of Allah (Almighty) upon His creation, and that He overlooks evil deeds and forgives {whoever repents and believes and does righteousness and then is [rightly] guided.} [Ṭā-Hā: 82]. It is not permissible for anyone to despair of the mercy of Allah, {Indeed, no one despairs of relief from Allah except the disbelieving people.} [Yūsuf: 87]. Regarding His saying (Exalted is He): {And We called him from the side of the mount's right and brought him near in [private] conversation.} [Maryam: 52]. And His saying (Exalted is He): {But when he came to it, he was called, 'O Moses!'} [Ṭā-Hā: 11]. And His saying (Exalted is He): {And [mention] when your Lord called Moses} [Ash-Shu'arā: 10]. And His saying (Exalted is He): {But when he came to it, he was called, 'Blessed is He who is in the fire and [all] around it. And exalted is Allah, Lord of the worlds. O Moses, indeed it is I - Allah, the Exalted in Might, the Wise.'} [An-Naml: 8-9]. And His saying (Exalted is He): {But when he came to it, he was called from the bank of the valley on the right side in the blessed spot, from the tree, 'O Moses, indeed it is I - Allah, Lord of the worlds.'} [Al-Qasas: 30]. And His saying (Exalted is He): {When his Lord called to him in the sacred valley of Ṭuwā} [An-Nāzi'āt: 16]. And His saying (Exalted is He): {And Allah spoke to Moses with [direct] speech.} [An-Nisā': 164]. And His saying (Exalted is He): {Those messengers - some of them We caused to exceed others. Among them were those to whom Allah spoke} [Al-Baqarah: 253]. In these blessed verses, there is conclusive proof of affirming the attribute of Speech for Allah (Exalted is He), and that He speaks whenever He wills and however He wills, and that Allah (Exalted is He) made Moses His interlocutor (Kalīm) just as He made Abraham and Muhammad His intimate friends (Khalīl). And His saying (Exalted is He): {in the blessed spot, from the tree} [Al-Qasas: 30]. That is, the call came from the blessed spot, from near the tree, just as you say, "I heard Zayd's speech from the house. " Your saying "from the house " indicates the beginning of the boundary, not that the house is the speaker. Likewise, the tree is not the speaker; rather, Moses heard the speech of Allah from near the tree, for the tree is not the one saying: {O Moses, indeed it is I - Allah} [Al-Qasas: 30], but the one who said that is the Lord of the worlds. And His saying: {indeed we fear that he may hasten [punishment] upon us or that he may transgress} [Ṭā-Hā: 45]. The meaning of {that he may hasten [punishment] upon us} is that he may hasten our punishment before hearing our speech. And His saying (Exalted is He): {And when Moses had completed the term} [Al-Qasas: 29]. That is, he finished it, executed it, and fulfilled it, for the word 'qaḍā' may be used to mean to fulfill or execute. Hence, the saying of the poet: "Every debtor settled and repaid his creditor, except 'Azzah, whose creditor is postponed. "" "210 And His, the Almighty's, saying: "As if it were a *Jann* " (Al-Qasas: 31). Meaning that the staff became like the *Jann*, which is a white, quick-moving serpent with kohl-rimmed eyes (*akhal al-'ayn*). And His, the Almighty's, saying: "And draw in your hand to your side, dispelling the fear " (Al-Qasas: 32). Meaning: place your hand upon your chest so that the terror, panic, and fear which struck you may vanish. And may the blessings of Allah be upon you. To the next chapter, if Allah wills. And peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you. Chapter Forty-Ninth: Continuation of the Story of Moses (Peace be upon him) 211 Continuation of the Story of Moses Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, guided Moses to present to Pharaoh the sign of the staff and the sign of the hand. When Moses arrived in Egypt and was joined by his brother, Aaron son of Imran, they proceeded to Pharaoh and asked him to dedicate worship solely to Allah. They informed him that they were Messengers of the Lord of the Worlds, and Moses said to him: "Is there [any inclination] for you to purify yourself, and that I guide you to your Lord so you would fear [Him]? " (An-Naziat: 18-19). And be happy in this world and the Hereafter? "I do not say about Allah except the truth " (Al-A'raf: 105). "And we have come to you with a sign from your Lord " (Ta-Ha: 47)—a manifest and overwhelming miracle. So believe in Allah and "send with us the Children of Israel. " Pharaoh said: "Did we not rear you among us as a child, and did you not remain among us for many years of your life? " (Ash-Shu'ara: 18). "And you did the deed which you did " (Ash-Shu'ara: 19), and you are ungrateful for the favor we bestowed upon you. Moses said: I did it unintentionally. I did not intend to kill the Coptic man when I struck him. And knowing that you would not judge this case justly, I fled from you because I was afraid of you. "Then my Lord granted me authority and made me one of the Messengers " (Ash-Shu'ara: 21). And it has been revealed to us, O Pharaoh, that the punishment is upon whoever denies the signs of Allah, turns away from the religion of Allah, and rejects the Messengers. Do not be arrogant toward Allah, the Lord of the Worlds. Pharaoh said: "And what is the Lord of the Worlds? " (Ash-Shu'ara: 23). Moses said: "The Lord of the heavens and the earth and whatever is between them " (Ash-Shu'ara: 24). If there is anything one can be certain of, it is the Lord of the heavens and the earth, due to the clarity of His evidence and the certainty of His argument. He is the One who created everything and gave every created thing its distinct characteristic, and then guided it, by the innate nature He placed in it, to its food, drink, the survival of its progeny, and other matters. Thus, land animals, birds, and fish know their paths. Allah, Exalted is He, has deposited in them signs and favors that no one can comprehend except Allah, Exalted is He. In the world are clear signs and decisive proofs that testify they are the creation of the Lord of the Worlds. He has established in every thing in the universe a sign, as the poet said: Stories of the Prophets (The True Story) 212 O wonder! How is the Deity disobeyed, or how does the denier deny Him? And in everything, there is a sign for Him, indicating that He is the One. And even if we spent all the inkwells on Earth to explain the signs of Allah in man, the heavens, the earth, and what is between them, and all that human comprehension has reached, we would be unable to fulfill that. Therefore, Moses sufficed with his saying to Pharaoh: "He said: Our Lord is the One who gave all things their creation, then guided [them] " (Ta-Ha: 50). Do you not listen to what he says? "Such as the saying of the Most High, mentioning a group of Prophets and Messengers: *“Indeed, We have revealed to you, as We revealed to Noah and the prophets after him. And We revealed to Abraham, Ishmael, Isaac, Jacob, the Descendants (the Tribes), Jesus, Job, Jonah, Aaron, and Solomon, and to David We gave the Book (the Zabur). And [We sent] messengers about whom We have told you before, and messengers about whom We have not told you. And to Moses, Allah spoke directly.”* [An-Nisa: 163-164]. And His saying, the Most High: *“Those messengers - We preferred some of them over others. Among them were those to whom Allah spoke.”* [Al-Baqarah: 253]. And His saying, the Most High: *“O Moses, I have chosen you over the people for My messages and My words. So take what I have given you and be among the grateful.”* [Al-A'raf: 144]. And His saying, the Most High: *“He has ordained for you of religion what He enjoined upon Noah and that which We have revealed to you, [O Muhammad], and what We enjoined upon Abraham and Moses and Jesus - to establish the religion and not be divided therein.”* [Ash-Shura: 13]. To the next chapter, if Allah wills, and peace and the mercy of Allah and His blessings be upon you. * ### Chapter Fifty-Nine Continued: Moses Moses continued to propagate the Light and Guidance that Allah the Most High had revealed to him, the Torah, with the assistance of his brother Aaron, until Allah took the soul of Aaron (may Allah be pleased with him) while they were both in the wandering with the Children of Israel. Moses (peace and prayers be upon him) had performed the Hajj (Pilgrimage) to the Ancient House (the Kaaba) in Mecca. Muslim reported a Hadith from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him and his father) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) passed by the valley of Al-Azraq and asked: *“What valley is this?”* They said: *“The Valley of Al-Azraq.”* He said: *“It is as if I am looking at Moses, descending from the mountain pass, raising his voice to Allah with the Talbiyah (the pilgrim's chant).”* Then he came to the mountain pass of Harsha and asked: *“What mountain pass is this?”* They said: *“This is the pass of Harsha.”* He said: *“It is as if I am looking at Jonah, son of Matta, on a red she-camel, wearing a wool cloak, the nose-string of his camel made of fiber—meaning palm fiber—while he is reciting the Talbiyah.”* When speaking about Abraham the Close Friend, I mentioned some of the characteristics of Moses: that he was Adam (a dark complexion or tanned), curly-haired, large-bodied, and tall, as if he were one of the men of Azd Shanu'ah. Al-Bukhari and Muslim reported a Hadith from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him and his father) that the Messenger of Allah said: *“On the night of my Ascension (Mi'raj), I saw Moses, son of Imran, a tall, curly-haired man, as if he were one of the men of Shanu'ah.”* Likewise, Al-Bukhari reported in his Sahih, via Mujahid, that he heard Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him and his father), and they mentioned the Dajjal (the Antichrist) and that it is written between his eyes 'disbeliever' or (k.f.r.). He said: *“I did not hear him say this, but he said: 'As for Abraham, look at your companion (i.e., Muhammad). As for Moses, he is on a red camel, bridled with palm fibers; it is as if I am looking at him descending into the valley.' ”* However, Moses' death came before he entered the Holy Land. He asked Allah to bring him near the Holy Land at the distance of a stone's throw. Al-Bukhari and Muslim reported in their Sahihs, a Hadith from Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him), who said: The Angel of Death was sent to Moses. When the Angel came to him, Moses struck him. The Angel returned to his Lord and said: *“You sent me to a servant who does not want to die.”* Allah said: *“Go back to him and tell him to place his hand on the back of a bull, and he will be granted one year for every hair his hand covers.”* Moses asked: *“O my Lord, then what?”* He replied: *“Then death.”* Moses said: *“Then now (from a close distance)!”* Then he asked Allah to bring him near the Holy Land at the distance of a stone's throw. Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him) said that the Messenger of Allah said: *“If I were there, I would show you his grave beside the road near the red sand dune.”* Al-Bukhari (may Allah have mercy on him) then said: Ma'mar informed us, from Hammam, who said: Abu Hurayrah narrated to us from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) a similar Hadith. Muslim reported in his Sahih, from Hammam bin Munabbih, who said: This is what Abu Hurayrah narrated to us from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). He mentioned several Hadiths, among which the Messenger of Allah said: *“The Angel of Death came to Moses and said to him: 'Answer the call of your Lord.' Moses then slapped the eye of the Angel of Death and blinded it. The Angel returned to Allah the Most High and said: 'You sent me to a servant of Yours who does not want to die, and he has blinded my eye.' Allah restored his eye to him and said: 'Go back to My servant and tell him: Do you want life? If you want life, place your hand on the back of a bull, and you will live for a year for every hair your hand covers.' Moses asked: 'Then what?' He replied: 'Then death.' Moses said: 'Then now, from near! O my Lord, let me die at the distance of a stone's throw from the Holy Land.' ”* The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: *“By Allah, if I were there, I would show you his grave beside the road near the red sand dune.”* Some who claim knowledge have found this Hadith problematic, wondering how Moses could strike the Angel of Death and blind his eye. There is no strangeness in this, because Moses did not know that he was the Angel of Death, just as Abraham, the Close Friend of Allah, did not recognize the angels he hosted, and said to them when they did not eat his food: *“Indeed, we are fearful of you.”* [Hud: 70]. Moreover, Allah the Blessed and Most High does not take the soul of any of His prophets except after giving him the choice. It is reported that no prophet was taken except after being given the choice. That is why when the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was given the choice, he chose the Highest Companion. As for the astonishment at the blinding of the Angel's eye, it is based on a definition of angels that their *form is not subject to physical laws*, meaning that if the angel took the form of a man or otherwise, and one intended to kill him or cut off a limb, his form would not be affected by that, and he could not be harmed, unlike the Jinn, whose form is subject to physical laws; if the Jinn takes the form of an animal and that animal is killed, the Jinn is killed. However, since this definition is not established by any authentic narration from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), it is not permissible for a Muslim to reject an authentic and established Hadith from the Messenger of Allah based on it. I have seen many followers of misguided desires who are hostile to the Companions of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and to Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and other Imams of the Ahl As-Sunnah wal Jama'ah (People of the Sunnah and the Group) dwell on this authentic Hadith to malign the Companions of the Messenger of Allah and the scholars of Hadith. It is known that there is no doubt about the authenticity of this narration from the Messenger of Allah, the Truthful and Trustworthy. * ### The Distortion of the Torah by the Jews The Jews altered the Torah after Moses. The Torah in their possession consists of five books (sefarim): Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus (or the Book of Priests), Numbers, and Deuteronomy. The Jews claim that Moses wrote the Torah with his own hand. However, it is stated in the thirty-fourth chapter of Deuteronomy, paragraph five: *“So Moses the servant of the Lord died there in the land of Moab, according to the word of the Lord.”* And in paragraph six: *“And He buried him in the valley in the land of Moab, opposite Beth-Peor; but no one knows his burial place to this day.”* It is thus clear beyond doubt that this book was written after Moses. How could Moses write with his own hand that he died and was buried at Al-Jawa in the land of Moab opposite Beth-Peor, and that no one knows his grave to this day? Further confirming their alteration is what is stated in the thirty-first chapter of Deuteronomy, paragraph 24: *“When Moses had finished writing the words of this law in a book, to the very end, 25. Moses commanded the Levites who carried the ark of the covenant of the Lord, saying, 26. 'Take this Book of the Law and place it beside the ark of the covenant of the Lord your God, and it will remain there as a witness against you. 27. For I know your rebellion and your stiff neck. Even while I am still alive with you today, you have been rebellious against the Lord; how much more after my death! 28. Gather to me all the elders of your tribes and your officers, that I may speak these words in their hearing and call the heavens and the earth to witness against them. 29. For I know that after my death you will corrupt yourselves and turn aside from the way that I have commanded you.' ”* * ### Islam and the Origin of 'Judaism' Judaism is not the religion of Moses; his religion was Islam. The term 'Judaism' is an innovation that emerged after Moses. Therefore, there is no authentic report that Moses called them by this name. The term 'Judaism' could be derived from *'Al-Hawd'* (returning to God), meaning repentance, based on His saying: *“We have returned to You (Hudna Ilayk).”* [Al-A'raf: 156]. It may also be derived from *'Al-Tahwid'*, which is the repetition of sound softly with a trill and melodic embellishment; Jewish scholars used to recite to the public with pronounced melodies and nasalization. Alternatively, it could be a reference to Judah (Yehuda), a leader of the tribes of the Children of Israel, by way of predominance (Taghlib), and its application to all the Children of Israel is based on Judah (with a Dāl) or Yudha (with a Dhāl), as mentioned in Al-Qamus Al-Muhit (The Comprehensive Lexicon). One says *'Yahudhi'* or *'Yahudi'*. The name 'Jews' was never mentioned in the Book of Allah the Most High or in the Sunnah of His Messenger (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in a context of praise whatsoever. Everything reported about them during Moses' time was under the name of the People of the Book, people of Moses, and Children of Israel. The term 'Judaism' was only mentioned in the Book of Allah in a context of blame. And the knowledge rests with Allah. Peace be upon Moses and Aaron, and the mercy of Allah and His blessings.
source: Qur'an (Ta-Ha, Al-Qasas, Al-A'raf), Tafsir Ibn Kathir, Sahih al-Bukhari, Sahih Muslim
