texte_original: ## Chapter Forty-Three: Al-Yasa' and Dhul-Kifl In this chapter, we discuss two noble Prophets of Allah the Almighty, namely Al-Yasa' (Elisha) and Dhul-Kifl (Ezekiel?), upon whom be peace. Allah the Blessed and Exalted mentioned Al-Yasa' twice in His Book, including him among the Prophets whom Allah granted the argument against their people, and whom He commanded His Messenger (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to emulate. 1. In Surah Al-An'am (6:83-86, 90): "That was Our argument, which We gave to Abraham against his people. We raise in degrees whom We will. Indeed, your Lord is Wise and Knowing. And We gave to him Isaac and Jacob. All [of them] We guided. And [before that] We guided Noah, and among his descendants, David and Solomon and Ayyub and Joseph and Moses and Aaron. Thus do We reward the doers of good. And Zechariah and John and Jesus and Elias—all were of the righteous. And Ishmael and Al-Yasa' and Jonah and Lot—and all We favored over the worlds." Then He said: "Those are the ones whom Allah has guided; so take their guidance as an example." 2. In Surah Sad (38:48), He mentioned him again among the Prophets whom His Messenger Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was commanded to emulate in patience against the harm of his people, after saying: "Be patient over what they say, and remember Our servant David, the man of strength; indeed, he was ever returning [to Allah]" (38:17); and after narrating David's story, He said: "And We gave to David, Solomon. An excellent servant, indeed he was ever returning [to Allah]" (38:30). After Solomon's story, He mentioned Ayyub, who was more severely tested, and said at the end of his story: "Indeed, We found him patient, an excellent servant. Indeed, he was ever returning [to Allah]" (38:44). He then mentioned "Abraham and Isaac and Jacob, owners of power and [religious] vision" (38:45), and then said: "And remember Ishmael and Al-Yasa' and Dhul-Kifl, and all were of the outstanding." (38:48). Al-Yasa' is a name that could be Hebrew or Arabic. Abu Hayyan, in *Al-Bahr Al-Muhit* regarding the interpretation of Surah Al-An'am, said that the majority of readers recited *Al-Yasa'*, as if *Al* (the definite article) was introduced to an Arabic verb (*wasi'a*). Two readers (Hamzah and Al-Kisa'i) recited *Al-Laysi'* on the pattern of *fay'al*. Scholars differed on whether the name is Arabic or foreign (*'Ajami*). Those who considered it Arabic and followed the majority reading said it is an imperfect verb that was used as a name without a pronoun, was then inflected, and made definite with *Al*. Others said it was named after a verb like *Yazid* (increasing), and *Al* was added exceptionally, like in the phrase *Al-Yazid*. Those who considered it foreign said *Al* was added and became permanent exceptionally, a position supported by Abu Ali Al-Farisi. In any case, the discussion concludes that the most reliable view does not consider *Al* to be inseparable from the name. Abu Hayyan further stated that these foreign names are not declined with the Kasrah nor nunated, except for Al-Yasa', which is declined with the Kasrah but not nunated, and Lot (Lut), which is fully declined (triptote) due to the lightness of its structure, despite possessing the attributes of non-declination (being a proper noun and foreign). The claims that Al-Yasa' was Ibn Akhtub, or the son of the old woman, or that his name was Al-Asbat Ibn 'Adi from the descendants of Joseph, or that he was the cousin of Elias and was hiding with him, or that he succeeded Elias among his people in Banias of the Levant: all these sayings are not based on any authentic proof. What Allah has mentioned about him in His decisive Book is sufficient. And the perfect knowledge is with Allah. As for Dhul-Kifl, Allah the Exalted also mentioned him twice in His Noble Book: 1. In Surah Al-Anbiya (21:85-86), amongst the Messengers after the story of Ayyub, so that the Messenger Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) would emulate them in patience against the harm of his people. He said: "And [mention] Ishmael and Idrees and Dhul-Kifl; all were of the patient. And We admitted them into Our mercy. Indeed, they were of the righteous." 2. In Surah Sad (38:48), also after the story of Ayyub. He said: "And remember Our servants Abraham and Isaac and Jacob, owners of power and [religious] vision. Indeed, We chose them for an exclusive quality: remembrance of the home [of the Hereafter]. And indeed, they are near Us among the chosen and the outstanding. And remember Ishmael and Al-Yasa' and Dhul-Kifl, and all were of the outstanding." (38:45-48). Some people claimed that Dhul-Kifl was not a Prophet, attributing this rejected opinion to some of the early scholars (*Salaf*), relying on interpolated Israeli accounts (*Isra'iliyyat*), none of which are authentic from the Messenger of Allah. The apparent context of the Glorious Quran proves that he is one of the great Prophets, one of those whom Allah commanded His Messenger (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to emulate, as he was associated in Surah Al-Anbiya with a group of great Messengers, and in Surah Sad with a group of these Master Messengers, after Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was commanded to be patient by following their example, including Dhul-Kifl. The rule among the *Usuliyyun* (specialists in Islamic legal methodology) is that the principle is to act upon the apparent meaning of the text unless there is evidence to deviate from it, and no authentic evidence exists to prove that Dhul-Kifl was not among the Prophets. As for the narration by Ibn Jarir and Ibn Abi Hatim from Mujahid, stating that Al-Yasa' appointed a successor and stipulated that he should fast the day, pray the night, and never get angry, and that this man, who was unimpressive to look at, fulfilled the condition: this is among the tales of the Children of Israel (Bani Isra'il). Likewise, the report from Ibn Abi Hatim from Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari, who said in a sermon that Dhul-Kifl was not a Prophet, is a narration with a disturbed chain of transmission and carries the known characteristics of *Isra'iliyyat*. As for the Hadith narrated by Imam Ahmad (and classified as *Hasan*—good—by At-Tirmidhi) via Ibn Umar, that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "There was a man among the Children of Israel called Al-Kifl who would not refrain from any sin he committed. A needy woman came to him. He gave her sixty Dinars to commit sin with him, but when he sat with her as a man sits with his wife, she wept. He stood up, repented, gave her the Dinars, and died that very night. In the morning, it was written on his door, 'Allah has forgiven Al-Kifl.'" This Hadith, also narrated by At-Tirmidhi, and which some scholars stopped at Ibn Umar (making it *Mawquf*), is likewise among the fabrications of the Bani Isra'il against the Prophets of Allah. Ibn Kathir said about it in *Qisas Al-Anbiya':* "It is a very strange Hadith, and there is doubt in its chain of transmission." To the next chapter, if Allah wills. Peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you.
source: Holy Quran and Prophetic Sunnah, Exegeses of Ahlus Sunnah Wal Jama'ah (like Tafsir al-Tabari and Ibn Kathir)

bio_naissance_annee: Isaac was born many years after Abraham, Allah having promised Abraham the birth of Isaac in his old age.
bio_lieu_naissance: He was born in the land of Canaan.
bio_descendance: He had twin sons, Esau (Al-Eis) and Jacob (Yaqub).
texte_original: In this chapter, we speak about the Prophet and Messenger of Allah, Isaac, son of Abraham the Friend of Allah (peace be upon them). He was born to Abraham’s second son. Isaac is the blessing through which Allah favored His creation, and his righteous wife was Sarah. Isaac is one of the signs of Allah, born to his mother when she was old and barren, and from him descend all the tribes of the Children of Israel. Abraham had already reached one hundred years of age. The Noble Qur’an mentions Isaac in several places. Allah, exalted and glorified be He, mentioned the good news of his birth when He says in Surah Adh-Dhariyat: "When the guests of Abraham arrived, he hurried to his family and brought them a fat calf. They said: 'Peace.' He said: 'Peace.' He was relieved regarding them, fearing for them. They said: 'Do not fear, and We give you glad tidings of a knowledgeable boy.'" [Adh-Dhariyat: 24-30] Allah also says in Surah Hud: "And indeed, Our messengers came to Abraham with good news. When he saw their hands, which could not reach him, he recognized them as sent to a corrupt people, the people of Lot, and his wife was present. Then she laughed, saying: 'Are we sent to a corrupt people?' They gave her the glad tidings of Isaac and, through him, Jacob." [Hud: 69-75] Allah says in Surah Al-Hijr: "We give you glad tidings of a knowledgeable son. How do you give this news while old age has arrived?" [Al-Hijr: 51-56] Allah also says in Surah Al-Ankabut: "When Our messengers came to Abraham with good news, they said: 'We will destroy the inhabitants of this town because they were unjust.' Abraham said: 'But Lot is there.' They said: 'We know best who is in it; We will save him and his family, except his wife who will be among the losers.'" [Al-Ankabut: 31-32] And Allah says in Surah As-Saffat: "And We blessed Isaac as a prophet among the righteous, and We blessed his descendants; some were good and others wronged themselves." [As-Saffat: 112-113] Allah described Sarah when she received the glad tidings: when she heard the guests of Abraham announce the birth of Isaac, she approached them in astonishment, wondering how she could bear a child at this advanced age to this elderly husband. She covered her face due to the intensity of this news upon her, and Allah says: "Then his wife approached and covered her face and said: 'How can I bear a child while I am old and barren?'" [Adh-Dhariyat: 29] Allah also described Sarah as standing and laughing; her laughter was due to joy at the arrival of the guests and the announcement of Isaac’s birth, and the continuation of the lineage through Jacob. She said in astonishment: "How can I give birth while I am old and this is my husband? This is truly something amazing!" [Hud: 72] And in the same Surah: "The mercy and blessings of Allah be upon you, O household. He is indeed praiseworthy and glorious." [Hud: 73] This clearly indicates that the wife is part of the household, refuting those who deviate from the Sunnah of the Prophet (peace be upon him) and do not include the wives of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) in his household, as Allah says: "Allah only desires to remove all impurity from the family of the Prophet and to purify them completely." [Al-Ahzab: 33] Regarding the birth of Jacob: "And from Isaac’s descendants, Jacob…" [Hud: 71] This indicates that she gave birth to a knowledgeable boy who would live and have offspring. Allah is the One who named her son Isaac and her grandson Jacob. This may also indicate that she would live to see her grandson. There is no doubt that Jacob is the son of Isaac, and Allah says: "Were you present when Jacob was about to die and said to his sons: 'Whom will you worship after me?' They said: 'We will worship your God and the God of your fathers Abraham, Ishmael, and Isaac. We are submissive.'" [Al-Baqara: 133] Abraham is the grandfather, Ishmael is the uncle, Isaac is the father, and all are called ‘father’. Allah also says: "Thus your Lord will guide you and teach you the interpretation of stories and complete His blessings upon you and upon the descendants of Jacob, as He completed it upon your fathers Abraham and Isaac. Indeed, your Lord is Knowing and Wise." [Yusuf: 6] The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) confirmed that Jacob is the son of Isaac, son of Abraham, as narrated by Al-Bukhari: “Joseph the Noble is the son of Jacob, son of Isaac, son of Abraham.” Allah describes Jacob in the glad tidings of Isaac as righteous: "We gave him Isaac and Jacob as gifts, and We made them both righteous and guided them to perform prayer and do good deeds." [Al-Anbiya: 72-73] Ibn Abbas and Qatada explain that the term ‘gift’ (nafila) in this verse signifies the child given, Jacob, the son of Isaac. The Qur’an and Sunnah confirm that Jacob is the son of Isaac, son of Abraham (peace be upon them). Allah mentions Isaac among the prophets and messengers, and He says about Abraham: *"We gave him Isaac and Jacob…" [Maryam: 49] And He says: "We revealed to you, as We revealed to Noah and the prophets after him; and We revealed to Abraham, Ishmael, Isaac, Jacob, and the tribes, and to Jesus, Job, Jonah, Aaron, Solomon, and David, to whom We gave the Psalms. We related their stories to you previously, and some messengers We did not relate to you. Allah spoke to Moses directly. They were messengers, bringing good news and warnings, so that there would be a proof for people after the messengers. Allah is Mighty and Wise." [An-Nisa: 163]
