texte_original: David and Solomon We speak here about the two noble Prophets, Messengers, and Kings, David (Dāwūd) and Solomon (Sulaymān), peace and blessings be upon them. The first established mention of David is what Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, recounted concerning David's killing of Goliath (Jālūt) in the war that took place between Saul (Ṭālūt) and Goliath in Palestine. The clear indication from the context of the Holy Qur'an's narration of this war story is that the Children of Israel were fought by a group of polytheists (pagans) who drove them out of their homes and took their children captive. At the head of these pagans was Goliath, may Allah curse him. The Children of Israel were governed by Prophets; whenever a Prophet died, Allah would send them another Prophet to explain the Torah to them, judge among them by it, and clarify what they had altered, distorted, and replaced of the words from their (proper) places, according to His saying, the Most High: 'Indeed, We sent down the Torah, in which was guidance and light. By it, the Prophets who had submitted to Allah's will (i.e., submitted to His command) used to judge those who had become Jews (i.e., those who turned to Judaism), as did the rabbis and the scholars, by that which they were entrusted to preserve of the Book of Allah, and to which they were witnesses.' [Qur'an, Al-Mā'idah: 44]. Al-Bukhārī and Muslim narrated on the authority of Abū Hurayrah that the Messenger of Allah said: 'The Children of Israel were governed by Prophets; whenever a Prophet perished, another Prophet succeeded him. And indeed, there is no Prophet after me.' Thus, the Prophets of the Children of Israel were like the scholars of the Nation of Muhammad, except that revelation (wahy) was sent down to them. When the war intensified against the Children of Israel, they asked their Prophet to send them a king under whose banner they could fight the enemies of Allah, the pagans. Their Prophet informed them that he feared they would shrink from fighting if it was prescribed for them and would not fulfill their commitment. They said: 'And why should we not fight in the cause of Allah when we have been expelled from our homes and our children?' [Qur'an, Al-Baqarah: 246]—meaning, our lands were seized and our children were taken captive. Their Prophet then informed them that Allah had appointed a king for them from among themselves, who was Saul (Ṭālūt). They objected to this appointment and said: 'How can Allah appoint Ṭālūt as a king over us when none of his forefathers was a king, and we are more deserving of the kingship than him, given that he is poor and of little wealth?' Their Prophet replied to them that Allah had chosen him over you and favored him from among you, and Allah had granted him an abundance in knowledge and physical strength. He is more knowledgeable than you in the affairs of war and the management of matters, and stronger, more patient, and more resilient than you in facing the enemies. Do not object or be stubborn, as you know that it is Allah Who chose and appointed him as your king. Allah gives His kingdom to whom He wills, and Allah is Vast and All-Knowing. Their Prophet also told them: 'Indeed, Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, will make for you a sign of the correctness of Ṭālūt's kingship over you, which is the return of the Ark (Tabūt) containing some relics of Moses (Mūsā) and Aaron (Hārūn). You were unable to retrieve it from the hands of its usurpers, and you will not be required to exert effort in recovering it. Rather, the Ark will come, borne by the angels, containing reassurance for the Children of Israel, and a clear indication that nothing is impossible for Allah in the heavens or on the earth. Believe therefore in the promise of Allah, hasten to obey Ṭālūt, and have faith in what I have informed you of from Allah. When they submitted to this and prepared to fight Goliath and his troops under the banner of Ṭālūt, David was among them. Ṭālūt informed them that Allah would test them by a river they would pass while thirsty, and he forbade them from drinking from it, as army leaders know that drinking from it would harm them. Surprisingly, even today, some still forbid their soldiers from drinking during their march toward the enemy, due to the health damage that might result. However, they allow them to wet their throats with a single scoop by hand lightly. Therefore, Ṭālūt permitted his army to take a scoop to wet their throats, considering it not (actual) drinking. This was a manifestation of Ṭālūt's comprehensive knowledge. He warned them, the enemies of Allah, that whoever drank from this river would not accompany him in fighting and would not cross the river. However, when this army reached the river, they disobeyed Ṭālūt and drank from it, except for a small number of them who obeyed Ṭālūt. It is reported in some authentic narrations that those who crossed the river with Ṭālūt were three hundred and a few dozen men, the exact number of the companions of the Messenger of Allah on the Day of Badr. Al-Bukhārī reported in his Sahīh on the authority of Al-Barā' ibn 'Āzib, who said: 'The Companions of Muhammad who witnessed Badr told me that they were the number of Ṭālūt's companions who crossed the river with him: three hundred and a few dozen.' Al-Barā' added: 'Nay, by Allah, none crossed the river with him except a believer.' In another wording in Al-Bukhārī, on the authority of Al-Barā', he said: 'We, the Companions of Muhammad, used to talk about the fact that the number of the companions of Badr was the same as the number of Ṭālūt's companions who crossed the river with him, and none crossed with him except a believer: three hundred and a few dozen.' In another wording in Al-Bukhārī, on the authority of Al-Barā', he said: 'We used to talk about the companions of Badr being three hundred and a few dozen, the same number as Ṭālūt's companions who crossed the river with him, and none crossed with him except a believer.' When Ṭālūt and those who believed with him crossed the river, they found that their enemy, Goliath, had amassed troops and prepared immense equipment. Some of the believers among Ṭālūt's companions said: 'We have no strength or power today to fight this numerous enemy,' as if they underestimated themselves in facing their foe. Their scholars, who knew that Allah's promise is true and that victory comes from Allah, not from the multitude of numbers or the strength of equipment, encouraged them, stating that a Muslim should desire martyrdom and meeting Allah in His cause, saying to them: 'How many a small company has overcome a large company by permission of Allah! And Allah is with the patient.' And when they advanced to meet Goliath and his troops [Qur'an, Al-Baqarah: 249-250], they asked Allah to send down patience upon them, to make their feet firm in the encounter with the enemies, and to grant them victory over the disbelieving people. Allah answered their prayer and granted them victory over their enemies. David killed Goliath, their king. Ṭālūt hastened to relinquish the kingship to David. Allah sent David as a Prophet and Messenger, and made him a noble King over the Children of Israel. Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, praised Ṭālūt and described him with noble attributes. As for what some exegetes and chroniclers alleged, that Ṭālūt envied David, was afflicted with madness, and wandered in the desert, this is a baseless claim with no proof from an authentic report. Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, mentioned the story of Ṭālūt, his war against Goliath, and the conferral of kingship upon David, where He said: 'Have you not considered the assembly of the Children of Israel after [the time of] Moses, when they said to a prophet of theirs, “Appoint for us a king, and we will fight in the cause of Allah.” He said, “Would you perhaps refrain from fighting if fighting was prescribed for you?” They said, “And why should we not fight in the cause of Allah when we have been expelled from our homes and our children?” But when fighting was prescribed for them, they turned away, except for a few of them. And Allah is Knowing of the wrongdoers. And their prophet said to them, “Indeed, Allah has sent to you Ṭālūt as a king.” They said, “How can he have kingship over us while we are more deserving of kingship than him and he has not been given a great amount of wealth?” He said, “Indeed, Allah has chosen him over you and has increased him abundantly in knowledge and body. And Allah gives His sovereignty to whom He wills. And Allah is all-Encompassing [in favor] and Knowing.” And their prophet said to them, “Indeed, the sign of his kingship is that the Ark (Tabūt) will come to you in which is assurance from your Lord and a remnant of what the family of Moses and the family of Aaron left, carried by the angels. Indeed, in that is a sign for you, if you are believers.” And when Ṭālūt set out with the soldiers, he said, “Indeed, Allah will be testing you with a river. So whoever drinks from it is not of me, and whoever does not taste it is indeed of me, excepting one who takes [just] a scoop with his hand.” But they drank from it, except for a few of them. Then when he crossed it, he and those who believed with him, they said, “There is no power for us today against Goliath and his soldiers.” But those who were certain that they would meet Allah said, “How many a small company has overcome a large company by permission of Allah! And Allah is with the patient.” And when they advanced to meet Goliath and his soldiers, they said, “Our Lord, pour upon us patience and plant firmly our feet and give us victory over the disbelieving people.” So they defeated them by permission of Allah, and David killed Goliath. And Allah gave him the kingship and wisdom and taught him of that which He willed. And were it not that Allah checks the people, some by means of others, the earth would have been corrupted. But Allah is the possessor of favor over the worlds. These are the verses of Allah which We recite to you in truth, and indeed, you are among the messengers.' [Qur'an, Al-Baqarah: 246-252]. To the next chapter, if Allah wills, and peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you. Chapter Sixty-One The True Stories of the Prophets Continuation of David and Solomon After Allah established David in the land, gave him kingship and prophethood, revealed the Zabur (Psalms) to him, and taught him the upright methodology that he and the Children of Israel needed, Allah made the reading of the Zabur easy for David and lightened it for him to the extent that he would read it in the time it took to saddle his mounts, as was reported by the Truthful, the Confirmed, the Infallible one who does not speak from (his own) desire: Muhammad. Al-Bukhārī reported in his Sahīh on the authority of Abū Hurayrah that the Prophet said: 'The recitation (of the Qur'an/Zabur) was made easy for David. He would order his mounts to be saddled, and he would finish reading the Qur'an (the Zabur) before his mounts were saddled. And he would only eat from the work of his own hands.' The term 'Qur'an' (Recitation) here refers to the Zabur which Allah revealed to David, as He says: 'And to David We gave the Zabur.' [Qur'an, An-Nisā': 163]. 'Qur'an' is also used to refer to the recitation, meaning the reading of the Zabur. David had been granted by Allah a beautiful voice with which he would sing and chant as he read the Zabur. The Messenger of Allah described his chanting of the Zabur as having the sound of the pipes (*mizāmīr*). Al-Bukhārī and Muslim reported on the authority of Abū Mūsā Al-Ash'arī that the Messenger of Allah said to him: 'O Abū Mūsā, you have been given a pipe (*mizmār*) from the pipes of the family of David.' Ahmad reported in his Musnad: 'Abdul Razzāq narrated to us, who said: Ma'mar narrated to us, from Az-Zuhrī, from 'Urwah, from 'Ā’ishah, who said: The Messenger of Allah heard the voice of Abū Mūsā Al-Ash'arī while he was reciting and said: 'Abū Mūsā has been given a pipe from the pipes of the family of David.' David was committed to eating only from the work of his own hands, and he adopted a method in fasting and prayer that was the most beloved method which the Messenger of Allah encouraged for supererogatory acts. It is confirmed in the two Sahīh that the Messenger of Allah said: 'The most beloved prayer to Allah is the prayer of David, and the most beloved fasting to Allah is the fasting of David. He would sleep half the night, stand in prayer for a third of it, and sleep a sixth of it. And he would fast one day and break his fast one day, and he would not flee when he met (the enemy).' In a wording in Al-Bukhārī on the authority of 'Abdullāh ibn 'Amr, he said: The Messenger of Allah said to me: 'The most beloved fasting to Allah is the fasting of David: he would fast one day and break his fast one day. And the most beloved prayer to Allah is the prayer of David: he would sleep half the night, stand in prayer for a third of it, and sleep a sixth of it.' Al-Bukhārī also reported in his Sahīh on the authority of Al-Miqdād ibn Ma'dīkarib that the Messenger of Allah said: 'No one has ever eaten a food better than that which he eats from the work of his own hands. And the Prophet of Allah, David, used to eat from the work of his own hands.' Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, favored David by softening iron for him and teaching him the craft of making protective clothing (armor) for the believing fighters. He was the first to make the coats of mail, which may be called *az-zard*. Allah guided him to the optimal method for making them, by making them in rings after they had been plates, to make their use easy. He commanded him to make them full-length (*sābighāt*), covering the entire body of the wearer and dragging on the ground, and suitable for different body sizes, long and wide, so that their benefit would extend to all fighters. He also ordered him to be precise in the linkage (*as-sard*), meaning in the weaving of the armor, which is the interlocking of the rings, and not to make the rivets thick, which would break the ring, nor thin, which would make them loose, nor to increase their durability such that they become heavy for the fighter. This is a great blessing for which Allah drew the attention of the believers to the obligation of thanking Him, as He says: 'Will you then be grateful?' [Qur'an, Al-Anbiyā': 80]. Allah also subjected the mountains and birds to David: whenever he glorified Allah, they glorified Allah with him. He gave him wisdom and decisive speech. Concerning all of this, Allah says in Sūrah Al-Anbiyā': 'And We subjected the mountains to glorify with David, and the birds. And We were the doers. And We taught him the making of coats of mail for you, to protect you from your [mutual] violence. Will you then be grateful?' [Qur'an, Al-Anbiyā': 79-80]. And He says in Sūrah Saba': 'And certainly, We gave David a favor from Us. “O mountains, repeat [Our praises] with him, and [O] birds.” And We made the iron soft for him, [commanding him], “Make full coats of mail and measure the links [of the chain] accurately. And work righteousness. Indeed, I am Seeing of what you do.”' [Qur'an, Saba': 10-11]. And He says in Sūrah Ṣād, commanding the Master of the Messengers, Muhammad, to follow David's example in patience: 'Be patient over what they say and remember Our servant David, the man of strength; indeed, he was one who often turned back [to Allah]. Indeed, We subjected the mountains [to praise] with him, glorifying [Allah] in the evening and the sunrise. And the birds assembled, all with him oft-returning [to Allah]. And We strengthened his kingdom and gave him wisdom and decisive speech.' [Qur'an, Ṣād: 17-20]. The Jews fabricated many lies about David, just as they lied about the Prophets of Allah before and after him, and even killed some of the Prophets. They claimed that David went out one evening to walk on the roof of the royal palace, where he saw a beautiful woman bathing. He sent men to fetch her and bring her to him. She came to him, and he lay with her, and she conceived from him. He then worked to have her husband killed. It is stated in the eleventh chapter of the Second Book of Samuel, which they possess, in paragraph two: 'And it came to pass in an eveningtide, that David arose from off his bed, and walked upon the roof of the king’s house: and from the roof he saw a woman washing herself; and the woman was very beautiful to look upon.' In paragraph three: 'And David sent and enquired after the woman. And one said, Is not this Bathsheba, the daughter of Eliam, the wife of Uriah the Hittite?' In paragraph four: 'And David sent messengers, and took her; and she came in unto him, and he lay with her; for she was purified from her uncleanness: and she returned unto her house.' According to paragraph five: 'And the woman conceived, and sent and told David, and said, I am with child.' After the Second Book of Samuel narrates David's attempt to get rid of Uriah, the woman's husband, and sending him to war to be killed, the book says in paragraph 26: 'And when the wife of Uriah heard that Uriah her husband was dead, she mourned for her husband.' And in paragraph 27: 'And when the mourning was past, David sent and fetched her to his house, and she became his wife, and bore him a son. But the thing that David had done displeased the Lord.' The book then continues to narrate the Lord's reproach of David, the death of the child Bathsheba bore, then David's repentance and fasting, and finally his entry to Uriah's wife and lying with her, whereupon she conceived and bore a son named Solomon. The astonishing and strange thing is that this falsehood deceived some who claim knowledge of exegesis (Tafsīr), and they used it to interpret Allah's saying: 'Has there come to you the news of the disputants, when they scaled the wall of the prayer chamber (Mihrab)? When they entered upon David, he was alarmed by them. They said, “Fear not. [We are] two disputants; one of us has wronged the other, so judge between us with truth and do not exceed [it] and guide us to the sound path. Indeed, this [man] is my brother; he has ninety-nine ewes (na'jah), and I have one ewe, and he said, ‘Entrust her to me,’ and he overpowered me in the speech.” [David] said, “He has certainly wronged you by demanding your ewe [to be added] to his ewes. And indeed, many associates oppress one another, except for those who believe and do righteous deeds—and few are those.” And David realized that We had tried him, so he asked forgiveness of his Lord and fell down bowing [in prostration] and repented. So We forgave him that, and indeed, for him is nearness to Us and a beautiful place of return.' [Qur'an, Ṣād: 21-25]. Interpreting these verses to mean that David fell in love with Uriah's wife, forced him to give her up, and sought to have him killed until he was killed, while David had ninety-nine women and Uriah only this one woman, and that two angels came in the form of disputants to warn David of the ugliness of his deed: I say that this interpretation of these noble verses is void, false, corrupt, and worthless; it is a fabricated and innovated slander that common folk and riff-raff would reject for themselves, and a concocted Jewish plot that ears despise and natures reject. Therefore, it is reported that 'Alī (may Allah be pleased with him) said: 'Whoever tells you the story of David as narrated by the storytellers, flog him one hundred and sixty times,' which is the prescribed penalty for slander against the Prophets. It is also reported that a righteous man of knowledge was sitting with 'Umar ibn 'Abdul 'Azīz in the Mosque, and near them was a man narrating this fabricated story about David to the people. The righteous man said: 'O man, if the matter is contrary to what you claim, you have slandered the Prophet of Allah, David. And if the matter is as you claim, and Allah concealed His Prophet David by metaphorically saying *'na'jah'* (ewe) and did not say 'woman,' then it is not lawful for you to expose the Prophet of Allah, David.' 'Umar ibn 'Abdul 'Azīz said: 'This statement is dearer to me than everything the sun has risen upon.' To the next chapter, if Allah wills, and peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you. Chapter Sixty-Two The True Stories of the Prophets Continuation of David and Solomon I mentioned at the end of the previous chapter that the interpretation of those who explained the saying of the Most High: 'Has there come to you the news of the disputants, when they scaled the wall of the prayer chamber (Mihrab)?' [Qur'an, Ṣād: 21] up to His saying: 'and fell down bowing [in prostration] and repented.' [Qur'an, Ṣād: 24], by saying that David fell in love with Uriah's wife, forced him to give her up, and sought to have him killed until he was killed, and the interpretation of the 'ewe' (*na'jah*) in the verse as the 'woman,' I said that this interpretation is void, false, corrupt, and worthless, a fabricated and innovated slander that common folk and riff-raff would reject for themselves, and a Jewish plot that ears despise and natures reject. I mention here that the context of the Qur'an refutes it. Indeed, Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, mentioned in the introduction of this Surah, up to His saying: 'and they said, “Our Lord, hasten for us our share [of the punishment] before the Day of Account.”' [Qur'an, Ṣād: 16], the harm suffered by the Messenger of Allah from his people, their collusion against him, and their ridicule of him. So, Allah commanded him to be patient over what they said, and commanded him to remember the story of the righteous and oft-returning servant, David, then the story of Solomon, and then the story of Job (Ayyūb), and the distress they suffered, for which they were patient, and then relief came to them from Allah. It is well-known that the Glorious Qur'an is like a well-arranged string of pearls: every verse is completely linked to what precedes it and what follows it. So, would Allah command His Messenger Muhammad to be patient, following the example of David, the righteous and oft-returning servant, and then describe this oft-returning one as the lover who craves the wife of a believing man who has no other, while David had ninety-nine women? That is indeed an abominable saying and a falsehood. Rather, Allah commands His Messenger Muhammad in these verses to be patient regarding the harm from his people, and reminds him of what happened to his brother, the righteous and oft-returning servant David, when disputants scaled the wall of his Mihrab—meaning his palace—and he was alarmed by them, fearing they would assassinate him. When they reassured him that they had not come to harm him but as disputants, the claimant stepped forward, pointed to the defendant, and said: 'Indeed, this [man] is my brother; he has ninety-nine ewes (*na'jah*, meaning a domestic sheep), and I have one ewe, and he was kind to me at first when he saw me tending her alone, and he asked me to put her with his ewes to graze with them without any difficulty for me. But after a period of time, when I came to claim her, he denied my right to her, oppressed me, rejected the claim, and claimed she was his property.' When David heard the claimant and asked the defendant, who denied what the claimant was saying, David judged in favor of the claimant: 'He has certainly wronged you by demanding your ewe [to be added] to his ewes. And this is the custom of those who mingle (partners) who do not fear Allah, unlike the righteous believers, who are few.' When they departed, satisfied with his judgment, David reproached himself for being alarmed by them, and thought that he had been tested by his fear of them scaling the Mihrab. So, he fell down bowing and repented, and Allah forgave what happened from him. It is as if Allah, the Most High, is saying to the Master of the Messengers, the Imam of the pious, and the Chief of the men of resolution, Muhammad: 'Beware of being alarmed by the threats of Quraysh, and remember the story of your brother, the righteous and oft-returning servant David, when disputants scaled the wall of his Mihrab and he was alarmed by them; so he apologized to Allah for this alarm, thinking it was not befitting for the Prophets and Messengers. You are more deserving of not being alarmed by Quraysh, no matter how much they collude against you and threaten you, for the good outcome in this world and the Hereafter is for you, and Allah will protect you from the people.' The story of David in Sūrah Ṣād contains no mention of a woman, love, passion, or aggression against the wife of a believing man under the protection of her husband. Rather, it mentions the 'ewe' (*na'jah*). The Arabs—as I mentioned in the introduction to this book, Stories of the Prophets, in the second chapter—do not call a woman a *na'jah*. The term *na'jah* is applied to the female sheep or the wild cow (*baqar al-waḥsh*). It is used only for comparison, and a woman would never be pleased to be compared to a female sheep, but she would be pleased to be compared to the wild cows of Al-Falā, meaning the wild cow. If she is compared to the female sheep, what is meant is the Oryx (*al-Mahā*), which is the wild cow, as the poet said about two women: *'Statues of Hakar, they are two ewes from the ewes of Tabālah, near two fawns, or nearly.'* Tabālah is a place between Bīshah and An-Numāṣ where many wild cows were found, and *ju'dharayn* is the dual of *ju'dhar*, which is the fawn of the wild cow. *Dumā Hakar* means statues made of marble, and Hakar is a place containing these statues, or it is said to be a Roman monastery or a palace. Thus, the woman rejoices if she is compared to the wild cow for the beauty of her eyes and the beauty of her neck. That is why the poet said: *'The eyes of the Oryx (Al-Mahā) are between Ar-Raṣāfah and Al-Jisr.'* And another said: *'Indeed, the eyes with the corner-beauty (ḥawar) brought passion from where I know not. They killed us, and they do not revive our slain. They strike down the intelligent man until he has no movement, yet they are the weakest creatures of Allah as human beings.'* It is well-known that the wild cow does not graze under the care of a shepherd. Thus, applying the term *na'jah* to a woman is not standard Arabic usage; it is only by way of comparison to the wild cow, not the female sheep. Abū Ḥayyān, in his famous Tafsīr (*Al-Baḥr Al-Muḥīṭ*), concerning the saying of the Most High: 'Indeed, this [man] is my brother; he has ninety-nine ewes, and I have one ewe.' [Qur'an, Ṣād: 23], said: 'The apparent meaning is to keep the word *na'jah* in its literal sense, as being a female sheep, and it is not a metaphor for a woman, nor is there any necessity for it.' Then Abū Ḥayyān said: 'What I adhere to is what the apparent meaning of the verse indicates: that the people who scaled the Mihrab were humans who entered by an unusual entrance, and outside the time David sat for judgment, and that he was alarmed by them, thinking they would assassinate him, as he was alone in his Mihrab for the worship of his Lord. When it became clear to him that they had come for a judgment and two of them stepped forward for arbitration, as Allah recounted, David thought that their entry at that time and from that direction was a trial from Allah. What he feared did not happen, so he sought forgiveness for that thought. That is why Allah referred to it with His saying: 'So We forgave him that,' and nothing preceded it except His saying: 'And David realized that We had tried him.' It is definitely known that the Prophets are infallible (*ma'ṣūmūn*) from sins, and it is impossible for them to commit anything of the sort. If we were to permit any such thing for them, the religious laws would be invalidated, and we would not trust anything they report that Allah revealed to them... End quote. As for Al-Bukhārī's statement in his Book of the Stories of the Prophets in his Sahīh: 'A woman is called *na'jah* (ewe), and she is also called *shāh* (sheep/goat),' Al-Ḥāfiẓ Ibn Ḥajar, in *Fatḥ Al-Bārī*, indicated that he derived this from Abū 'Ubaydah Ma'mar ibn Al-Muthannā, who said: Abū 'Ubaydah said concerning His saying: 'and I have one ewe,' meaning a woman. Al-A'shā said: *'And I shot the unawareness of her eye about her sheep, and I hit the kernel of her heart and her spleen.'* It is known that Abū 'Ubaydah Ma'mar ibn Al-Muthannā interpreted some words in the Qur'an as being metaphorical (*majāz al-Qur'ān*). Many Imams criticized him for this path. He is not considered among the trustworthy narrators of reports. Al-A'shā's use of the word *shāh* for a woman was actually a comparison of the woman to the wild cow. Al-Ḥāfiẓ Adh-Dhahabī said in *Tadhkirat Al-Ḥuffāẓ* when mentioning Abū 'Ubaydah Ma'mar ibn Al-Muthannā: 'He is not a scholar of Hadith; rather, it was a slip of my pen to write his name.' Ibn Kathīr said in the story of David from *Al-Bidāyah wan-Nihāyah*: 'Many exegetes, from the predecessors and successors, have mentioned here stories and reports, most or all of which are *Isra’iliyyāt* (Judeo-Christian tales), and some of which are undoubtedly false. We have deliberately omitted reporting them in our book, contenting ourselves with merely reciting the story from the Glorious Qur'an. And Allah guides whom He wills to a straight path.' And he said in his Tafsīr after quoting the verses: 'The exegetes have mentioned here a story, most of which is taken from the *Isra’iliyyāt*, and no authentic Hadith from the infallible Prophet that must be followed has been established concerning it. However, Ibn Abī Ḥātim reported here a Hadith whose chain of transmission is not authentic, because it is narrated by Yazīd Ar-Raqāshī from Anas, and although Yazīd was a righteous man, he is weak in Hadith according to the Imams. It is therefore better to confine oneself to the mere recitation of this story and to refer the knowledge of it to Allah.' To the next chapter, if Allah wills, and peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you. Chapter Sixty-Three The True Stories of the Prophets Continuation: David and Solomon Allah, the Most High, bestowed upon David abundant favor: He gave him kingship and wisdom, and taught him what He willed. He granted him the righteous servant, the noble king, and the great Prophet, the oft-returning (to God): Solomon, son of David. Solomon grew up in the care of David and was raised in the household of prophethood and kingship. When he reached maturity, Allah filled him with clemency (*ḥilm*), meaning patience and reason. He was keen to attend the judicial sittings of his father David to witness his judgments among the people. He would sometimes suggest to his father that if he were the judge in that case, he would have ruled differently than his father had. The Glorious Qur'an mentioned one instance of these cases. Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, mentioned in Sūrah Al-Anbiyā' the case of the field (the harvest) when the people's sheep scattered in it (*nafasat*), meaning they spread out in it at night without a shepherd and damaged the crops. It is mentioned that David judged the owners of the sheep to pay the value (of the crops) to the owner of the field. Solomon said: 'If I had been the judge, I would have ruled differently.' His father David asked: 'How would you judge, my son?' He replied: 'I would give the sheep to the owners of the field so they could benefit from their milk and benefits, and the owners of the sheep would be responsible for repairing the field until it returned to its original state. Then, the field would be returned to its owners, and the sheep would be returned to their owners.' Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, favored Solomon's judgment and mentioned that He made him understand the judgment in this case. This does not diminish the status of David, for his joy at his son's success in judgment was no less than his joy would have been had he understood it himself. Therefore, Allah praised David and Solomon together, saying: 'And to each [of them] We gave judgment and knowledge.' Thus, David's judgment here was not an error, but Solomon's judgment in this case was preferable. Concerning this, Allah says: 'And [mention] David and Solomon, when they judged concerning the field, when the sheep of a people pastured therein by night; and We were witnesses to their judgment. And We gave understanding of the case to Solomon, and to each [of them] We gave judgment and knowledge.' [Qur'an, Al-Anbiyā': 78-79]. Ibn Kathīr (may Allah have mercy on him) said in his Tafsīr of this verse: 'As for the Prophets, they are all infallible, and there is no disagreement among the confirmed scholars, predecessors and successors, that they are supported by Allah.' As for others, it is confirmed in the Sahīh of Al-Bukhārī on the authority of 'Amr ibn Al-'Āṣ that the Messenger of Allah said: 'When a judge makes an independent legal decision (*ijtihād*) and is correct, he receives two rewards; and when he makes an independent legal decision and is mistaken, he receives one reward.' The Messenger of Allah also narrated another instance of David's judgment, where Solomon showed that he would have ruled differently if he had been the judge. Al-Bukhārī and Muslim reported in their Sahīh on the authority of Abū Hurayrah that he heard the Messenger of Allah say: 'There were two women with their two sons. A wolf came and took the son of one of them. The other said to her companion: “It only took your son.” The other replied: “Nay, it took your son.” They referred their dispute to David, who judged in favor of the elder one. They left and presented themselves to Solomon, son of David, and informed him. Solomon said: “Bring me a knife, and I will divide him between the two of you.” The younger one said: “Do not do that, may Allah have mercy on you! He is her son.” So he judged it to the younger one.' David continued his rule and kingship as long as Allah willed. When death reached him, Allah sent Solomon and made him a noble king and a great Messenger, taught him the language of the birds, and made him one of the Imams of the Messengers whom His Messenger Muhammad was commanded to follow as an example. The Qur'an began by mentioning David and Solomon after Noah (Nūḥ) in Sūrah Al-An'ām, where He says: 'And that was Our [conclusive] argument which We gave to Abraham against his people. We raise in degrees whom We will. Indeed, your Lord is Wise and Knowing. And We gave to him Isaac and Jacob. All [of them] We guided. And Noah, We guided before; and among his descendants, David and Solomon, Job and Joseph, Moses and Aaron. And thus do We reward the doers of good.' [Qur'an, Al-An'ām: 83-84]. After mentioning a group of Messengers, He said to His beloved Muhammad: 'Those are the ones whom Allah has guided; so follow their guidance. Say, [O Muhammad], “I ask of you for it no payment. It is not but a reminder to the worlds.” Those are the ones to whom We gave the Scripture and the authority and the prophethood. If they disbelieve in it, then We have entrusted it to a people who are not disbelievers in it.' [Qur'an, Al-An'ām: 89-90]. That is why the Messenger of Allah prostrated when he read Sūrah Ṣād, the prostration of David. Al-Bukhārī reported in his Sahīh on the authority of Mujāhid, who said: 'I asked Ibn 'Abbās about the prostration in Ṣād: “Why do we prostrate?” He said: “Do you not read: 'And among his descendants, David and Solomon... Those are the ones whom Allah has guided; so follow their guidance...' [Qur'an, Al-An'ām: 84-90]? David was among those whom your Prophet was commanded to follow as an example. David prostrated, so your Prophet prostrated.”' Regarding Solomon's succession to his father in kingship and prophethood, Allah says in Sūrah An-Naml: 'And We certainly gave to David and Solomon knowledge, and they said, “Praise to Allah, who has favored us over many of His believing servants.” And Solomon inherited David and said, “O people, we have been taught the language of birds, and we have been given from all things. Indeed, this is the manifest favor.”' [Qur'an, An-Naml: 15-16]. The inheritance meant here is the inheritance of kingship and prophethood, not the inheritance of wealth. It is reported in the two Sahīh that the Messenger of Allah said: 'We, the company of Prophets, do not pass on inheritance. What we leave is charity (*ṣadaqah*).' Just as the Jews lied about David and fabricated many things about him, they exaggerated in lying about Solomon and followed the devils (*shayāṭīn*) in that. They claimed that Solomon judged by means of his magic ring and that he was a sorcerer. They claimed that when he entered the privy, he would give the ring to his wife because it contained the mention of Allah, until he came out. And that a devil came to Solomon's wife in the form of Solomon, and she gave him the ring. The devil went and sat on the royal throne, judging among the Children of Israel. When Solomon came out of the privy, he asked his wife for the ring, and she said: 'Solomon left before you and took it,' and she did not recognize Solomon. Solomon wandered aimlessly until he worked for a fisherman. The fisherman would give him two fish as his daily wage. He would sell one fish to buy bread and cook the other fish. He continued this for forty days. Then the Children of Israel rose up against this devil sitting on Solomon's throne. The devil fled from them—and I do not know why the ring was of no use to him—and threw the ring into the sea. A fish swallowed it, and then it fell into the fisherman's net. When the fisherman gave Solomon his two fish as payment, he sold one and cooked the other, which had the ring inside it. When he opened it, he found his ring, put it on, and returned to his kingdom. It is strange that this slander infiltrated some of the great scholars who believed it, to the extent that you find in most books of Tafsīr regarding His saying: 'and We cast upon his chair a body (jasad).' [Qur'an, Ṣād: 34], they say it was a devil. The mention of Solomon's ring and its properties has spread among the common people and the elite, even though Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, warned in Sūrah Al-Baqarah about the lies of the Jews against Solomon by following the devils in this regard, saying: 'And they followed [instead] what the devils had recited during the reign of Solomon. And Solomon did not disbelieve, but the devils disbelieved, teaching people magic.' [Qur'an, Al-Baqarah: 102], etc. Yet, the Messenger of Allah explained Solomon's trial and the casting of the body upon his chair: He swore that he would go around one hundred of his wives that night, so that each of them would conceive a knight carrying arms and fighting in the cause of Allah. He forgot to say: 'If Allah wills.' He went around them, but only one of them conceived and gave birth to half a child, which was taken and cast upon his chair. He then sought forgiveness from Allah, and Allah accepted his excuse, for he did not seek the child out of arrogance or boasting, but so that they might fight in the cause of Allah. Allah accepted his excuse and substituted for him the wind: 'So We subjected to him the wind, running by his command wherever he directed. And [also] the devils [of jinn]—all builders and divers. And others bound in shackles. [We said], “This is Our gift; so grant [it] or withhold, without reckoning.”' [Qur'an, Ṣād: 36-38]. To the next chapter, if Allah wills, and peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you. Chapter Sixty-Four The True Stories of the Prophets Continuation of David and Solomon I mentioned at the end of the chapter that the Messenger of Allah explained the saying of the Most High: 'And We certainly tried Solomon and cast upon his chair a body; then he repented.' [Qur'an, Ṣād: 34] with the story of his oath to go around one hundred of his wives so that each of them would conceive and give birth to a knight fighting in the cause of Allah, and he forgot to say: 'If Allah wills.' He went around them, but only one of them conceived and gave birth to half a child, which was taken and cast upon his chair. Al-Bukhārī and Muslim reported in their Sahīh on the authority of Abū Hurayrah that the Messenger of Allah said: 'Solomon, son of David, said: “I will go around one hundred women tonight, and every woman will give birth to a boy who will fight in the cause of Allah.” He forgot to say: “If Allah wills.” He went around them, but none of the women gave birth except one who gave birth to half a person.' The Messenger of Allah said: 'If he had said: “If Allah wills,” he would not have broken his oath, and he would have achieved his need.' In a wording in Al-Bukhārī: 'She bore nothing except one who was half-formed (sāqiṭ).' The Prophet said: 'If he had said it, they would have fought in the cause of Allah.' So, I am astonished how some scholars abandoned this established explanation from the Messenger of Allah concerning Solomon's trial and instead brought the lies of the Jews and the devils. Ibn Kathīr said in the Stories of the Prophets from *Al-Bidāyah wan-Nihāyah* concerning His saying: 'And We certainly tried Solomon and cast upon his chair a body; then he repented.' [Qur'an, Ṣād: 34]: Ibn Jarīr, Ibn Abī Ḥātim, and others among the exegetes mentioned here many reports from a group of the Salaf (predecessors), and most or all of them are derived from the *Isra’iliyyāt*, and many of them contain severe anomaly. We have drawn attention to this in our book of Tafsīr, and here we have contented ourselves with mere recitation. Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, favored Solomon by granting him many sources of strength and compensating him with strength exceeding one hundred fighting sons. He subjected to him: 'the wind, running by his command wherever he directed. And [also] the devils [of jinn]—all builders and divers. And others bound in shackles. [We said], “This is Our gift; so grant [it] or withhold, without reckoning.”' [Qur'an, Ṣād: 36-39]. Just as Allah honored Solomon's status in this world, He prepared for him a high rank and a beautiful place of return in the Hereafter. Concerning this, Allah, the Most High, says: 'And We certainly tried Solomon and cast upon his chair a body; then he repented. He said, “My Lord, forgive me and grant me a kingdom such as will not belong to anyone after me. Indeed, You are the Bestower.” So We subjected to him the wind, running by his command wherever he directed. And [also] the devils [of jinn]—all builders and divers. And others bound in shackles. [We said], “This is Our gift; so grant [it] or withhold, without reckoning.” And indeed, for him is nearness to Us and a beautiful place of return.' [Qur'an, Ṣād: 34-40]. Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, described the wind He subjected to Solomon in a way that implies it was subject to Solomon's will: if he wanted it to be gentle and calm, it became so, and if he wanted it to be stormy, fierce, and fast, it was so. It covered in the morning journey (*ghadāh*), meaning from the start of the day until noon, a distance that would take a month of normal travel to cover, and it covered in the afternoon journey (*rawāḥ*), meaning from noon until sunset, a distance that would take a month of normal travel to cover, approximately four hundred eighty miles for the morning journey and the same for the evening journey. All of this is referred to in His saying in Sūrah Ṣād: 'So We subjected to him the wind, running by his command wherever he directed.' [Qur'an, Ṣād: 36], and His saying in Sūrah Al-Anbiyā': 'And to Solomon [We subjected] the tempestuous wind, running by his command toward the land which We had blessed. And We are of all things Knowing.' [Qur'an, Al-Anbiyā': 81], and His saying in Sūrah Saba': 'And to Solomon [We subjected] the wind—its morning journey was a month [of travel] and its evening journey was a month [of travel].' [Qur'an, Saba': 12]. Just as He made iron soft for David, He made the spring of molten copper flow for Solomon, meaning He liquefied the spring of copper and iron for him, so that copper and iron flowed from its mine like a running spring of water, without needing to light a fire on it, to ease his task and increase his strength. He also subjected to him the devils (*shayāṭīn*), who are the rebellious jinn and those beneath them. They worked before him by the command of their Lord, subservient; not one of them dared to flee from serving Solomon, fearing God's swift punishment. They made for Solomon what he wished: *maḥārīb*—meaning high, smooth palaces (of glass)—for the *miḥrāb* is the palace. Applying this term to what is known as the *Qiblah* (niche) in the wall of the mosque to indicate it is a modern usage not known to the Arabs, and it is a grave error to cite the saying of the Most High: 'Every time Zechariah entered upon her in the Mihrab (chamber), he found with her provision.' [Qur'an, Al 'Imrān: 37] for these niches, as they are not intended by this noble verse. The jinn also made for Solomon what he wished in the form of statues (*tamāthīl*), meaning wall decorations of images of trees, flowers, and the like. They also made large bowls as big as cisterns in which food was served. They also made for him fixed cooking pots that could not be moved from their place due to their size. The jinn also performed diving work to extract jewels. Concerning all of this, Allah says in Sūrah Al-Anbiyā': 'And among the devils were those who dived for him and did other work than that; and We were for them Keepers.' [Qur'an, Al-Anbiyā': 82]. And He says in Sūrah Saba': 'And We caused to flow for him a spring of [molten] copper. And of the jinn were those who worked before him by the permission of his Lord. And whoever deviated among them from Our command—We will make him taste of the punishment of the Blaze. They made for him what he willed of elevated chambers (maḥārīb) and statues and bowls like reservoirs and firmly fixed cooking pots. [We said], “Work, O family of David, in gratitude.” And few of My servants are grateful.' [Qur'an, Saba': 12-13]. And He says in Sūrah Ṣād: 'And [also] the devils [of jinn]—all builders and divers. And others bound in shackles. [We said], “This is Our gift; so grant [it] or withhold, without reckoning.” And indeed, for him is nearness to Us and a beautiful place of return.' [Qur'an, Ṣād: 37-40]. Just as Allah subjected the birds to David, gathered and returning (to God) and glorifying Allah with his glorification, He likewise subjected the birds to Solomon, who would gather them whenever he willed and knew their language and the languages of insects. Concerning this, Allah says in Sūrah An-Naml: 'And Solomon inherited David and said, “O people, we have been taught the language of birds.”
source: Holy Quran and Prophetic Sunnah, Exegeses of Ahlus Sunnah Wal Jama'ah

bio_naissance_annee: No specific date, approximately 800 years before Christ
bio_lieu_naissance: Nineveh (currently in Iraq)
bio_descendance: Son of Matta, sent to the people of Nineveh
texte_original: Yunus ibn Matta In this chapter, we speak to you about the Prophet and Messenger of Allah, Dhun-Nun, Yunus ibn Matta (Jonah, son of Amittai), peace and blessings be upon him. Allah, the Blessed, the Exalted, sent Yunus to the people of Nineveh, from Mosul in Iraq. He called them to Allah Alone and to abandon the worship of everything besides Him. He offered them advice and delivered his Lord's message. Since Yunus was not one of the Messengers of Firm Resolve (Ulul-'Azm min al-Rusul), he did not bear the level of endurance shown by the Messengers of Firm Resolve concerning the rejection and abuse from his people. Allah, the Blessed, the Exalted, indicated that his people had angered him and that he had sensed their disbelief (Kufr). He then threatened them with a punishment from Allah that might befall them if they did not believe in him. The signs of the torment began to appear in their atmosphere, and the precursors of the punishment started to move towards them. Yunus then thought that he had fulfilled the burdens of the message (al-Risalah), as he had clarified the path for his people, introduced them to Allah's Straight Path (Sirat Allah al-Mustaqim), and warned them against the causes of Allah's displeasure and wrath. He believed that Allah the Exalted would not restrict him if he emigrated from the land of his people and that he was free to go wherever he wished. So, he headed towards the sea and boarded a heavily laden ship. It appears that when the ship's crew saw him and witnessed his dignity and splendor, they did not attempt to stop him from boarding their vessel. However, when the sea became rough, the ship's passengers were compelled to lighten its load of people. They held a lottery to cast into the sea whoever's lot fell upon them. Yunus was « among the losers » (Surah As-Saffat: 141), meaning among those upon whom the arrows fell. He was cast into the sea while afflicted by the distress, grief, and worry that caused him to leave his people. Allah then prepared a whale (i.e., a large fish) for him, and the whale swallowed him. Allah, the Blessed, the Exalted, protected Yunus from any harm within the whale; no bone was broken, and no flesh was scratched. Instead, the whale's belly became a temporary prison for Yunus. The darkness of the whale's belly, within the darkness of the sea, enveloped him. Yunus cried out, calling upon his Lord, appealing to Him with the word of Monotheism (Tawhid) for which Allah created jinn and humans, for which He revealed the Books and sent the Messengers, and for which the market of Paradise and Hell is established. He glorified Allah, purifying Him from every imperfection, and apologized to Allah for fleeing his people, saying: « There is no deity (worthy of worship) except You; exalted are You. Indeed, I was among the wrongdoers. » (Surah Al-Anbiya: 87). Allah answered his call and saved him from the distress. The whale rushed to the seashore and cast Yunus out onto the bare land (al-'Ara), while he was sick (saqim) from the intensity of the terror, distress, anxiety, and grief that had afflicted him. Allah caused a gourd plant (Yaqtin) to grow over him. *Yaqtin* is a plant that has no stem, and its fruit is called *al-Qara'* (pumpkin) or *al-Dubba'* (squash), a type of gourd. Scholars have mentioned the wisdom behind the gourd plant growing over Yunus: the leaf of the gourd plant is extremely soft, abundant, shady, and flies do not approach it. Its fruit can be eaten from the beginning to the end, raw or cooked, with its peel and seeds. It contains many benefits, strengthening the brain and body, and so on. This is why it is narrated that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) loved the gourd. Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated from the hadith of Anas ibn Malik that a tailor invited the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) to a meal he had prepared. Anas said: « I went with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) and I saw him searching for the pieces of gourd from around the platter. » He added: « I have loved the gourd ever since that day. » Allah, the Blessed, the Exalted, restored Yunus to full health and informed him that his people had believed when they saw Allah's punishment approaching them. Allah accepted their faith and removed the punishment of disgrace from them in the life of this world. Allah, the Blessed, the Exalted, commanded him to return to them and to continue guiding them to Allah's Straight Path. Yunus returned to them; they were more than one hundred thousand people. Allah bestowed upon them an abundance of goodness and blessings, and they lived in safety under the Law of Allah (Shari'ah) with which Yunus had been sent. Allah, the Blessed, the Exalted, mentioned aspects of the story of Yunus in various places in His Noble Book, and in each context, He presented the discourse appropriate for it. In the Surah named Yunus entirely after him, He mentioned the favor He granted to the nation of Yunus, a unique favor among the preceding nations. He excluded them from the rule that the faith of disbelievers is of no benefit when they see the punishment, according to His saying (approximate translation): « But when they saw Our might, they said, 'We believe in Allah alone and disbelieve in that which we used to associate with Him.' But their belief did not benefit them when they saw Our might. (This is) the way of Allah which has passed concerning His servants; and the disbelievers thereupon lost (everything). » (Surah Ghafir: 84-85). The nation of Yunus was excluded from this rule, for when they saw the onset of the punishment approaching, they believed and believed Yunus. Regarding this, Allah says (approximate translation): « Why was there not among the generations a single town that believed so that its faith benefited it (and averted its punishment) - except the people of Yunus? When they believed, We removed from them the punishment of disgrace in the worldly life and permitted them enjoyment for a time. » (Surah Yunus: 98). In Surah Al-Anbiya (The Prophets), He says (approximate translation): « And (mention) Dhun-Nun, when he went off in anger and thought that We would not restrict him. He called out within the darknesses, 'There is no deity (worthy of worship) except You; exalted are You. Indeed, I was among the wrongdoers.' So We responded to him and saved him from the distress. And thus, We save the believers. » (Surah Al-Anbiya: 87-88). His saying, « Dhun-Nun » (the Companion of the Fish, *An-Nun* being the fish), refers to Yunus, whom Allah named as such due to the whale's swallowing him, His mercy upon him, and his stay inside it for a period of time, and His deliverance from drowning until He cast him onto the shore. His saying, « when he went off in anger » (*idh dhahaba mughadhiban*), means that he left angered by his people, filled with wrath towards them for their disbelief and denial of him, and they were angry at him. His saying, « and thought that We would not restrict him » (*fa-zanna an lan naqdira 'alayh*), means that he assumed that Allah the Exalted would not constrain him (make life difficult for him) if he left his disbelieving people after conveying his Lord's message. This was from his own personal judgment (*Ijtihad*). The meaning of *naqdira* is to constrain or make difficult, as in His saying (approximate translation): « But he whose provision is restricted - let him spend from that which Allah has given him. » (Surah At-Talaq: 7) and His saying (approximate translation): « Indeed, your Lord extends provision for whom He wills of His servants and restricts (it) for him. » (Surah Al-Qasas: 82) and « Your Lord extends provision for whom He wills and restricts (it). » (Surah Al-Isra: 30) – meaning, He widens or restricts for whom He wills. It should not occur to the mind of a Muslim that *naqdira* here means « to be able », for no ordinary believer, let alone a Prophet, would think that Allah is incapable of anything or unable to do it, as He is Omnipotent over all things. Until the next chapter, if Allah wills. Peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you. * ### Chapter Forty-One: Continuation of Yunus ibn Matta I mentioned at the end of the previous chapter the meaning of Allah's saying about Yunus (approximate translation): « And (mention) Dhun-Nun, when he went off in anger and thought that We would not restrict him. » (Surah Al-Anbiya: 87). As for His saying (approximate translation): « He called out within the darknesses, 'There is no deity (worthy of worship) except You; exalted are You. Indeed, I was among the wrongdoers.' » (Surah Al-Anbiya: 87), this means he cried out, seeking help from his Lord, in the darkness of the whale's belly, in the deep sea, appealing to Him with the word of Monotheism, glorifying Allah the Exalted from every imperfection, describing Him with all perfection, and seeking forgiveness from Allah for having left his people without permission from Allah, saying: « There is no deity (worthy of worship) except You; exalted are You. Indeed, I was among the wrongdoers. » (Surah Al-Anbiya: 87). His saying, « Indeed, I was among the wrongdoers, » does not imply that he committed a sin or an act of disobedience. It is established that even Noah, a Messenger of Allah and one of the Messengers of Firm Resolve, said: « My Lord, indeed my son is of my family; and indeed, Your promise is the truth, and You are the most just of judges. He said, 'O Noah, indeed he is not of your family; indeed, he is (the result of) unrighteous work. So ask Me not for that about which you have no knowledge. Indeed, I advise you lest you be among the ignorant.' He said, 'My Lord, I seek refuge in You from asking that of which I have no knowledge. And unless You forgive me and have mercy upon me, I will be among the losers.' » (Surah Hud: 45-47). As for His saying (approximate translation): « So We responded to him and saved him from the distress. And thus, We save the believers. » (Surah Al-Anbiya: 88), this means: We answered Yunus when he called upon Us while in the whale's belly, and We delivered him from the distress, worry, sadness, and affliction that befell him. The whale cast him onto the seashore, and We completed Our Favor upon him. Likewise, We save every believer who falls into grief and distress and seeks refuge in Us. We deliver him from his sorrow and affliction: « Is not He (better than your gods) Who responds to the desperate one when he calls upon Him and removes evil, and makes you inheritors of the earth? Is there any deity with Allah? Little do you remember. » (Surah An-Naml: 62). Allah the Exalted says in Surah As-Saffat (The Ranks): « And indeed, Yunus was among the messengers. When he ran away to the laden ship. And he drew lots and was among the losers (or defeated). Then the whale swallowed him while he was blameworthy. And had he not been of those who exalt Allah, he would have remained inside its belly until the Day they are resurrected. But We cast him onto the bare shore while he was sick. And We caused to grow over him a plant of gourd. And We sent him to [a people of] a hundred thousand or more. And they believed, so We gave them enjoyment for a time. » (Surah As-Saffat: 139-148). His saying, « ran away » (*abaq*), means that he left without fear or secretly. Then « he drew lots » (*fasahama*), meaning he participated in the lottery with the ship's passengers to cast into the sea whoever's lot fell upon them in order to lighten the ship's load and save those who were not designated. His saying, « was among the losers » (*fa-kana min al-mudhhadhina*), means that he was among the defeated upon whom the lot fell to be cast into the sea. His saying, « Then the whale swallowed him while he was blameworthy » (*fa-ltaqamahu al-hutu wa huwa mulim*), means that the whale swallowed Yunus while he was blameworthy or reproaching himself for leaving his people without permission from his Lord. Blame (*al-lawm*) is reproach and censure. The fact that some Prophets do something for which they are blamed through personal judgment (*Ijtihad*) is harmless. This even happened to the most perfect of Allah's creation and the Master of the Messengers, Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), on the Day of Badr, when he consulted his companions about what to do with the prisoners. Abu Bakr advised keeping them and accepting ransom, while Umar advised killing them to weaken the strength of the polytheists. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) never chose between two matters except for the easier one, unless it was a sin. So, he inclined towards Abu Bakr's opinion and accepted ransom from the prisoners. Allah reproached him for accepting the ransom and said concerning it (approximate translation): « It is not for a prophet to have captives until he has thoroughly subdued (the enemy) in the land. You desire the goods of this world, while Allah desires the Hereafter. And Allah is Exalted in Might and Wise. If not for a decree from Allah that preceded, you would have been touched, for what you took, by a great punishment. So consume what you took of war booty (as) lawful and good, and fear Allah. Indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful. » (Surah Al-Anfal: 67-69). As for His saying (approximate translation): « And had he not been of those who exalt Allah, he would have remained inside its belly until the Day they are resurrected. » (Surah As-Saffat: 143-144), this means that had Yunus not been of those who frequently remember Allah, glorifying Him with praise in ease and hardship, We would have made the whale's belly his grave. But he knew Allah in times of ease, so Allah relieved his distress in hardship. This is why it is reported that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said to Ibn Abbas, as narrated by Ahmad and some compilers of the Sunan: « O young man, I will teach you some words: Guard Allah, and He will guard you. Guard Allah, and you will find Him in front of you. Know Allah in times of ease, and He will know you in times of hardship. » His saying (approximate translation): « But We cast him onto the bare shore while he was sick » (*fa-nabadhnahu bi-al-'ara-i wa huwa saqim*), means that We commanded the whale to cast him onto the seashore, on the open land. He was weakened and sick from the grief, distress, and the whale's belly. The word « or » (*aw*) in His saying (approximate translation): « And We sent him to [a people of] a hundred thousand or more » is not an expression of doubt about the number sent to, but rather for correction (*idrab*), meaning « rather ». He first established the number one hundred thousand, so this large number settled in the minds of the listeners, and then he mentioned that they were « or more », which is an increase in the emphasis on the magnitude of the number sent to. This is more eloquent and concise than saying: « He was sent to more than one hundred thousand. » This serves as consolation for the heart of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) because of the favor Allah bestowed upon Yunus. The amount beyond one hundred thousand is known only to Allah, as no specific determination of this increase was reported from the infallible Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him). His saying (approximate translation): « And they believed, so We gave them enjoyment for a time » (*fa-amanu fa-matta'nahum ila hin*), means that they persisted in their faith and increased in belief through what Yunus prescribed for them. Allah opened the doors of blessings and goodness for them as long as they adhered to the religion Yunus brought to them. Allah says in Surah Nun (Al-Qalam): « So be patient for the decision of your Lord, and be not like the Companion of the Fish (Yunus) when he called out while he was distressed. If not for the favor from his Lord which reached him, he would have been cast onto the bare shore while he was condemned. But his Lord chose him and placed him among the righteous. » (Surah Al-Qalam: 48-50). In this noble context of mentioning Yunus, Allah begins by commanding His beloved Messenger Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) to be patient with the abuse of his people, no matter what they did, because he is the Master of the Messengers of Firm Resolve. Then He warns him against letting his patience run out as his brother Yunus's did after he was filled with distress and grief due to the harm from his people. Yunus is not among the Messengers of Firm Resolve; he is one of the Messengers who are not among the *Ulul-'Azm*. Allah said about one of them, their father Adam (approximate translation): « And We had already taken a covenant from Adam before, but he forgot; and We found not in him firm resolve. » (Surah Ta-Ha: 115). And the Master of the Messengers, Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), was told (approximate translation): « So be patient, as were those of firm resolve among the messengers; and do not seek to hasten (the punishment) for them. » (Surah Al-Ahqaf: 35). This does not prevent the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) from following the example of his brothers, the Prophets, in the guidance they brought, including Yunus. That is why when Allah mentioned a group of Prophets and Messengers in Surah Al-An'am (The Cattle), including Yunus, Allah said to His Messenger (peace and blessings be upon him) after mentioning them (approximate translation): « Those are the ones whom Allah has guided, so take their guidance as an example. » (Surah Al-An'am: 90). Until the next chapter, if Allah wills. Peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you. * ### Chapter Forty-Two: Continuation of Yunus I mentioned at the end of the previous chapter the meaning of Allah's saying about Yunus from Surah Nun (Al-Qalam): « So be patient for the decision of your Lord, and be not like the Companion of the Fish » (Surah Al-Qalam: 48). His saying (approximate translation): « when he called out while he was distressed » (Surah Al-Qalam: 48) is not included in the prohibition, for the call (invocation) of the distressed and his prayer to his Lord are beloved and sought. The meaning of « when he called out while he was distressed » is that he called upon his Lord while he was filled with distress and grief, when he said while in the whale's belly: « There is no deity (worthy of worship) except You; exalted are You. Indeed, I was among the wrongdoers. » (Surah Al-Anbiya: 87). As for His saying (approximate translation): « If not for the favor from his Lord which reached him, he would have been cast onto the bare shore while he was condemned » (Surah Al-Qalam: 49), this means: Had it not been for the mercy and care of Allah that reached him, he would have been cast onto the open ground while blamed (condemned). But since Allah's mercy reached him, the whale cast him onto the shore without being blamed. It is as if Allah, the Blessed, the Exalted, favored Yunus and did not hold him accountable for his personal judgment (*Ijtihad*) in leaving his people in anger without permission from his Lord, just as He favored Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) by not holding him accountable for accepting the ransom of the prisoners on the Day of Badr, when He said (approximate translation): « If not for a decree from Allah that preceded, you would have been touched, for what you took, by a great punishment. » (Surah Al-Anfal: 68). The particle *Lawla* (If not for) is a particle of abstention for a reason. The answer was omitted here because its condition existed. Everyone who is not reached by Allah's mercy is condemned, but Yunus was not condemned because Allah's mercy reached him. His saying (approximate translation): « But his Lord chose him and placed him among the righteous » (Surah Al-Qalam: 50) is an additional favor from Allah the Exalted upon Yunus, meaning that Allah chose him (*ijtabahu*), i.e., elevated his rank among the chosen and the best, and placed him among the perfect in righteousness (*as-salihin*). Many authentic hadiths indicate the virtue of Yunus and prohibit preferring the Master of the Prophets and the Chief of the Messengers, Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), over Yunus ibn Matta. These are interpreted as being a matter of his humility (*Tawadu'*), as I mentioned in the story of Ibrahim, Lot, and Joseph, where the humility of a person of high rank does not diminish his status. The Qur'an explicitly states that Allah favored some Prophets over others, as in His saying (approximate translation): « Those messengers - We preferred some of them over others. Among them were those to whom Allah spoke, and He raised some of them in degrees (or ranks). » (Surah Al-Baqarah: 253). There is no doubt among the people of knowledge that the Messengers of Firm Resolve (Ulul-'Azm), namely Muhammad, then his spiritual father Ibrahim, are superior to the other Prophets and Messengers. The best of the *Ulul-'Azm* is Muhammad, the Beloved of the Most Merciful (peace and blessings be upon them all). However, scholars have ruled that if the situation is one of conflict between religions and a cause for inciting evil and harming Muslims, then abstaining from expressing preference (*Tafdhil*) is necessary, in accordance with His saying (approximate translation): « And do not insult those they invoke other than Allah, lest they insult Allah in enmity without knowledge. Thus, We have made pleasing to every community their own doings. Then to their Lord is their return, and He will inform them about what they used to do. » (Surah Al-An'am: 108). Idols and statues deserve to be insulted, but if insulting them provokes their worshippers against the Muslims, then insulting them is forbidden for that reason. Similarly, expressing preference (*Tafdhil*) out of pride, bias, or fanaticism (*Asabiyyah*) is forbidden. This is how the reports from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) prohibiting him from being preferred over Moses or Yunus ibn Matta (peace and blessings be upon them all) are interpreted. Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated from the hadith of Abu Hurayrah that a Jew was displaying his goods. He was offered something for them that he disliked or rejected, and he said: « No, by Him Who chose Moses over humanity! » A man from the Ansar (Medinese) heard him and slapped him saying: « Do you say, 'By Him Who chose Moses over humanity,' while the Messenger of Allah is among us? » The Jew went to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) and said: « O Abul-Qasim (the Prophet's nickname), so-and-so slapped my face! » The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: « Why did you slap his face? » He said: « He said, 'By Him Who chose Moses over humanity,' and you are among us, O Messenger of Allah. » The Messenger of Allah became angry until the anger was visible on his face, then he said: « Do not make distinction of preference between the Prophets of Allah. » He added: « For the Trumpet will be blown, and all who are in the heavens and all who are on the earth will be struck down, except whom Allah wills. » He said: « Then it will be blown again, and I will be the first to be resurrected, or among the first. Then, I will see Moses holding onto the Throne (of Allah). I do not know if he was resurrected before me or if he was exempted from the stunning (swoon) on the Day of the Mount (Tur). And I do not say that anyone is better than Yunus ibn Matta. » His saying in this hadith concerning Moses: « I will be the first to be resurrected, and I will see Moses holding onto the Throne. I do not know if he was resurrected before me or if he was exempted from the stunning on the Day of the Mount » does not indicate that Moses is better than Muhammad, as the rule established among scholars is that particular excellence (*al-maziyyah*) does not negate general superiority (*al-afdaliyyah*). That is, if a person is proven to have a particular excellence over another in one aspect, it does not mean that the possessor of this excellence is superior to the other. For example, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) saw in his dream that Bilal was walking in front of him in Paradise. Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated, with the wording of Al-Bukhari, from the hadith of Abu Hurayrah, that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said to Bilal at the Fajr prayer: « O Bilal, tell me about the most hopeful deed you have done in Islam, for I heard the light sound of your sandals ahead of me in Paradise. » He replied: « The most hopeful deed I have done is that I never performed ablution (purification) at any time of night or day except that I prayed with those ablutions whatever Allah decreed for me to pray. » And in a narration by Muslim: « I heard tonight. » And in another narration, instead of « the light sound of your sandals » (*daffu na'layk*), it is « the rustle of your sandals » (*khashfu na'layk*), with *Daff* and *Khashf* both meaning a light movement. In the narration of At-Tirmidhi, Ibn Khuzaymah, and Ahmad, from the hadith of Buraydah, in this hadith of Bilal, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: « O Bilal, how did you precede me to Paradise? » It would not cross the mind of any Muslim that Bilal is superior to the Messenger of Allah because of this particular excellence. Perhaps someone might think he is better than Yunus ibn Matta upon hearing His saying (approximate translation): « and be not like the Companion of the Fish » (Surah Al-Qalam: 48), being ignorant that the purpose of this noble mention is to warn the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) – as I mentioned – to emulate the Messengers of Firm Resolve in the matter of patience, and not to emulate those who are not of the *Ulul-'Azm* in this regard. He also forgets that Allah commanded His Messenger Muhammad to emulate the Prophets and Messengers, including Yunus, in the path toward the Straight Path, as mentioned in Surah Al-An'am. For all these reasons, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) warned Muslims against any satanic thought in this matter. Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated from the hadith of Ibn Abbas that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: « It does not befit a servant to say: 'I am better than Yunus ibn Matta,' » mentioning him by his father's name. And in a narration by Al-Bukhari from the hadith of Abdullah ibn Mas'ud, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: « It does not befit a servant to say: 'I am better than Yunus ibn Matta.' » Likewise, Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated from the hadith of Abu Hurayrah that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: « It does not befit a servant to say: 'I am better than Yunus ibn Matta.' Peace be upon Yunus among the Messengers. » Until the next chapter, if Allah wills. Peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you.
source: Holy Quran and Prophetic Sunnah, Exegeses of Ahlus Sunnah Wal Jama'ah
