texte_original: en": "Jesus, Son of Mary Allah the Blessed and Most High mentioned in His Noble Book that when the angels gave Mary (Maryam) the glad tidings of a son, they told her that his name would be the Messiah, Jesus son of Mary (Al-Masih 'Isa Ibn Maryam). By this name, the Messiah of Guidance is distinguished from the Messiah of Misguidance, the Dajjal (Antichrist). The word Al-Masih (The Messiah) is said to be Hebrew, meaning The Blessed. Others say he was called the Messiah because he would anoint/touch (yamsah) those with afflictions and they would be cured by Allah's permission. It is also said because he had smooth feet (flat-footed), or because Allah anointed him, meaning He created him with a blessed creation. Others suggest it is derived from *As-Siyahah* (traveling), which is moving about the earth for propagation and worship. Ibn Manzur in *Lisan Al-Arab* reported that Ibn Sida said: “The Messiah, Jesus son of Mary (peace be upon our Prophet and upon them both), was named so for his truthfulness, or because he was a perpetual traveler in the land, not settling.” Still others say he was named the Messiah because he came out of his mother's womb anointed (mamsuh) with oil, just as the Dajjal is called the Messiah because he has a rubbed-out (mamsuh) eye (i.e., blind). The Messiah of Guidance, Jesus son of Mary, will kill the Messiah of Misguidance, the Dajjal, as informed by the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), when he descends at the end of time. As for the name 'Isa (Jesus), some say it is not derived, and is a Hebrew or Syriac name that the corruptors have changed and altered to 'Yasou' (Jesus). Others say it is derived from *Al-'Ays*, which is a whiteness tinged with redness, and the white camels whose whiteness is mixed with a reddish hue are called *'Is*. * ### The Habitation and Mission of Jesus Allah the Blessed and Most High indicated that He prepared for Jesus and his mother a high place (rabwah) with a resting place and a flowing spring ('ayn). The *rabwah* is a raised place, and being *dhat qarar* means it is level for its dwellers to settle upon, and *Al-Ma'in* is visible, flowing water. There is no authentic narration specifying the exact location of this elevated place. Some people say it is Jerusalem, others the Ghouta of Damascus, others Palestine, and yet others the Faiyum region of Egypt. The knowledge of this rests with Allah. The intent is that Allah the Blessed and Most High facilitated a safe habitation and a righteous dwelling for them. In this regard, Allah the Most High says: *“And We made the son of Mary and his mother a Sign, and We gave them refuge on a high ground (rabwah) having a place of rest and a flowing spring ('ayn).”* [Al-Mu'minun: 50]. Allah the Blessed and Most High indicated that Jesus learned writing and that Allah granted him Wisdom and understanding of the Torah. When he reached his full strength, Allah sent him to the Children of Israel and revealed to him the Gospel (Al-Injil), which contained guidance, light, and an admonition for the righteous, along with the glad tidings (bishara) of the Master of the Messengers (Muhammad). Allah commanded him to call the Children of Israel to judge by the Gospel. Allah the Blessed and Most High supported Jesus with stunning sensory miracles and manifest, overwhelming signs testifying that he was a Messenger from the Lord of the worlds. * ### The Five Miracles of Jesus Jesus came to the Children of Israel, informing them that he was the Messenger of Allah and His servant, that He had granted him the Gospel, that there is no deity but Allah, and no one truly worthy of worship other than Him. He informed them that he had come to them with signs from their Lord, consisting of five sensory signs: 1. Creating the shape of a bird from clay and breathing into it so it becomes a bird by Allah's permission: He would mold the shape of a bird from clay, then breathe into it, and it would become a bird and fly away by Allah's permission, as they watched with their own eyes. This miracle was to be a clear sign that he was a Messenger from the Lord of the worlds. 2. Curing the one born blind (Al-Akmah) by Allah's permission: The *Akmah* is one born with both eyes rubbed out (lacking pupils). Curing him to see is beyond the capacity of any physician, ancient or modern, and it is one of the most manifest physical miracles that no human can accomplish. 3. Curing and healing the leper (Al-Abras) by Allah's permission: Leprosy is a known disease, a whiteness that affects human skin, which skilled doctors have been unable to treat throughout history. 4. Resurrecting the dead by Allah's permission: These four signs are beyond the ability of any single human being, past or present. This followed the Divine Law that Allah sends every prophet with a miracle that surpasses the highest degree of knowledge in which his people excelled, to make the truth more apparent and for them to know it is from Allah. Thus, Moses was sent when his people excelled in magic, and Jesus was sent during a time when people were skilled in medicine and the knowledge of nature. *“And [make him] a messenger to the Children of Israel, [who will say]: 'Indeed, I have come to you with a sign from your Lord in that I design for you from clay [that which is] like the form of a bird, then I breathe into it, and it becomes a bird by permission of Allah. And I cure the blind [from birth] and the leper, and I give life to the dead by permission of Allah. And I inform you of what you eat and what you store in your houses. Indeed in that is a sign for you, if you are believers. And [I have come] confirming that which was before me of the Torah and to make lawful for you some of what was forbidden to you. And I have come to you with a sign from your Lord, so fear Allah and obey me. Indeed, Allah is my Lord and your Lord, so worship Him. This is a straight path.'”* [Al 'Imran: 48-51]. 5. Informing them of what they ate and what they stored in their homes: He would say to one of them: You ate such-and-such today, and you have stored such-and-such in your house for tomorrow, something they knew no one else could know. Jesus informed them that this was a sign from Allah, benefiting those whose hearts Allah opened to faith. Jesus believed in the preceding heavenly Books, confirmed the Torah, and his law made lawful for the Children of Israel some things that were forbidden to them in the law of Moses. He clarified for them the correct view on the issues they differed upon, showing them the truth and correctness. He then presented the essence of his call: to sincerely worship Allah alone and obey what Allah legislated through him, demanding of them the fear of Allah: *“So fear Allah and obey me. Indeed, Allah is my Lord and your Lord, so worship Him. This is a straight path.”* [Al 'Imran: 50-51]. * ### Jesus, the Last Prophet of Israel and the Announcer of Muhammad Allah the Blessed and Most High indicated that He made Jesus the last of the prophets sent specifically to the Children of Israel. Jesus came confirming the Torah and bearing the glad tidings of the Messenger who would come after him, Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), whose name is also Ahmad. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) stated that he was the closest person to Jesus, son of Mary, as there was no prophet between them. He said: *“The prophets are children of 'Allat (brothers from the same father but different mothers); their mothers are diverse, but their religion is one, and there is no prophet between me and him.”* The meaning of *“children of 'Allat”* is that the root of the religion of all prophets is one (Tawhid/Monotheism, Prophethood, Resurrection, etc.), while the specific laws and regulations (*shari'ah*) vary according to the time and place of each nation, as Allah said: *“For each We have appointed a divine law (shir'ah) and a clear way (minhaj).”* [Al-Ma'idah: 48]. The word Injil (Gospel) is a Greek word meaning Glad Tidings. Although the Gospel revealed to Jesus was a Book of legal rulings, it prominently featured the glad tidings (bishara) of the coming of the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), fulfilling the covenant Allah took from all the prophets. Allah the Most High said: *“And [mention] when Jesus, the son of Mary, said, 'O Children of Israel, indeed I am the messenger of Allah to you, confirming what came before me of the Torah and bringing good tidings of a messenger to come after me, whose name is Ahmad.' But when he came to them with clear evidences, they said, 'This is obvious magic.'”* [As-Saff: 6]. Ahmad or Muhammad is the meaning of *'Al-Munhamanna'* or *'Al-Farqalit'* (the Paraclete) mentioned in the books held by Christians, as it signifies *the one praised abundantly* (Al-Mahmud Al-Hamd Al-Kathir). The scholars of the People of the Book knew the descriptions of the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) as well as they knew their own sons, due to the prophets' prophecies. * ### The Disciples and the Table from Heaven Jesus presented his bright message, backed by miracles, to the Children of Israel. Despite the signs, he faced hardship and conspiracy from a faction of the Children of Israel who deemed him a sorcerer and colluded with the pagan Romans against him. However, a group of the Children of Israel believed in Jesus and became his Disciples (Al-Hawariyyun), who were his closest companions and supporters. The word *Hawari* originally means minister, helper, or launderer (due to their white clothes or their purifying role). Allah inspired (awha) the Disciples to believe in Jesus and support him. The Disciples, though not prophets, were not infallible, as they asked Jesus: *“O Jesus, Son of Mary, is your Lord able to send down to us a table [spread with food] from the heaven?”* [Al-Ma'idah: 112]. Jesus warned them of the grave nature of this request but they explained that they wished to eat from it, for their hearts to be assured, their faith to increase, and to be witnesses of the miracle. Jesus then supplicated to Allah: *“O Allah, our Lord, send down to us a table [spread with food] from the heaven to be for us a festival for the first of us and the last of us and a sign from You. And provide for us, and You are the best of providers.”* Allah replied: *“Indeed, I will send it down to you. But whoever disbelieves among you after that, then indeed, I will punish him with a punishment which I have not punished anyone among the worlds.”* [Al-Ma'idah: 114-115]. The whole Surah (Chapter) of the Qur'an is named after this event: Al-Ma'idah (The Table Spread with Food). The Jews and the Romans intended to kill Christ, the son of Mary, and were determined to slay him. Stories of the Prophets, The True Narrative 312. When they surrounded his dwelling and thought they had overcome him, Allah, blessed and exalted be He, saved him from their evil and their scheme. He cast his likeness upon one of his haters, whom they mistook for 'Issa (Jesus). They seized him, killed him, and crucified him. As for 'Issa, Allah raised him to Himself and foiled the plotting of the plotters, repelling the scheme of the disbelievers. Regarding this, Allah, Exalted is He, says: « And they planned, and Allah planned. And Allah is the best of planners. [Mention] when Allah said, "O Jesus, indeed I will take you and raise you to Myself and purify you from those who disbelieve and make those who follow you superior to those who disbelieve until the Day of Resurrection. Then to Me is your return, and I will judge between you in that which you used to differ. And as for those who disbelieve, I will punish them with a severe punishment in this world and the Hereafter, and they will have no helpers. But as for those who believed and did righteous deeds, He will give them in full their rewards. And Allah does not like the wrongdoers. » [Surah Al 'Imrân: 54-57]. Thus, Allah decreed to grant victory to His Messengers and the believers, and to humiliate His disbelieving enemies. Allah, Exalted is He, has affirmed that 'Issa was neither killed nor crucified, but that a likeness was made for the Jews. Regarding this, He says: « And [We cursed them] for their disbelief and their saying against Mary a great slander, and [for] their saying, "Indeed, we have killed the Messiah, Jesus, the son of Mary, the Messenger of Allah. " And they did not kill him, nor did they crucify him; but [another] was made to resemble him to them. And indeed, those who differ over it are in doubt about it. They have no knowledge of it except the following of assumption. And they did not kill him for certain. Rather, Allah raised him up to Himself. And ever is Allah Exalted in Might and Wise. » [Surah An-Nisâ’: 156-158]. And if you wonder, then it is indeed strange that the Christians should believe the Jews' claim that they killed and crucified the Christ, especially those who deviated from the truth and claimed that 'Issa is a god or the son of God. How can it cross the mind of anyone with the slightest trace of reason to believe that a god can be crucified or killed? It is mentioned in the Gospel of Matthew and the Gospel of Mark that those who intended to kill and crucify the Christ did not know him. In the twenty-sixth chapter of the Book of Matthew, in verse forty-seven of that chapter: « While he was still speaking, Judas, one of the twelve, arrived, accompanied by a large crowd with swords and clubs, who had come from the chief priests and the elders of the people. » And in verse forty-eight: « Now the betrayer had given them a sign, saying, "The one I will kiss is the man; seize him. " » And in the Gospel of Mark, in the fourteenth chapter, in verse forty-three thereof: « Immediately, while he was still speaking, Judas, one of the twelve, arrived, and with him a crowd with swords and clubs, from the chief priests and the scribes and the elders. » And in verse forty-four: « Now the betrayer had given them a sign, saying, "The one I will kiss is the man; seize him and lead him away safely. " » To be continued in the next chapter, if Allah wills, and peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you. Chapter Seventy-Sixth, Continued: Christ, Son of Mary 314 Stories of the Prophets, The True Narrative. I mentioned at the end of the previous chapter that those who intended to kill and crucify the Christ did not know him, and I cited the text from the Gospel of Matthew and the Gospel of Mark regarding this. It is also mentioned in the Gospels accepted by the Christians that Allah instilled doubt even in the hearts of 'Issa's companions regarding the identity of the Christ, so they became hesitant whether this was Jesus who was taken to be killed and crucified or someone else. There was a great resemblance between the Christ and Judas Iscariot, who entered upon the Christ to hand him over to the Jews and Romans. Thus, they did not know whether the one who was taken was the Christ or Judas Iscariot. The four Gospels report the Christ's saying to His companions on the night His enemies determined to seize Him: « You will all fall away because of me this night » as mentioned in the twenty-sixth chapter of the Gospel of Matthew, in verse thirty-one, and as mentioned in the fourteenth chapter of the Gospel of Mark, in verse twenty-seven. The Gospel of Barnabas explicitly states that the soldiers seized Judas Iscariot himself, thinking he was the Christ, because his likeness was cast upon him. George Sale, the Englishman, mentioned in his translation of the Qur'an in Surah Al 'Imrân, on page thirty-eight, that Judas Iscariot resembled the Christ in his features. He also mentioned that a sect from the oldest Christian sects, the Cerinthians and the Carpocratians, denied the crucifixion of the Christ and stated that the one crucified was Judas Iscariot, who resembled him perfectly. End of quote. And the Christians are in consensus that Judas Iscariot disappeared after the crucifixion incident and did not reappear, although Christians differed on the story of his end. In the Gospel of Matthew, in the twenty-seventh chapter, in verse four, it is mentioned about Judas Iscariot that he « went and hanged himself. » The Epistle of Acts of the Apostles contradicted the Gospel of Matthew regarding the end of Judas Iscariot. Chapter Seventy-Sixth, Continued: Christ, Son of Mary 315 In the first chapter, in verse eighteen of the Epistle of Acts of the Apostles, authored by Luke, the owner of the Gospel, it is mentioned about Judas: « Now this man acquired a field with the reward of his wickedness, and falling headlong, he burst open in the middle and all his bowels gushed out. » This contradiction between the Gospel of Matthew and the Epistle of Acts of the Apostles—and the Christians sanctify these two books—I say: This contradiction is evidence of their ignorance of the fate of Judas Iscariot, a clear and irrefutable proof that the person crucified by the Jews and Romans was not the certain identity [of Jesus] according to them. Allah, blessed and exalted be He, confirmed this meaning with His saying: « And they did not kill him, nor did they crucify him; but [another] was made to resemble him to them. And indeed, those who differ over it are in doubt about it. They have no knowledge of it except the following of assumption. And they did not kill him for certain. Rather, Allah raised him up to Himself. And ever is Allah Exalted in Might and Wise. » [Surah An-Nisâ’: 157-158]. And they fell into doubt and confusion. The matter was ambiguous for the Jews, Christians, and Romans, and the hesitation: was the crucified one 'Issa or someone else? Some of them would say: it was indeed Jesus, and some would say: it was someone else. This was due to the resemblance of Judas Iscariot to 'Issa. Added to this, there was another person with him, Barabbas, as mentioned in the Gospel of Matthew, in verse seventeen of the twenty-seventh chapter, where Pilate, as they were gathered, said to them: « Whom do you want me to release for you: Barabbas, or Jesus who is called Christ? » And Allah, blessed and exalted be He, raised Christ, the son of Mary, to Himself and rescued him from the hateful and envious disbelievers. Regarding this, He says in Surah Al 'Imrân: « O Jesus, indeed I will take you and raise you to Myself... » [Surah Al 'Imrân: 55]. And He says in Surah An-Nisâ’: « Rather, Allah raised him up to Himself. And ever is Allah Exalted in Might and Wise. » [Surah An-Nisâ’: 158]. The majority of the people of the Sunnah and the Community hold that Allah, Exalted is He, raised Christ to Himself with his body and soul. They interpret the term 'Tawaffi' (taking a life) in His saying: « O Jesus, indeed I will take you and raise you to Myself... » as casting sleep upon him until Allah raised him to the sky, similar to His saying: « Allah takes the souls at the time of their death, and those that do not die [He takes] during their sleep. » [Surah Az-Zumar: 42], and His saying: « And it is He who takes your souls by night and knows what you have committed by day. » [Surah Al-An'âm: 60], meaning, He puts you to sleep at night and knows what you have earned of deeds during the day. 316 Stories of the Prophets, The True Narrative. And He specified sleep for the night and earning for the day, because that is the original pattern suitable for human nature. Although a person might not sleep at night or earn during the day, this harms his nature and the stability of his soul. The general consensus of the people of the Sunnah and the Community is that 'Issa is alive in the sky and that he will descend at the end of time upon the appearance of the False Messiah (Al-Dajjâl), whom he will kill at Ludd in the land of Palestine. He will also kill the Jews who are with him, pour out the wine, break the cross, abolish the Jizya (poll tax), kill the swine, and accept nothing but Islam. During the time of his descent, Gog and Magog will emerge, and they will swarm down from every hill. 'Issa will supplicate to Allah and call upon Him to destroy Gog and Magog, and Allah will answer his prayer. Allah, blessed and exalted be He, alluded to the descent of 'Issa at the end of time as one of the signs of the Hour, where He says: « And indeed, he is [a sign for] knowledge of the Hour. So have no doubt about it. » [Surah Az-Zukhruf: 61], according to the interpretation of some scholars of exegesis and commentary. That is, the descent of the Christ is a sign of the Hour's nearness, or that the creation of 'Issa without a father is proof that Allah is capable of all things, and that it is evidence of Allah's power to resurrect the dead and to raise people on the Day of Resurrection. Also, some scholars held that the meaning of His saying: « And there is none of the People of the Scripture but that he will surely believe in him before his death. » [Surah An-Nisâ’: 159] is that all disbelievers among the Jews and Christians, when death comes to them and they are cut off from the world, will know that 'Issa is the servant of Allah, His Messenger, His Word which He cast upon Mary, and a Spirit from Him. They will believe that he was neither killed nor crucified, and they will affirm that Allah raised him to Himself and protected him from the plot and scheme of the Jews, and that he is neither a god nor the son of God, as the Christians claim—may the curses of Allah, the Angels, and all mankind be upon them and the Jews. This faith at the sight of death will not benefit them. The majority of exegetes refer the pronoun in « his death » to 'Issa, and that upon his descent, the righteous and the wicked will believe in him and hasten to affirm his truth. This is the apparent meaning, because His saying: « And there is none of the People of the Scripture but that he will surely believe in him before his death. » [Surah An-Nisâ’: 159] was revealed to assert the falsehood of the Jews' claim of killing and crucifying 'Issa, and the acceptance of this claim by the ignorant Christians who submitted to them. Thus, Allah, Exalted is He, informed that the matter was not so, but a likeness was cast upon another person for them, and they killed the likeness while they did not realize it, but rather Allah raised him up to Himself, and he is alive, and he will descend before the Day of Resurrection. Chapter Seventy-Sixth, Continued: Christ, Son of Mary. The descent of the Christ at the end of time is one of the beliefs of the people of the Sunnah and the Community, from which only a misguided and doomed person would deviate. Al-Bukhârî and Muslim narrated through several chains from Abû Hurayrah that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: « By Him in Whose Hand is my soul, the son of Mary will surely descend among you as a just judge, he will break the cross, kill the swine, abolish the Jizya, and wealth will flow so abundantly that no one will accept it, and a single prostration will be better for him than the whole world and what is in it. » Then Abû Hurayrah would say: « Read if you wish: « And there is none of the People of the Scripture but that he will surely believe in him before his death; and on the Day of Resurrection he will be a witness against them. » [Surah An-Nisâ’: 159]. Similarly, Muslim narrated from the hadith of Abû Hurayrah that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: « By Him in Whose Hand is my soul, the son of Mary will surely utter the Talbiyah (invocation) at the valley of Ar-Rawhâ’, performing Hajj or 'Umrah, or combining them. » That is, he will combine the two. Likewise, Al-Bukhârî and Muslim narrated from the hadith of Abû Hurayrah that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: « How will you be when the Christ, son of Mary, descends among you, and your Imam is from among you? » Muslim also narrated in his Sahih from the hadith of Abû Hurayrah that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: « The Hour will not be established until the Romans descend at Al-A'mâq or Dâbiq. An army from Medina will go forth against them, consisting of the best people on earth at that time. When they line up for battle, the Romans will say: "Do not stand between us and those who took captives from us; we will fight them. " The Muslims will say: "No, by Allah, never will we leave our brothers to you. " They will fight them, and one third will flee, whom Allah will never forgive; one third will be killed, and they are the best martyrs with Allah; and one third will conquer, and they will never be afflicted by temptation. And his saying: « he will lead them in prayer » means the intention of the Muslims to follow their Imam in prayer, or the aforementioned Imam: « and your Imam is from among you. » The first interpretation is clearer due to the narration in Al-Bukhârî and Muslim: « he will be from among you. » Muslim also narrated from the hadith of Jâbir that the Messenger of Allah said: « A group from my Ummah will continue to fight for the truth, triumphant, until the Day of Resurrection. » He said: « Then 'Issa, son of Mary, will descend, and their Amir (leader) will say: "Come, lead us in prayer. This is evidence that Allah will preserve this Ummah's religion from alteration and change until the end of time, until the Christ, son of Mary, descends and rules by the Law of Muhammad. To be continued in the next chapter, if Allah wills, and peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you. Chapter Seventy-Seventh, Continued: Christ, Son of Mary 319 Here is another set of authentic hadiths, established from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding the descent of Christ, the son of Mary, upon the appearance of the False Messiah (Al-Dajjâl). Muslim narrated in his Sahih from the hadith of An-Nawwâs ibn Sam'ân Al-Kilâbî that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, mentioned the Dajjâl to us one morning and belittled him and then magnified him, until we thought he was in the palm grove. When we returned to him in the afternoon, he recognized this. He said: « What preoccupied you and what did you magnify? » We said: « O Messenger of Allah, you mentioned the Dajjâl this morning, and you belittled him and then magnified him, until we thought he was in the palm grove. » He said: « It is not the Dajjâl that I fear most for you. If he appears while I am among you, I will be his contender on your behalf. But if he appears after me, then every man must be his own contender, and Allah is my Vicegerent over every Muslim. He is a young man with very curly hair, his eye is floating, I liken him to 'Abd Al-'Uzzâ ibn Qatan. He will appear on a path between Ash-Shâm (Greater Syria) and Iraq, and he will cause corruption to the right and to the left. O servants of Allah, be firm. » We said: « O Messenger of Allah, how long will he stay on Earth? » He said: « Forty days: one day like a year, one day like a month, one day like a week, and the rest of his days like your days. » We said: « O Messenger of Allah, on that day that is like a year, will the prayers of one day suffice us? » He said: « No. Estimate its measure for it. » We said: « O Messenger of Allah, what is his speed on Earth? » He said: « Like rain driven by the wind. He will come to a people and call them, and they will believe in him and respond to him. He will then command the sky to rain, and the earth to bring forth, and their livestock will return to them in the evening with the highest humps, the fullest udders, and the widest flanks. Then he will come to a people and call them, and they will reject his word. He will turn away from them, and they will awaken in the morning with nothing left of their wealth, in famine. Then he will pass by a ruin and say to it: "Bring forth your treasures, " and its treasures will follow him like the swarms of bees. Then he will call a man in the prime of his youth, strike him with a sword, and cut him into two pieces, the distance of a target's throw. Then he will call him, and he will come forward with a radiant, laughing face. And while he is thus, Allah will send the Christ, the son of Mary. 320 Stories of the Prophets, The True Narrative. He will descend at the white minaret, east of Damascus, between two garments dyed with saffron (or *hird*), placing his palms on the wings of two Angels. When he lowers his head, drops will fall from it, and when he raises it, beads like pearls will roll down from it. It will not be lawful for any disbeliever who senses the scent of his breath to remain alive, and his breath will extend as far as his gaze reaches. He will pursue him until he overtakes him at the gate of Ludd and kills him. Then 'Issa, the son of Mary, will come to a people whom Allah has protected from him. He will wipe their faces and inform them of their ranks in Paradise. While he is thus, Allah will reveal to 'Issa: "I have brought forth servants of Mine whom no one will be able to fight. So gather My servants to Mount Tur. " And Allah will send Gog and Magog, and they will swarm down from every hill. The first of them will pass by Lake Tiberias and drink all its water. The last of them will pass by and say: "There was once water here. " Then they will walk until they reach the Mountain of Al-Khamr (the Mountain of the Temple in Jerusalem), and they will say: "We have killed those on Earth; let us kill those in the Sky. " They will shoot their arrows toward the sky, and Allah will return their arrows stained with blood. The Prophet of Allah, 'Issa, and his companions will be besieged to the extent that the head of an ox will be better for one of them than a hundred dinars are for one of you today. The Prophet of Allah, 'Issa, and his companions will supplicate to Allah. Allah will then send the *Naghf* (worms) upon their necks, and they will die, all of them, as a single soul dies. Then the Prophet of Allah, 'Issa, and his companions will descend to the Earth, and they will not find a space of a hand span on the Earth that is not filled with their stench and putrefaction. The Prophet of Allah, 'Issa, and his companions will supplicate to Allah. Allah will then send birds with necks like those of Bactrian camels, which will carry them and throw them where Allah wills. Then Allah will send rain that no house of clay or hair (tent) can keep out, and it will wash the Earth until it leaves it like a mirror. Then it will be said to the Earth: "Bring forth your fruits and restore your blessings. " On that day, a group of people will eat from a single pomegranate and seek shade under its peel. And blessings will be put into the milk, to the extent that the milk of a she-camel will suffice a large group of people, the milk of a cow will suffice an entire tribe, and the milk of a sheep will suffice a small clan. While they are thus, Allah will send a pleasant wind that will take them under their armpits and take the soul of every believer and every Muslim. Only the wickedest people will remain, who will publicly copulate like donkeys, and it is upon them that the Hour will be established. » And his saying in the Hadith: « belittled him and then magnified him » means he humbled him and magnified him, or he lowered his voice after speaking at length to rest, then returned and raised his voice to reach all the listeners. And his saying: « until we thought he was in the palm grove » means in extreme proximity to us, and that he was near to appearing. Chapter Seventy-Seventh, Continued: Christ, Son of Mary. And his saying: « When we returned to him in the afternoon » means when we returned to our gathering, as the Messenger of Allah's discussion of the Dajjâl was in the morning. And his saying: « He is a young man with very curly hair » (*Shaabun Qaṭaṭ*) means very kinky hair. And his saying: « He will appear on a path between Ash-Shâm and Iraq » (*Khallatun*) means on a path between them. And his saying: « and their livestock will return to them in the evening with the highest humps »: *Sâriḥatuhum* are their grazing animals that go out at the beginning of the day to the pasture and return in the evening; *Adh-Dhurâ* is the plural of *Dharwah*, which is the top and the hump; and the meaning is that they increase in height due to the speed of their growth. And his saying: « the fullest udders » (*Asbaġhu Ḍurū'an*) means the longest udders due to the abundance of milk. And his saying: « and the widest flanks » (*Amadduhu Khawâṣir*) means due to their fullness from satiety. And his saying: « like the swarms of bees » (*Ka-Ya'âsîb An-Naḥl*): *Al-Ya'âsîb* is the plural of *Ya'sûb*, which is the male bee and their prince. The meaning here is the group of bees in their following of their *Ya'sûb*. The intent is that the treasures of the Earth will follow him just as the group of bees follows their *Ya'sûb* without ever lagging behind. And his saying: « and cut him into two pieces, the distance of a target's throw » (*Jazlatayn Ramiyata Al-Gharad*) means two pieces, and he will make the distance between the two pieces the extent of an arrow's throw toward the target. And his saying: « between two garments dyed with saffron (or *hird*) » (*Mahrūdatayn*): *Al-Mahrûd* garment is one dyed with *Waras* (a saffron-like dye) and then with saffron. And his saying: « whom no one will be able to fight » (*Lâ Yadâni Li'aḥadin Biqitâlihim*) means no one has the power to fight them. And his saying: « Allah will then send the *Naghf* upon their necks » (*Al-Naghf Fī Riqâbihim*) means Allah will inflict upon them the *Naghf*, which is a worm that affects the noses of camels and sheep. And his saying: « and they will die » (*Farsâ*) means dead. And his saying: « until it leaves it like a mirror » (*Kâz-Zulfa*) means like a mirror. And his saying: « and seek shade under its peel » (*Qahfihâ*): *Al-Qahf* is the peel. And *Al-Fi'âm* is a large group of people. And his saying: « who will publicly copulate like donkeys » (*Yatahârajûna Fīhâ Tahâruj Al-Ḥumur*) means they will lose all shame, and men will consort with women, and they will copulate in the streets without shyness or concern. The hadiths describing the descent of 'Issa upon the appearance of the False Messiah are mutawâtir (mass-transmitted). Ibn Kathîr said regarding the hadiths concerning the interpretation of the saying of Allah: « And there is none of the People of the Scripture but that he will surely believe in him before his death; and on the Day of Resurrection he will be a witness against them. » [Surah An-Nisâ’: 159], that they mention the descent of 'Issa, the son of Mary, from the sky at the end of time, before the Day of Resurrection, and that he will call to the worship of Allah alone, without any partner. After citing a large number of these hadiths reported in Al-Bukhârî, Muslim, Musnad Al-Imâm Ahmad, Sunan At-Tirmidhî, Abû Dâwûd, and the rest of the authors of the Sunan, he said: « These hadiths are mutawâtir from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, narrated by Abû Hurayrah, Ibn Mas'ûd, 'Uthmân ibn Abî Al-'Âs, Abû Umâmah, An-Nawwâs ibn Sam'ân, 'Abd Allah ibn 'Amr ibn Al-'Âs, Mujamma' ibn Jâriyah, and Abû Surayhah Hudhayfah ibn Usayd. They indicate the description of his descent and his location, that it will be in Ash-Shâm, specifically in Damascus, at the Eastern Minaret, and that this will be at the time of the *Fajr* (Dawn) prayer. » End of quote. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, described 'Issa, the son of Mary, as being of medium height, reddish, and whoever saw him would think he had just emerged from a *dīmās* (bathhouse) after bathing. Al-Bukhârî and Muslim narrated from the hadith of Abû Hurayrah that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, described 'Issa after seeing him on the night of the *Isrâ’* and *Mi'râj* (Night Journey and Ascension), saying: « Of medium height, reddish, as if he had just emerged from a *dīmās* (meaning the bathhouse). » In a narration by Al-Bukhârî from the hadith of Ibn 'Umar describing 'Issa, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: « As for 'Issa, he is reddish, curly-haired, with a broad chest. » And in a narration by Muslim from the hadith of Ibn 'Umar from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, he said: « And Allah showed me, in a dream, at the Ka'bah, a man who was brown, the best brown man you could see, his hair reaching between his shoulders, his hair neither straight nor curly, water dripping from his head, placing his hands on the shoulders of two men, and he was circumambulating the House. I asked: "Who is this? " They said: "He is the Christ, the son of Mary. " » And in a wording by Al-Bukhârî from the hadith of Ibn 'Umar from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, he said: « While I was sleeping, I saw myself circumambulating the Ka'bah, and behold, a man, brown, with straight hair, swaying between two men, water dripping from his head - or being poured over his head. I asked: "Who is this? " They said: "The son of Mary. " » The meaning of his saying: « of medium height » (*Rab'ah*) is average height, between tall and short. And the meaning of his saying: « curly-haired » (*Ja'd*) is that his hair is not straight (*Sabt*). And it is said: *Rajul Ja'd* (a curly-haired man) meaning a generous man. And the meaning of his saying: « brown » (*Âdam*) is a light brown color, and the reddish color can also be used to describe it if it is not excessively white. And his saying: « his hair reaching between his shoulders » (*Li-mmatuhu Bayna Mankibayhi*): The *Lammah* is the hair that goes past the earlobe. And the meaning of his saying: « his hair neither straight nor curly » (*Rajil Ash-Sha'r*) is used when his hair is between straightness and curliness. This qualifies the absolute description of 'Issa's hair as either 'straight' or 'curly'. And the meaning of his saying: « water dripping from his head » (*Yanṭif Ra'suhu Mâ'an*) means it is dripping and flowing. To be continued in the next chapter, if Allah wills, and peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you. Chapter Seventy-Eighth, Continued: Christ, Son of Mary. 323 Allah, blessed and exalted be He, mentioned in the enumeration of the Jews' crimes that they said to Moses: « Show us Allah outright », that they took the Calf after the clear proofs had come to them, that they killed the Prophets without right, that they broke the covenant, that they disbelieved in the verses of Allah, and that they transgressed the Sabbath. And that they said: « Our hearts are uncircumcised. » Then Allah, Exalted is He, said: « And [We cursed them] for their disbelief and their saying against Mary a great slander, and [for] their saying, "Indeed, we have killed the Messiah, Jesus, the son of Mary, the Messenger of Allah. " » [Surah An-Nisâ’: 156-157]. And His saying, Exalted is He, here: « the Messenger of Allah » (*Rasûla Allâh*) with the accusative (nasb) on *Rasûl* (Messenger), it is possible that it is a continuation of the Jews' statement, and they said it mockingly, similar to the saying of the polytheists of Mecca about Muhammad: « O you upon whom the message has been sent down, indeed you are mad. » [Surah Al-Ḥijr: 6], and the saying of Pharaoh about Moses: « Indeed, your messenger who was sent to you is mad. » [Surah Ash-Shu'arâ’: 27]. It is also possible that His saying: « the Messenger of Allah » is not part of the Jews' statement, but Allah mentioned it with the accusative for exclusivity and praise, to point to the atrocity of their deed, the degree of their ignorance, and the wickedness of their claim, their malice, and their hatred for the Prophets and Messengers. There is no doubt that the Apostles stood up after the raising of the Christ to spread the call to the Oneness of Allah, that there is no god but Allah, and that 'Issa is the servant of Allah, His Messenger, His Word which He cast upon Mary, and a Spirit from Him. They were subjected to all kinds of torture at the hands of the Jews and Romans, and not a single one of them claimed that 'Issa was a god or the son of God, or that Allah was the third of three. The call to Monotheism that 'Issa brought continued in its purity for a time, not too long. Then, a great persecution fell upon his followers. They were scattered, tortured, killed, and crucified until the hallmarks of Christianity almost disappeared from the Earth due to those persecutions carried out by the Roman Emperors and their governors, as well as the Jews. The most severe suffering they endured was during the reign of the Emperor Nero (46 CE), then the Emperor Trajan (106 CE), then the Emperor Decius (251 CE), then the Emperor Diocletian (284 CE). As for Nero, he accused them of burning the city of Rome and devised various tortures for them. He would order his followers to clothe the followers of 'Issa in animal hides and then throw them to the dogs to tear them apart. Some of these Christians were also dressed in clothes smeared with tar, and then used as torches to light the way. The Patriarch of Alexandria described some of what he witnessed under Decius, saying: « Fear seized everyone. Some fled with their religion, and every Christian was removed from state service, no matter how intelligent he was. Every Christian who was reported was quickly brought and presented to the idol temple, and he was required to offer a sacrifice to the idol. The punishment for whoever refused to offer the sacrifice was to become the sacrifice himself, after they had tried hard to force him by intimidation. » Then the Patriarch said: « And among the weak in faith were those who denied their Christianity, and some followed suit, while others clung to escape or were thrown into the depths of prisons. » End of quote. As for Diocletian, he came to Egypt and brought calamity upon it, ordering the demolition of churches, the burning of books, issuing an order to arrest bishops and throw them into the depths of prisons, and compelling Christians to deny their religion, killing about three hundred thousand of them. The followers of the Christ were called "Naṣârâ " (Nazarenes), in relation to Naṣrânah, the village of the Christ in the land of Galilee in Palestine. This village is also called Nazareth (An-Nâṣirah) or An-Naṣûriyyah. I do not know exactly when *An-Naṣrâniyyah* became the proper noun for the religion of the People of the Gospel. This word, with this meaning, was found in the early second century CE, when Pliny (Pliny the Younger), who was a governor in Asia, wrote a letter to the Emperor Trajan (in 106 CE) explaining his method of torturing Christians. He said: « I dealt with those accused of being Nazarenes in the following way: I asked them if they were Christians, and if they admitted it, I asked them again a second and a third time, threatening them with death. If they persisted, I carried out the death sentence on them. » Pliny then added: « The accusation was directed at many in unsigned documents, and they denied that they were Nazarenes. » End of quote. Chapter Seventy-Eighth, Continued: Christ, Son of Mary 325 It can be understood from the Holy Qur'an that they themselves coined this name, as Allah, blessed and exalted be He, says: « Those who said, "We are Christians. " » [Surah Al-Mâ’idah: 82]. The term *An-Naṣrâniyyah* (Christianity/Nazarene-ism) does not inherently imply praise or blame, as it is a reference to a homeland, and association with a homeland implies neither praise nor blame, for a single homeland includes both righteous and wicked people. As for Christianity (*Al-Masīḥiyyah*), it is only proper to apply it to those who truly follow the Law of the Christ. After the mission of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, by which Allah abrogated every law, it is not appropriate to apply the name Christianity to the Nazarenes, because in reality, they do not follow the Christ. If they had followed him, they would have hastened to believe in Muhammad. That is why the Qur'an and the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, did not name them Christians, but rather called them the People of the Gospel (*Ahl Al-Injīl*). The Jews were the most hostile of people to the religion of Christ, the son of Mary, and they exerted every effort to destroy it. With their satanic thinking, they decided that some of them should pretend to embrace it and its followers in order to distort this religion and distance people from it. Saul the Jew, who was one of those keen on torturing and afflicting the Christians, stood up to carry out this deception. Christian scholars agree that he approved of the killing of Christians, and he would raid the churches, enter the houses, and drag away men and women to deliver them to prison. He was described in the Epistle of Acts of the Apostles as being « full of all deceit and all malice, son of the devil, enemy of all righteousness, who does not cease to pervert the straight ways of the Lord », as stated in the thirteenth chapter of this epistle, in verse ten. Saul claimed that he went to the Jewish chief priest and requested letters from him to the congregations in Damascus, so that if he found any persons of « the Way » (*Min Aṭ-Ṭarīq*), whether men or women, he might bring them bound to Jerusalem. This was in the thirty-eighth year of the Common Era, a short time after the Christ was raised. Saul said of himself: « You have heard of my former life in Judaism, how I persecuted the church of God violently and tried to destroy it. And I was advancing in Judaism beyond many of my own age among my people, so extremely zealous was I for the traditions of my fathers. » Then Saul claimed that while he was on his way to Damascus, he saw Jesus, believed in him, and was named Paul. Luke, the author of the Gospel named after him, recounts this story of Saul as Saul claimed it, in his epistle called Acts of the Apostles. In the ninth chapter of this epistle concerning Saul, he says: « He went to the high priest and asked him for letters to the synagogues at Damascus, so that if he found any belonging to the Way, men or women, he might bring them bound to Jerusalem. » And while he was traveling, « it happened that as he was approaching Damascus, suddenly a light from heaven flashed around him. And falling to the ground, he heard a voice saying to him, "Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me? " And he said, "Who are you, Lord? " And he said, "I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting. " » Then he says: « And he, trembling and astonished, said, "Lord, what do you want me to do? " » Then he says: « And immediately he proclaimed Jesus in the synagogues, saying, "He is the Son of God. " » The idea of 'Issa's divinity or his sonship to God was not previously known to the Christians; they knew him only as the servant of Allah, His Messenger, His Word cast upon Mary, and a Spirit from Him. When Saul, who called himself Paul, came with this claim, the Apostles denied it and doubted this story that Saul had fabricated. They did not forget that he was their greatest enemy among the Jews. However, Barnabas advised the Apostles not to be hasty with Saul and presented him favorably to them. Yet, Barnabas himself did not remain loyal to Saul. Not long after, the bonds of affection between them were severed. Moreover, the general body of disciples became alienated from Saul, and only Luke remained his companion, considering himself the closest disciple of Paul. Luke was a physician and was not one of the Apostles. Saul (Paul) later called him « the beloved physician. » Paul began to preach a Christianity that the Apostles did not know. He had received no teaching of any kind from 'Issa or the Apostles. He then began to claim that Jesus was teaching him directly from Heaven without any intermediary. He said: « No one is allowed to accept any other teaching than mine, » and forbade his disciples from listening to or taking anything from the Apostles. To be continued in the next chapter, if Allah wills, and peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you. Chapter Seventy-Ninth, Continued: Christ, Son of Mary 327 I mentioned at the end of the previous chapter that Saul, who called himself Paul, intended to abolish all the teachings the Apostles had received from the Christ. He would say: « No one is allowed to accept any other teaching than mine, » and forbade his disciples from listening to or taking anything from the Apostles. Regarding this, he says in a book he sent to his disciple Timothy: « As I urged you when I was going to Macedonia, remain at Ephesus so that you may charge certain persons not to teach any different doctrine, nor to devote themselves to myths and endless genealogies, which promote speculations rather than the stewardship from God that is by faith. The aim of our charge is love that issues from a pure heart and a good conscience and a sincere faith. Certain persons, by swerving from these, have wandered into vain discussion, desiring to be teachers of the law, although they do not understand either what they are saying or the things about which they make confident assertions. » He also says: « If anyone teaches a different doctrine, he is puffed up with conceit and understands nothing. » Thus, this Jew, Saul, who claimed to have converted and named himself Paul, began to assert that he was the teacher of Christianity, disparaging all the Apostles and describing them as lacking understanding. He began to spread doctrines derived from the beliefs of Hindus, Buddhists, Greek philosophers, and some Jewish teachings. He introduced for the first time the idea of the Trinity and the concept that the Christ is the Son of God, and that He descended to sacrifice Himself as an expiation for the sin of mankind, and that He ascended to sit at the right hand of His Father to judge and condemn mankind. Exalted is Allah far above what they say! He did not stray far in his call from the saying of his forefathers, the Jews, who said: « Uzair is the son of Allah. » He took the claim that 'Issa is the Son of God from the corrupt and misguided claims of his forefathers. He added to it what he took from the Buddhists concerning Buddha, and what he took from the Hindus concerning Krishna, and what he took from others. 328 Stories of the Prophets, The True Narrative. Krishna is called by his Hindu followers the Savior, the Redeemer, the Comforter, the Good Shepherd, the Mediator, the Son of God, and the Second Person of the Holy Trinity: the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit. Buddha was also called by some of his followers by these same titles, which are exactly those Paul applied to the Christ. The followers of Krishna said that he was born of the Virgin Devaki, whom God chose as the mother of His son because of her purity and chastity. Some followers of Buddha said that he was born of the Virgin Mâyâ, whom God chose as the mother of His son because of her purity and chastity. This is the very phrase Saul (Paul) applied to the Christ's mother and her child. The followers of Krishna said that people learned of his birth from his star that appeared in the sky. Some followers of Buddha said the same about Buddha. And the teachings of Saul (Paul) said: « When the Christ was born, his star appeared in the East, and by the appearance of his star, people knew the place of his birth. » The followers of Krishna also claimed that his mother Devaki was betrothed to Nanda, and when she gave birth to Krishna, Nanda heard a call from the sky telling him: « Arise, take the child and his mother, and flee with them to Kakul, and cross the Yamunâ River, for the king seeks to destroy him. » In the teachings that Saul spread: « When Jesus was born, Joseph the carpenter, the betrothed of His mother, was absent. Joseph the carpenter, the betrothed of Mary, the mother of Jesus, was warned in a dream to take the child and his mother and flee with them to Egypt, for the king sought to destroy him. » Likewise, the name of the city where Krishna was born and performed miraculous signs was Matr. And Saul spread that the name of the city to which Jesus the Christ, his mother, and her betrothed Joseph the carpenter migrated was Al-Maṭariyyah in Egypt, and that he performed miraculous signs there after leaving the land of Judea. Note that Krishna existed around 950 BCE, and Buddha existed around the middle of the sixth century BCE. Paul's teachings and ideas spread in the West among the pagans and Greeks at the same time they were resisted in the East. Paul says about this in a letter to his disciple Timothy: « You know that all who are in Asia have turned away from me. » Nevertheless, Paul continued to travel in the provinces, establish churches, deliver speeches, and send letters that became the pillar of the distorted Christianity, until he was killed during the persecutions of Nero in 66 or 76 CE. However, some of the Apostles, including Barnabas, who initially thought well of Paul, resisted these teachings that Paul brought. Barnabas authored a Gospel, the introduction of which mentions the reason for its composition: he wrote it to refute those who claimed the divinity of the Christ or that he was the son of God. Barnabas says at the beginning of his Gospel: « O dear ones, the marvelous and great God has visited us in these days with His Prophet Jesus Christ with great mercy for teaching, and with signs that Satan has taken as a pretext to mislead many under the guise of piety, preaching a doctrine of severe disbelief, calling the Christ the Son of God, rejecting the circumcision that God has always commanded, permitting all unclean flesh. Paul (Saul the Jew), whom I speak of only with sorrow, is among those who have strayed. This is the reason for which I write this truth that I have seen. » End of quote. Christian historians agree that in past ages there were various Gospels adopted by ancient Christian sects, and that each sect adhered only to its own Gospel. The Church decided in the early third century CE to keep only four Gospels: Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John, and forbade all others. Some historians have mentioned that these four Gospels were not mentioned until the end of the second century CE. The first to mention all four Gospels was Irenaeus of Alexandria in 209 CE, and he was followed by Clement of Alexandria in 216 CE, who showed that these four Gospels were obligatory to accept. "en": "## Chapter Eighty-Fourth: Continued Jesus, Son of Mary (p. 349) Despite these many clear and decisive (muhkamat) proofs in the Book of Allah the Almighty, revealed in Mecca and Medina, and in the sound, established reports of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) that Allah the Almighty is far removed from having a son or a partner, the Christians of Najran, when they came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) in the ninth year of the Hijra, tried to argue that Jesus is the Son of God based on certain words in the Book of Allah. They interpreted these words in a way not intended, due to deviation in their hearts, seeking discord and turning people away from the path of Allah. They claimed that the Quran contained a proof that Jesus is the Son of God in the verse about His saying: "...and a Spirit from Him. " \[Surah An-Nisa (The Women): 171]. They interpreted the word "from " here as indicating a part, thus making Jesus a part and portion of God. They ignored the fact that the word "from " in this context is not intended to mean a part, but rather to indicate the beginning of the origin (the source), meaning that Jesus is one of the souls whose creation God began. They turned a blind eye to the many explicit verses stating that Jesus is a servant of Allah and a creature from His creation, and a servant cannot be a son, and that Allah: "He neither begot nor was begotten. Nor is there to Him any equivalent. " \[Surah Al-Ikhlas (The Sincerity): 3-4]. The word "from " has many meanings, including the beginning of the origin, as in this case. Undoubtedly, the Arabs use the word "from " for many meanings, such as indicating the genus, as in His saying: "So shun the abomination of idols... " \[Surah Al-Hajj (The Pilgrimage): 30], meaning: shun the abomination that is the idols. One of its meanings is "part, " as in your saying: "I ate from this loaf, " meaning: I ate a part of it. The Christians of Najran abandoned the manifest, decisive meaning and resorted to the unintended interpretation, exploiting the apparent similarity of the term, because of the deviation in their hearts. Allah the Blessed and Most High revealed concerning them, from the beginning of Surah Aal 'Imran up to the eighty-fourth verse, refuting their falsehood and dispelling their ambiguity, and explaining that because of the deviation in their hearts, they follow the ambiguous parts of the Quran and ignore the explicit, decisive ones, which prove that Allah has not taken a son. Indeed, Allah the Blessed and Most High made a part of the Quran decisive (muhkam), which is clear and manifest, and whose intended meaning is not hidden from the general and specific populace, and another part ambiguous (mutashabih), as a trial and test. The ambiguous word is that which can bear more than one meaning, such as the word "from " in His saying: "...and a Spirit from Him. " As for the people of faith, they refer the ambiguous to the decisive and interpret the word "from " here according to its intended meaning, which is the beginning of the origin. But those in whose hearts is deviation interpret it according to the unintended meaning. "...but no one knows its interpretation except Allah. And those firmly grounded in knowledge say: 'We believe in it; all of it is from our Lord.' " \[Surah Aal 'Imran: 7]. His speech neither contradicts nor clashes; exalted is Allah far above that. Allah the Blessed mentioned in this context of Surah Aal 'Imran clear proofs that "There is no god but He, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer of existence. " \[Surah Aal 'Imran: 2], and that He revealed the Quran to Muhammad in truth, just as He revealed the Torah to Moses and the Gospel to Jesus as a guidance for mankind before this. And He sent down the Criterion (the Quran). Indeed, those who disbelieve in the verses of Allah will have a severe punishment, and Allah is Exalted in Might, the Possessor of retribution. " \[Surah Aal 'Imran: 4-6]. To be continued in the next chapter, if Allah wills. This serves to refute the ambiguity of the Christians of Najran and those like them who neglect the decisive (muhkam) verses that are manifest, clear, and absolute in their indication, which bear only one meaning, and instead cling to and argue with the ambiguous (mutashabih) terms, which, in principle, can have many meanings. Even if these meanings are not distinguishable from one another when the words are isolated, the context of the speech determines the intended meaning. " \[Surah Aal 'Imran: 55], and I cited similar verses in the Book of Allah the Almighty. " \[Surah Aal 'Imran: 141]. The believer is honored by Allah in both victory and defeat. That is why the Companions of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) did not rejoice when they gained an advantage over their enemy, nor did they despair when their enemy gained an advantage over them. In this regard, Ka'b ibn Zuhayr said in his poem *Bânat Su'âd*, describing the Companions of the Messenger of Allah: * "They are not overly joyful when their spears reach a people, nor are they despairing when they are reached. "* And Hassân (may Allah be pleased with him) said: * "We are elevated when war reaches us with its claws. They do not boast when they gain an advantage over their enemy, and if they are afflicted, there is no weakness or panic. They are like lions in the battle and death is visible, when the frivolous people are humbled by its claws. "* His saying: "and death is visible " means it is near and witnessed. They do not fear the causes of death. It is not known that any of the Companions of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) was killed while turning his back in retreat. That is why Ka'b ibn Zuhayr said: * "The thrusting does not occur except in their chests, and they have no hesitation concerning the watering-places of death. "* His saying: "and they have no hesitation concerning the watering-places of death " means they do not flee from the sources of destruction and the battlefields, nor do they hold back from them. The support of Allah for His believing servants and their honor is achieved in every situation. Let us give an example from the story of the Companions of Ar-Rajî'. Al-Bukhari reported in his Sahih, from the Hadith of Abu Hurayrah (may Allah be pleased with him), who said: "The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) sent out a reconnaissance party and appointed 'Asim ibn Thâbit as their leader. They set out until they were between 'Ushfân and Mecca. They were mentioned to a tribe of Hudhayl called Banu Lihyan. They pursued them with nearly a hundred archers. They tracked their footprints until they came to a place where they had camped and found date-stones they had brought from Medina. They said: 'These are the dates of Yathrib.' They followed their tracks until they overtook them. When 'Asim and his companions were overtaken, they sought refuge on a fadfad (an elevated mound). The people came and surrounded them and said: 'We give you a covenant and a promise that if you descend to us, we will not kill any man among you.' 'Asim said: 'As for me, I will not descend under the protection of a disbeliever. O Allah, inform Your Prophet about us.' They shot them with arrows until they killed 'Asim and seven men. Khubayb, Zayd, and another man remained. They gave them the covenant and the promise. When they gave them the covenant and the promise, they descended to them. But when they gained control over them, they loosened the strings of their bows and tied them with them. The third man who was with them said: 'This is the first treachery.' He refused to accompany them. They dragged him and insisted that he accompany them, but he refused, so they killed him. They went with Khubayb and Zayd until they sold them in Mecca. Banu Al-Hârith ibn 'Amir ibn Nawfal bought Khubayb. Khubayb was the one who had killed Al-Hârith on the Day of Badr. He remained a captive with them. When they decided to kill him, he borrowed a razor from one of Al-Hârith's daughters to perform *istihdâd* (to clean himself and remove his pubic hair), and she lent it to him. She said: 'I was distracted from my young son, and he crawled to him until he reached him, and Khubayb placed him on his thigh. When I saw him, I was seized with a fright that Khubayb noticed, and the razor was in his hand. He said: 'Do you fear that I will kill him? I would not do that, if Allah wills.' She used to say: 'I never saw a captive better than Khubayb. I saw him eating a cluster of grapes, even though there was no fruit in Mecca at that time, and he was shackled in iron. It was nothing but sustenance Allah had provided for him.' They took him out of the sanctuary to kill him. He said: 'Let me pray two *rak'ât*.' Then he turned to them and said: 'Had I not feared that you would think that what I have is fear of death, I would have prolonged the prayer.' He was the first to establish the two *rak'ât* before being killed. Then he said: 'O Allah, count them by number.' Then he said: * "I do not care when I am killed as a Muslim, in what side Allah causes my death. And if He wills, He will bless the limbs of a dismembered body. "* 'Uqbah ibn Al-Hârith stepped forward and killed him. Quraysh sent for 'Asim to bring them something from his body to recognize him, for 'Asim had killed a great man of theirs on the Day of Badr. But Allah sent upon him what resembled a shade of Dabr (a cloud of wasps or male bees) to protect him from being mutilated. It protected him from their messengers, and they could not get anything from his body. Some people claimed that the meaning of Allah's saying: "And [I will] make those who follow you superior to those who disbelieve " \[Surah Aal 'Imran: 55] is that those who follow him are the Christians and those who disbelieve are the Jews. This is not a sound view. Indeed, whoever claims that Jesus is a god, or the son of a god, or that God is the third of a trinity, is not a follower of Jesus, but rather an enemy of his. The one who exaggerated concerning Jesus among the Christians is like the one who was negligent concerning him among the Jews. They are all enemies of Allah and enemies of the Messengers. That is why the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) warned the Muslims against exaggerating about him, just as the Christians exaggerated about Christ, the son of Mary. Al-Bukhari reported in his Sahih, from the way of Ibn 'Abbâs (may Allah be pleased with them both), that he heard 'Umar ibn Al-Khattâb (may Allah be pleased with him) say on the *minbar*: "I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) say: « Do not exaggerate in praising me as the Christians exaggerated in praising Jesus, the son of Mary. For I am only a slave, so say: The slave of Allah and His Messenger. » " The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) explained that no one who came after Jesus will enter Paradise unless he affirms that Jesus is the servant of Allah and His Messenger, His Word which He cast upon Mary, and a Spirit from Him. Al-Bukhari and Muslim reported in their Sahih, from the Hadith of 'Ubâdah ibn As-Sâmit (may Allah be pleased with him), that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said: « Whoever testifies that there is no deity except Allah alone, without any partners, and that Muhammad is His slave and Messenger, and that Jesus is the slave of Allah and His Messenger, and His Word which He cast upon Mary, and a Spirit from Him, and that Paradise is true, and the Fire is true, Allah will admit him into Paradise, whatever his deeds may have been. » Allah the Almighty has judged and decreed that whoever claims that Jesus is a god, or the son of a god, or that God is the third of three, is a disbeliever, a polytheist, to whom Allah forbids Paradise. As He says: "They have certainly disbelieved who say that Allah is Christ, the son of Mary. Say, 'Then who could possess [power] against Allah at all if He had intended to destroy Christ, the son of Mary, or his mother or everyone on the earth?' And to Allah belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth and whatever is between them. He creates what He wills, and Allah is over all things competent. " \[Surah Al-Ma'idah (The Table Spread): 17]. And He says: "They have certainly disbelieved who say that Allah is Christ, the son of Mary. While [in fact] Christ had said, 'O Children of Israel, worship Allah, my Lord and your Lord.' Indeed, he who associates others with Allah - Allah has forbidden him Paradise, and his refuge is the Fire. And there are not for the wrongdoers any helpers. They have certainly disbelieved who say, 'Allah is the third of three.' And there is no god except one God. And if they do not desist from what they are saying, there will surely afflict those who disbelieve among them a painful punishment. " \[Surah Al-Ma'idah: 72-73]. To be continued in the next chapter, if Allah wills. And peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you. --- ## Chapter Eighty-Seventh: Continued Jesus, Son of Mary (p. 359) I mentioned at the end of the previous chapter that Allah the Almighty judged as disbelievers those who claimed that Christ is the Son of God, or that He is God, or that God is the third of three, and I cited the explicit Quranic evidence for that. Allah the Blessed and Most High presented in His Noble Book a scene of truth where He questions Jesus the son of Mary, to denounce those who worshipped him and his mother besides Allah. He says: "[Mention] the Day when Allah will assemble the messengers and say, 'What was the response given to you?' They will say, 'We have no knowledge; indeed, it is You who is the Knower of the unseen.' " \[Surah Al-Ma'idah: 109]. Then He says: "And [mention] when Allah will say, 'O Jesus, Son of Mary, did you say to the people, 'Take me and my mother as two gods besides Allah?' He will say, 'Exalted are You! It was not for me to say that to which I have no right. If I had said it, You would have known it. You know what is within my soul, and I do not know what is within Yours. Indeed, it is You who is the Knower of the unseen. I said not to them except what You commanded me - to worship Allah, my Lord and your Lord. And I was a witness over them as long as I was among them; but when You took me up, You were the Observer over them, and You are, over all things, Witness. If You should punish them - indeed, they are Your servants; but if You forgive them - indeed, it is You who is the Exalted in Might, the Wise.' " \[Surah Al-Ma'idah: 116-118]. His saying here: "but if You forgive them - indeed, it is You who is the Exalted in Might, the Wise. " \[Surah Al-Ma'idah: 118] should not be understood to mean that one who dies in a state of polytheism may be forgiven. The speech focuses on the whole group to whom Jesus was sent, among whom were those who believed in him as the servant and Messenger of Allah, those who disbelieved in him during his lifetime among them, and those who disbelieved after his ascension, claiming he was a god or the son of a god. The context's purpose is to show that Jesus only told them what Allah commanded him: to worship Allah alone, without any partners. He testifies in favor of those who responded to him during his life, and against those who disobeyed him during his life as well. When Allah took him up to Him, his knowledge of their subsequent conditions was removed. Allah alone was the Observer over them. Jesus had no knowledge of their affairs regarding who followed the guidance or who deviated from the straight path. The matter of all rests with Allah: He punishes whom He wills among the disobedient out of His Justice, and rewards and forgives whom He wills out of His Grace, for all are His servants, and He is the Exalted in Might, the Wise. Muslim reported in his Sahih, from the Hadith of 'Abdullah ibn 'Amr ibn Al-'Âs (may Allah be pleased with him), that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) recited the saying of Allah regarding Abraham: "My Lord, indeed they have led astray many among the people. So whoever follows me is of me, and whoever disobeys me - indeed, You are Forgiving and Merciful. " \[Surah Ibrahim (Abraham): 36], and the saying of Jesus: "If You should punish them - indeed, they are Your servants; but if You forgive them - indeed, it is You who is the Exalted in Might, the Wise. " \[Surah Al-Ma'idah: 118]. He then raised his hands and said: "O Allah, my Nation! My Nation! " and wept. Allah said: "O Gabriel, go to Muhammad - and your Lord knows best - and ask him: What makes you weep? " Gabriel (peace be upon him) came to him and asked him. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) informed him of what he had said - and Allah knows best. Then Allah said: "O Gabriel, go to Muhammad and tell him: We will satisfy you concerning your Nation and will not harm you. " There is no doubt that until the time of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), there remained Christians who knew that Jesus is the servant of Allah and His Messenger, due to the continuation of the call of Arius and his followers. That is why, when Ja'far ibn Abî Tâlib recited to the Negus, the King of Abyssinia, a part of Surah Maryam (Mary) which included the story of the Christ's birth and his speaking in the cradle that he was the servant of Allah, that He had given him the Scripture and made him a prophet, the Negus wept until his beard was soaked. He affirmed that what Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) brought regarding the Oneness of Allah and what Jesus brought came from one and the same light source (*mishkâh wâhidah*). Ibn Ishâq said in the Prophetic Biography (*Sîrah Nabawiyyah*): Muhammad ibn Muslim Az-Zuhrî narrated to me, from Abu Bakr ibn 'Abd Ar-Rahmân ibn Al-Hârith ibn Hishâm Al-Makhzûmî, from Umm Salamah bint Abî Umayyah ibn Al-Mughîrah, the wife of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), who said: "When we arrived in the land of Abyssinia, we had the best neighbor, the Negus. We were safe in our religion, and we worshipped Allah the Almighty, neither being harmed nor hearing anything we disliked. When Quraysh learned of this, they consulted among themselves to send two strong men to the Negus concerning us, and to present the Negus with gifts that were considered rare from Mecca. Leather was one of the most astonishing things that came from it. So they collected a great deal of leather, and they did not leave any of his generals (*batâriqah*) without giving him a gift. Then they sent 'Abdullah ibn Abî Rabî'ah and 'Amr ibn Al-'Âs with that. They instructed them with their orders, saying: 'Give the gift to every general before you speak to the Negus about them. Then present his gifts to the Negus and ask him to hand them over to you before he speaks to them.' She said: They set out until they came to the Negus, and we were in the best of dwellings, with the best of neighbors. They did not leave any of his generals without giving him his gift before speaking to the Negus. They said to each general: 'Some foolish youths from our people have sought refuge in the King's country. They have abandoned the religion of their people and have not entered your religion. They have brought a newly invented religion which neither we nor you know. The nobles of their people have sent us to the King concerning them, to return them to them, for their people are more watchful over them and more knowledgeable of what they criticize in them. Advise him, therefore, to hand them over to us and not to speak to them.' She said: They replied: 'Yes.' Then they presented their gifts to the Negus, and he accepted them from them. Then they spoke to him and said: 'O King, some foolish youths from our people have sought refuge in your country. They have abandoned the religion of their people and have not entered your religion. They have brought a newly invented religion which neither we nor you know. The nobles of their people, their fathers, uncles, and clans, have sent us to you concerning them, to return them to them, for their people are more watchful over them and more knowledgeable of what they criticize in them and have reprimanded them for it.' She said: Nothing was more hateful to 'Abdullah ibn Abî Rabî'ah and 'Amr ibn Al-'Âs than for the Negus to hear them speak. She said: Then the most eminent of his generals around him said: 'They speak the truth, O King. Their people are more watchful over them and more knowledgeable of what they criticize in them. Hand them over to them, so they may return them to their country and people.' She said: The Negus became angry and said: 'No, by God, I will not hand them over to them, nor will they harm them. A people who sought refuge with me, came to my country, and chose me over others! If they are as these two say about them, I will hand them over to them and return them to their people. But if they are otherwise, I will protect them from these two and be a good neighbor to them as long as they reside with me.' She said: Then he sent for the Companions of the Messenger of Allah and invited them. When they came, the Negus had summoned his bishops, who had spread their Gospels around him. They gathered, and some said to others: 'What will you say to the man when you come to him?' They said: 'By God, we will say what we know and what our Prophet has commanded us, whatever happens.' He said to them: 'What is this religion for which you have abandoned your people, and which you have not entered into my religion nor the religion of any of these communities?' She said: The one who spoke to him was Ja'far ibn Abî Tâlib. He said: 'O King, we were an ignorant people. We worshipped idols, ate the dead carcass, committed immoralities, cut off the ties of kinship, treated our neighbors badly, and the strong among us consumed the weak. We were upon that until Allah sent to us a Messenger from ourselves, whose lineage, truthfulness, trustworthiness, and chastity we know. He called us to Allah, that we should unite Him and worship Him, and remove what we and our fathers used to worship of stones and idols. He commanded us to be truthful in speech, to render trusts, to maintain the ties of kinship, to treat our neighbors well, and to refrain from unlawful acts and bloodshed. He forbade us from immoralities, false speech, consuming the property of the orphan, and slandering chaste women. He commanded us to worship Allah alone, associating nothing with Him. He commanded us to pray, to pay *Zakât*, and to fast.' She said: He enumerated the matters of Islam. 'We believed him, had faith in him, and followed him in what he brought from Allah. We worshipped Allah alone, associating nothing with Him. We forbade what He forbade us and permitted what He permitted us. Then our people attacked us, tortured us, and tempted us away from our religion to return us to the worship of idols instead of the worship of Allah the Almighty, and to permit vile things. When they overpowered us, wronged us, made life difficult for us, and came between us and our religion, we left for your country. We chose you over others, desired your protection, and hoped that we would not be wronged in your presence, O King.' She said: Then the Negus said to him: 'Do you have with you anything that he brought from Allah?' Ja'far said to him: 'Yes.' The Negus said: 'Then recite it to me.' He recited to him the beginning of a Surah of [Mary]. She said: By God, the Negus wept until his beard was soaked, and his bishops wept until their Gospels were soaked, when they heard what he recited to them. Then the Negus said: 'Indeed, this and what Jesus brought come from one and the same light source (*mishkâh wâhidah*). Go! By God, I will not hand them over to you, nor will they harm them...' To be continued in the next chapter, if Allah wills. And peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you. --- ## Chapter Eighty-Eighth: Continued Jesus, Son of Mary (p. 363) I mentioned in the previous chapter that until the time of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), there remained Christians who knew the true religion, and that Jesus is the servant of Allah and His Messenger, His Word which He cast upon Mary, and a Spirit from Him. I recounted the story of the Negus, the King of Abyssinia, with the emigrant Companions of the Messenger of Allah, and how the Negus wept until his beard was soaked, and the priests and monks with him wept until their Gospels were soaked, upon hearing Ja'far ibn Abî Tâlib (may Allah be pleased with him) recite the beginning of Surah Maryam. Allah the Blessed and Most High alluded in His Noble Book to the weeping of some priests and monks when they heard the Quran, and He mentioned that those who recognize the truth are the closest in affection to the believers. In this regard, Allah says in Surah Al-Ma'idah (The Table Spread): "You will surely find the most intense of people in animosity toward the believers to be the Jews and those who associate others with Allah; and you will surely find the nearest of them in affection to the believers to be those who say, 'We are Christians.' That is because among them are priests and monks and because they are not arrogant.
