And when they hear what has been revealed to the Messenger, you see their eyes overflowing with tears because of what they have recognized of the truth. They say, 'Our Lord, we have believed, so register us among the witnesses. And why should we not believe in Allah and what has come to us of the truth, while we aspire that our Lord will admit us [to Paradise] with the righteous people?' So Allah rewarded them for what they said with Gardens [in Paradise] beneath which rivers flow, wherein they abide forever. And that is the reward of the doers of good. " \[Surah Al-Ma'idah: 82-85]. He says in Surah Al-Isra' (The Night Journey): "Indeed, those who were given knowledge before it - when it is recited to them, they fall upon their faces in prostration and say, 'Exalted is our Lord! Indeed, the promise of our Lord has been fulfilled.' And they fall upon their faces weeping, and it [the Qur'an] increases them in humble submission. " \[Surah Al-Isra': 107-109]. He says in Surah Al-Qasas (The Stories): "Those to whom We gave the Scripture before it - they believe in it. And when it is recited to them, they say, 'We have believed in it; indeed, it is the truth from our Lord. Indeed, we were, of submission, before it.' Those will be given their reward twice for what they patiently endured and [because] they avert evil with good, and they spend from what We have provided them. And when they hear ill speech, they turn away from it and say, 'For us are our deeds, and for you are your deeds. Peace be upon you; we seek not the ignorant.' " \[Surah Al-Qasas: 52-55]. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) informed that whoever from the People of the Scripture believed in his Prophet, and then believed in Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), Allah will grant him his reward. Al-Bukhari and Muslim reported in their Sahih, from the Hadith of Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari (may Allah be pleased with him), who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: "There are three [types of] people for whom there are two rewards: A man from the People of the Scripture who believed in his Prophet and then believed in Muhammad, and a slave who fulfills the rights of Allah and the rights of his masters, and a man who had a female slave, educated her well, taught her well, then freed her and married her; he will have two rewards. " His saying: "That is because among them are priests and monks and because they are not arrogant. " \[Surah Al-Ma'idah: 82] is not a praise for every priest or monk, nor is it an endorsement of these two titles. Rather, the praise is for the one who was a priest or a monk, and then recognized that the religion of Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) is the true religion, the religion of Islam, and that "whoever desires other than Islam as religion - never will it be accepted from him. " \[Surah Aal 'Imran: 85]. So he hastened to enter Islam and hold fast to its laws. That is why no one among them is described as a priest or a monk after entering Islam, just as a Jew or Christian who enters Islam is no longer described as a Jew or a Christian. Al-Qissîs (priest) is the head of the Christians in knowledge and religion. Its linguistic origin is "to follow and seek a thing. " Ru'bah ibn Al-'Ajjâj, describing chaste women who do not seek to spread gossip, said: * "They wake up unconcerned with the seeking of harm (qass al-adhâ). "* It is said: *taqassast aswâtahum bi-l-layl* (I listened attentively to their voices at night). Al-Rahbân is the plural of *Râhib* (monk), who among the Christians devotes himself to worship in hermitages and does not mix with people, derived from *Rahbâniyyah* (monasticism), which is worship in hermitages with the avoidance of women. The Christians innovated monasticism and imposed strictness upon themselves in it, according to His saying: "...and monasticism, which they innovated; We did not prescribe it for them, except [that they sought] the approval of Allah ; but they did not observe it with due observance. " \[Surah Al-Hadid (The Iron): 27]. His saying: "except [that they sought] the approval of Allah " is a discontinuous exception, meaning: We did not prescribe it for them, but they innovated it by themselves, striving to seek the pleasure of Allah. They became like one who exhausts himself in traveling and stops; he has neither crossed the land nor preserved his mount. That is why the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) forbade extremism and exaggeration in religion, and commanded gentleness and ease. When news reached him that some of his Companions had been affected by the sermon of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) and had resolved not to eat meat, nor approach women, nor wear perfume, they gathered in the house of one of the Companions, and he forbade them from that with the strongest prohibition. Similarly, the story of the three groups of men who came to the wives of the Messenger of Allah asking about the worship of the Messenger of Allah. When they were informed, they seemed to regard it as little, and said: "Where are we compared to the Messenger of Allah? Allah has forgiven him his past and future sins. " One of them said: "As for me, I will pray all night and never sleep. " The other said: "I will fast continuously and never break my fast. " And the other said: "I will abstain from women and never marry. " The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) came to them and said: « Are you the ones who said such and such? By Allah, I am the most fearful of Allah among you and the most pious, but I fast and I break my fast, I pray and I sleep, and I marry women. Whoever turns away from my *Sunnah* (way) is not of me. » Allah the Blessed and Most High often condemned the Jews and Christians, explaining that their hearts are filled with mutual hatred, and that each faction accuses the other of having no basis. In this regard, Allah says: "And they say, 'None will enter Paradise except one who is a Jew or a Christian.' That is [merely] their aspirations. Say, 'Produce your proof, if you should be truthful.' " \[Surah Al-Baqarah (The Cow): 111]. Meaning: The Jews said: None will enter Paradise except one who is a Jew, and the Christians said: None will enter Paradise except one who is a Christian, and they have no proof other than these false aspirations. He says: "And the Jews say, 'The Christians are not on anything,' and the Christians say, 'The Jews are not on anything,' while they recite the Scripture. Thus spoke those who did not know, like their saying. But Allah will judge between them on the Day of Resurrection concerning that over which they used to differ. " \[Surah Al-Baqarah: 113]. He says: "And never will the Jews or the Christians approve of you until you follow their religion. Say, 'Indeed, the guidance of Allah is the [only] guidance.' If you were to follow their desires after what has come to you of knowledge, you would have against Allah no protector or helper. " \[Surah Al-Baqarah: 120]. And He says: "And they say, 'Be Jews or Christians, then you will be guided.' Say, 'Rather, [we follow] the religion of Abraham, inclining toward truth, and he was not of the polytheists.' " \[Surah Al-Baqarah: 135]. And He says: "Or were you witnesses when death approached Jacob, when he said to his sons, 'What will you worship after me?' They said, 'We will worship your God and the God of your fathers, Abraham and Ishmael and Isaac - one God. And we are in submission to Him.' Or do you say that Abraham and Ishmael and Isaac and Jacob and the Descendants were Jews or Christians? Say, 'Are you more knowing or is Allah?' And who is more unjust than one who conceals a testimony he has from Allah? And Allah is not unaware of what you do. " \[Surah Al-Baqarah: 140]. And He says: "O People of the Scripture, why do you argue about Abraham while the Torah and the Gospel were not revealed until after him? Then will you not reason? Here you are - those who argued about that for which you had [some] knowledge. But why do you argue about that for which you have no knowledge? And Allah knows, while you know not. Abraham was neither a Jew nor a Christian, but he was a monotheist [inclining toward truth] and a Muslim [submitting to Allah]. And he was not of the polytheists. Indeed, the most deserving of all people to Abraham are those who followed him and this Prophet, and those who have believed. And Allah is the protector of the believers. " \[Surah Aal 'Imran: 65-68]. When the saying of Allah was revealed concerning the polytheists of Mecca: "Indeed, you and whatever you worship other than Allah are the firewood of Hell. You will be incoming to it. Had these [false deities] been gods, they would not have entered it, but all are to abide therein eternally. For them therein is [only] sighing, and they will not hear therein. " \[Surah Al-Anbiya (The Prophets): 98-100], they said: "Then we are satisfied that our gods will be with Jesus the son of Mary in the Fire, because Jesus is worshipped besides Allah. " They were ignorant that whoever is worshipped besides Allah, but did not call people to worship him and is not pleased to be worshipped besides Allah, that will not harm him. So Allah revealed His saying: "Indeed, those for whom the best [reward] has preceded from Us - they will be removed therefrom. " \[Surah Al-Anbiya: 101]. And He said: "And when the son of Mary was presented as an example, immediately your people laughed at it. And they said, 'Are our gods better, or is he?' They did not present the comparison to you except to argue. But [in fact], they are a people given to dispute. He was not but a servant upon whom We conferred favor and made an example for the Children of Israel. And if We willed, We could have made [instead of you] angels in the land succeeding [one another]. And indeed, Jesus will be [a sign] for [knowledge of] the Hour, so do not be in doubt of it and follow Me. This is a straight path. And let not Satan avert you. Indeed, he is to you a clear enemy. And when Jesus brought clear proofs, he said, 'I have come to you with wisdom and to make clear to you some of that over which you differ, so fear Allah and obey me. Indeed, Allah is my Lord and your Lord, so worship Him. This is a straight path.' But the factions differed among themselves, so woe to those who wronged from the punishment of a painful Day. " \[Surah Az-Zukhruf (The Ornaments of Gold): 57-65]. "Peace be upon Jesus among the messengers! And [all] praise is for Allah, Lord of the worlds! " \[Surah As-Saffat (Those Who Set the Ranks): 181-182]. }
source: Holy Quran and Prophetic Sunnah, Exegeses of Ahlus Sunnah Wal Jama'ah

bio_naissance_annee: No specific date, believed to have lived before Musa (Moses) and to be from the lineage of Ishaq (Isaac) son of Ibrahim (peace be upon them).
bio_lieu_naissance: The Levant region (Hawran area or modern-day Jordan), where he owned lands and livestock.
bio_descendance: From the descendants of Ishaq (peace be upon him). He had many children and wealth, which Allah restored to him after the affliction. His wife is Rahmah (in some narrations).
texte_original: ## Chapter Thirty-Eight: Ayyub (Job) In this chapter, we speak about the Prophet and Messenger of Allah, Ayyub (Job), the role model for the patient, whose patience in affliction is proverbial. Most scholars agree that he was from the progeny of Ibrahim (Abraham), based on Allah's statement (Al-An'am 6:83-84): "That was Our argument, which We gave to Abraham against his people. We raise in degrees whom We will. Indeed, your Lord is Wise and Knowing. And We gave to him Isaac and Jacob. All [of them] We guided. And [before that] We guided Noah, and among his descendants, David and Solomon and Ayyub and Joseph and Moses and Aaron. Thus do We reward the doers of good." This is predicated on the pronoun in "among his descendants" referring back to Ibrahim, as the discourse is about him. Some scholars disagree, making the pronoun refer back to Noah, as he is the closest one mentioned, although Allah restricted the Prophethood after Ibrahim to his progeny (Al-Ankabut 29:27): "And We placed in his descendants Prophethood and the Scripture." The story of Ayyub in the Book of Allah and the Sunnah of His Messenger (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) includes several points: his affliction; the harm (Ad-Dhurr) that touched him in his person and family, causing him to feel 'Nusbun wa Adhâb' (fatigue, pain, and hardship) ; he was afflicted and made an oath to do something whose fulfillment would be painful and difficult for him; and he was tried with vast wealth and abundant property. Neither Allah nor His Messenger has definitively specified the exact nature of the physical affliction that struck Ayyub. However, the Glorious Quran indicates he suffered from a type of severe fever, as Allah made his cure to be washing and drinking cold water. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) recommended washing with cold water for certain types of fever, as reported by Al-Bukhari and Muslim: "Fever is from the exhalation of Hell, so extinguish it with water" (Reported by Ibn Umar and Aisha). However, not every illness or fever is treated by cooling with water; it is a specific type, as cold water can be lethal for some fevers. It is apparent that the illness that struck Ayyub was extreme in its severity and pain. This is not strange, as the people most severely tested are the Prophets, then the next best, then the next best (Ad-Dârimi, An-Nasa'i, At-Tirmidhi, Ibn Mâjah). Al-Bukhari and Muslim report a Hadith of Ibn Mas'ud: "I entered upon the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) while he was suffering from a severe fever... The Messenger of Allah said: 'Yes, I am afflicted with a fever like that of two men among you.'" And the Prophet added: "No Muslim is afflicted by harm from illness or anything else, except that Allah will drop his sins as a tree drops its leaves." As for the stories mentioning that Ayyub's illness lasted so long that his companions shunned him, he was driven out of his town and cast onto a garbage heap outside it, people abandoned him, and only his wife remained devoted; that worms crawled over his body, and his flesh wasted away until only bone and sinew remained; and that this lasted for three, seven, thirteen, or eighteen years—none of these fabricated stories are established by an authentic report from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). The consensus among scholars is that Allah protects His Prophets from repulsive diseases. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) indicated that Allah had given Ayyub vast wealth. Al-Bukhari reported from Abu Hurayrah that the Messenger of Allah said: "While Ayyub was bathing naked, a swarm of golden grasshoppers fell upon him. He began scooping them into his garment. His Lord called out to him: 'O Ayyub, did I not enrich you from what you see?' He said: 'Yes, O Lord, but I have no independence from Your blessing (Barakah)!'" Allah the Exalted narrated his story in two places in His Noble Book: 1. In Surah Al-Anbiya (21:83-84): "And [mention] Job, when he called to his Lord, 'Indeed, adversity has touched me, and You are the most Merciful of the merciful.' So We responded to him and removed what was upon him of adversity. And We gave him [back] his family and the like thereof with them, as mercy from Us and a reminder for the worshippers." Allah followed this by stating that patience is a quality of the Messengers (21:85): "And [mention] Ishmael and Idrees and Dhul-Kifl; all were of the patient." 2. In Surah Sad (38:41-44): "And remember Our servant Job, when he called to his Lord, 'Indeed, Satan has afflicted me with distress and suffering (Nusbun wa Adhâb).' [So he was told], 'Strike [the ground] with your foot; this is a cool [water] bath and drink.' And We gave him [back] his family and the like thereof with them, as mercy from Us and a reminder for those of understanding. And take in your hand a bundle of sprouts, and strike therewith and do not break your oath. Indeed, We found him patient, an excellent servant. Indeed, he was ever returning [to Allah]." In this noble context, Ayyub attributes the harm to Satan, out of respectful etiquette (Adab) towards Allah in attributing evil to Satan, who is the cause of every affliction that strikes the son of Adam in this world (being the one who caused Adam to be expelled from Paradise). As for the command: "And take in your hand a bundle of sprouts..." (Ad-Dhighth), which is a handful of mixed wet and dry grass, it refers to his having sworn in a state of anger to strike a loved one a specific number of times. Allah commanded him to fulfill his oath by striking the person with this bundle as a reward for his patience and excellence, because hitting with a whip or similar would have caused pain to both the striker and the struck. Allah thus relieved his distress. "And whoever fears Allah - He will make for him a way out and will provide for him from where he does not expect. And whoever relies upon Allah - then He is sufficient for him. Indeed, Allah will accomplish His purpose. Allah has already set for everything a [decreed] extent." (At-Talaq 65:2-3). To the next chapter, if Allah wills. Peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you.
source: Holy Quran and Prophetic Sunnah, Exegeses of Ahlus Sunnah Wal Jama'ah

bio_naissance_annee: The Year of the Elephant (approx. 570 or 571 CE)
bio_lieu_naissance: Mecca Al-Mukarramah
bio_descendance: From the Quraysh tribe, son of Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib
texte_original: Ibn Sa'd reported that the Mother of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "When I gave birth to him, a light issued forth from my private parts and illuminated the palaces of Syria. " Ahmad reported a similar account from Al-Irbad ibn Sariyah. It is narrated that foreshadowing events of the Prophetic Mission occurred at the time of birth: fourteen balconies of the iwan of Chosroes fell, the fire worshipped by the Magians was extinguished, and the churches around Lake Sawa collapsed after the lake dried up. These facts are reported by Al-Bayhaqi, but Muhammad Al-Ghazali does not endorse them. Among the Banu Sa'd: It was the custom of the Arabs residing in the settled areas to seek wet nurses for their children to keep them away from the diseases of the cities, so that their bodies would be strengthened, their nerves toughened, and they would master the Arabic language in their cradle. Abdul-Muttalib thus sought wet nurses for the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and had him suckled by a woman from the Banu Sa'd ibn Bakr – she was Halima bint Abi Dhu'ayb – and her husband, Al-Harith ibn 'Abdul-'Uzza, nicknamed Abu Kabsha, from the same tribe. The foster-siblings of our Master Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) were: 'Abdullah ibn Al-Harith, Anisa bint Al-Harith, and Hudhafa or Judhama bint Al-Harith (who is Ash-Shayma – a nickname that predominated over her name). She used to nurse the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), as well as Abu Sufyan ibn Al-Harith ibn 'Abdul-Muttalib, the cousin of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). His uncle Hamza ibn 'Abdul-Muttalib was also nursed among the Banu Sa'd ibn Bakr. His mother (Hamza's mother) breastfed the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) one day while he was with his mother Halima. Thus, Hamza was the foster-brother of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in two ways: through Thuwayba and through the Sa'diyya woman. Halima witnessed wonders from the blessing of our Master Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Let us allow her to narrate it in detail: Ibn Ishaq said that Halima used to relate that she left her country with her husband and her suckling infant son, in the company of a group of women from the Banu Sa'd ibn Bakr, seeking infants to nurse. She said: "That was in a year of drought ('shahba'), which had left us nothing. " She said: "I set out on my gray donkey, with an old she-camel of ours which, by Allah, did not yield a single drop (of milk). We did not sleep all night because of our child with us, due to his crying from hunger, for I had no milk in my breast to satisfy him, nor did our she-camel have anything to feed him. But we were hoping for rain and relief. " She said: "I set out on that donkey of mine, and it slowed down the riders until it became difficult for them due to its weakness and leanness, until we arrived in Mecca seeking infants to nurse. There was no woman among us to whom the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was not offered, who did not refuse him when told he was an orphan. This was because we were hoping for the generosity of the child's father. We would say, 'An orphan? What can his mother and grandfather do?' So we disliked him for that. No woman who came with me remained without taking an infant, except for me. " When we decided to depart, I said to my companion: "By Allah, I dislike returning among my companions without having taken an infant. By Allah, I will go to that orphan and take him! " He said: "There is no harm in you doing so. Perhaps Allah will grant us a blessing through him. " She said: "So I went to him and took him. Nothing prompted me to take him but that I found no one else. " She said: "When I took him, I returned with him to my lodging. When I placed him on my lap, my breasts overflowed with as much milk as Allah willed. He drank until he was satisfied, and his (foster) brother drank with him until he was satisfied. Then they both slept, something we had not done with him before. My husband went to that old she-camel of ours, and behold, she was full. He milked from her what he drank and what I drank with him until we were fully satisfied and full. We spent the best of nights. " She said: "My companion said to me when we awoke: 'Know, by Allah, O Halima, you have taken a blessed soul!' " She said: "I said: 'By Allah, I hope so!' " She said: "Then we set out. I rode my donkey and carried him with me. By Allah, she overtook the riders with a speed none of their reddish mounts could equal, until my companions would say to me: 'O daughter of Abi Dhu'ayb, woe to you! Keep pace with us! Is this not the same donkey you set out on?' I would say to them: 'Yes, by Allah, it is indeed the same!' They would say: 'By Allah, she has a story!' " She said: "Then we arrived at our homes in the land of the Banu Sa'd, and I know of no land of Allah more barren than it. But my sheep would return to us, after we arrived with him, full of milk. We would milk and drink, while no one else could milk a single drop of milk or find it in the udder. The residents of our tribe would say to their shepherds, 'Woe to you! Graze where the shepherd of the daughter of Abi Dhu'ayb grazes!' Their sheep would return hungry, not yielding a drop of milk, while my sheep returned full of milk. We continued to recognize this increase and goodness from Allah until his two years were complete and I weaned him. He grew rapidly, unlike other boys. Before he reached two years, he was a robust youth. " She said: "We brought him back to his mother, while we were most eager for him to stay with us, because of the blessing we had witnessed. We spoke to his mother and I said to her: 'If only you would leave my son with me until he grows stronger, for I fear the plague of Mecca for him.' " She said: "We kept appealing to her until she returned him with us. " Thus, our Master Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) remained among the Banu Sa'd until, in the fourth or fifth year of his birth, the incident of the splitting of his chest occurred. Muslim reported from Anas: "That the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was playing with the boys when Gabriel came to him, took him, threw him to the ground, split open his heart, extracted the heart, removed a blood clot from it, and said: 'This is the portion of Satan in you.' Then he washed it in a golden basin with Zamzam water, sealed it, and returned it to its place. The boys came running to his mother – meaning his foster mother – and said: 'Muhammad has been killed!' They met him while his color was pale. To his Affectionate Mother: Halima feared for him after this incident, so she returned him to his mother. He remained with his mother until he reached the age of six. Amina, wanting to fulfill the memory of her late husband, decided to visit his grave in Yathrib. She left Mecca, covering a journey of about five hundred kilometers, accompanied by her orphan son – Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) – her maidservant Umm Ayman, and his guardian 'Abdul-Muttalib. She stayed for a month, then returned. While she was on her way back, illness pursued her, pressing hard upon her at the start of the journey, and she died at Al-Abwa, between Mecca and Medina. To his Compassionate Grandfather: 'Abdul-Muttalib returned with him to Mecca. The feelings of tenderness in his heart grew toward his orphan grandson, who had suffered a new calamity that reopened old wounds. He showed him a fondness he had not shown to any of his own children. He did not leave him to his imposed solitude, but preferred him over his own sons. Ibn Hisham said that a mattress was laid out for 'Abdul-Muttalib in the shade of the Kaaba, and his sons would sit around that mattress until he came out to it. None of his sons would sit on it out of reverence for him. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), while a robust youth, would come and sit on it. His uncles would try to take him away, but 'Abdul-Muttalib, seeing this, would say: "Leave my son, for by Allah, he has a great destiny! " Then he would sit with him on his mattress, wipe his back with his hand, and be pleased with what he saw and did. At eight years, two months, and ten days of age (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), his grandfather 'Abdul-Muttalib died in Mecca. Before his death, he entrusted the care of his grandson to his uncle Abu Talib, his father's full brother. To his Sympathetic Uncle: Abu Talib fulfilled his duty to his nephew in the most perfect way. He included him with his own children, preferred him over them, and showed him special respect and appreciation. For over forty years, he strengthened his position, extended his protection over him, and befriended and antagonized others for his sake. Excerpts of this will come in their respective places. A Life of Hardship: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did not have a specific occupation in his early youth, but narrations concur that he used to tend sheep. He herded them among the Banu Sa'd, and in Mecca for its people for a few Qirats. At the age of twenty-five, he traveled as a merchant to Syria with the wealth of Khadija (may Allah be pleased with her). Ibn Ishaq said that Khadija bint Khuwaylid was a noble and wealthy merchant woman who hired men to trade with her money, sharing the profit with them. The Quraysh were a trading people. When she heard about the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) – about his truthfulness in speech, his great honesty, and his noble character – she sent for him and offered him to travel to Syria as a merchant with her wealth, and she would give him a better share than she gave others, along with her servant named Maysara. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) accepted her offer and set out with her wealth, accompanied by her servant Maysara, until they reached Syria. His Marriage to Khadija: When he returned to Mecca, Khadija saw in her wealth an honesty and blessing she had not seen before. Her servant Maysara informed her of the pure qualities, noble traits, sound judgment, truthful logic, and trustworthy conduct he had observed in him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). She found her sought-after aspiration – although chiefs and leaders were eager to marry her, she refused them. She confided her feelings to her friend Nafisa bint Munya, who went to him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to propose the marriage to Khadija. He agreed, and he spoke to his uncles, who went to Khadija's uncle and asked for her hand. The marriage was concluded shortly thereafter, two months after his return from Syria. The Banu Hashim and the chiefs of Mudar attended the contract. He gave her a dowry of twenty young she-camels. She was then forty years old and was the best woman of her people in lineage, wealth, and intellect. She was the first woman the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) married, and he did not marry anyone else while she was alive until she died. All his children (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) were from her, except Ibrahim. She first bore him Al-Qasim – by whom he was nicknamed (Abu al-Qasim) – then Zaynab, Ruqayya, Umm Kulthum, Fatima, and 'Abdullah. 'Abdullah was nicknamed At-Tayyib (the Good) and At-Tahir (the Pure). All his sons died in their infancy. As for his daughters, all of them reached Islam, embraced it, and emigrated, but they all passed away during his lifetime (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), except for Fatima (may Allah be pleased with her), who survived him by six months, then joined him. The Building of the Kaaba and the Arbitration Issue: In the thirty-fifth year of his birth (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), the Quraysh undertook the rebuilding of the Kaaba. This was because the Kaaba was merely a pile of stones, a little taller than a man (about nine cubits high) since the time of Isma'il, and it had no roof. A group of thieves had stolen the treasure inside it. Furthermore, being an ancient structure, it had been exposed to elements that damaged its building and cracked its walls. Five years before his Prophetic Mission (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), a massive flood swept through Mecca and flowed into the Sacred House, nearly causing the Kaaba to collapse. The Quraysh were compelled to renovate its structure, out of concern for its status. They agreed not to include anything in its construction except what was lawfully earned (good/pure money), excluding a harlot's dowry, the profit from usurious sales, or the money from any injustice. They were hesitant to tear it down, but Al-Walid ibn Al-Mughira Al-Makhzumi started the demolition, and the people followed him when they saw that no harm befell him. They continued demolishing until they reached the foundations of Ibrahim. Then they wanted to start building. They divided the Kaaba and allocated a section to each tribe. Each tribe collected stones separately and began building. A Roman builder named Baqoum oversaw the construction. When the building reached the spot of the Black Stone, they disputed over who would have the honor of placing it in its position. The dispute lasted four or five nights and intensified until it nearly turned into a fierce war in the Sacred Precinct. However, Abu Umayya ibn Al-Mughira Al-Makhzumi proposed that they take as an arbiter the first person to enter upon them from the gate of the Mosque. They agreed. By the will of Allah, it was the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). When they saw him, they exclaimed: "This is Al-Amin (the Trustworthy)! We accept him! This is Muhammad! " When he reached them and they informed him of the situation, he asked for a cloak. He placed the Stone in its center and asked the chiefs of the disputing tribes to all hold the edges of the cloak. He ordered them to lift it. When they had raised it to its designated spot, he took it with his hand and placed it in its position. This was a wise solution that satisfied the people. The legitimate funds of the Quraysh fell short, so they excluded from the northern side about six cubits, which is called Al-Hijr and Al-Hatim. They raised the door from the ground so that only those they wished could enter it. When the building reached fifteen cubits in height, they roofed it with six columns. After its completion, the Kaaba had an approximately square shape, with a height of 15 meters. The length of the side with the Black Stone and the opposite side was 10.10 meters, and the Stone was placed at a height of 1.50 meters from the floor of the circumambulation area. The length of the side with the door and the opposite side was 12 meters, and its door was two meters above the ground. It is surrounded on the outside, at its base, by a low wall of masonry called Ash-Shadharwan, with an average height of 0.25 meters and an average width of 0.30 meters. This was part of the original House, but the Quraysh left it out. Summary of the Biography Before Prophethood: Our Master Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) had gathered in his upbringing the best qualities of all people. He was a refined model of sound thinking, keen insight, and possessed a large share of good judgment, originality of thought, and correctness of means and purpose. He used his long silence for deep contemplation, constant reflection, and the search for truth. With his fertile mind and pure nature, he read the pages of life, the affairs of people, and the conditions of communities. He rejected the superstitions outside of that and kept away from them. Then he associated with people with a clear understanding of his own situation and theirs. What he found good, he participated in, otherwise he returned to his accustomed seclusion. He did not drink wine, nor eat what was slaughtered for idols, nor attend any festival or celebration for the idols. Rather, from the beginning of his youth, he naturally disliked these false deities, to the extent that nothing was more hateful to him than them, and he could not bear to hear anyone swear by Al-Lat and Al-Uzza. There is no doubt that Destiny surrounded him with protection. Whenever the desires of the soul prompted him to explore some worldly pleasures, and whenever he might have been inclined to follow some disapproved traditions, divine care intervened to prevent him. Ibn Al-Athir reported that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "I never intended to do anything that the people of the pre-Islamic era (Jahiliyya) used to do, except for two times, and in both cases, Allah prevented me from it. Then I never intended to do it again until He honored me with His Message. " He said: "One night I said to the youth who was herding sheep with me in upper Mecca, 'If you would watch my sheep for me, I would enter Mecca and spend the evening there as young men do.' He replied, 'I will do so.' So I went out. When I reached the first house in Mecca, I heard music. I asked, 'What is this?' They said, 'It is the wedding of so-and-so to so-and-so.' I sat down to listen, but Allah struck my ears (with a deep sleep), and I slept. Nothing woke me but the heat of the sun. I returned to my companion, who asked me, and I informed him. The next night, I said the same thing and entered Mecca, and the same thing happened to me as the first night. After that, I never intended to do any evil. " Al-Bukhari reported from Jabir ibn 'Abdullah: "When the Kaaba was being built, the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and 'Abbas were carrying stones. 'Abbas said to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), 'Put your lower garment on your neck to protect you from the stones.' He fainted to the ground, his eyes fixed on the sky. When he recovered, he said: 'My garment! My garment!' He then tied his garment around himself. " In another narration, "His private parts were never seen after that. " The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was distinguished among his people by his gentle manners, noble character, and generous qualities. He was the most noble of his people in chivalry, the best in character, the most protective of his neighbors, the most patient, the most truthful in speech, the most easygoing, the most chaste, the most generous in goodness, the most righteous in action, the most faithful to his covenants, and the most trustworthy, to the extent that his people called him "Al-Amin " (The Trustworthy) for all the righteous conditions and praiseworthy qualities he possessed. He was, as the Mother of the Believers Khadija (may Allah be pleased with her) said, one who bore the burdens of the weak, earned for the destitute, honored the guest, and assisted in calamities that struck the truth. In the Shadow of Prophethood and Message: In the Cave of Hira: When he approached the age of forty (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and his past contemplations had widened the intellectual gap between him and his people, he began to love seclusion. He would take *sawiq* (a type of groats) and water and go to the Cave of Hira on Mount An-Nur (Mount of Light), about two miles from Mecca – a small cave, four cubits long and one and three-quarter iron cubits wide – with his family nearby. He would stay there for the month of Ramadan, feed the poor who came to him, and spend his time in worship and contemplation of the surrounding cosmic scenes and the creative power behind them. He was not satisfied with the flimsy polytheistic beliefs and weak conceptions of his people, but he had no clear path, no defined methodology, and no direct way before him that he could trust and approve. His choice of this isolation (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was part of Allah's planning for him, to prepare him for the great matter that awaited him. Any soul destined to influence the reality of human life and turn it in another direction... that soul needs a period of solitude and isolation, a withdrawal from worldly preoccupations, the noise of life, and the small concerns of people that occupy life. Thus, Allah prepared our Master Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) as He readied him to carry the great trust, to change the face of the Earth, and to modify the course of history... He arranged this isolation for him three years before entrusting him with the Message. He would spend a month in this seclusion, communing with the free spirit of existence, contemplating the hidden unseen beyond existence, until the time came for interaction with this unseen when Allah permitted it. Gabriel Descends with the Revelation: When he completed forty years – the age of perfection, and it is said: the age at which Messengers are sent – the signs of Prophethood began to glimmer and shine for him from beyond the horizons of life. These signs were true dreams. He would not see a dream that did not come true like the break of dawn. This lasted for six months – the duration of Prophethood being twenty-three years, so this dream was one part out of forty-six parts of Prophethood. When Ramadan came in the third year of his isolation (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in Hira, Allah willed to pour out His mercy upon the inhabitants of the Earth. He honored him with Prophethood, and Gabriel descended to him with verses of the Qur'an. Upon review and reflection on the circumstantial evidence and proofs, we can determine that day to be Monday, the night of the twenty-first of Ramadan, corresponding to August 10, 610 AD. His age (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was exactly forty lunar years, six months, and 12 days, which is approximately 39 solar years, three months, and 12 days. Let us listen to 'A'isha As-Siddiqah (may Allah the Most High be pleased with her) narrate to us the story of this event, which was a spark of divine light that began to open the dark shadows of disbelief and error, changing the course of life and altering the path of history. 'A'isha (may Allah be pleased with her) said: The beginning of the Revelation vouchsafed to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was the true dream in sleep. He would not see a dream that did not come true like the break of dawn. Then seclusion became dear to him. He used to seclude himself in the Cave of Hira, where he engaged in *tahannuth* – which is worship – for a number of nights before returning to his family. He would take provision for that, then return to Khadija to take provision for a similar period. This continued until the Truth came to him while he was in the Cave of Hira. The Angel came to him and said: "Read! " I said: "I am not a reader. " He said: "He seized me and squeezed me until I was utterly exhausted, then he released me and said: 'Read!' " I said: "I am not a reader. " He seized me and squeezed me a third time, then he released me and said: {READ IN THE NAME OF YOUR LORD WHO CREATED, * CREATED MAN FROM A CLINGING SUBSTANCE. * READ! AND YOUR LORD IS THE MOST GENEROUS.} [Al-'Alaq: 1-3]. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) returned with it, his heart trembling. He entered upon Khadija bint Khuwaylid and said: "Cover me! Cover me! " They covered him until the fear left him. He said to Khadija: "What is wrong with me? " and he informed her of the news: "I feared for myself. " Khadija responded: "Nay, by Allah, Allah will never disgrace you! You maintain kinship ties, you bear the burdens of the weak, you earn for the destitute, you honor the guest, and you assist in the calamities that strike the truth. " Khadija took him until she brought him to Waraqa ibn Nawfal ibn Asad ibn 'Abdul-'Uzza, Khadija's cousin, who had become a Christian in the pre-Islamic era. He used to write the Hebrew script, writing from the Gospel in Hebrew as much as Allah willed him to write. He was a very old man who had gone blind. Khadija said to him: "O cousin, listen to your nephew. " Waraqa said to him: "O my nephew, what do you see? " The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) informed him of what he had seen. Waraqa said to him: "This is the Namus (the Angel of Revelation) that Allah sent down to Moses. Oh, would that I were a young man then! Would that I were alive when your people expel you! " The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) asked: "Will they expel me? " He replied: "Yes. Never has a man brought what you have brought except that he was opposed. And if your day overtakes me, I will support you strongly. " Soon after, Waraqa died, and the Revelation ceased temporarily. At-Tabari and Ibn Hisham reported what indicates that he left the Cave of Hira after being surprised by the Revelation, then returned and completed his seclusion, and after that, returned to Mecca. The narration of At-Tabari sheds light on the reason for his leaving, and this is its text: Our Master Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said after mentioning the coming of the Revelation: "Nothing created by Allah was more hateful to me than a poet or a madman. I could not bear to look at them. " He said: "I said to myself: 'This distant one (meaning himself) is either a poet or a madman. The Quraysh will talk about it forever. I will deliberately go to a high cliff of the mountain and throw myself from it to kill myself and find rest.' " He said: "I went out intending that. When I was halfway up the mountain, I heard a voice from the sky saying: 'O Muhammad! You are the Messenger of Allah, and I am Gabriel!' " He said: "I raised my head to the sky, and behold, Gabriel was in the form of a man, standing with his feet at the horizon of the sky, saying: 'O Muhammad! You are the Messenger of Allah, and I am Gabriel!' " He said: "I stood still, looking at him, and that distracted me from what I intended. I did not move forward or backward. I started turning my face away in the horizons of the sky, but I did not look in any direction but saw him like that. I remained standing, neither advancing nor retreating, until Khadija sent her messengers to look for me. They reached Mecca and returned to her, while I was still standing in my place. " He said: "Then he turned away from me, and I returned to my family. When I came to Khadija, I sat on her thigh, leaning against her. " She said: "O Abul-Qasim, where have you been? By Allah, I sent people to look for you until they reached Mecca and returned to me! " Then he told her what he had seen. She said: "Rejoice, O cousin, and be firm! By Him in Whose Hand is Khadija's soul, I hope that you will be the Prophet of this Nation! " Then she got up and went to Waraqa and informed him. He said: "Holy! Holy! By Him in Whose Hand is Waraqa's soul, the Greater Namus (Angel of Revelation) that came to Moses has come to him! He is the Prophet of this Nation! Tell him to be firm! " Khadija returned and informed him of Waraqa's words. When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) completed his seclusion and returned to Mecca, Waraqa met him and, after hearing his story, said: "By Him in Whose Hand is my soul, you are the Prophet of this Nation! And the Greater Namus that came to Moses has come to you! " The Period of Interruption of Revelation (*Fatra*): As for the duration of the interruption of the Revelation (*Fatra*), Ibn Sa'd reported from Ibn 'Abbas what suggests it lasted for a few days, and this is the most likely and even certain view after considering all aspects. The widespread notion that it lasted for three years or two and a half years is by no means correct, and this is not the place for a detailed refutation. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) remained sad and grieved during the days of *Fatra*, afflicted by confusion and astonishment. Al-Bukhari reported in the Book of Interpretation of Dreams: "The Revelation ceased for a period, and the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) grieved, as reached us, a grief that led him to attempt several times to throw himself from the tops of high mountains. Whenever he reached a mountain peak to throw himself off, Gabriel would appear to him and say: 'O Muhammad, you are truly the Messenger of Allah.' This would soothe his heart and calm his soul, and he would return. If the interruption of the Revelation lengthened, he would go out to do the same, and whenever he reached the mountain peak, Gabriel would appear to him and say the same thing. " Gabriel Descends with the Revelation a Second Time: Ibn Hajar said: "This interruption (of the Revelation for a few days) was to dispel the fear the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) had felt and to generate in him the longing for its return. " When the shadows of confusion receded, the signs of truth were established, and he (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) knew with certainty that he had become a Prophet of Allah, the Great, the Exalted, and that what came to him was the Ambassador of the Revelation conveying news from Heaven, his longing and anticipation for the return of the Revelation became the reason for his firmness and endurance when it returned. Gabriel came to him a second time. Al-Bukhari reported from Jabir ibn 'Abdullah that he heard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) speak about the *Fatra* of the Revelation. He said: "While I was walking, I heard a voice from the sky. I raised my gaze towards the sky, and behold, the Angel who had come to me in Hira was sitting on a throne between the heaven and the earth. I was so overwhelmed by him that I fell to the ground. I came to my family and said, 'Cover me! Cover me!' So they covered me. Then Allah the Most High revealed: {O you who is wrapped up (in a mantle)!} to His saying: {And abandon the abomination}, and after that, the Revelation became intense and successive. " Digression on the Categories of Revelation: Before detailing the life of the Message and the Prophethood, we believe it is appropriate to understand the categories of the Revelation, which is the source of the Message and the support of the Call. Ibn Al-Qayyim – mentioning the ranks of the Revelation – said: The first: The true dream, which was the beginning of his Revelation (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). The second: What the Angel cast into his heart and soul without him seeing him, as the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "The Holy Spirit has breathed into my soul that no soul shall die until it has completed its provision, so fear Allah, and be moderate in seeking (provision). Let not the delay in provision lead you to seek it by disobeying Allah, for what is with Allah cannot be attained except through obedience to Him. " The third: The Angel would materialize for him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in the form of a man and speak to him until he understood what he said. At this rank, the Companions would sometimes see him. The fourth: The Revelation would come to him like the ringing of a bell. This was the hardest upon him, and the Angel would cling to him, so much so that his forehead would profusely sweat on an intensely cold day, and his riding animal would kneel to the ground if he was riding it. The Revelation once came to him like this while his thigh was upon Zayd ibn Thabit's thigh, and it became so heavy that it almost crushed it. The fifth: He would see the Angel in his original form in which he was created, and he would reveal to him what Allah willed to reveal. This happened to him twice, as Allah mentioned in Surat An-Najm. The sixth: What Allah revealed to him while he was above the heavens on the Night of Al-Mi'raj (Ascension), such as the prescribing of the prayer and other matters. The seventh: Allah's speech to him directly, without the mediation of an angel, just as Allah spoke to Moses ibn 'Imran. This rank is definitely established for Moses by the text of the Qur'an. Its establishment for our Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is in the narration of Al-Isra' (The Night Journey). Some have added an eighth rank, which is Allah speaking to him face-to-face without a veil, but this is a matter of difference of opinion between the predecessors and the later scholars. End of quote, with a slight summary in explaining the first and eighth ranks. The Command to Commence the Call (Da'wa): The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) received several commands in the word of Allah the Most High: {O YOU WHO IS WRAPPED UP (IN A MANTLE)! * ARISE AND WARN! * AND YOUR LORD, MAGNIFY! * AND YOUR GARMENTS, PURIFY! * AND ABANDON THE ABOMINATION! * AND DO NOT GIVE, EXPECTING MORE IN RETURN! * AND FOR YOUR LORD, BE PATIENT!} [Al-Muddaththir: 1-7]. Commands that are seemingly simple and naive, but far-reaching in scope and purpose, and powerful in effect and reality. The purpose of the warning is not to leave anyone in existence who opposes Allah's pleasure without warning him of its grave consequences, until a tremor and earthquake occur in his heart and soul. The purpose of magnifying the Lord is not to leave any arrogance on Earth without breaking its power and turning it upside down, so that nothing remains on Earth but the majesty of Allah the Most High. The purpose of purifying garments and abandoning abomination is to reach a degree of perfection in purifying the exterior and the interior, and in purifying the soul from all impurities and defilements, as much as is possible for a human soul under the sheltering shade of Allah's mercy, His preservation, His care, His guidance, and His light, so that he may be the highest example in human society, attracting sound hearts and inspiring awe and grandeur in misguided hearts, until the entire world revolves around him, whether in agreement or disagreement. The purpose of not seeking to gain more by giving is not to consider one's actions and efforts as grandiose and great. Rather, one should continue striving action after action, exerting much effort, sacrifice, and self-annihilation, then forget all of that, being absorbed in the consciousness of Allah to the extent that one does not feel or perceive what one has given and accomplished. The last verse is a reference to the harm he will face from the opponents, ranging from opposition, mockery, and ridicule, to serious efforts to kill him and his Companions, and to eliminate all the believers who gathered around him. Allah the Most High commands him to endure all of this with strength and fortitude, not for the sake of any worldly gain, but solely for the pleasure of his Lord. Allahu Akbar (Allah is the Greatest)! How simple these commands are in their apparent form, and how wonderful they are in their calm, captivating rhythms! But how great, majestic, and demanding they are in action, and how powerfully they stir up a raging storm that encompasses all sides of the world, leaving them to clash with one another. The verses themselves contain the substance of the Call and the transmission of the Message. The warning itself necessitates that there are actions with a bad consequence that their doers will face. Given that everyone knows that the world does not fully reward or punish people for all their actions, the warning necessitates a Day of Requital separate from the days of this world, which is called the Day of Resurrection, the Day of Recompense and Judgment (*Ad-Din*). This requires a life other than the one we live in this world. The remaining verses demand pure Monotheism (Tawhid) from the servants, the submission of all matters to Allah the Most High, and the forsaking of the pleasure of the self and the pleasure of the servants for the pleasure of Allah the Most High. Thus, these points are summarized in: a – Monotheism (Tawhid). b – Belief in the Last Day. c – The purification of the soul by refraining from wrongdoings and indecencies that lead to an evil end, and by acquiring virtues, perfections, and good deeds. d – The submission of all matters to Allah the Most High. e – All of this subsequent to belief in the Message of Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and under his noble leadership and wise guidance. Furthermore, the beginning of the verses contained the elevated summons – in the voice of the Great, the Exalted – commissioning the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) for this tremendous task, pulling him from sleep, wrapping, and warmth into struggle, battle, and hardship: {O YOU WHO IS WRAPPED UP! * ARISE AND WARN!}... It is as if it was said: 'He who lives for himself may live in comfort. But you, who bear this great burden, what business do you have with sleep? What business do you have with rest? What business do you have with the warm bed, the quiet life, and the comfortable enjoyment? Arise for the great matter that awaits you, and the heavy burden prepared for you! Arise for the effort and toil, the struggle and fatigue! Arise, for the time of sleep and rest is over! From this day forth, there is only continuous vigilance and a long, arduous struggle! Arise, prepare yourself and be ready for this matter!' It is a great and formidable word that draws him from the warmth of the bed in the quiet house and the warm embrace to push him into the midst of the chaos, between gales and storms, and between the push and pull in people's consciences and in the reality of life alike. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) arose and remained standing for more than twenty years thereafter, never resting or settling down, and never living for himself or his family. He arose and remained standing for the Call of Allah. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) carried on his shoulders the heavy, crushing burden without giving way to it: the burden of the greatest trust on this Earth, the burden of all humanity, the burden of the entire creed, and the burden of struggle and jihad in various fields. He lived in the constant, ongoing battle for more than twenty years, with no concern distracting him from another during this period, ever since he heard the majestic heavenly call and received the terrifying commission. May Allah reward him best on our behalf and on behalf of all humanity. The following pages are but a simple, miniature depiction of this long, arduous struggle carried out by the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) during that period. The Stages and Phases of the Call (*Da'wa*): We can divide the era of the Muhammadan Call – upon its author be peace, blessings, and salutations – into two periods, each distinctly separated from the other: The Meccan Period: Approximately thirteen years. The Medinan Period: Ten full years. Each of these two periods comprises phases, each with distinguishing characteristics, which become clear after careful observation of the circumstances through which the Call passed during both periods. The Meccan Period can be divided into three phases: The Phase of the Secret Call: Three years. The Phase of the Public Declaration of the Call to the People of Mecca: From the beginning of the fourth year of Prophethood to the end of the tenth year. The Phase of the Call Outside Mecca and its Spread Among Them: From the end of the tenth year of Prophethood until his Emigration (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to Medina. As for the phases of the Medinan Period, they will be detailed in their appropriate place. Phase One – The Struggle of the Call Three Years of the Secret Call: It is well known that Mecca was the center of the Arabs' religion. It had the custodians of the Kaaba and the guardians of the idols and statues sacred to all Arabs. Thus, achieving the goal of reform there was more difficult and intense than if it were far away. The matter required a resolve that would not be shaken by calamities and disasters. Hence, it was wise for the Call to be secret in its beginning, so as not to surprise the people of Mecca and provoke them. The First Rank (*Ar-Ra'il Al-Awwal*): It was natural for the Messenger (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to first present Islam to the people closest to him: his household and his friends. He invited them to Islam, and he invited everyone he considered good among those he knew and who knew him—whom he knew for their love of truth and goodness, and who knew him for his commitment to honesty and righteousness. A group of these people responded to him—those who never had a shadow of a doubt about the greatness of the Messenger (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), the nobility of his soul, and the truthfulness of his news. They are known in Islamic history as The First Precursors (As-Sabiqun Al-Awwalun). At the forefront were his wife, the Mother of the Believers Khadija bint Khuwaylid, his freed slave Zayd ibn Thabit ibn Shurahbil Al-Kalbi, his cousin 'Ali ibn Abi Talib – who was a young boy under the Messenger's guardianship – and his close friend Abu Bakr As-Siddiq. These embraced Islam on the very first day of the Call. Then Abu Bakr became active in inviting to Islam. He was a friendly, beloved, and easygoing man, possessing good character and kindness. The men of his people would come to him and enjoy his company due to his knowledge, his trade, and his good companionship. He began inviting those of his people whom he trusted, who frequented him and sat with him. Through his invitation, 'Uthman ibn 'Affan Al-Umawi, Az-Zubayr ibn Al-'Awwam Al-Asadi, 'Abdul-Rahman ibn 'Awf, Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas Az-Zuhriyyani, and Talha ibn 'Ubaydullah At-Taymi embraced Islam. These eight individuals who preceded others were the First Rank and the vanguard of Islam. Among the early Muslims were Bilal ibn Rabah Al-Habashi (the Abyssinian), followed by the Trustworthy of this Nation, Abu 'Ubayda 'Amir ibn Al-Jarrah from the Banu Al-Harith ibn Fihr, Abu Salama ibn 'Abdul-Asad, Al-Arqam ibn Abi Al-Arqam Al-Makhzumiyyan, 'Uthman ibn Maz'un and his two brothers Qudama and 'Abdullah, 'Ubayda ibn Al-Harith ibn Al-Muttalib ibn 'Abd Manaf, Sa'id ibn Zayd Al-'Adawi, and his wife Fatima bint Al-Khattab Al-'Adawiyya, the sister of 'Umar ibn Al-Khattab, Khabbab ibn Al-Aratt, 'Abdullah ibn Mas'ud Al-Hudhali, and others. These were the First Precursors, coming from all the clans of Quraysh. Ibn Hisham counted them as more than forty individuals, although the inclusion of some of them among the First Precursors is subject to deliberation. Ibn Ishaq said: "Then people entered Islam in groups, men and women, until the mention of Islam spread in Mecca and became a topic of conversation. " These individuals embraced Islam secretly. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) would meet with them and guide them to the religion in concealment, as the Call was still individual and secret. The Revelation had become continuous and intense after the descent of the initial verses of Al-Muddaththir. The verses and sections of Surahs revealed during this time were short, with brilliant, powerful breaks (at the ends of verses), and calm, captivating rhythms, consistent with that gentle, whispering atmosphere. They emphasized the betterment and purification of the souls and condemned their contamination with worldly desires. They described Paradise and Hell as though seen with the naked eye, leading the believers into an atmosphere different from the one prevailing in human society at that time. The Prayer (*Salat*): Among the first things revealed was the command for prayer. Muqatil ibn Sulayman said: "In the beginning of Islam, Allah made obligatory the prayer of two units (*rak'at*) in the morning and two units in the evening, " based on the words of Allah the Most High: {AND EXALT WITH THE PRAISE OF YOUR LORD IN THE EVENING AND IN THE EARLY MORNING.} [Ghafir: 55]. Ibn Hajar said: "The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) certainly used to pray before the *Isra'* (Night Journey), and so did his Companions, but there is a difference of opinion as to whether anything from the prayers was obligated before the Five Prayers. It was said that the obligation was a prayer before sunrise and a prayer before sunset. " End of quote. Al-Harith ibn Usama reported through the chain of Ibn Lahi'ah, connected to Zayd ibn Haritha, that when the Revelation was first made to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), Gabriel came to him and taught him the ablution (*Wudu'*). When he finished the ablution, he took a handful of water and sprinkled his private parts with it. Ibn Majah reported a similar meaning. A similar account is reported from Al-Bara' ibn 'Azib and Ibn 'Abbas, and in the hadith of Ibn 'Abbas, "This was among the first obligations. " Ibn Hisham mentioned that when the time for prayer came, the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and his Companions would go into the ravines and conceal their prayer from their people. Abu Talib once saw the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and 'Ali praying and spoke to them about it, but when he understood the reality of the matter, he ordered them to be firm. The News Reaches the Quraysh Generally: It appears from a review of various aspects of the events that the Call (*Da'wa*) – even though it was secret and individual at this stage – had reached the Quraysh, yet they did not pay much attention to it. Sheikh Muhammad Al-Ghazali said: "These reports reached the Quraysh, but they did not heed them. Perhaps they considered Muhammad one of those religious men who spoke about divinity and its rights, as Umayya ibn Abi As-Salt, Quss ibn Sa'ida, 'Amr ibn Nufayl, and their like had done. However, they were wary of his news spreading and his influence extending, and they began to watch the fate of him and his Call over time. " Three years passed, and the Call remained secret and individual. During this period, a group of believers was formed, built upon brotherhood, cooperation, the transmission of the Message, and its establishment. Then the Revelation descended, commissioning the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to openly challenge his people, confront their falsehood, and attack their idols. Phase Two – The Public Call The First Command to Proclaim the Call: The first thing revealed in this regard was the word of Allah the Most High: {AND WARN YOUR NEAREST KINSMEN.} [Ash-Shu'ara: 214]. The Surah in which this verse occurs – Surah Ash-Shu'ara – first mentions the story of Moses (peace be upon him), from the beginning of his prophethood until his emigration with the Children of Israel, their rescue from Pharaoh and his people, and the drowning of Pharaoh's people with him. This story included all the phases Moses (peace be upon him) went through during his call of Pharaoh and his people to Allah. It should be noted that this detail was brought when the Messenger (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was commanded to call his people to Allah, so that he and his Companions would have a model of the denial and persecution they would face when proclaiming the Call, and so that they would be aware of their situation from the beginning of their Call. On the other hand, this Surah mentions the destiny of those who denied the Messengers: the people of Noah, 'Ad, Thamud, the people of Ibrahim, the people of Lot, and the Dwellers of Al-Ayka – in addition to the account of Pharaoh and his people – so that those who were about to deny would know the outcome of their affair and the punishment of Allah they would face if they persisted in denial, and so that the believers would know that the good outcome was for them, not for the deniers. The Call to the Nearest Kinsmen: The first thing our Master Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did after the revelation of this verse was to summon the Banu Hashim. They gathered, along with some men from the Banu Al-Muttalib ibn 'Abd Manaf, totaling forty-five men. Abu Lahab immediately preempted him and said: "These are your paternal uncles and your cousins, so speak and leave the boys. Know that your people, among all the Arabs, do not have the strength to face this. And I am the most worthy of taking care of you. The sons of your father are enough for you. If you persist in what you are doing, it will be easier for them for the clans of the Quraysh to attack you and for the Arabs to support them, than for you to bring upon the sons of your father something worse than what you have brought. " The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) remained silent and did not speak at that gathering. Then he invited them a second time and said: "All praise is due to Allah. I praise Him, seek His help, believe in Him, and rely upon Him. And I bear witness that there is no god but Allah, alone, with no partner. " Then he said: "A scout does not lie to his people. By Allah, other than Whom there is no god, I am the Messenger of Allah to you specifically and to mankind generally. By Allah, you will surely die as you sleep, and you will surely be resurrected as you wake up, and you will surely be held accountable for what you do. It will be Paradise forever or the Fire forever. " Abu Talib said: "How much we desire to assist you, how readily we accept your advice, and how strongly we believe in your words! These are the sons of your father, gathered here. I am but one of them, but I am the quickest to do what you love. Proceed with what you have been commanded. By Allah, I will continue to protect and defend you, but my soul does not allow me to abandon the religion of 'Abdul-Muttalib. " Abu Lahab said: "By Allah, this is a disgrace! Take him before others do! " Abu Talib said: "By Allah, we will defend him as long as we live. " On Mount As-Safa: After the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was assured of Abu Talib's commitment to protect him as he conveyed his Lord's message, he stood one day on As-Safa and cried out: "Ya Sabahah! " (A morning alarm cry). The clans of the Quraysh gathered around him. He called them to Monotheism, belief in his Message, and the Last Day. Al-Bukhari reported a part of this story from Ibn 'Abbas, who said: "When {AND WARN YOUR NEAREST KINSMEN} was revealed, the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) ascended As-Safa and began calling out: 'O Banu Fihr...! O Banu 'Adiyy!' – to the clans of the Quraysh – until they gathered. A man who could not come sent a messenger to see what the matter was. Abu Lahab and the Quraysh came. He said: 'If I were to tell you that cavalry is in the valley, intending to raid you, would you believe me?' They said: 'Yes, we have never known anything from you but truthfulness.' He said: 'Then I am a Warner to you before a severe torment.' Abu Lahab said: 'Perish you for the rest of the day! Is this why you gathered us?' Then {MAY THE HANDS OF ABU LAHAB BE RUINED, AND MAY HE BE RUINED!} [Al-Masad: 1] was revealed." Muslim narrated another part of this story on the authority of Abû Hurayra, may Allah be pleased with him. He said: When this verse was revealed: {AND WARN YOUR CLOSEST KINDRED} [Ash-Shu'ara': 214], the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) called out generally and specifically. He said: "O people of Quraysh, save yourselves from the Fire! O people of Banû Ka'b, save yourselves from the Fire! O Fâtima, daughter of Muhammad, save yourself from the Fire! For by Allah, I possess nothing for you from Allah, except that you have a kinship which I shall maintain (lit. keep it moist with its moisture). " This loud cry is the utmost proclamation. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) made it clear to the people closest to him that believing in this Message is the lifeblood of the connection between him and them, and that the tribal solidarity based on kinship, on which the Arabs relied, melted away in the heat of this warning coming from Allah. * The Proclamation of the Truth and the Reactions of the Polytheists: This voice did not cease its reverberation throughout Makkah until the saying of the Almighty was revealed: {THEREFORE PROCLAIM WHAT YOU ARE COMMANDED, AND TURN AWAY FROM THE POLYTHEISTS} [Al-Hijr: 94]. Thereupon, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) stood up, challenging the superstitions and absurdities of polytheism (Shirk). He spoke of the reality of the idols and their true worthlessness, citing examples of their incapacity, and clearly demonstrating that whoever worships them and takes them as a means between himself and Allah is in manifest error. Makkah erupted with feelings of anger and was stirred by astonishment and denunciation when it heard a voice openly proclaiming the error of the polytheists and idol-worshippers, as if it were a thunderbolt striking the cloud, causing thunder, lightning, and shaking the peaceful atmosphere. Quraysh prepared to resolve this revolution that had suddenly erupted, fearing that it might destroy its traditions and inheritance. They rose because they knew that the meaning of Faith entailed the denial of divinity for anything other than Allah, and that the meaning of Faith in the Message and the Last Day was complete surrender and absolute delegation (to Allah), such that they would have no choice concerning their persons and their wealth, let alone others. This meant the eradication of their sovereignty and arrogance over the Arabs, which was religious in nature, and their inability to fulfill their desires in the face of the pleasure of Allah and His Messenger, as well as their inability to commit the injustices they inflicted upon the lower classes, and the evil deeds they perpetrated morning and evening. They understood this meaning, and their souls refused to accept this disgraceful state, not out of honor or goodness, but rather: {BUT MAN WANTS TO PERSIST IN HIS WICKEDNESS BEFORE HIM} [Al-Qiyâmah: 5]. They understood all of this very well, but what would they do in the face of a truthful, trustworthy man, the highest example of human values and noble morals, for whom they had known no parallel or equal throughout a long period of the history of their fathers and peoples? What would they do? They were perplexed, and they had every right to be. After considering their options, they found no way but to approach his uncle, Abû Tâlib, and ask him to restrain his nephew from what he was doing. To give their request a semblance of seriousness and truth, they decided to say: "The call to abandon their deities, and the claim that they have no benefit or power, is a foul insult and a severe humiliation for them, and it involves disparagement and misguidance for their fathers who were upon this religion. " They found this path and hastened to take it. * -Quraysh's Delegation to Abû Tâlib: Ibn Is-hâq said: Men from the nobles of Quraysh walked to Abû Tâlib and said: "O Abû Tâlib, your nephew has insulted our gods, criticized our religion, mocked our intellect, and declared our fathers misguided. Either restrain him from us, or leave us to deal with him, for you are in disagreement with him just as we are, and we will rid you of him. " Abû Tâlib spoke to them gently and sent them away kindly. They departed from him, and the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) continued as he was, manifesting the religion of Allah and calling to it. * The Consultative Council to Prevent Pilgrims from Hearing the Call: During these days, another matter concerned Quraysh. The open proclamation of the Message had only lasted a few months before the Hajj season approached. Quraysh knew that the Arab delegations would arrive. So, they deemed it necessary to have a word to say to the Arabs concerning Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) so that his message would not have an effect on the souls of the Arabs. They gathered to Al-Walîd ibn Al-Mughîrah to deliberate on that word. Al-Walîd said to them: "Agree upon a single opinion, and do not differ, lest some of you belie others, and your words contradict each other. " They said: "Then you speak. " He said: "Rather, you speak, and I will listen. " They said: "We say: (He is) a soothsayer (Kâhin). " He said: "No, by Allah, he is not a soothsayer. We have seen soothsayers, and he has neither the soothsayer's murmur nor his rhymed prose. " They said: "Then we say: (He is) mad (Majnûn). " He said: "He is not mad. We have seen and known madness. He has none of its choking, its convulsions, or its whispering. " They said: "Then we say: (He is) a poet (Shâ'ir). " He said: "He is not a poet. We have known all poetry: its *Rajaz*, its *Hajaz*, its *Qarîd* (composed), its *Maqbûd* (contracted), and its *Mabsût* (extended), and it is not poetry. " They said: "Then we say: (He is) a sorcerer (Sâhir). " He said: "He is not a sorcerer. We have seen sorcerers and their magic. He has neither their blowing nor their knots. " They said: "Then what should we say? " He said: "By Allah, his speech has a sweetness, its root is a rich branch (of fruit), and its top is full of produce. You will not say anything of this except that it will be known to be false. The closest statement to the truth is to say: 'He is a sorcerer who came with a word that is magic, by which he separates a man from his father, a man from his brother, a man from his wife, and a man from his clan.' " They dispersed from him based on this. Some narrations indicate that when Al-Walîd rejected everything they proposed, they said: "Show us your opinion that is flawless. " He said to them: "Give me time to think about it. " Al-Walîd continued to think until he presented to them the opinion mentioned earlier. It was concerning Al-Walîd that Allah the Almighty revealed sixteen verses of Sûrat Al-Muddaththir, depicting the manner of his thinking: {INDEED, HE THOUGHT AND MADE A DETERMINATION. * SO CURSED IS HE, HOW HE DETERMINED! * AND AGAIN, CURSED IS HE, HOW HE DETERMINED! * THEN HE LOOKED. * THEN HE FROWNED AND LOOKER SOURLY. * THEN HE TURNED AWAY AND WAS ARROGANT. * AND SAID, "THIS IS NOT BUT MAGIC INHERITED [FROM OTHERS]. * THIS IS NOT BUT THE WORD OF A MORTAL. " } [Al-Muddaththir: 18-25]. After the council agreed on this decision, they began to implement it. They sat on the routes of the people when they arrived for the season. No one passed by them except that they warned him against him and mentioned his matter to them. The one who took the lead in this was Abû Lahab. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) would follow the people when they arrived for the season in their dwellings, at 'Ukâdh, Majannah, and Dhû Al-Majâz, calling them to Allah, and Abû Lahab would be behind him saying: "Do not obey him, for he is a Sabian, a liar. " This resulted in the Arabs leaving that season informed about the matter of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and his mention spread throughout all the lands of the Arabs. * Various Methods to Confront the Call: When Quraysh saw that neither this nor that deterred Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) from his Message, they thought again and chose methods to suppress this call, which are summarized as follows: * Scoffing and belittlement, ridicule, denial, and jesting, intended to discourage the Muslims and weaken their morale. They hurled frivolous accusations and foolish insults at the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). They called him mad: {AND THEY SAY, "O YOU UPON WHOM THE REMINDER HAS BEEN SENT DOWN, INDEED, YOU ARE MAD. "} [Al-Hijr: 6]. They labeled him with magic and falsehood: {AND THEY WONDERED THAT THERE HAD COME TO THEM A WARNER FROM AMONG THEMSELVES; AND THE DISBELIEVERS SAID, "THIS IS A MAGICIAN AND A GREAT LIAR. "} [Sâd: 4]. They would send him off and greet him with intense, malevolent looks, and agitated, turbulent emotions: {AND INDEED, THOSE WHO DISBELIEVED WOULD ALMOST SLIP YOU WITH THEIR EYES WHEN THEY HEAR THE REMINDER AND THEY SAY, "INDEED, HE IS MAD. "} [Al-Qalam: 51]. And when he sat with the weak among his companions around him, they would mock them and say: {ARE THESE THE ONES UPON WHOM ALLAH HAS GRANTED FAVOR AMONG US?} [Al-An'âm: 53]. Allah the Almighty said: {IS NOT ALLAH MOST KNOWING OF THE THANKFUL?} [Al-An'âm: 53]. And they were, as Allah informed us: {INDEED, THOSE WHO COMMITTED CRIMES USED TO LAUGH AT THOSE WHO BELIEVED. * AND WHENEVER THEY PASSED BY THEM, THEY WOULD WINK AT EACH OTHER [IN MOCKERY]. * AND WHEN THEY RETURNED TO THEIR PEOPLE, THEY WOULD RETURN JESTING. * AND WHEN THEY SAW THEM, THEY WOULD SAY, "INDEED, THOSE ARE ASTRAY. " * BUT THEY HAD NOT BEEN SENT AS GUARDIANS OVER THEM.} [Al-Mutaffifîn: 29-33]. * Distortion of his teachings and the raising of doubts, the spread of false propaganda, and the publication of weak arguments about these teachings, as well as about his self and his personality, and the exaggeration of all this so that the general public would have no opportunity to ponder his Message. They said about the Qur'an: {TALES OF THE FORMER PEOPLES WHICH HE HAS WRITTEN DOWN, AND THEY ARE RECITED TO HIM MORNING AND AFTERNOON} [Al-Furqân: 5]. {THIS IS NOT BUT A LIE WHICH HE HAS INVENTED, AND OTHER PEOPLE HAVE HELPED HIM WITH IT} [Al-Furqân: 4]. And they said: {IT IS ONLY A HUMAN BEING WHO TEACHES HIM} [An-Nahl: 16]. And they said about the Messenger (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): {WHAT IS THIS MESSENGER THAT EATS FOOD AND WALKS IN THE MARKETS?} [Al-Furqân: 7]. The Qur'an contains many examples of refutations of their arguments, either after quoting them or without quoting them. * Opposing the Qur'an with the tales of the former peoples, and preoccupying the people with them away from it.
