It is reported that An-Nadr ibn Al-Hârith once said to Quraysh: "O people of Quraysh, by Allah, a matter has come upon you for which you have not yet found a trick! Muhammad was among you as a young man, the most pleasing to you, the most truthful in speech, the most trustworthy, until you saw gray hair on his temples, and he brought you what he brought you. You said: 'Sorcerer'. No, by Allah, he is not a sorcerer. We have seen sorcerers, their blowing, and their knots. You said: 'Soothsayer'. No, by Allah, he is not a soothsayer. We have seen soothsayers and their convulsions and heard their rhymed prose. You said: 'Poet'. No, by Allah, he is not a poet. We have seen poetry and heard all its descriptions, its *Hazaj* and its *Rajaz*. You said: 'Mad'. No, by Allah, he is not mad. We have seen madness, and he has none of its choking, its whispering, or its confusion. O people of Quraysh, look into your matter, for, by Allah, a great matter has come upon you. " Then An-Nadr went to Al-Hîrah and learned there the stories of the kings of Persia, the stories of Rustam and Asfandiâr. Thus, when the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) sat in a gathering to remind people of Allah and warn them of His retribution, An-Nadr would follow him and say: "By Allah, Muhammad does not have better stories than me. " Then he would tell them stories about the kings of Persia, Rustam, and Asfandiâr, and then say: "In what way is Muhammad's story better than mine? " A narration from Ibn 'Abbâs states that An-Nadr had bought singing slave girls (Qaynât). He would not hear of a man inclining toward the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) except that he would send one of them to him to feed him, give him drink, and sing for him so that he would have no inclination left for Islam. Concerning him, the saying of the Almighty was revealed: {AND AMONG THE PEOPLE IS HE WHO BUYS WASTEFUL SPEECH TO MISLEAD [OTHERS] FROM THE WAY OF ALLAH} [Luqmân: 6]. * Negotiations by which they tried to make Islam and the Jâhiliyyah (era of ignorance) meet halfway, by having the polytheists abandon some of what they were upon, and the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) abandon some of what he was upon: {THEY WISH THAT YOU WOULD COMPROMISE [IN RELIGION] SO THEY WOULD COMPROMISE} [Al-Qalam: 9]. There is a narration reported by Ibn Jarîr and At-Tabarânî indicating that the polytheists proposed to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) that he should worship their deities for one year, and they would worship his Lord for one year. Another narration by 'Abd ibn Humayd indicates that they said: "If you accepted our deities, we would worship your God. " Ibn Is-hâq narrated with his chain of transmission, saying: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), while circumambulating the Ka'bah, was confronted by Al-Aswad, Al-Muttalib ibn Asad ibn 'Abd Al-'Uzzâ, Al-Walîd ibn Al-Mughîrah, Umayyah ibn Khalaf, and Al-'Âs ibn Wâ'il As-Sahmî – and they were elderly men among their people – and they said: "O Muhammad, come! Let us worship what you worship, and you worship what we worship, and we will share the matter, you and us. If what you worship is better than what we worship, we would have taken our share of it. And if what we worship is better than what you worship, you would have taken your share of it. " Thereupon, Allah the Almighty revealed concerning them: {SAY, "O YOU DISBELIEVERS, * I DO NOT WORSHIP WHAT YOU WORSHIP}... (the entire Sûrah) [Al-Kâfirûn: 1-2]. Allah resolved their ridiculous negotiation with this decisive separation. Perhaps the difference in the narrations is because they attempted this negotiation repeatedly. * The Persecutions: The polytheists gradually implemented the methods we mentioned to stop the Message after its appearance at the beginning of the fourth year of the Prophethood. Weeks and months passed, and they were limited to these methods, not moving on to the path of persecution and torture. But when they saw that these methods were of no benefit in stopping the Islamic Message, they gathered again and formed a committee of twenty-five men from the leaders of Quraysh, chaired by Abû Lahab, the uncle of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). After consultation and reflection, this committee took a decisive resolution against the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and his Companions. It decided to spare no effort in fighting Islam, harming His Messenger, torturing those who entered it, and subjecting them to various forms of punishment and pain. They took this resolution and resolved to implement it. As for the Muslims – especially the weak among them – it was very easy. But as for the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), he was a noble, dignified man with a unique personality that was held in high esteem by the souls of both enemies and friends, so that such a person could only be met with reverence and honor, and only the lowest and most foolish people dared to commit vile and vicious acts against him. Moreover, he was under the protection of Abû Tâlib, and Abû Tâlib was one of the counted men of Makkah, honored in his lineage, honored among the people. No one dared to violate his protection or attack his position. This situation troubled Quraysh, but how long could this prolonged patience last in the face of a Message that sought to eliminate their religious leadership and their worldly prominence? They began the aggressions against the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), with Abû Lahab at the forefront. He had taken this stance against the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) from the very first day before Quraysh even contemplated it. We have previously mentioned what he did to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) at the gathering of Banû Hâshim and what he did at As-Safâ. It is reported in some narrations that – when he was at As-Safâ – he took a stone to strike the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) with it. Abû Lahab had married his two sons, 'Utbah and 'Utaybah, to the two daughters of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), Ruqayyah and Umm Kulthûm, before the Prophethood. When the Prophethood came, he harshly and severely ordered them to divorce them, which they did. When 'Abdullâh – the second son of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) – died, Abû Lahab rejoiced and hurried to his companions, announcing to them that Muhammad had become sterile (*Abtar*). We have already mentioned that Abû Lahab would follow the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) during the Hajj season and in the markets to belie him. Târiq ibn 'Abdillâh Al-Muhâribî reported what indicates that he did not limit himself to denial but would strike him with a stone until his heels bled. Abû Lahab's wife – Umm Jamîl Arwâ bint Harb ibn Umayyah, the sister of Abû Sufyân – was no less hostile to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) than her husband. She would carry thorns and place them on the path of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and at his door at night. She was a foul-mouthed woman who used her tongue against him, prolonged her slander and scheming, fanned the flames of tribulation, and incited a fierce war against the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). That is why the Qur'an described her as the "Carrier of Wood " (*Hammâlat Al-Hatab*). When she heard what had been revealed in the Qur'an about her and her husband, she came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) while he was sitting in the Mosque near the Ka'bah, with Abû Bakr As-Siddîq. In her hand, she held a *Fahr*, which is a handful of stones. When she stood before them, Allah took away her sight of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), so she only saw Abû Bakr. She said: "O Abû Bakr, where is your companion? I have heard that he has satirized me. By Allah, if I find him, I will strike his mouth with this stone. By Allah, I am a poetess too. " Then she said: "To Mudhammam (*the blamed one*), we disobeyed, And his command we rejected, And his religion we hated. " Then she left. Abû Bakr said: "O Messenger of Allah, did you not see that she saw you? " He replied: "She did not see me. Allah took away her sight of me. " Abû Bakr Al-Bazzâr narrated this story. In it, when she stood before Abû Bakr, she said: "Abû Bakr, your companion has satirized us. " Abû Bakr said: "No, by the Lord of this structure (the Ka'bah), he neither speaks poetry nor pronounces it. " She said: "You are truthful. " Abû Lahab did all this while he was the uncle and neighbor of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), his house was adjacent to his. Likewise, others of the Messenger of Allah's neighbors would harm him while he was in his house. Ibn Is-hâq said: The individuals who harmed the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in his house were Abû Lahab, Al-Hakam ibn Abî Al-'Âs ibn Umayyah, 'Uqbah ibn Abî Mu'ayt, 'Adî ibn Hamrâ' Ath-Thaqafî, and Ibn Al-Asdâ' Al-Hudhali – and they were his neighbors. None of them embraced Islam except Al-Hakam ibn Abî Al-'Âs. One of them would throw a stone at him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to hide from them when he prayed. When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was afflicted with that harm, he would carry it out on a stick, stand by his door and say: "O Banû 'Abd Manâf, what kind of neighborliness is this? " Then he would throw it in the street. 'Uqbah ibn Abî Mu'ayt increased his wickedness and malice. Al-Bukhârî narrated on the authority of 'Abdullâh ibn Mas'ûd (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was praying near the Ka'bah, and Abû Jahl and some of his companions were sitting. Some of them said to others: "Which of you will bring the filth of the slaughtered camel of Banû so-and-so and place it on Muhammad's back when he prostrates? " The most wretched among the people ('Uqbah ibn Abî Mu'ayt) stood up, brought it, and waited. When the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) prostrated, he placed it on his back between his shoulders. I was watching, unable to do anything, if only I had power to defend myself. They began to laugh and lean on each other (in joy and arrogance), while the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was in prostration, not raising his head until Fâtima came, threw it off his back, and he raised his head. Then he said: "O Allah, I entrust Quraysh to You, " (three times). That distressed them when he prayed against them, for they believed that the supplication in that land was answered. Then he named: "O Allah, I entrust Abû Jahl to You, and 'Utbah ibn Rabî'ah, Shaybah ibn Rabî'ah, Al-Walîd ibn 'Utbah, Umayyah ibn Khalaf, and 'Uqbah ibn Abî Mu'ayt! " – He named a seventh person, but he did not remember him. – "By the One in whose hand is my soul, I saw those whom the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) named, dead in the pit, the pit of Badr. " Umayyah ibn Khalaf, when he saw the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), would mock and backbite him. Concerning him, the verse was revealed: {WOE TO EVERY SLANDERER AND BACKBITER} [Al-Humazah: 1]. Ibn Hishâm said: The *Humazah* (slanderer) is one who openly insults a man, glares at him, and mocks him. The *Lumazah* (backbiter) is one who secretly blames and harms people. As for his brother Ubayy ibn Khalaf, he and 'Uqbah ibn Abî Mu'ayt were close friends. 'Uqbah once sat with the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and listened to him. When this reached Ubayy, he admonished him, rebuked him, and asked him to spit in the face of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), which he did. Ubayy ibn Khalaf himself crumbled a rotten bone and then blew it in the wind toward the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Al-Akhnas ibn Sharîq Ath-Thaqafî was among those who attacked the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). The Qur'an described him with nine attributes that indicate what he was upon, in the saying of the Almighty: {AND DO NOT OBEY EVERY HABITUAL SWEARER [WHO IS] CONTEMPTIBLE, * A BACKBITER, GOING ABOUT WITH SLANDER, * A PREVENTER OF GOOD, AGGRESSIVE, SINFUL, * CRUEL, AND AFTER THAT, BASEBORN} [Al-Qalam: 10-13]. Abû Jahl would sometimes come to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to hear the Qur'an, then leave without believing, obeying, behaving properly, or fearing (Allah). He would harm the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) with words, hinder people from the path of Allah, and then leave, strutting proudly at what he had done, boasting of the evil he had committed, as if he had done something noteworthy. Concerning him, the verse was revealed: {SO HE NEITHER BELIEVED NOR PRAYED}... etc. He would prevent the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) from praying from the first day he saw him praying in the Sanctuary. Once, he passed by him while he was praying near the station (Maqâm) and said: "O Muhammad, did I not forbid you from this? " He threatened him, and the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) spoke harshly to him and rebuked him. He said: "O Muhammad, with what are you threatening me? By Allah, I have the largest assembly (Nâdî) in this valley! " Then the verse was revealed: {THEN LET HIM CALL HIS ASSEMBLY} [Al-'Alaq: 17]. In one narration, the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) grabbed him by the neck and shook him, saying: {WOE TO YOU, AND WOE! * THEN WOE TO YOU, AND WOE!} [Al-Qiyâmah: 34-35]. The enemy of Allah said: "Are you threatening me, O Muhammad? By Allah, neither you nor your Lord can do anything. I am the most honored of those who walk between its two mountains. " Abû Jahl did not recover from his stupidity after this rebuke, but rather became even more wretched afterward. Muslim reported on the authority of Abû Hurayra: Abû Jahl said: "Does Muhammad rub his face in the dust among you? " It was said: "Yes. " He said: "By Al-Lât and Al-'Uzzâ, if I see him, I will step on his neck and rub his face in the dust. " He came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) while he was praying, intending to step on his neck. They were suddenly surprised to see him retreating on his heels, protecting himself with his hands. They said: "What is wrong with you, O Abâ Al-Hakam? " He said: "Indeed, there is a trench of fire and wings between him and me! " The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "If he had come close to me, the angels would have snatched him limb by limb. " These aggressions against the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), despite the dignity and majesty of his unique personality in the hearts of the common and elite, and despite the protection of Abû Tâlib, the most respected man in Makkah, were serious. But as for the Muslims – especially the weak among them – the measures were harsher and more bitter. At the same time, every tribe began to torture in various ways those of its members who embraced Islam, and those who had no tribe were subjected to various forms of oppression by the rabble and the leaders, the mere mention of which frightens the heart of the patient man. Abû Jahl, if he heard that a man of high status and protection had embraced Islam, would reprimand him, disgrace him, and threaten him with huge losses in wealth and status. If he was weak, he would beat him and incite others against him. The uncle of 'Uthmân ibn 'Affân would wrap him in a mat of palm leaves and then smoke him from underneath. When Mus'ab ibn 'Umayr's mother learned of his Islam, she starved him and expelled him from her house. He had lived the most luxurious life, and his skin began to peel like a snake's. Bilâl was the slave of Umayyah ibn Khalaf Al-Jumahî. Umayyah would put a rope around his neck, then hand him over to the boys who would drag him through the hills of Makkah until the mark of the rope was visible on his neck. Umayyah would tie him tightly, then beat him with a stick. He would force him to sit in the intense heat of the sun, and he would also compel him to starve. Worse than all that, he would take him out when the midday heat was intense, throw him on the scorching sand of Makkah, and then order a huge rock to be placed on his chest, saying: "By Allah, you will remain like this until you die or disbelieve in Muhammad and worship Al-Lât and Al-'Uzzâ. " And Bilâl, in that state, would say: "One, One (Ahad, Ahad)! " One day, Abû Bakr passed by and saw them doing this to him. He bought him for a black slave, or, according to another version, for seven or five ounces of silver, and freed him. 'Ammâr ibn Yâsir (may Allah be pleased with him) was a client of Banû Makhzûm. He, his father, and his mother embraced Islam. The polytheists – with Abû Jahl at their head – would take them out to the open area (Al-Abtah) when the sand was scorching hot and torture them with its heat. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) passed by them while they were being tortured and said: "Patience, O family of Yâsir, for your appointed destination is Paradise! " Yâsir died under the torture, and Abû Jahl stabbed Sumayyah – 'Ammâr's mother – in her private part with a spear, and she died. She was the first martyr in Islam. They intensified the torture against 'Ammâr, sometimes with heat, other times by placing a hot red stone on his chest, and other times by drowning. They said: "We will not leave you until you insult Muhammad or speak well of Al-Lât and Al-'Uzzâ. " He agreed to this under duress and came weeping, apologizing to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Then Allah revealed: {WHOEVER DISBELIEVES IN ALLAH AFTER HIS BELIEF – EXCEPT FOR ONE WHO IS COMPELLED [TO DO SO] WHILE HIS HEART IS FIRM WITH FAITH} [An-Nahl: 106]. Abû Fukayhah – whose name was Aflah – was a slave of Banû 'Abd Ad-Dâr. They would tie a rope to his leg and drag him on the ground. Khabbâb ibn Al-Aratt was a slave of Umm Anmâr bint Sibâ' Al-Khuzâ'iyyah. The polytheists would make him taste various forms of torture. They would grab his hair and pull it, violently twisting his neck. They repeatedly laid him down on burning charcoal, then placed a rock on him so that he could not get up. Zunairah, An-Nahdiyyah and her daughter, and Umm 'Ubayse were slave women who had embraced Islam. The polytheists subjected them to tortures similar to those mentioned. A slave girl of Banû Mu'ammal – a clan of Banû 'Adî – converted. 'Umar ibn Al-Khattâb – who was a polytheist at the time – would beat her, until, tired, he would say: "I only left you out of weariness. " Abû Bakr bought these slave girls and freed them, just as he freed Bilâl and 'Âmir ibn Fuhayrah. The polytheists would wrap some of the Companions in the hides of camels and cows, then throw them into the heat of the scorching sand. They would clothe others in iron coats of mail, then throw them onto a burning rock. The list of those tortured for the sake of Allah is long and very painful. There was no one whose conversion they learned of except that they confronted him and harmed him. * Dâr Al-Arqam: In the face of these persecutions, it was wise for the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to prevent the Muslims from declaring their Islam in word or deed and to meet with them only in secret. If he were to meet with them openly, there is no doubt that the polytheists would prevent him from purifying the Muslims and teaching them the Book and the Wisdom, and this might lead to a clash between the two parties. This actually happened in the fourth year of the Prophethood. The Companions of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to gather in the ravines and pray there secretly. A group of Quraysh disbelievers saw them, insulted them, and fought them. Sa'd ibn Abî Waqqâs struck a man, and his blood flowed. This was the first blood shed in Islam. It is known that if the clash had multiplied and prolonged, it would have led to the destruction and annihilation of the Muslims. Therefore, it was wise to go into hiding. The majority of the Companions concealed their Islam, their worship, their call, and their gatherings. As for the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), he openly proclaimed the Message and worship in the midst of the polytheists, with nothing diverting him from that, but he met with the Muslims in secret for their benefit and the benefit of Islam. Dâr Al-Arqam ibn Abî Al-Arqam Al-Makhzûmî was on As-Safâ. It was away from the eyes and gatherings of the tyrants. He made it a center for his Message and for his meetings with the Muslims from the fifth year of the Prophethood. * The First Hijra to Abyssinia: The persecutions began in the middle or late fourth year of the Prophethood. They started weakly and then continued to intensify day by day and month by month until they became severe and critical in the middle of the fifth year, to the extent that remaining in Makkah became unbearable for them, and this compelled them to think of a trick to save them from this painful torment. In this dark, difficult hour, Sûrat Al-Kahf was revealed in response to questions posed by the polytheists to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). But it contained three stories with eloquent allusions from Allah the Almighty to His believing servants. The story of the Companions of the Cave (*Ashâb Al-Kahf*) guides one to emigrate from the centers of disbelief and aggression when fearing temptation for one's religion, relying on Allah: {AND WHEN YOU HAVE WITHDRAWN FROM THEM AND THAT WHICH THEY WORSHIP EXCEPT ALLAH, SHELTER THEREFORE IN THE CAVE; YOUR LORD WILL SPREAD FOR YOU OF HIS MERCY AND WILL PREPARE FOR YOU FROM YOUR AFFAIR AMENITY} [Al-Kahf: 16]. The story of Al-Khidr and Moses indicates that circumstances do not always unfold or yield results according to their apparent nature. Rather, the matter might be completely the opposite of the apparent. There is a subtle allusion here that the war waged against the Muslims will completely reverse, and these polytheist tyrants – if they do not believe – will be defeated by these weak, repressed Muslims. The story of Dhû Al-Qarnayn indicates that the earth belongs to Allah, and He inherits it to whomever He wills of His servants. And that success is only found on the path of Faith, not disbelief, and that Allah continues to send among His servants – from time to time – one who will save the weak from the Gog and Magog of that time. And that the most deserving of inheriting the earth are the righteous servants of Allah. Then Sûrat Az-Zumar was revealed, alluding to the emigration, and declaring that the earth of Allah is not narrow: {FOR THOSE WHO HAVE DONE GOOD IN THIS WORLD IS GOOD, AND THE EARTH OF ALLAH IS VAST. INDEED, THE PATIENT WILL BE GIVEN THEIR REWARD WITHOUT ACCOUNT} [Az-Zumar: 10]. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) knew that Ashama An-Najâshî, the king of Abyssinia, was a just king, with whom no one was oppressed. So, he commanded the Muslims to emigrate to Abyssinia to flee the tribulations for their religion. In Rajab of the fifth year of the Prophethood, the first group of Companions emigrated to Abyssinia. It consisted of twelve men and four women, led by 'Uthmân ibn 'Affân, accompanied by Sayyidah Ruqayyah, the daughter of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said about them that they were the first household to emigrate for the cause of Allah after Abraham and Lot (peace be upon them). The departure of these individuals was stealthy in the darkness of the night – so that Quraysh would not notice them. They headed to the sea, aiming for the port of Shu'aybah. Destiny provided them with two merchant ships that sailed them to Abyssinia. Quraysh noticed and went out in pursuit of them, but by the time they reached the shore, the Muslims had departed safely, and they settled in Abyssinia, enjoying the best neighborly protection. In Ramadân of the same year, the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) went to the Sanctuary, where there was a large gathering of Quraysh, including their leaders and notables. He stood up among them and suddenly began reciting Sûrat An-Najm. Those disbelievers had not heard the Word of Allah before, because their constant method was to act upon what they had mutually advised each other, by saying: {DO NOT LISTEN TO THIS QUR'AN AND DISTURB [IT] THAT YOU MAY OVERCOME} [Fussilat: 26]. When he surprised them with the recitation of this Sûrah, and magnificent, captivating Divine Words – whose splendor and majesty defy description – struck their ears, they forgot what they were doing, and everyone remained listening to him, thinking of nothing else. Until, at the end of this Sûrah, he recited verses that make hearts fly, and then read: {SO PROSTRATE TO ALLAH AND WORSHIP [HIM]} [An-Najm: 62], and then he prostrated. No one could restrain himself from falling into prostration. In reality, the grandeur of the Truth had cracked the stubbornness in the souls of the arrogant and the mockers, and they could not help but fall in prostration to Allah. They were dismayed when they realized that the majesty of Allah's Word had restrained them, and they had committed the very thing they were striving to erase and eliminate. Reproach and blame poured upon them from all sides, from those polytheists who had not witnessed this scene. At that, they lied about the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and claimed that he had spoken favorably of their idols, saying about them: "Those are the exalted goddesses (*Al-Gharânîq Al-'Ulâ*), and their intercession is hoped for. " They brought this manifest falsehood to excuse their prostration with the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and this is not surprising from a people who concocted lies and prolonged scheming and slander. This news reached the emigrants in Abyssinia, but in a form completely different from its reality. They were informed that Quraysh had embraced Islam. So, they returned to Makkah in Shawwâl of the same year. When they were an hour's journey from Makkah, in broad daylight, and learned the truth of the matter, some of them returned to Abyssinia. None of the rest entered Makkah except secretly or under the protection of a man from Quraysh. Then the affliction and torment from Quraysh intensified against them and against the Muslims, and their tribes fiercely attacked them. The news of the Negus's good protection was hard for Quraysh to bear. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) saw no alternative but to suggest to his Companions to emigrate to Abyssinia once more. This Second Hijra was more difficult than the first, as Quraysh had become vigilant and resolved to thwart it. However, the Muslims were faster, and Allah facilitated their travel. They reached the Negus of Abyssinia before they could be overtaken. This time, eighty-three men emigrated – there is doubt about 'Ammâr being among them – and eighteen or nineteen women. The scholar Muhammad Sulaymân Al-Mansûrfûrî affirmed the former number. * Quraysh's Plot Against the Abyssinian Emigrants: It was unbearable for the polytheists that the emigrants found refuge for themselves and their religion. They chose two strong and intelligent men, 'Amr ibn Al-'Âs and 'Abdullâh ibn Abî Rabî'ah – before they embraced Islam – and sent with them rare gifts for the Negus and his patriarchs. After the two men delivered these gifts to the patriarchs and provided them with arguments by which those Muslims would be expelled, and after the patriarchs agreed to advise the Negus to send them away, they presented themselves to the Negus, offered him the gifts, and spoke to him. They said to him: "O King, some foolish youths have sought refuge in your country. They have abandoned the religion of their people, have not entered your religion, and have brought a religion they invented, which neither we nor you know. The nobles of their people, their fathers, their uncles, and their clans, have sent us to you concerning them, so that you may return them to them, as they know them better and are more aware of what they find fault with and blame them for. " The patriarchs said: "They have spoken the truth, O King. Hand them over to them, so that they may return them to their people and their land. " But the Negus saw that it was necessary to investigate the matter and hear all sides. He sent for the Muslims and summoned them. They came, and they were resolved to speak the truth, whatever the outcome. The Negus asked them: "What is this religion for which you have separated from your people, and which you have not entered into my religion or the religion of any of these faiths? " Ja'far ibn Abî Tâlib – who was the spokesman for the Muslims – said: "O King, we were a people of the Jâhiliyyah (ignorance), we worshipped idols, ate carrion, committed indecencies, cut off kinship ties, and were bad neighbors. The strong among us consumed the weak. We were upon that until Allah sent to us a Messenger from among ourselves, whose lineage, truthfulness, trustworthiness, and chastity we know. He called us to Allah to unify Him and worship Him, and to cast off what we and our fathers used to worship besides Him, of stones and idols. He commanded us to be truthful in speech, to render trusts, to maintain kinship ties, to be good neighbors, and to restrain from unlawful things and bloodshed. He forbade us from indecencies, false testimony, consuming the wealth of the orphan, and slandering chaste women. He commanded us to worship Allah Alone, associating nothing with Him. He commanded us to [observe] prayer, *Zakât*, and fasting. " – He enumerated the matters of Islam to him. – "So, we believed in him, had faith in him, and followed him in what he brought us from the religion of Allah. We worshipped Allah Alone, associating nothing with Him. We forbade what He forbade us and permitted what He permitted us. Our people attacked us, tortured us, and tempted us away from our religion to return us to the worship of idols instead of the worship of Allah the Almighty, and to consider permissible the evil things we used to consider permissible. When they conquered us, oppressed us, constrained us, and came between us and our religion, we came out to your country, chose you over others, desired your protection, and hoped not to be oppressed with you, O King. " The Negus asked him: "Do you have anything with you of what he brought from Allah? " Ja'far said: "Yes! " The Negus said to him: "Then read it to me. " He recited to him the beginning of {KÂF HÂ YÂ 'AYN SÂD} [Maryam: 1]. By Allah, the Negus wept until his beard was soaked, and his patriarchs wept until their Scriptures were soaked when they heard what he recited to them. Then the Negus said to them: "This and what Jesus brought come from the same niche (source). " He said to 'Amr ibn Al-'Âs and his companion: "Go! By Allah, I will never hand them over to you, nor will they be harmed. " – Addressing 'Amr ibn Al-'Âs and his companion. – They left. 'Amr ibn Al-'Âs said to 'Abdullâh ibn Rabî'ah: "By Allah, I will come back to them tomorrow with something about them that will utterly eradicate them. " 'Abdullâh ibn Rabî'ah said to him: "Do not do that, for they have kinship ties, even if they have opposed us. " But 'Amr insisted on his opinion. The next day, he said to the Negus: "O King, they say a grave thing about Jesus, son of Mary. " The Negus sent for them to ask them about their saying concerning the Christ. They were frightened but resolved to speak the truth, whatever the outcome. When they entered upon him and he asked them, Ja'far said to him: "We say about him what our Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) brought us: He is the servant of Allah, His Messenger, His Spirit, and His Word which He cast upon Mary, the Pure Virgin. " The Negus took a stick from the ground and then said: "By Allah, Jesus, son of Mary, did not exceed what you said by the length of this stick. " His patriarchs grumbled. He said: "Even if you grumble, by Allah! " Then he said to the Muslims: "Go, for you are safe (*Shuyûm*) in my land. " – *Ash-Shuyûm* means "the safe ones " in the Abyssinian language. – "Whoever insults you will be fined, whoever insults you will be fined, whoever insults you will be fined. I would not love to have a mountain (*Dibr*) of gold and harm one of you. " – *Ad-Dibr* means "the mountain " in the Abyssinian language. Then he said to his entourage: "Return their gifts to them, for I have no need of them. By Allah, Allah did not take a bribe from me when He restored my kingdom to me, so should I accept a bribe concerning it? And I did not obey the people in it, so should I obey them now? " Umm Salamah, who narrates this story, said: They departed from him disgraced and with their gifts returned to them, and we remained with him in the best abode with the best neighbor. This is the narration of Ibn Is-hâq. Others mentioned that 'Amr ibn Al-'Âs's delegation to the Negus occurred after Badr. Some combined the two by saying that there were two delegations, but the questions and answers reported to have taken place between the Negus and Ja'far in the second delegation are almost the same as those mentioned by Ibn Is-hâq. Furthermore, the content of those questions indicates that they occurred during the first presentation to the Negus. The polytheists' trick failed, and their plot was foiled. They realized that they could only manifest their malice within the limits of their authority. Because of this, a terrifying idea arose among them. They concluded that escaping this "calamity " was impossible without the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) completely stopping his Message, or without executing him. But how could they achieve this when Abû Tâlib protected him and stood between them and him? They decided to confront Abû Tâlib on this matter. * Quraysh Threatens Abû Tâlib: The leaders of Quraysh came to Abû Tâlib and said to him: "O Abû Tâlib, you have age, nobility, and status among us. We asked you to restrain your nephew, but you did not. By Allah, we will not tolerate this anymore, his insulting our fathers, mocking our intellect, and finding fault with our deities. Either restrain him from us, or we will fight you and him over this until one of the two parties perishes. " This threat and severe warning weighed heavily on Abû Tâlib. He sent for the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and said to him: "O my nephew, your people have come to me and said such and such. Have mercy on me and on yourself, and do not burden me with a matter I cannot bear. " The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) thought that his uncle was abandoning him and that he was too weak to support him. He said: "O uncle, by Allah, if they were to place the sun in my right hand and the moon in my left hand on the condition that I abandon this matter – until Allah makes it victorious or I perish pursuing it – I would never abandon it! " Then he sobbed and wept, and got up. When he turned to leave, Abû Tâlib called out to him. When he turned back, he said to him: "Go, my nephew, say what you like. By Allah, I will never hand you over for anything. " And he recited: "By Allah, they shall never reach you with their gathering, Until I am laid, buried in the dust. So proclaim your command; there is no blame on you, And rejoice, and refresh your eyes with that. " * Quraysh Before Abû Tâlib Once More: When Quraysh saw that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was proceeding with his work, they knew that Abû Tâlib refused to abandon the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and that he was resolved to separate from them and be hostile to them in this matter. They went to him with 'Umârah ibn Al-Walîd ibn Al-Mughîrah and said to him: "O Abû Tâlib, this young man is the most vigorous and handsome youth in Quraysh. Take him, and you will have his intellect and support. Adopt him as a son, he is yours. And hand over to us your nephew, this one who has opposed your religion and the religion of your fathers, divided the unity of your people, and mocked their intellect, so that we may kill him. It is one man for one man. " He said: "By Allah, what an evil thing you propose to me! You give me your son for me to feed him for you, and I give you my son for you to kill him? By Allah, this will never happen! " Al-Mut'im ibn 'Adî ibn Nawfal ibn 'Abd Manâf said: "By Allah, O Abû Tâlib, your people have been just to you and have strived to resolve what he has caused. I do not see that you wish to accept anything from them. " He said: "By Allah, you have not been just to me. But you are resolved to forsake me and ally yourselves with the people against me. So, do what you think best. " Historical sources do not mention the time of these two delegations, but it seems, after examining the clues and evidence, that they occurred in the middle of the sixth year of the Prophethood, and that the interval between the two delegations was short. * The Tyrants' Idea to Execute the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): After the failure and disappointment of Quraysh in the two delegations, they returned to their ferocity and torment, more intense than before. During these days, the idea of executing the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in another way arose among their tyrants. This idea and that ferocity were what led to the strengthening of Islam by two noble heroes of Makkah: Hamzah ibn 'Abd Al-Muttalib and 'Umar ibn Al-Khattâb (may Allah be pleased with them). Among that ferocity, it is reported that 'Utaybah ibn Abî Lahab came one day to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and said: "I disbelieve in {By the star when it descends} [An-Najm: 1] and in {The one who approached and descended} [An-Najm: 8]. " Then he attacked him with harm, tore his shirt, and spat in the face of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), but the spittle did not reach him. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) then prayed against him and said: "O Allah, set a dog from among Your dogs upon him. " His prayer (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was answered. 'Utaybah went out one day with a group of Quraysh until they stopped at a place in Syria called Az-Zarqâ'. A lion circled them that night. 'Utaybah began to say: "Woe to my brother! By Allah, it is the one that will devour me, as Muhammad prayed against me! He killed me while he is in Makkah, and I am in Syria! " The lion lunged at him from among the people, seized his head, and slaughtered him. Also among that is the mention that 'Uqbah ibn Abî Mu'ayt stepped on his noble neck while he was in prostration, so much so that his eyes almost bulged out. What indicates that their tyrants wanted to kill him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is what Ibn Is-hâq reported in a long Hadith, saying: Abû Jahl said: "O people of Quraysh, Muhammad has refused everything except what you see: finding fault with our religion, insulting our fathers, mocking our intellect, and insulting our deities. I swear by Allah that I will sit for him with a stone that I can barely lift. If he prostrates in his prayer, I will smash his head with it. Hand me over then, or protect me. Let the Banû 'Abd Manâf do what they want after that. " They said: "By Allah, we will never hand you over for anything. Proceed with what you want. " When morning came, Abû Jahl took a stone as he had described, and then sat for the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), waiting for him. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) went out as he usually did and began to pray. Quraysh had also gone out and sat in their assemblies, waiting to see what Abû Jahl would do. When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) prostrated, Abû Jahl lifted the stone and approached him. When he got close to him, he retreated, defeated, his color changed, having not carried out his intention. Ibn Ishaq said: It was mentioned to me that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: “That is Gabriel (peace be upon him). If he had drawn closer, he would have seized him.” After that, Abu Jahl did to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) what led to the conversion of Hamza (may Allah be pleased with him), as will be related later. As for the tyrants of Quraysh, the idea of execution continued to mature in their hearts. Ibn Ishaq narrated on the authority of Abd Allah ibn Amr ibn al-As, who said: I was present when they gathered in the Hijr (the Kaaba enclosure). They mentioned the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and they said: “We have not seen anything like what we have endured from this man's affair. We have shown great patience regarding him.” While they were like that, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) appeared. He walked until he kissed the Corner (of the Kaaba), then passed them while circumambulating the House (the Kaaba). They insulted him with some words, and I saw the effect of that on the face of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). When he passed them the second time, they insulted him with the like, and I saw the effect on his face. Then, he passed them the third time, and they insulted him with the like. He stopped and said: “Are you listening, O people of Quraysh? By the One in Whose Hand is my soul, I have brought you slaughter!” His words struck the people, so much so that there was no man among them who did not feel as if a bird was sitting upon his head. Even the most hostile among them softened and spoke to him with the best words they could find, saying: “Leave, O Abul-Qasim! By Allah, you were never ignorant.” The next day, they gathered again, discussing his affair, when he appeared to them. They leaped at him as one man and surrounded him. I saw one man take hold of the gathering of his cloak. Abu Bakr stood up for him, weeping and saying: “Would you kill a man because he says, 'My Lord is Allah'?” Then they dispersed from him. Ibn Amr said: That was the worst thing I ever saw Quraysh inflict upon him. End of summary. In a narration by Al-Bukhari on the authority of Urwah ibn Az-Zubayr, he said: I asked Ibn Amr ibn al-As, “Tell me about the severest thing the polytheists did to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him).” He said: While the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was praying in the Hijr of the Kaaba, Uqbah ibn Abi Mu'ayt came forward, put his garment around the Prophet's neck, and strangled him severely. Abu Bakr came forward, took hold of his shoulders, pushed him away from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and said: “Would you kill a man because he says, 'My Lord is Allah'?” In the Hadith of Asma, she said: A cry of alarm came to Abu Bakr, saying: “Go to your companion!” He left our house, wearing his four braids, and he went out saying: “Would you kill a man because he says, 'My Lord is Allah'?” They neglected the Prophet and turned their attention to Abu Bakr. He returned to us, and we could not touch anything of his braids without them coming loose. The Conversion of Hamza (may Allah be pleased with him) : In this atmosphere overcast with the clouds of oppression and tyranny, a flash of light illuminated the path for the oppressed, which was the conversion of Hamza ibn Abd al-Muttalib (may Allah be pleased with him). He embraced Islam in the latter part of the sixth year of the Prophethood, and it is most probable that he embraced Islam in the month of Dhu al-Hijjah. The reason for his conversion was that one day, Abu Jahl passed by the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) near As-Safa, harmed him, and reviled him. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) remained silent, not speaking to him. Then, Abu Jahl struck him on the head with a stone, wounding him until blood flowed, and then he left him for the Quraysh gathering place near the Kaaba and sat with them. A female slave belonging to Abd Allah ibn Jud'an, whose dwelling was on As-Safa, witnessed this. Hamza returned from hunting, carrying his bow, and the slave informed him of what she had seen Abu Jahl do. Hamza became enraged – he was the most honoured and most resolute young man among Quraysh – and rushed out. He stopped for no one, intent on inflicting harm upon Abu Jahl when he met him. When he entered the Mosque, he stood over Abu Jahl and said to him: “O you who makes his buttocks yellow! Do you insult my nephew when I follow his religion?” Then, he struck him with his bow, inflicting a nasty wound. Men from Banu Makhzum – Abu Jahl's tribe – leaped up, and the Banu Hashim – Hamza's tribe – leaped up. Abu Jahl said: “Leave Abu Umara alone, for I did indeed revile his nephew with a terrible insult.” Hamza's conversion was initially the pride of a man who refused to see his ally humiliated. Then, Allah opened his heart, and he held fast to the firmest handhold. The Muslims gained immense pride from him. The Conversion of Umar ibn al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) : Within this atmosphere overcast with the clouds of oppression and tyranny, another flash of light appeared, even brighter and more illuminating than the first: the conversion of Umar ibn al-Khattab. He embraced Islam in Dhu al-Hijjah of the sixth year of the Prophethood, three days after Hamza's conversion (may Allah be pleased with him). The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) had prayed to Allah for his conversion. Al-Tirmidhi narrated from Ibn Umar, and authenticated it, and Al-Tabarani narrated from Ibn Mas'ud and Anas that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: “O Allah, strengthen Islam with the one of the two men You love more: Umar ibn al-Khattab or Abu Jahl ibn Hisham.” The one more beloved to Allah was Umar (may Allah be pleased with him). After reviewing all the narrations regarding his conversion, it appears that the entrance of Islam into his heart was gradual. However, before presenting their summary, we should point out the emotions and feelings that he possessed (may Allah be pleased with him). He (may Allah be pleased with him) was known for his sharp temper and strong resolve. Muslims had suffered various forms of harm from him many times. It appears that conflicting emotions were struggling within him: his respect for the traditions established by his fathers and grandfathers, his indulgence in the pleasures of drinking and amusement he was accustomed to, then his admiration for the steadfastness of the Muslims and their endurance of tribulation for the sake of their belief, and finally, the doubts that assailed him – like any sensible person – that what Islam called for might be nobler and purer than anything else. Therefore, whenever he flared up, he would eventually tire out. The summary of the narrations, combining them, regarding his conversion (may Allah be pleased with him) is that one night he decided to sleep outside his house. He came to the Sanctuary and entered behind the curtain of the Kaaba. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was standing in prayer and had begun reciting Surah *Al-Haqqah* (The Reality). Umar began to listen to the Quran and was amazed by its composition. He said: “I said to myself: By Allah, he is a poet, as Quraysh claimed.” He recited: {Indeed, it is the word of a noble Messenger. And it is not the word of a poet; little do you believe.} [Al-Haqqah: 40-41]. He said: “I said: A soothsayer.” He recited: {Nor is it the word of a soothsayer; little do you remember. [It is] a revelation from the Lord of the worlds.} [Al-Haqqah: 42-43] until the end of the Surah. He said: “Then Islam fell into my heart.” This was the first planting of the seed of Islam in his heart. However, the outer layer of *Jahiliyyah* (pre-Islamic ignorance) inclinations, traditional tribal partisanship, and pride in the religion of the ancestors predominated over the core truth that his heart was whispering. So, he remained zealous in his actions against Islam, heedless of the feeling lurking behind this layer. Because of his sharp temper and excessive enmity towards the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), he went out one day, wearing his sword, intending to eliminate the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). He was met by Nu'aym ibn Abd Allah An-Nahham Al-'Adawi, or a man from Banu Zuhrah, or a man from Banu Makhzum, who asked: “Where are you heading, O Umar?” He replied: “I want to kill Muhammad.” The man said: “How will you be safe from Banu Hashim and Banu Zuhrah after killing Muhammad?” Umar said to him: “I only see you as having apostatized and abandoned your religion.” The man replied: “Should I not tell you of something amazing, O Umar? Your sister and your brother-in-law have indeed apostatized and abandoned your religion.” Umar walked in a rage until he reached them. Khabbab ibn al-Aratt was with them, holding a parchment containing {Ta-Ha} and reciting it to them – he used to visit them and teach them the Quran. When Khabbab heard Umar's footsteps, he hid inside the house, and Fatima – Umar's sister – concealed the parchment. Umar had heard Khabbab's recitation to them when he approached the house. When he entered, he asked: “What is this murmuring I heard coming from you?” They replied: “It was just a conversation we were having amongst ourselves.” He said: “Perhaps you two have apostatized!” His brother-in-law said to him: “O Umar, what if the truth lies in a religion other than yours?” Umar leaped upon his brother-in-law and trod on him severely. His sister came to lift him off her husband, and Umar struck her a blow with his hand, bloodying her face – in Ibn Ishaq's narration, he struck and wounded her. She said, angrily: “O Umar, if the truth lies in a religion other than yours, I bear witness that there is no god but Allah, and I bear witness that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah!” When Umar gave up, and saw the blood on his sister, he regretted and was ashamed. He said: “Give me this book you have so I may read it.” His sister replied: “You are unclean, and none but the purified may touch it. Stand up and wash yourself (perform a ritual bath).” He stood up and washed himself. Then he took the book and read {In the Name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful}. He said: “Good and pure Names.” Then he read {Ta-Ha} until he reached His saying: {Indeed, I am Allah. There is no god besides Me, so worship Me and establish prayer for My remembrance.} [Ta-Ha: 14]. He said: “How beautiful and noble are these words! Guide me to Muhammad.” When Khabbab heard Umar's words, he came out of the house and said: “Rejoice, O Umar! I hope that you are the one for whom the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) prayed on Thursday night (O Allah, strengthen Islam with Umar ibn al-Khattab or with Abu Jahl ibn Hisham).” The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was in the house at the foot of As-Safa. Umar took his sword and strapped it on. Then he set out until he reached the house. He knocked on the door. A man stood looking through the crack of the door and saw him with his sword strapped on. He informed the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). The people gathered. Hamza asked them: “What is the matter with you?” They said: “Umar.” Hamza said: “And what about Umar? Open the door for him. If he has come desiring good, we will bestow it upon him; and if he has come desiring evil, we will kill him with his own sword.” The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was inside, receiving revelation. He came out to Umar and met him in the courtyard. He took hold of the edges of his cloak and the straps of his sword, then pulled him with a jerk and said: “Will you not desist, O Umar, until Allah sends down upon you the disgrace and punishment that He sent down upon Al-Walid ibn al-Mughirah? O Allah, this is Umar ibn al-Khattab. O Allah, strengthen Islam with Umar ibn al-Khattab.” Then Umar said: “I bear witness that there is no god but Allah, and that you are the Messenger of Allah.” He embraced Islam, and the people of the house pronounced a *Takbir* (Allah is Greater) that the people of the Mosque heard. Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) was a man of indomitable resolve. His conversion created an uproar among the polytheists, filled with humiliation and disgrace, and clothed the Muslims with pride, honour, and joy. Ibn Ishaq narrated with his chain of transmission from Umar, who said: “When I embraced Islam, I remembered who among the people of Mecca was the most hostile to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him).” He said: “I thought: Abu Jahl. So, I went and knocked on his door. He came out to me and said: 'Welcome. What brings you?' I said: 'I came to inform you that I have believed in Allah and His Messenger Muhammad, and I have believed in what he has brought.'” He said: “He slammed the door in my face and said: 'May Allah curse you, and curse what you have brought.'” Ibn al-Jawzi mentioned that Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) said: “When a man embraced Islam, other men would cling to him, striking him, and he would strike them.” He said: “When I embraced Islam, I went to my maternal uncle, Al-As ibn Hashim, and informed him, but he went back into his house.” He said: “I also went to a man from the leaders of Quraysh, perhaps Abu Jahl, and informed him, and he went back into his house.” Ibn Hisham, and likewise Ibn al-Jawzi in a summarized form, mentioned that when he embraced Islam, he went to Jamil ibn Ma'mar Al-Jumahi – who was the quickest of Quraysh to spread news – and informed him that he had embraced Islam. Jamil shouted at the top of his voice that Ibn al-Khattab had apostatized. Umar – who was behind him – said: “He lies, I have only embraced Islam.” They rushed upon him, and he kept fighting them, and they fighting him, until the sun stood over their heads. Umar became exhausted and sat down. They stood over his head, and he said: “Do whatever you want! I swear by Allah that if we were three hundred men, we would have left it to you, or you would have left it to us.” After that, the polytheists marched to his house, intending to kill him. Al-Bukhari narrated from Abd Allah ibn Umar who said: While he – meaning Umar – was in the house, fearful, Al-As ibn Wa'il As-Sahmi, Abu Amr, came to him, wearing a *sabra* cloak and a shirt trimmed with silk. He was from Banu Sahm, our allies during the *Jahiliyyah*. He asked him: “What is the matter with you?” He replied: “Your people claim that they will kill me if I embrace Islam.” Al-As said: “No one can reach you.” – After he said that, Umar felt safe. Al-As went out and met the people who were streaming in the valley. He asked: “Where are you going?” They replied: “This Ibn al-Khattab who has apostatized.” He said: “No one can reach him.” So, the people turned back. In another wording, in Ibn Ishaq's narration, it is said: “By Allah, it was as if a cloth had been stripped from him (Umar).” This concerns the polytheists. As for the Muslims, Mujahid narrated from Ibn Abbas, who said: I asked Umar ibn al-Khattab, “Why were you named Al-Farooq (the Distinguisher)?” He replied: “Hamza embraced Islam three days before me.” – Then he narrated to him the story of his conversion and said at the end: “I said – meaning, when I embraced Islam – O Messenger of Allah, are we not upon the truth, whether we die or live?” He said: “Yes, by the One in Whose Hand is my soul, you are upon the truth whether you die or live.” He said: “I asked: Then why the concealment? By the One Who sent you with the truth, we will surely go out!” So, he led us out in two rows, Hamza in one and I in the other, with a rustling sound like the rustling of flour, until we entered the Mosque. He said: “I looked at Quraysh and at Hamza, and a depression overcame them that they had never felt before.” So, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) named me Al-Farooq that day. Ibn Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) used to say: “We were not able to pray near the Kaaba until Umar embraced Islam.” Suhayb ibn Sinan Ar-Rumi (may Allah be pleased with him) said: “When Umar embraced Islam, Islam was manifested, and the call to it was made openly. We sat in circles around the House, we circumambulated the House, we took our rights from those who were harsh towards us, and we responded to some of their attacks.” Abd Allah ibn Mas'ud said: “We have been respected ever since Umar embraced Islam.” The Representative of Quraysh before the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) : After the conversion of these two noble heroes – Hamza ibn Abd al-Muttalib and Umar ibn al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with them) – the clouds began to clear, and the polytheists awoke from their intoxication of inflicting torment and punishment upon the Muslims. They attempted a negotiation with the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) by lavishly offering him everything he might desire, so that he would cease his call. These poor souls did not realize that everything the sun rises upon was not worth the wing of a mosquito compared to his call. They failed and were frustrated in what they intended. Ibn Ishaq said: Yazid, Ziyad related to me from Muhammad ibn Ka'b Al-Qurazi, who said: I was told that Utbah ibn Rabi'ah, who was a chief, said one day while he was in the Quraysh gathering place and the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was sitting alone in the Mosque: “O people of Quraysh, should I not go to Muhammad? I will speak to him and offer him proposals, perhaps he will accept some of them, and we will give him whatever he wants, and he will leave us alone.” This was after Hamza (may Allah be pleased with him) had embraced Islam, and they saw the Companions of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) increasing in number. They said: “Yes, O Abu al-Walid, go to him and speak with him.” Utbah stood up and went to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) until he sat beside him. He said: “O my nephew, you are among us in the high position in the clan and in the lineage that you know. But you have brought to your people a great matter by which you have divided their unity, deemed their dreams foolish, criticized their gods and their religion, and disbelieved in your ancestors who have passed away. So, listen to me. I will propose things to you; consider them, perhaps you will accept some of them.” The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: “Speak, O Abu al-Walid, I am listening.” He said: “O my nephew, if by this matter you only desire wealth, we will gather for you from our wealth so that you become the richest of us. If you desire honour, we will make you our chief so that we do not decide any matter without you. And if you desire kingship, we will make you our king. And if what comes to you is a spirit that you see and cannot repel from yourself, we will seek a remedy for you and spend our wealth on it until we cure you of it, for sometimes an affiliated spirit may overcome a man until he is treated for it,” – or similar words. When Utbah finished, and the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was listening to him, he said: “Have you finished, O Abu al-Walid?” He replied: “Yes.” The Prophet said: “Then listen to me.” He said: “I will.” Then the Prophet recited: {In the Name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. Hâ, Mîm. A revelation from the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. A Book whose verses have been detailed, an Arabic Quran for a people who know. A bearer of good news and a warner. But most of them turn away, so they do not hear. And they say: 'Our hearts are within coverings from that to which you invite us.'} [Fussilat: 1-5]. Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) continued reciting it to him. When Utbah heard it from him, he listened intently, resting his hands behind his back, leaning on them to hear. Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) reached the verse of prostration in it and prostrated. Then he said: “O Abu al-Walid, you have heard what you have heard, so it is up to you.” Utbah stood up and went back to his companions. Some of them said to others: “We swear by Allah, Abu al-Walid has come back with a different face than the one he left with.” When he sat with them, they asked: “What is behind you, O Abu al-Walid?” He replied: “What is behind me is that I heard a speech. By Allah, I have never heard anything like it! By Allah, it is neither poetry, nor magic, nor soothsaying. O people of Quraysh, obey me and leave it to me: leave this man alone with what he is doing and isolate yourselves from him. For, by Allah, the speech I heard from him will have a great consequence. If the Arabs deal with him, you will be rid of him by others. And if he prevails over the Arabs, his kingship is your kingship, and his honour is your honour, and you will be the happiest of people because of him.” They said: “By Allah, O Abu al-Walid, he has bewitched you with his tongue.” He said: “This is my opinion about him, so do what you think best.” In another narration, Utbah listened until the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) reached the saying of Allah (the Exalted): {But if they turn away, then say: 'I have warned you of a thunderbolt like the thunderbolt of 'Ad and Thamûd.'} [Fussilat: 13]. He stood up, terrified, and placed his hand over the mouth of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), saying: “I implore you by Allah and the bond of kinship!” This was out of fear that the warning would fall. He went to the people and said what he said. Abu Talib Gathers Banu Hashim and Banu Abd al-Muttalib: The course of circumstances changed, and situations and conditions were altered, but Abu Talib did not cease to fear ill-will from the polytheists towards his nephew. He considered the past events – the polytheists had threatened him with combat, then they had tried to negotiate the exchange of his nephew for Umara ibn al-Walid to kill him, Abu Jahl had gone to his nephew with a stone to crush him, Uqbah ibn Abi Mu'ayt had strangled his nephew with his cloak and almost killed him, Ibn al-Khattab had gone out with a sword to eliminate his nephew – Abu Talib pondered these events and sensed an air of evil that made his heart tremble. He became certain that the polytheists were determined to violate their pledge of protection, determined to kill his nephew. What good would Hamza or Umar or others be if one of the polytheists suddenly rushed upon his nephew? This became certain to Abu Talib, and it was only the truth, for they had unanimously agreed to kill the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) openly. There is an allusion to this consensus in the saying of Allah (the Exalted): {Or have they determined [upon] a matter? Then indeed, We are determining [it].} [Az-Zukhruf: 79]. So, what was Abu Talib to do? When he saw the coalition of Quraysh against his nephew, he stood up among his family from Banu Hashim and Banu al-Muttalib, descendants of Abd Manaf, and called them to uphold his stand of protecting his nephew and standing up for him. Both their Muslims and their disbelievers answered him out of zeal for the Arab covenant of protection, except for his brother, Abu Lahab, who left them and joined Quraysh. The Last Delegation of Quraysh to Abu Talib The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) left the mountain pass (*Shi'b*) and continued to act according to his nature. Although Quraysh had ceased the boycott, they remained acting according to their nature of pressuring the Muslims and obstructing the path of Allah. As for Abu Talib, he continued to protect his nephew, but he was over eighty years old. The continuous pains and immense events over the years – especially the siege in the pass – had weakened and enfeebled his joints and broken his resolve. Only a few months after his departure from the pass, he was overtaken by sickness, and it intensified. At that point, the polytheists feared a bad reputation among the Arabs if they committed an outrage against his nephew after his death. They tried one more time to negotiate with the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in his presence, and to offer some of what they had refused to give before. Thus, they formed a delegation, which was their last, to Abu Talib. Ibn Ishaq and others said: When Abu Talib fell ill, and Quraysh learned of his grave condition, some of Quraysh said to others: “Hamza and Umar have embraced Islam, and the affair of Muhammad has spread throughout all the tribes of Quraysh. Let us go to Abu Talib, so that he may take a pledge from his nephew and give us a pledge from him. By Allah, we do not feel safe that they will seize our authority from us.” In another wording: “We fear that this old man may die and something happen to him, and the Arabs would fault us, saying they left him alone until his uncle died, then they seized him.” They went to Abu Talib and spoke to him. They were the chiefs of his people: Utbah ibn Rabi'ah, Shaybah ibn Rabi'ah, Abu Jahl ibn Hisham, Umayyah ibn Khalaf, and Abu Sufyan ibn Harb, among other men of their nobility – about twenty-five men. They said: “O Abu Talib, you are among us in the position you know, and what you see has befallen you, and we fear for you. You know what is between us and your nephew. Summon him, take a pledge for him from us, and take a pledge for us from him, so that he will leave us alone, and we will leave him alone, and he will leave us our religion, and we will leave him his religion.” Abu Talib sent for him, and he came. Abu Talib said: “O my nephew, these are the chiefs of your people. They have gathered for you, to offer you (something) and to take (a pledge) from you.” He then informed him of what they had said and their proposal of mutual non-aggression. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to them: “What do you think if I gave you one word, by which you would possess the Arabs, and by which the non-Arabs would submit to you?” In one wording, addressing Abu Talib, he said: “I want them to utter one word by which the Arabs will submit to them, and by which the non-Arabs will pay them the *Jizyah* (tribute).” In another wording, he said: “O my uncle, would you not invite them to what is better for them?” He asked: “And what do you invite them to?” He replied: “I invite them to utter one word by which the Arabs will submit to them, and by which they will possess the non-Arabs.” And in the wording of Ibn Ishaq's narration: “One word you utter, by which you will possess the Arabs, and by which the non-Arabs will submit to you.” When he spoke these words, they paused and were bewildered, not knowing how to refuse this single word that was so beneficial and far-reaching. Then Abu Jahl said: “What is it? By your father, we will give it to you and ten times its like!” He said: “You say: 'There is no god but Allah,' and you renounce what you worship besides Him.” They clapped their hands, then said: “Do you want, O Muhammad, to make the gods into one God? Your affair is truly astonishing!” Then some of them said to others: “By Allah, this man will not give you anything you want. So, go and hold fast to the religion of your fathers until Allah judges between you and him.” Then they dispersed. Concerning these very people, the saying of Allah (the Exalted) was revealed: {Sâd. By the Quran, full of Reminder. But those who disbelieve are in pride and dissension. How many generations have We destroyed before them of a time, and they cried out, but there was not a time to escape. And they wonder that a warner has come to them from among themselves; and the disbelievers say: 'This is a sorcerer and a liar. Has he made the gods [into] one God? Indeed, this is a remarkable thing.' And the eminent among them went forth, [saying], 'Continue and be patient over your gods. Indeed, this is a thing intended. We have not heard of this in the latest religion. This is not but an invention.'} [Sâd: 1-7]. The Year of Sorrow – The Death of Abu Talib: The illness intensified for Abu Talib, and it was not long before death came to him. His death occurred in Rajab of the tenth year of the Prophethood, six months after leaving the pass. It is also said: He died in the month of Ramadan, three days before the death of Khadijah (may Allah be pleased with her). In *Sahih* (authentic collection) from Al-Musayyab, when Abu Talib was at the point of death, the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) entered upon him, and Abu Jahl was present. The Prophet said: “O my uncle, say: 'There is no god but Allah,' a word with which I will argue for you before Allah.” Abu Jahl and Abd Allah ibn Abi Umayyah said: “O Abu Talib, do you renounce the religion of Abd al-Muttalib?” They kept speaking to him until the last thing he said to them was that he was upon the religion of Abd al-Muttalib. Then the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: “I will ask forgiveness for you as long as I am not forbidden to do so.” Then the verse was revealed: {It is not for the Prophet and those who have believed to ask forgiveness for the polytheists, even if they were relatives, after it has become clear to them that they are companions of the Hellfire.} [At-Tawbah: 113], and the verse was revealed: {Indeed, you do not guide whom you love.} [Al-Qasas: 56]. There is no need to explain the protection and support that Abu Talib gave. He was the fortress with which the Islamic call was protected from the attacks of the chiefs and the ruffians. However, he remained upon the religion of the elders of his ancestors and did not achieve complete success. In the *Sahih*, Al-Abbas ibn Abd al-Muttalib said to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): “What benefit did you bring to your uncle, for he used to protect you and get angry on your behalf?” He replied: “He is in a shallow puddle of fire. If it were not for me, he would have been in the lowest level of the Fire.” On the authority of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, he heard the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) – when his uncle was mentioned – say: “Perhaps my intercession will benefit him on the Day of Resurrection, and he will be placed in a shallow puddle of fire that reaches his ankles.” Khadijah goes to the Mercy of Allah: About two months, or three days, after the death of Abu Talib – according to the difference of opinion – Umm al-Mu'minin Khadijah al-Kubra (may Allah be pleased with her) died. Her death occurred in the month of Ramadan of the tenth year of the Prophethood. She was sixty-five years old, and the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was fifty years old at that time. Khadijah was one of the great blessings of Allah upon the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). She remained with him for a quarter of a century, comforting him in his moments of anxiety, supporting him in his most critical times, helping him convey his message, sharing with him the bitter hardships of *Jihad*, and consoling him with her person and her wealth. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: “She believed in me when people disbelieved in me, she accepted me as truthful when people called me a liar, she shared her wealth with me when people deprived me, and Allah granted me children from her, and denied them from others.” In the *Sahih*, on the authority of Abu Hurayrah, he said: Gabriel came to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and said: “O Messenger of Allah, this is Khadijah, she is coming, and she has with her a vessel containing seasoning, food, or drink. When she comes to you, convey to her the greetings from her Lord, and give her the good news of a house in Paradise made of hollow, polished pearls (or reeds), where there will be neither noise nor toil.” The Accumulation of Sorrows: These two painful events occurred within a few days. Feelings of grief and pain shook the heart of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Then, the calamities from his people continued to befall him. They became more daring towards him, openly inflicting punishment and harm after Abu Talib's death. His grief increased upon grief, so much so that he despaired of them. He went out to At-Ta'if, hoping that they would respond to his call, or give him refuge and support against his people. But he found neither shelter nor supporter. Moreover, they harmed him with the severest of injuries, inflicting upon him what his own people had not inflicted. The pressure from the people of Mecca on the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) intensified, and it also intensified upon his Companions, to the extent that his companion Abu Bakr As-Siddiq (may Allah be pleased with him) resorted to emigration from Mecca. He set out until he reached Bark al-Ghimad, intending to go to Abyssinia, but Ibn Ad-Dughunnah brought him back under his protection. Ibn Ishaq said: When Abu Talib died, Quraysh inflicted upon the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) such harm as they had not dared to hope for during Abu Talib's lifetime. A fool among the fools of Quraysh intercepted him and scattered dust upon his head. He entered his house with the dust on his head. One of his daughters stood up and began washing the dust from his head while weeping. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to her: “Do not weep, my little daughter, for Allah will protect your father.” He also said during this time: “Quraysh did not do anything to me that I disliked until Abu Talib died.” Because of the succession of such pains in this year, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) named it The Year of Sorrow, and it became known by this title in history. Marriage to Sawdah (may Allah be pleased with her) : In Shawwal of this same year, the 10th year of the Prophethood, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) married Sawdah bint Zam'ah. She was one of those who embraced Islam early and had participated in the second emigration to Abyssinia. Her husband, As-Sakran ibn Amr, had embraced Islam and emigrated with her, but he died in Abyssinia or after returning to Mecca. When her waiting period ended, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) proposed to her and married her. She was the first woman he married after the death of Khadijah. After several years, she gifted her turn to A'ishah. The Isra and the Mi'raj (The Night Journey and the Ascension) While the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was in this phase where his call was carving a path between success and persecution, and faint stars were glimmering on distant horizons, the event of the Isra and the Mi'raj occurred. There is a difference of opinion regarding the exact timing of the event: It was said: The Isra took place in the year Allah honoured him with Prophethood. This was the view chosen by At-Tabari. It was said: It was five years after the beginning of the Prophetic Mission. This was the preferred view of An-Nawawi and Al-Qurtubi. It was said: It was on the night of the twenty-seventh of Rajab in the 10th year of the Prophethood. This was the view chosen by the scholar Al-Mansurpuri. It was said: Sixteen months before the Hijra, meaning in the month of Ramadan of the 12th year of the Prophethood. It was said: One year and two months before the Hijra, meaning in Muharram of the 13th year of the Prophethood. It was said: One year before the Hijra, meaning in Rabi' al-Awwal of the 13th year of the Prophethood. The first three opinions are refuted by the fact that Khadijah (may Allah be pleased with her) died in Ramadan of the tenth year of the Prophethood, and her death occurred before the five daily prayers were prescribed. It is unanimously agreed that the five prayers were made obligatory on the night of the Isra. As for the remaining three opinions, I found nothing to prefer one over the others, except that the context of Surah *Al-Isra* (The Night Journey) indicates that the Isra was very late. The imams of Hadith narrated the details of this event. We summarize them as follows: Ibn al-Qayyim said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was transported by night, with his body according to the most authentic view, from the Sacred Mosque (Mecca) to Al-Aqsa Mosque (Jerusalem), riding Al-Burâq, accompanied by Gabriel (peace and blessings be upon them). He dismounted there, prayed as the Imam of the Prophets, and tied Al-Burâq to the ring of the Mosque door. Then, he ascended that night from Jerusalem to the first Heaven. Gabriel requested the opening for him, and it was opened. There he saw Adam, the father of mankind. He greeted him, and Adam welcomed him, returned the greeting, and acknowledged his Prophethood. Allah showed him the souls of the martyrs on his right and the souls of the wretched on his left. Then, he ascended to the second Heaven. Gabriel requested the opening for him, and it was opened. There he saw Yahya ibn Zakariyyah and 'Isa ibn Maryam (John and Jesus). He met them and greeted them. They returned the greeting, welcomed him, and acknowledged his Prophethood. Then, he ascended to the third Heaven. There he saw Yusuf (Joseph). He greeted him. He returned the greeting, welcomed him, and acknowledged his Prophethood. Then, he ascended to the fourth Heaven. There he saw Idris. He greeted him, welcomed him, and acknowledged his Prophethood. Then, he ascended to the fifth Heaven. There he saw Harun ibn 'Imran (Aaron). He greeted him, welcomed him, and acknowledged his Prophethood. Then, he ascended to the sixth Heaven. There he met Musa ibn 'Imran (Moses). He greeted him, welcomed him, and acknowledged his Prophethood. When he passed him, Musa wept. He was asked: “What makes you weep?” He replied: “I weep because a young man sent after me will enter Paradise with more of his community than will enter with my community.” Then, he ascended to the seventh Heaven. There he met Ibrahim (Abraham) (peace be upon him). He greeted him, welcomed him, and acknowledged his Prophethood. Then, he was raised to Sidrat al-Muntaha (the Lote Tree of the Utmost Boundary), and then Al-Bayt al-Ma'mur (the Frequented House) was raised up for him.
