Then, he ascended to Al-Jabbâr (the All-Powerful), exalted be His Majesty. He drew near to Him until he was at the distance of two bow lengths or nearer. Allah then revealed to His servant what He revealed, and He obligated fifty prayers upon him. He returned until he passed Musa. Musa asked him: “What were you commanded?” He replied: “Fifty prayers.” Musa said: “Your community will not be able to bear that. Return to your Lord and ask Him for a reduction for your community.” The Prophet looked at Gabriel, as if consulting him about that. He gestured: “Yes, if you wish.” Gabriel ascended with him until he reached Al-Jabbâr (Blessed and Exalted be He), who was in His place – this is the wording of Al-Bukhari in some narrations. He removed ten prayers from him. Then, he descended until he passed Musa, and informed him. Musa said: “Return to your Lord and ask for a reduction.” He kept going back and forth between Musa and Allah (Mighty and Majestic) until He made them five. Musa ordered him to return and ask for a reduction. The Prophet said: “I am ashamed of my Lord. I am content and submit.” When he moved away, a caller cried out: “I have confirmed My obligation and lightened it for My servants.” End of quote. Ibn al-Qayyim then mentioned the difference of opinion regarding the Prophet's vision (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) of his Lord (Blessed and Exalted be He), and then mentioned the words of Ibn Taymiyyah in this regard. The conclusion of the research is that the vision with the eye is not established as evidence, and it is a saying that none of the Companions upheld. As for what was narrated from Ibn Abbas concerning the absolute vision and the vision with the heart, the former does not contradict the latter. He then said: “As for His saying (the Exalted) in Surah *An-Najm* (The Star): {Then he approached and descended} [An-Najm: 8], this ‘drawing near’ is different from the one in the Isra story. The ‘drawing near’ in Surah *An-Najm* is the drawing near and descent of Gabriel, as 'A'ishah and Ibn Mas'ud said, and the context indicates it. As for the drawing near and descent in the Hadith of the Isra, that is explicit that it is the drawing near and descent of the Lord (Blessed and Exalted be He). Surah *An-Najm* does not address that. Rather, it mentions that he saw him (Gabriel) a second time at Sidrat al-Muntaha. This is Gabriel, whom Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) saw in his (true) form twice: once on earth, and once at Sidrat al-Muntaha. And Allah knows best.” End of quote. The incident of the splitting of his chest (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) also occurred this time. During this journey, he saw numerous things. He was offered milk and wine. He chose the milk. It was said to him: “You have been guided to the *Fitrah* (primordial nature) or you have attained the *Fitrah*. If you had taken the wine, your community would have been misguided.” He saw four rivers in Paradise: two visible and two hidden. The two visible ones are the Nile and the Euphrates. This means that his message would be established in the fertile valleys of the Nile and the Euphrates, and its people would be the carriers of Islam generation after generation. It does not mean that the water of the two rivers originates from Paradise. He saw Malik, the keeper of the Fire, who did not smile, and whose face showed neither cheerfulness nor joy. He also saw Paradise and the Fire. He saw the wrongful devourers of the property of orphans. They had lips like the lips of camels. Chunks of fire, like boulders, were thrown into their mouths and came out of their posteriors. He saw the devourers of usury. They had large bellies because of which they could not move from their place, and the people of Pharaoh passed by when they were presented to the Fire, trampling upon them. He saw the fornicators. They had good, fat meat before them, and next to it, thin, stinking meat. They were eating the thin, stinking meat and leaving the good, fat meat. He saw the women who introduced to men children who were not their own. He saw them suspended by their breasts. He saw a caravan of the people of Mecca coming and going, and he guided them to a camel that had run away from them, and he drank their water from a covered vessel while they were sleeping, then left the vessel covered. This became proof of the truth of his claim on the morning of the night of the Isra. Ibn al-Qayyim said: When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) reached his people in the morning, he informed them of what Allah (Mighty and Majestic) had shown him of His greater signs. Their denial of him intensified, as did their harm and pressure against him. They asked him to describe Al-Aqsa Mosque. Allah made it visible to him, so he saw it clearly. He began to inform them of its signs, and they could not refute anything he said. He informed them about their caravan on its journey and return, informed them of the time of its arrival, and informed them about the camel that was leading it. And the matter was exactly as he said. But that only increased their aversion, and the unjust refused everything but disbelief. It is said that Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with him) was named As-Siddiq (the Truthful) because of his confirmation of this event when the people denied it. The most concise and greatest justification for this journey is the saying of Allah (the Exalted): {That We might show him some of Our signs.} [Al-Isra: 1]. This is the way of Allah with the Prophets. He said: {And thus did We show Abraham the realm of the heavens and the earth that he would be among the firm believers.} [Al-An'am: 75], and He said to Moses: {That We might show you [some] of Our greatest signs.} [Ta-Ha: 23]. The purpose of this will is explained by His saying: {that he would be among the firm believers.} After the Prophets' knowledge is based on seeing the signs, they attain a certainty of conviction that cannot be estimated. Hearing is not like seeing. They can then endure in the path of Allah what others cannot endure, and all the powers of the world become to them like the wing of a mosquito, which they do not heed when faced with trials and torments. As for the wisdoms and secrets that lie behind the details of this journey, their place of research is in the books on the mysteries of the Sharia (Islamic law). But here are simple facts that spring forth from the sources of this blessed journey and flow into the gardens of the Prophet's Biography (peace and blessings and salutations be upon him). I deem it appropriate to briefly mention some of them. The reader sees in Surah *Al-Isra* that Allah mentioned the story of the Isra in only one verse, and then began mentioning the scandals and crimes of the Jews, and then alerted them that this Quran guides to that which is most upright. The reader might assume there is no link between the two verses, but that is not the case. By this style, Allah (the Exalted) indicates that the Isra occurred to Jerusalem only because the Jews were about to be removed from the position of leadership of the human nation, due to the crimes they had committed, which left no room for their retention of this position. And that Allah would effectively transfer this position to His Messenger (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), uniting for him both centres of the Abrahamic call. The time had come for the spiritual leadership to be transferred from one nation to another, from a nation that filled its history with treachery, betrayal, sin, and aggression, to a nation that overflows with righteousness and goodness, and whose Messenger still enjoys the revelation of the Quran that guides to that which is most upright. But how can this leadership be transferred while the Messenger is wandering in the mountains of Mecca, driven away among the people? This question lifts the veil from another truth, which is that one phase of this Islamic call was nearing its end and completion, and another phase, different from the first in its course, was about to begin. Therefore, we see some verses containing a blatant warning and severe threat to the polytheists: {And when We intend to destroy a city, We command its affluent ones [to obey Us], but they defiantly disobey therein; so the word [of decree] comes into effect upon it, and We destroy it with complete destruction.} [Al-Isra: 16], {And how many generations have We destroyed after Noah! And sufficient is your Lord as an All-Knower and All-Seer of the sins of His servants.} [Al-Isra: 17]. Alongside these verses are other verses that explain to the Muslims the principles and clauses of civilization upon which their Islamic society is to be built, as if they have taken refuge in a land where they control their affairs in all respects, and form a cohesive unit around which the mill of society revolves. This indicates that the Messenger (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) would find a sanctuary and a safe haven where his affair would be established, and it would become a centre for spreading his call throughout the world. This is one of the secrets of this blessed journey, related to our research, so we chose to mention it. It is for this wisdom and similar reasons that we see the Isra occurred either just before the First Pledge of Aqabah or between the two pledges. And Allah knows best. – The Hijra (Emigration) of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) When the tyrannical decision to kill the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was made, Gabriel descended to him with the revelation from his Lord (Blessed and Exalted be He). He informed him of the Quraysh conspiracy, and that Allah had permitted him to leave and specified the time of the Hijra, saying: “Do not spend this night in the bed on which you usually sleep.” The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) went to Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with him) in the midday heat to finalize the stages of the Hijra with him. 'A'ishah (may Allah be pleased with her) said: While we were sitting in Abu Bakr's house in the heat of midday, someone said to Abu Bakr: “This is the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) coming, covering his face, at an hour when he did not usually come to us.” Abu Bakr said: “May my father and mother be sacrificed for him! By Allah, he has not come at this hour except for an important matter.” She said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) came and asked for permission to enter. He was granted permission and entered. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to Abu Bakr: “Ask those who are with you to leave.” Abu Bakr said: “They are only your family members. May my father be sacrificed for you, O Messenger of Allah.” The Prophet said: “I have been permitted to leave.” Abu Bakr asked: “The companionship, may my father be sacrificed for you, O Messenger of Allah?” The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) replied: “Yes.” After finalizing the plan of the Hijra, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) returned to his house to await the coming of the night. The Siege of the Messenger of Allah's House: As for the major criminals of Quraysh, they spent their day preparing to execute the plan that the Mecca parliament, *Dar an-Nadwah* (the Council Hall), had ratified in the morning. Eleven chiefs from these notables were chosen for this purpose: 1. Abu Jahl ibn Hisham. 2. Al-Hakam ibn Abi al-'As. 3. Uqbah ibn Abi Mu'ayt. 4. An-Nadr ibn al-Hârith. 5. Umayyah ibn Khalaf. 6. Zam'ah ibn al-Aswad. 7. Tu'aymah ibn 'Adiyy. 8. Abu Lahab. 9. Ubayy ibn Khalaf. 10. Nabîh ibn al-Hajjâj. 11. Munabbih ibn al-Hajjâj. Ibn Ishaq said: When the early part of the night came, they gathered at his door, watching for when he would fall asleep, so they could rush upon him. They were confident and absolutely certain of the success of this vile conspiracy. Abu Jahl stood in a posture of pride and arrogance, addressing his companions surrounding the house with sarcasm and mockery: “Muhammad claims that if you follow him in his matter, you will be the kings of the Arabs and the non-Arabs, and then you will be resurrected after your death, and gardens like the gardens of Jordan will be made for you. And if you do not do that, there will be slaughter for you from him, and then you will be resurrected after your death, and a Fire will be made for you in which you will be burned.” The appointed time for the execution of that conspiracy was after midnight. They stayed awake, awaiting zero hour. But Allah prevails over His command, and the dominion of the heavens and the earth is in His Hand. He does what He wills, and He grants protection, and no protection can be granted against Him. He carried out what He addressed to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) later: {And [remember, O Muhammad], when those who disbelieved plotted against you to restrain you or kill you or exile you. They plan, and Allah plans. And Allah is the best of planners.} [Al-Anfâl: 30]. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) Leaves His House: Despite the extreme preparedness of Quraysh to execute their plan, they failed miserably. In this critical hour, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to Ali ibn Abi Talib: 'Sleep on my bed, and cover yourself with this green Hadrami cloak of mine. Sleep in it, for nothing they wish for you that you dislike will reach you.' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to sleep in that cloak when he slept. They were certain and absolutely convinced of the success of this vile conspiracy, so much so that Abu Jahl stood up with pride and arrogance, addressing his surrounding companions with sarcasm and mockery, saying: 'Muhammad claims that if you follow him in his command, you will be the kings of the Arabs and the non-Arabs, and then be resurrected after your death, and you will be given gardens like the gardens of Urdunn. And if you do not, he will have a slaughter amongst you, and then you will be resurrected after your death, and then you will be assigned to a fire in which you will be burned.' The appointed time for the execution of that conspiracy was after midnight. They stayed awake, waiting for the zero hour, but Allah is predominant over His Command, the dominion of the heavens and the earth is in His hand, He does what He wills, and He grants refuge, but none can be granted refuge against Him. He did what He addressed the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) with later: {And [remember] when the disbelievers plotted against you to restrain you or kill you or exile you. They plot, and Allah plots. And Allah is the best of plotters.} [Al-Anfal: 30]. Despite the extreme preparedness of Quraysh to execute their plan, they failed miserably. In this critical hour, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to Ali ibn Abi Talib: 'Sleep on my bed, and cover yourself with this green Hadrami cloak of mine. Sleep in it, for nothing they wish for you that you dislike will reach you.' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to sleep in that cloak when he slept. Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) went out, passed through their ranks, took a handful of pebbles and began to scatter it over their heads. Allah had taken away their sights from him, and they did not see him, as he recited: {And We have put before them a barrier and behind them a barrier and covered them, so they do not see.} [Ya-Sin: 9]. Not a single man among them remained but had dust placed on his head. He then proceeded to the house of Abu Bakr, and they both exited through a small opening in Abu Bakr's house at night until they reached the Cave of Thawr in the direction of Yemen. The besiegers remained waiting for the zero hour to arrive, but just before it arrived, disappointment and failure became apparent to them. A man who was not with them came, saw them at his door, and said: 'What are you waiting for?' They said: 'Muhammad.' He said: 'You have failed and lost. By Allah, he passed by you, scattered dust on your heads, and went away for his need.' They said: 'By Allah, we did not see him.' They stood up, dusting the dirt from their heads. But they looked through the gap in the door and saw Ali. They said: 'By Allah, that is Muhammad sleeping, with his cloak upon him.' They remained like that until morning. Ali got up from the bed, and they were at a loss. They asked him about the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and he said: 'I have no knowledge of him.' From the House to the Cave: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) left his house on the night of the 27th of Safar, in the 14th year of Prophethood, corresponding to September 12/13, 622 CE. He went to the house of his companion – the most trusted person to him in his company and wealth – Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with him). Then they left the latter's house through a back door, to exit Mecca in haste, before the dawn broke. Since the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) knew that Quraysh would search for him diligently, and that the path to which attention would first turn was the main road to Medina, heading north, he took the completely opposite road, which was the one located south of Mecca, heading towards Yemen. He travelled this path for about five miles until he reached a mountain known as Jabal Thawr. This is a lofty mountain, rugged in terrain, difficult to ascend, with many stones. The feet of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) became bruised. It is also said that he walked on the tips of his feet on the road to hide his tracks, which bruised his feet. Whatever the case, Abu Bakr carried him when they reached the mountain and hurried with him until he reached a cave at the top of the mountain, known historically as the Cave of Thawr. When They Were in the Cave: When they reached the cave, Abu Bakr said: 'By Allah, you will not enter it until I enter before you, so that if there is anything in it, it will strike me instead of you.' He entered and swept it, and found holes on its side. He tore his lower garment and blocked them with it. Two remained, so he blocked them with his feet. Then he said to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'Enter.' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) entered, placed his head on his lap and slept. Abu Bakr was stung in his leg from one of the holes, but he did not move for fear of waking the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). His tears fell onto the face of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), who said: 'What is the matter with you, O Abu Bakr?' He said: 'I have been stung, may my father and mother be sacrificed for you.' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) spat on it, and the pain left his body. They remained hidden in the cave for three nights: the night of Friday, the night of Saturday, and the night of Sunday. Abdullah ibn Abi Bakr used to spend the night with them. Aisha said that he was an intelligent and perceptive young man. He would leave them before dawn and arrive in Mecca among Quraysh as if he had spent the night there. He would not hear of any plot being devised against them except that he would retain it, until he came to them with the news when darkness fell. And Amir ibn Fuhayra, Abu Bakr's freed slave, used to graze for them a gift of sheep, and he would bring them to rest for them when an hour of the evening had passed, and they would spend the night drinking the milk of those sheep (their milk and preserved food) until Amir ibn Fuhayra would drive them away just before dawn. He did this every night of those three nights. Amir ibn Fuhayra would follow the tracks of Abdullah ibn Abi Bakr with his sheep after he left for Mecca, in order to erase them. As for Quraysh, they went mad when they confirmed that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) had escaped on the night the plot was to be executed. The first thing they did was to beat Ali, drag him to the Kaaba, and imprison him for an hour, hoping to extract news of the two men. When they got no benefit from Ali, they came to Abu Bakr's house and knocked on his door. Asma bint Abi Bakr came out to them. They asked her: 'Where is your father?' She said: 'By Allah, I do not know where my father is.' Abu Jahl raised his hand – he was a foul and malicious man – and slapped her on the cheek, knocking off her earring. Quraysh decided in an urgent emergency session to use all available means to capture the two men. They placed all the roads leading out of Mecca (in all directions) under strict armed surveillance. They also decided to give a huge reward of one hundred camels for each of the two men to whoever would return them to Quraysh, dead or alive, whoever that person might be. Thereupon, horsemen, infantry, and trackers worked diligently in the search, spreading out into the mountains, valleys, lowlands, and plateaus, but without success or gain. The pursuers reached the entrance of the cave, but Allah is predominant over His Command. Al-Bukhari narrated from Anas from Abu Bakr who said: 'I was with the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in the cave, and I raised my head, and behold, I saw the feet of the people. I said: 'O Prophet of Allah, if one of them were to look down, he would see us.' He said: 'Be quiet, O Abu Bakr. Two, and Allah is their third.' In another narration: 'What do you think, O Abu Bakr, of two whose third is Allah?' It was a miracle with which Allah honored His Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). The pursuers turned back when there were only a few steps between them and him. On the Way to Medina: When the fire of the search subsided, the operations of the inspection patrols ceased, and the fury of Quraysh calmed down after a continuous intense pursuit of three days without avail, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and his companion prepared to leave for Medina. They had hired Abdullah ibn Urayqit al-Laythi, who was an expert and skillful guide – proficient in the route – who was on the religion of the disbelievers of Quraysh, and they trusted him with that. They handed over their two riding camels to him, and arranged to meet him at the Cave of Thawr after three nights with the camels. When it was the night of Monday – the first of Rabi' al-Awwal in the 1st year AH / September 16, 622 CE – Abdullah ibn Urayqit came to them with the two riding camels. At that moment, Abu Bakr said to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'May my father be sacrificed for you, O Messenger of Allah, take one of these two riding camels,' and he offered him the best of them. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'For the price.' Asma bint Abi Bakr (may Allah be pleased with her) brought them their provisions bag, and forgot to make a strap for it. When they were about to depart, she went to hang the provisions bag, but found it had no strap. She tore her waist belt into two, hung the provisions bag with one piece, and tied the other piece around her waist, and so she was named *Dhat al-Nitaqayn* (The Possessor of the Two Belts). Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with him) departed, and Amir ibn Fuhayra travelled with them. The guide – Abdullah ibn Urayqit – took them along the coastal road. The first route he took after leaving the cave was to proceed far south towards Yemen, then head west towards the coast. When he reached a road that people were unfamiliar with, he headed north close to the shore of the Red Sea, taking a path that was rarely travelled by anyone. Ibn Ishaq mentioned the places the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) passed through on this road. He said: When the guide left with them, he took them below Mecca, then proceeded with them along the coast until he intersected the road below Usfan, then he took them below Amj, then passed with them until he intersected the road after passing Qudayd, then he passed with them from that place. He took them through Al-Kharrar, then through Thaniyyat al-Murra, then through Laqf, then he passed with them through Mudlajatu Laqf, then descended with them into Mudlajatu Mujah, then through Marajh Mahaj, then through the bottom of Marajh Dhil-Ghuduwayn, then the bottom of Dhi Kushr, then he took them through Al-Jadajid, then through Al-Ajrad, then through Dhu Salam, from the bottom of A'da' Mudlajatu Ta'han, then through Al-Ababid, then he passed with them through Al-Fajja, then he descended with them to Al-Arj, then he took them through Thaniyyat al-A'ir – to the right of Rukubah – until he descended with them to Batn Ri'm, then he brought them to Quba. Here are some incidents that occurred on the way: 1. Al-Bukhari narrated from Abu Bakr As-Siddiq (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: 'We travelled our night and the next day until the heat of noon stood still, and the road was empty, no one passing by. A tall rock appeared to us with a shade that the sun had not yet reached. We dismounted by it, and I leveled a place for the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) with my hand for him to sleep on, and I spread a sheepskin over it. I said: 'Sleep, O Messenger of Allah, and I will clear for you what is around you.' He slept, and I went out to clear what was around him. Suddenly, I saw a shepherd approaching with his sheep towards the rock, wanting from it what we had wanted. I asked him: 'Whose are you, O boy?' He said: 'A man from the people of Medina or Mecca.' I asked: 'Is there any milk in your sheep?' He said: 'Yes.' I asked: 'Will you milk?' He said: 'Yes.' He took a sheep, and I said: 'Wipe the dust, hair, and filth from the udder.' He milked a small amount of milk into a hollow vessel. I had with me a waterskin that I had brought for the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), for him to drink and perform ablution from. I came to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and I disliked waking him. I met him when he woke up. I poured water on the milk until the bottom was cool. I said: 'Drink, O Messenger of Allah.' He drank until I was satisfied. Then he said: 'Is it not time to depart?' I said: 'Yes.' He said: 'Then we departed.' 2. It was the custom of Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with him) that he was riding behind the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). He was an older man who was known, and the Prophet of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was young and not known. A man would meet Abu Bakr and say: 'Who is this man in front of you?' He would say: 'This man is guiding me to the path,' and the questioner would assume he meant the physical road, but he only meant the way of goodness. 3. Suraqa ibn Malik pursued them on the road. Suraqa said: 'While I was sitting in an assembly of my people, Banu Mudlij, a man from them came forward and stood over us while we were sitting, and said: 'O Suraqa, I saw silhouettes just now by the coast, I think they are Muhammad and his companions.' Suraqa said: 'I knew they were them.' I said to him: 'They are not them, but you saw so-and-so and so-and-so who departed before our eyes.' I stayed in the assembly for an hour, then I got up and went inside. I ordered my servant girl to bring out my mare, which was behind a small hill, and hold her for me. I took my spear and went out with it from the back of the house. I traced a line with its tip on the ground and lowered its upper end until I reached my mare. I mounted her, and she hurried me forward until I was close to them. My mare stumbled with me, and I fell off. I stood up, put my hand into my quiver, took out the divining arrows, and sought to know if I would harm them or not. The result came out as the one I disliked. I mounted my mare and disobeyed the arrows. She hurried me forward until I heard the recitation of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) – who did not look back, while Abu Bakr looked back often – the forelegs of my mare sank into the ground up to the knees. I fell off her. Then I rebuked her and she got up, barely able to pull out her feet. When she stood upright, the dust rising from her forelegs was like smoke in the sky. I sought the omen with the divining arrows again, and the result came out as the one I disliked. I called out to them for safety (*aman*), and they stopped. I mounted my mare until I came to them. It occurred to me, when I encountered what I did in being restrained from them, that the affair of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) would prevail. I told him that my people had set a reward for you, and I informed them of the news of what the people intended for them. I offered them provisions and goods, but they did not take anything from me, nor did they ask me for anything except that he said: 'Keep our secret.' I asked him to write for me a document of security. He ordered Amir ibn Fuhayra, who wrote it for me on a piece of leather. Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) proceeded. Arrival at Quba: On Monday, 8th of Rabi' al-Awwal in the 14th year of Prophethood – which is the first year of the Hijra – corresponding to September 23, 622 CE, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) arrived at Quba. Urwah ibn Az-Zubayr said: The Muslims in Medina heard about the departure of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) from Mecca, and they used to go out every morning to the Harra (rocky plateau) to wait for him until the heat of noon forced them back. One day they returned after a long wait, and when they reached their homes, a man from the Jews climbed up one of their fortresses for some purpose he was looking at. He caught sight of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and his companions, dressed in white, moving with the mirage. The Jew could not help but shout at the top of his voice: 'O company of Arabs, this is your good fortune that you were waiting for!' The Muslims rushed to their weapons. Ibn Al-Qayyim said: And the clamor and *Takbir* (saying *Allahu Akbar*) were heard in Banu Amr ibn Auf. The Muslims said *Allahu Akbar* in joy at his arrival, and went out to meet him. They received him and greeted him with the salutation of Prophethood, surrounding him on all sides. Serenity covered him, and the Revelation descended upon him: {But if you assist one another against him, then indeed Allah is his Protector, and Gabriel and the righteous among the believers, and the angels, moreover, are his helpers.} [At-Tahrim: 4]. Urwah ibn Az-Zubayr said: They received the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and he turned with them to the right until he stopped at Banu Amr ibn Auf. That was on Monday in the month of Rabi' al-Awwal. Abu Bakr stood up to address the people, and the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) sat silently. Those of the Ansar who had not seen the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) began to greet – or in one version, to come to – Abu Bakr, until the sun struck the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Then Abu Bakr came forward and shaded him with his cloak. It was then that the people recognized the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). The entirety of Medina had marched out for the reception. It was a momentous historical day, unlike any Medina had witnessed in its history. The Jews saw the truth of the good news concerning the Prophet, that God would come from Tayman, and the Holy One from the mountains of Paran. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) stayed at Quba with Kulthum ibn Al-Hidm. It is said that it was rather with Sa'd ibn Khaythama, but the former is more established. Ali ibn Abi Talib remained in Mecca for three days to return the deposits that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) held for the people. Then he migrated on foot until he caught up with them at Quba, and stayed with Kulthum ibn Al-Hidm. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) stayed at Quba for four days: Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday. He established the Mosque of Quba and prayed in it; it is the first mosque founded on piety after the Prophethood. On the fifth day – Friday – he mounted his ride by the command of Allah, with Abu Bakr riding behind him. He sent for Banu An-Najjar – his maternal uncles – and they came wearing their swords. He proceeded towards Medina, and the Friday prayer caught up with him at Banu Salim ibn Auf. He led them in the Friday prayer in the mosque in the bottom of the valley. They were one hundred men. Entering Medina: After the Friday prayer, the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) entered Medina – and from that day the town of Yathrib was called the City of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), abbreviated to *Al-Madinah* – and it was a glorious historical day. The houses and streets were resounding with the sounds of praise and glorification (*tahmid* and *taqdis*). The girls of the Ansar were singing these verses in joy and happiness: The full moon has risen upon us from the valleys of Wada' * And gratitude is incumbent upon us as long as a caller calls to Allah * O you who were sent among us, you have come with a command that must be obeyed. Even though the Ansar were not people of vast wealth, every one of them wished for the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to stay with him. He would not pass by a house of the Ansar but they would seize the rein of his riding camel, saying: 'Come to us, we have the number, the equipment, the weapons, and the protection.' He would say to them: 'Leave her way, for she is commanded.' She continued walking with him until she reached the place of the Prophet's Mosque today and knelt down. He did not dismount until she got up and walked a little, then turned back, returned, and knelt down in her first place. He dismounted from her, and that was with Banu An-Najjar – his maternal uncles (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). This was by the success granted to her by Allah, for He loved for him to stay with his maternal uncles to honor them with that. The people began to speak to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) about staying with them. Abu Ayyub al-Ansari rushed to his baggage and brought it into his house. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) kept saying: 'A man is with his baggage.' And As'ad ibn Zurarah came and took the rein of his riding camel, and it remained with him. In the narration of Anas in Al-Bukhari, the Prophet of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'Which of our family's houses is nearest?' Abu Ayyub said: 'I am, O Messenger of Allah, this is my house, and this is my door.' He said: 'Then go and prepare a resting place for us.' He replied: 'Come, with the blessing of Allah.' After a few days, his wife Sawda, his two daughters Fatima and Umm Kulthum, Usama ibn Zayd, and Umm Ayman arrived. Abdullah ibn Abi Bakr left with them, bringing Abu Bakr's family, including Aisha. Zaynab remained with Abul-As, who did not allow her to leave until she migrated after Badr. Aisha said: When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) came to Medina, Abu Bakr and Bilal fell ill with fever. I entered upon them and said: 'O my father, how do you find yourself? And O Bilal, how do you find yourself?' She said: When the fever took Abu Bakr, he would say: A man finds the morning among his family, And death is nearer than the strap of his sandal. And when Bilal recovered, he would raise his voice and say: Alas, would that I knew if I would ever spend a night in a valley Surrounded by *idhkhir* and *jalil* grass * And would that I would one day reach the waters of Majannah, And would that Shamah and Tufail would appear to me. Aisha said: I came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and informed him. He said: 'O Allah, make Medina beloved to us as we love Mecca, or even more. Make it healthy, and bless its *Sa'* and its *Mudd* (measures), and move its fever and place it in Al-Juhfa.' At this point, a segment of his life (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) ended, and a phase of the Islamic Call was completed, which was the Meccan phase. Life in Medina: The Medinan era can be divided into three phases: 1. A phase in which unrest and discord were stirred up, and obstacles were erected from within, and enemies marched on Medina from without to uproot its greenery. This phase ends with the Truce of Al-Hudaybiyyah, in Dhul-Qa'dah of the 6th year of the Hijra. 2. The phase of truce with the pagan leadership, which ends with the Conquest of Mecca, in Ramadan of the eighth year of the Hijra. This is the phase of calling kings to Islam. 3. The phase of people entering the religion of Allah in droves. This is the phase of tribes and peoples flocking to Medina, and this phase extends until the end of the life of the Messenger (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in Rabi' al-Awwal of the 11th year of the Hijra. - Construction of the Prophet's Mosque (An-Nabawi): The first step the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) took after that was the establishment of the Prophet's Mosque. At the place where his she-camel knelt, he ordered the building of this mosque. He bought it from two orphaned boys who owned it, and he participated in its construction himself. He would carry the bricks and stones and say: O Allah, there is no life but the life of the Hereafter, So forgive the Ansar and the Muhajirun. And he would say: This burden is not the burden of Khaybar, This is more righteous and purer for our Lord. This increased the Companions' activity in the construction, to the extent that one of them said: If we sit while the Prophet works, That would be a misguided deed from us. In that location were the graves of the polytheists, ruins, palm trees, and a *Gharqad* tree. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) ordered the graves of the polytheists to be dug up, the ruins leveled, and the palms and the tree to be cut down and arranged towards the *Qiblah* of the mosque (the direction of prayer), which was then towards Jerusalem. Its doorposts were made of stones, its walls were erected from mud bricks and mud, its roof was made of palm leaves, its pillars were tree trunks, and its floor was spread with sand and gravel. Three doors were made for it. Its length from the *Qiblah* to its rear was one hundred cubits, and the two sides were the same or less. Its foundation was about three cubits. He built houses adjacent to it, stone houses with mud bricks and roofs of palm leaves and trunks. These were the chambers of his wives (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). After the chambers were completed, he moved into them from the house of Abu Ayyub. The mosque was not only a place for performing prayers, but also a university where Muslims received the teachings and guidance of Islam, a forum where the various tribal elements, which had long been divided by the biases and wars of the pre-Islamic era, met and united, a base for managing all affairs and launching initiatives, and a parliament for holding advisory and executive councils. In addition to all this, it was a home where a large number of poor refugee *Muhajirun* resided, who had no home, wealth, family, or children there. In the early days of the Hijra, the call to prayer (*Adhan*) was instituted, the celestial melody that resonates in the horizons five times a day, making the entire world tremble. The story of Abdullah ibn Zayd ibn Abd Rabbih's dream regarding this is well-known, narrated by At-Tirmidhi, Abu Dawud, Ahmad, and Ibn Khuzaymah. Fraternization between the Muslims: Just as the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) established the mosque, the center of gathering and unity, he undertook another act, one of the most magnificent recorded by history: the fraternization between the *Muhajirun* (Emigrants) and the *Ansar* (Helpers). Ibn al-Qayyim said: 'Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) established brotherhood between the Muhajirun and the Ansar, in the house of Anas ibn Malik. They were ninety men, half of them from the Muhajirun and half from the Ansar. He established brotherhood between them on the basis of sharing, and they would inherit from each other after death, to the exclusion of blood relatives, until the Battle of Badr. When Allah (Almighty and Majestic) revealed: {…but those of [blood] relation are more entitled to [inherit] than [others] in the decree of Allah…} [Al-Anfal: 75], the inheritance was revoked, but the bond of brotherhood remained.' It is also said that he established a second brotherhood between the Muhajirun themselves. But the first is more established, and the Muhajirun were self-sufficient with the brotherhood of Islam, the brotherhood of the home, and the kinship of lineage, unlike the Muhajirun with the Ansar (end quote). The meaning of this brotherhood, as Muhammad Al-Ghazali said, is that the tribalisms of the pre-Islamic era dissolve, and there is no zeal except for Islam, and that the differences of lineage, color, and homeland disappear, so that no one is advanced or lagged behind except by his moral worth and piety. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) made this brotherhood an enforceable contract, not an empty word, and an action related to lives and wealth, not a greeting that tongues babble without effect. The feelings of altruism, consolation, and companionship were intertwined in this brotherhood, filling the new society with the most magnificent examples. Al-Bukhari reported that when they came to Medina, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) established brotherhood between Abdur-Rahman and Sa'd ibn Ar-Rabi'. Sa'd said to Abdur-Rahman: 'I am the wealthiest of the Ansar. Divide my wealth into two halves, and I have two wives. Look at the one who pleases you most, tell me her name, and I will divorce her, and when her waiting period is over, you may marry her.' He replied: 'May Allah bless you in your family and your wealth. Where is your market?' They directed him to the market of Banu Qaynuqa. He did not return until he had a surplus of dried cheese and butter. Then he continued to go out every morning. One day he came with a trace of yellowness (perfume). The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) asked: 'What is this?' He said: 'I got married.' He asked: 'How much dowry did you give her?' He said: 'The weight of a date pit in gold.' It was reported from Abu Hurayrah that the Ansar said to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'Divide the palm trees between us and our brothers.' He said: 'No.' Then they said: 'Then you will spare us the labor and we will share the fruit with you.' They replied: 'We hear and we obey.' This shows us the extreme hospitality of the Ansar towards their brothers the Muhajirun, and their sacrifice, altruism, affection, and purity, and the appreciation of the Muhajirun for this generosity, not exploiting it and not taking from it except what was necessary for their sustenance. Truly, this fraternization was a singular wisdom, a sound and sagacious policy, and a wonderful solution to many of the problems facing the Muslims, which we have pointed out. The Battle of Badr (Al-Kubra): The First of the Decisive Battles of Islam We previously mentioned in the account of the Expedition of Al-Ushayrah that a caravan of Quraysh had escaped the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) on its way from Mecca to Syria. When its return from Syria to Mecca approached, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) sent Talhah ibn Ubaydillah and Sa'id ibn Zayd north to scout for news of it. They reached Al-Hawra and remained there until Abu Sufyan passed by with the caravan. They hurried to Medina and informed the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) of the news. The caravan was loaded with immense wealth belonging to the people of Mecca, one thousand camels heavily laden with goods worth no less than fifty thousand gold dinars, and was guarded by only about forty men. It was a golden opportunity for the army of Medina, and a crippling military, political, and economic blow against the polytheists if they lost this immense wealth. Therefore, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) announced to the Muslims: 'This is the caravan of Quraysh with their wealth. Go out to intercept it, perhaps Allah will grant it to you as spoils.' He did not compel anyone to go out, but left the matter to absolute willingness, because he did not expect at this mobilization that he would clash with the army of Mecca – instead of the caravan – in this violent confrontation at Badr. That is why many of the Companions remained in Medina, assuming that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him)'s journey in this direction would not exceed what they were accustomed to in previous expeditions. Therefore, no one was rebuked for staying behind in this campaign. Strength of the Islamic Army and Distribution of Commands: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) prepared to leave with three hundred and some ten men (313, 314, or 317 men), 82, 83, or 86 of the *Muhajirun*, 61 of the Aws, and 170 of the Khazraj. They did not celebrate this departure elaborately, nor did they take their full readiness. They had only two horses: one horse for Az-Zubayr ibn Al-Awwam and one horse for Al-Miqdad ibn Al-Aswad Al-Kindi. They had seventy camels, so that two or three men would take turns riding one camel. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), Ali, and Marthad ibn Abi Marthad al-Ghanawi took turns riding one camel. He left Ibn Umm Maktum as his deputy over Medina and for leading the prayer. When he was at Ar-Rawha, he sent back Abu Lubabah ibn Abd Al-Mundhir and appointed him as governor of Medina. He gave the banner of general command to Mus'ab ibn Umayr al-Qurashi al-Abdari. This banner was white. He divided his army into two battalions: 1. The *Muhajirun* battalion, whose standard he gave to Ali ibn Abi Talib. 2. The *Ansar* battalion, whose standard he gave to Sa'd ibn Mu'adh. He appointed Az-Zubayr ibn Al-Awwam to the command of the right flank, and Al-Miqdad ibn Amr to the command of the left flank – they were the only two horsemen in the army, as previously mentioned – and he appointed Qays ibn Abi Sa'sa' to the rearguard. The general command remained in his hand (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) as the supreme commander of the army. The Islamic Army Moves Towards Badr: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) marched with this unprepared army. He left through the pass of Medina and proceeded on the main road leading to Mecca until he reached the well of Ar-Rawha. When he left there, he kept the Mecca road to his left, and turned right towards An-Naziyyah, intending for Badr. He traveled through a part of it until he cut across a valley called Rahqan, between An-Naziyyah and the narrow pass of As-Safra. Then he passed through the pass, and descended from it until he was close to As-Safra. There, he sent Basbas ibn Amr al-Juhani and Adiyy ibn Abi az-Zaghba al-Juhani to Badr to spy on the caravan's news for him. The Warning in Mecca: As for the news of the caravan, Abu Sufyan – who was in charge of it – was extremely cautious and vigilant. He knew that the Mecca road was fraught with dangers, and he was scouting for news, questioning everyone he met from the travelers. Soon, his intelligence reported to him that Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) had mobilized his companions to intercept the caravan. At that moment, Abu Sufyan hired Damdam ibn Amr al-Ghifari to go to Mecca, calling on Quraysh to mobilize to defend it against Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and his companions. Damdam rushed out until he came to Mecca, shouting in the bottom of the valley, standing on his camel, whose nose he had split, whose saddle he had reversed, and whose shirt he had torn, saying: 'O company of Quraysh, the caravan! The caravan! Your wealth is with Abu Sufyan, Muhammad and his companions have intercepted it. I do not think you will catch up with it! Help! Help!' The Composition of the Meccan Army: The strength of this army was about one thousand three hundred fighters at the beginning of its march. It had one hundred horses, six hundred shields, and many camels, whose exact number is not known. Its general commander was Abu Jahl ibn Hisham. Nine men from the nobles of Quraysh were in charge of provisioning it, slaughtering nine camels one day and ten the next. The Caravan Escapes: As for the story of Abu Sufyan, he was traveling on the main road, but he remained cautious and vigilant, and he doubled his scouting activities. When he approached Badr, he advanced his caravan until he met Majdi ibn Amr and asked him about the army of Medina. He said: 'I have not seen anyone whom I would suspect, except that I saw two riders kneel down near this hill, then they drank from a waterskin they had, and then left.' Abu Sufyan rushed to their resting place, took some of the dung of their camels, and crumbled it. He found date pits in it. He said: 'By Allah, this is the fodder of Yathrib.' He quickly returned to his caravan, struck its face, turning its direction towards the coast to the west, leaving the main road that passes through Badr on the left. Thus, he saved the caravan from falling into the hands of the army of Medina. He sent his message to the Mecca army, which they received at Al-Juhfa. The First of the Decisive Battles of Islam The Critical Situation of the Islamic Army: As for the intelligence of the Medina army, it conveyed to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) – while he was still on the road in the valley of Dhakran – the news of the caravan and the mobilization. He became certain, after deliberation on those reports, that there was no room left to avoid a bloody encounter, and that there must be an advance based on courage, bravery, daring, and boldness. There was no doubt that if the Mecca army was allowed to wander through that region, it would strengthen Quraysh's military position, extend its political authority, and weaken the word of the Muslims and undermine it. Furthermore, the Islamic movement might remain thereafter a body without a soul, and everyone who harbored hatred or resentment against Islam in that region would dare to do evil. After all this, would there be anyone to guarantee to the Muslims that the Mecca army would be prevented from continuing its march towards Medina, moving the battle to its walls, and invading the Muslims in their own home? No, for any retreat by the Medina army would have the worst effect on the dignity and reputation of the Muslims. The Consultative Council: In view of this sudden and dangerous development, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) held a supreme consultative military council, in which he pointed out the current situation and exchanged opinions with his army in general and its commanders. At that time, the hearts of a group of people were shaken, and they feared the bloody encounter. These are the ones about whom Allah said: {Just as your Lord caused you to go out from your home with the truth, while indeed, a party of the believers were unwilling, * Arguing with you concerning the truth after it had become clear, as if they were being driven toward death while they were looking on.} [Al-Anfal: 5-6]. As for the army commanders, Abu Bakr As-Siddiq stood up, spoke, and spoke well. Then Umar ibn Al-Khattab stood up, spoke, and spoke well. Then Al-Miqdad ibn Amr stood up and said: 'O Messenger of Allah, proceed as Allah has shown you, for we are with you. By Allah, we will not say to you what the Children of Israel said to Moses: 'Go, you and your Lord, and fight; indeed, we are remaining right here,' but rather: 'Go, you and your Lord, and fight; indeed, we are fighting with both of you.' By the One who sent you with the truth, if you marched with us to Bark al-Ghimad, we would fight with you before it until you reached it.' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) spoke kindly to him and prayed for him with good. These three commanders were from the *Muhajirun*, who were a minority in the army. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) wished to know the opinion of the *Ansar* commanders, because they represented the majority of the army, and the burden of the battle would fall on their shoulders, especially since the terms of the Pledge of Al-Aqaba did not obligate them to fight outside their homeland. So, after hearing the words of these three commanders, he said: 'Advise me, O people,' meaning the Ansar. Sa'd ibn Mu'adh, the chief of the Ansar and their standard-bearer, understood this and said: '... By Allah, it is as if you mean us, O Messenger of Allah?' He said: 'Yes.' He said: 'We have believed in you, we have affirmed your truthfulness, and we have testified that what you brought is the truth, and we have given you our covenants and pledges of hearing and obeying. So, proceed with what you have decided, O Messenger of Allah. By the One who sent you with the truth, if you were to traverse this sea and wade into it, we would wade into it with you. Not a single man among us would stay behind. We do not dislike meeting our enemy tomorrow. We are enduring in war, truthful in the encounter. Perhaps Allah will show you from us what will please your eyes. So, march with us with the blessing of Allah.' In another narration, Sa'd ibn Mu'adh said to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'Perhaps you fear that the Ansar consider it their duty not to support you except in their own homes. I speak for the Ansar and answer for them. Travel wherever you wish, establish ties with whomever you wish, cut ties with whomever you wish, take from our wealth whatever you wish, and give us whatever you wish. What you take from us is dearer to us than what you leave. And any matter you command, our command follows yours. By Allah, if you marched until you reached Al-Birk of Ghumdan, we would march with you. And by Allah, if you were to traverse this sea, we would wade into it with you.' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was pleased with Sa'd's words and it invigorated him. Then he said: 'March on and be of good cheer, for Allah Almighty has promised me one of the two parties. By Allah, it is as if I am looking now at the places of death of the people.' The Messenger (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) Conducts a Reconnaissance Operation: There, he himself conducted a reconnaissance operation with his companion in the cave, Abu Bakr As-Siddiq (may Allah be pleased with him). As they were touring around the Mecca camp, they came across an elderly Arab man. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) asked him about Quraysh and about Muhammad and his companions – he asked about both armies for increased secrecy. But the old man said: 'I will not inform you until you inform me of who you are.' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to him: 'If you inform us, we will inform you.' He said: 'Is it so?' He replied: 'Yes.' The old man said: 'It has reached me that Muhammad and his companions left on such-and-such a day, and if the one who informed me spoke the truth, they are today in such-and-such a place' – referring to the location of the Medina army. 'And it has reached me that Quraysh left on such-and-such a day, and if the one who informed me spoke the truth, they are today in such-and-such a place' – referring to the location of the Mecca army. When he finished his report, he asked: 'Who are you from?' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to him: 'We are from water.' Then he left him. The old man kept muttering: 'From water? From the water of Iraq?' The Descent of Rain: And Allah Almighty sent down a single rain that night. It was a severe downpour for the polytheists, preventing them from advancing, and it was a light drizzle for the Muslims, purifying them, removing from them the defilement of Satan, hardening the ground, firming up the sand, establishing their feet, smoothing the resting place, and strengthening their hearts. The Islamic Army Precedes to the Most Important Military Centers: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) moved with his army to precede the polytheists to the water of Badr, and prevent them from seizing it. He dismounted in the evening at the nearest water to Badr's wells. It was here that Al-Hubab ibn Al-Mundhir stood up as a military expert and said: 'O Messenger of Allah, do you see this position? Is it a position that Allah has caused you to occupy, which we are not permitted to advance beyond or retreat from? Or is it a matter of opinion, war, and deception?' He replied: 'Rather, it is a matter of opinion, war, and deception.' He said: 'O Messenger of Allah, this is not a suitable position. Move the people until we reach the nearest water to the people – Quraysh – we encamp there, and we destroy (i.e., fill in) the wells behind it. Then we build a basin over it and fill it with water. Then we fight the people, and we will drink, and they will not drink.' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'You have given a wise opinion.' So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) moved with the army until he reached the water nearest to the enemy and encamped there for half the night. Then they made the basins and filled in all the other wells. Continuation of the Battle of Badr (Al-Kubra) The First of the Decisive Battles of Islam The Command Headquarters: After the Muslims had settled at the water, Sa'd ibn Mu'adh suggested to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) that the Muslims should build a headquarters for his command in preparation for emergencies and in consideration of defeat before victory. He said: 'O Prophet of Allah, shall we not build for you a canopy (*arish*) where you may be, and we will prepare your riding camels near you? Then we will meet our enemy. If Allah honors us and grants us victory over our enemy, that will be what we love. And if the outcome is otherwise, you will sit on your riding camels and join those of our people who remained behind us. Indeed, some people stayed behind you, O Prophet of Allah, who do not love you less than us. If they had thought you would meet a war, they would not have stayed behind you. Allah will protect you by them, they will advise you sincerely and fight alongside you.' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) praised him and prayed for him with good. The Muslims built a canopy on a raised hill located northeast of the battleground, overlooking the battlefield. Similarly, a squad of Ansar youth led by Sa'd ibn Mu'adh was chosen to guard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) around his command headquarters. Army Mobilization and Spending the Night: Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) mobilized his army and walked on the battleground, pointing with his hand: 'This will be the place of death of so-and-so tomorrow, if Allah wills, and this will be the place of death of so-and-so tomorrow, if Allah wills.' Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) spent the night praying by a tree trunk there. The Muslims spent their night in calm breaths, with bright horizons, confidence filled their hearts, and they took their share of rest, hoping to see the signs of their Lord in the morning: {When He overwhelmed you with slumber as a security from Him, and sent down upon you from the sky, water, that He might purify you thereby and remove from you the defilement of Satan and reinforce your hearts and make firm your feet thereby.} [Al-Anfal: 11]. This night was the night of Friday, the seventeenth of the month of Ramadan, in the second year of the Hijra, and his departure had been on the 8th or 12th of the same month. The Two Armies Face Each Other: When the polytheists appeared and the two groups came face to face, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'O Allah, here is Quraysh, who has come with its arrogance and pride, defying You and denying Your Messenger. O Allah, grant me the victory You promised me. O Allah, destroy them this morning.' And the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said, when he saw Utbah ibn Rabi'ah among the people on his red camel: 'If there is any good in any of the people, it is with the owner of the red camel. If they obey him, they will be rightly guided.' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) straightened the ranks of the Muslims. While he was adjusting them, a strange incident occurred. He held a stick in his hand with which he was adjusting the ranks. Sawad ibn Ghaziyyah had stepped out of the line. The Prophet poked him in the stomach with the stick and said: 'Be straight, O Sawad.' Sawad said: 'O Messenger of Allah, you have hurt me, so grant me retaliation (*Qisas*).' He uncovered his stomach and said: 'Take your retaliation.' Sawad embraced him and kissed his stomach. He asked: 'What made you do this, O Sawad?' He said: 'O Messenger of Allah, what you see is imminent, and I wanted my last contact with you to be my skin touching yours.' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) prayed for him with good. When the ranks were straightened, he gave his orders to his army not to start fighting until they received his final commands. Then he gave them a special instruction regarding the battle. He said: 'If they overwhelm you – meaning if they outnumber you – shoot at them but save your arrows. And do not draw your swords until they close in on you.' Then he returned to the canopy, accompanied only by Abu Bakr, and Sa'd ibn Mu'adh stood with the guard squad at the entrance of the canopy. As for the polytheists, Abu Jahl made an invocation that day, saying: 'O Allah, cut off the kinship from us and bring upon us what we do not know, then destroy him this morning. O Allah, whichever of us was more beloved to You and more pleasing to You, grant him victory today.' It was regarding this that Allah revealed: {If you [disbelievers] seek the victory [to be judged between us], the victory has come to you. And if you cease [your hostility], it will be better for you. But if you return [to battle], We will return [to assistance], and never will your force avail you aught, even if it was great, and [know] that Allah is with the believers.} [Al-Anfal: 19]. Zero Hour and the First Fuel of the Battle: The first one to fuel the battle was Al-Aswad ibn Abd Al-Asad Al-Makhzumi – a fierce man with bad character – who came out saying: 'I swear by Allah that I will drink from their basin, or I will destroy it, or I will die before it.' When he came out, Hamza ibn Abd Al-Muttalib (may Allah be pleased with him) came out to meet him. When they met, Hamza struck him and severed his foot with half of his leg, while he was short of the basin. He fell on his back, his leg spurting blood towards his companions. Then he crawled towards the basin until he plunged into it, wanting to fulfill his oath. But Hamza followed up with another blow that finished him off while he was inside the basin. The Duel (*Mubarazah*): And it was this first killing that ignited the fire of the battle. Following it, three of the best knights of Quraysh, who belonged to one family, came out: 'Utbah and his brother Shaybah, the sons of Rabi'ah, and Al-Walid bin 'Utbah. When they separated from the rank, they asked for a duel. Three young men from the Ansar came out to face them: 'Awf and Mu'awwadh, the sons of Al-Harith – whose mother was 'Afra – and 'Abdullah bin Rawahah. They asked them: “Who are you?” They replied: “A group from the Ansar.” They said: “Noble equals. We have no need of you; we only want our cousins.” Then their caller shouted: “O Muhammad, bring forth our equals from our own people!” The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: “Stand up, O 'Ubaydah bin Al-Harith, stand up, O Hamzah, and stand up, O 'Ali.” When they stood up and approached them, [the Meccans] asked: “Who are you?” They informed them, and [the Meccans] said: “You are noble equals.” 'Ubaydah – who was the eldest of the group – challenged 'Utbah bin Rabi'ah, Hamzah challenged Shaybah, and 'Ali challenged Al-Walid. As for Hamzah and 'Ali, they did not give their opponents respite and killed them. As for 'Ubaydah, he and his opponent exchanged two blows, and each severely wounded the other. Then 'Ali and Hamzah rushed upon 'Utbah and killed him. They carried 'Ubaydah, whose leg had been severed. He remained silent until he died at As-Safra' four or five days after the Battle of Badr, while the Muslims were on their way to Medina. 'Ali swore by Allah that these verses were revealed concerning them: “These are two adversaries who have disputed about their Lord.” [Al-Hajj: 19]. The General Assault: The end of this duel was a bad start for the polytheists. They lost three of their finest knights and leaders all at once. They were filled with rage and rushed upon the Muslims as one man. As for the Muslims, after seeking victory and succor from their Lord, being sincere to Him, and supplicating before Him, they received the successive attacks of the polytheists, holding fast to their positions, adopting a defensive stance. They inflicted heavy losses upon the polytheists, all the while saying: “One! One!” (Allah is Unique). The Messenger (PBUH) Appeals to His Lord: As for the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), ever since he returned after adjusting the ranks, he had been appealing to his Lord for the promised victory, saying: “O Allah, fulfill Your promise to me! O Allah, I beseech You by Your covenant and Your promise!” When the heat of the battle intensified, and the grinding of war turned severely, and the fighting raged, reaching its peak, he said: “O Allah, if this small band perishes today, You will not be worshipped. O Allah, if You will, You will never be worshipped after this day.” He overdid his earnest supplication until his mantle fell from his shoulders. As-Siddiq (Abu Bakr) put it back on him and said: “Enough for you, O Messenger of Allah, you have pleaded enough with your Lord.” Allah revealed to His angels: “Indeed, I am with you, so strengthen those who have believed. I will cast terror into the hearts of those who disbelieved.” [Al-Anfal: 12] And He revealed to His Messenger: “I will reinforce you with a thousand of the angels in succession.” [Al-Anfal: 9] Meaning, they are following you closely, or they follow one another in successive waves, not all coming at once. The Descent of the Angels: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) dozed off for a moment, then raised his head and said: “Rejoice, O Abu Bakr, this is Jibril with the dust on his front teeth (i.e., the dust of the road).” In a narration by Muhammad bin Ishaq, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: “Rejoice, O Abu Bakr, the victory of Allah has come to you. This is Jibril, holding the rein of his horse and leading it, with dust on his front teeth.” Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) came out from the door of the canopy, leaping in his armor and reciting: “The host will be routed, and they will turn their backs (in flight).” [Al-Qamar: 45] Then he took a handful of pebbles, faced Quraysh with them, and said: “May these faces be disgraced!” (Shahat al-Wujuh) and threw them into their faces. There was no one among the polytheists who was not hit in his eye, nostrils, and mouth by that handful. Concerning this, Allah revealed: “And you did not throw when you threw, but it was Allah who threw.” [Al-Anfal: 17]. Continuation of the Great Battle of Badr The First Decisive Battle of Islam Iblis Withdraws from the Battlefield: When Iblis – who had come in the form of Suraqah bin Malik bin Ju'shum Al-Mudliji, as mentioned, and had not left them since that time – saw what the angels were doing to the polytheists, he fled and retreated on his heels. Al-Harith bin Hisham – thinking he was Suraqah – clung to him. [Iblis] jabbed Al-Harith in the chest and threw him down, then ran away. The polytheists asked him: “Where are you going, Suraqah? Did you not say that you were our protector and would not leave us?” He replied: “Indeed, I see what you do not see. I fear Allah, and Allah is severe in punishment.” Then he fled until he threw himself into the sea. The Crushing Defeat: The signs of failure and disorder began to appear in the ranks of the polytheists. Their lines began to crumble before the fierce attacks of the Muslims. The battle neared its end, and the multitudes of polytheists began to flee and withdraw in disarray. The Muslims rode on their backs, capturing and killing until the defeat was complete. The Steadfastness of Abu Jahl: As for the greatest tyrant, Abu Jahl, when he saw the first signs of disorder in his ranks, he tried to stand firm against this flood. He began to encourage his army, saying to them fiercely and arrogantly: “Do not be defeated by Suraqah’s abandonment of you, for he had an agreement with Muhammad. And do not be terrified by the killing of 'Utbah, Shaybah, and Al-Walid, for they were hasty. By Al-Lat and Al-'Uzza, we will not return until we have them bound with ropes! And let no man among you kill one of them, but take them captive until we make them realize the evil of their deeds.” However, the reality of this arrogance soon became apparent to him. It was not long before the ranks began to crack under the currents of the Muslim attack. Yes, a band of polytheists remained around him, forming a fence of swords and thickets of spears around him, but the storm of the Muslim attack dispersed this fence and uprooted these thickets. It was then that this tyrant appeared, and the Muslims saw him roaming on his horse. Death was waiting to drink his blood at the hands of two young men from the Ansar. The Death of Abu Jahl: 'Abd Ar-Rahman bin 'Awf said: “I was in the rank on the Day of Badr when I turned and saw on my right and left two young men who were newly adult. I was somewhat uneasy about their presence, when one of them whispered to me, away from his companion: ‘Uncle, show me Abu Jahl.’ I asked: ‘My nephew, what would you do with him?’ He said: ‘I was informed that he insults the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him).’ He said: ‘By the One in Whose hand is my soul, if I see him, my person will not leave his person until the sooner of us dies.’ I was astonished by this.” He added: “The other one nudged me and said the same thing to me. It was not long before I looked and saw Abu Jahl roaming among the people. I said: ‘Do you not see? This is your man you were asking me about.’ He said: “They rushed at him with their swords and struck him until they killed him. Then they returned to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), who asked: ‘Which of you killed him?’ Each of them said: ‘I killed him.’ [The Prophet] asked: ‘Have you wiped your swords?’ They said: ‘No.’ The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) looked at the two swords and said: ‘Both of you killed him,’ and the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) decreed his spoils to Mu'adh bin 'Amr bin Al-Jamuh. The two men were Mu'adh bin 'Amr bin Al-Jamuh and Mu'adh bin 'Afra.” Ibn Ishaq reported that Mu'adh bin 'Amr bin Al-Jamuh said: “I heard the people, while Abu Jahl was in a dense formation like a thicket (Al-Harajah is a dense tree, or an inaccessible tree; he compared the spears and swords of the polytheists around Abu Jahl for his protection to this tree), saying: ‘Abu Al-Hakam cannot be reached.’” He said: “When I heard that, I made him my concern and headed towards him. When I could reach him, I charged him and struck him a blow that made his foot fly off – cutting it off mid-leg. By Allah, when it flew off, I only likened it to a date pit flying out from under a date-pit pounder when it is struck.” He added: “His son 'Ikrimah struck me on my shoulder, cutting off my hand, which was left hanging by a strip of skin next to my flank. The fighting distracted me from him, and I fought most of my day dragging it behind me. When it bothered me, I put my foot on it, then pulled at it until I threw it off.” Then Mu'awwadh bin 'Afra passed by Abu Jahl – who was severely wounded – and struck him until he finished him off, leaving him with his last breath. Mu'awwadh fought until he was killed. When the battle was over, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) asked: “Who will look for what Abu Jahl has done?” People dispersed in search of him. 'Abdullah bin Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) found him taking his last breath. He placed his foot on his neck and took hold of his beard to cut off his head, and said: “Has Allah disgraced you, O enemy of Allah?” He replied: “And how has He disgraced me? What is worse than a man you have killed? Is there anything beyond a man you have killed?” He added: “If only a non-farmer had killed me!” Then he asked: “Tell me, to whom is the turnover today?” He replied: “To Allah and His Messenger.” Then he said to Ibn Mas'ud – who had his foot on his neck –: “You have climbed a difficult height, O little shepherd of goats!” (Ibn Mas'ud was one of the goat herders in Mecca). After this exchange, Ibn Mas'ud cut off his head and brought it to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and said: “O Messenger of Allah, this is the head of Allah's enemy, Abu Jahl!” He asked: “Allah, besides whom there is no deity?” He repeated it three times, then said: “Allah is the Greatest! Praise be to Allah Who fulfilled His promise, helped His servant, and defeated the confederates alone! Go, show him to me.” We went, and I showed him to him. He said: “This is the Pharaoh of this Ummah.” That day, 'Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) killed his maternal uncle, Al-'As bin Hisham bin Al-Mughirah. Abu Bakr As-Siddiq (may Allah be pleased with him) called out to his son 'Abd Ar-Rahman – who was with the polytheists at the time – and said: “Where is my property, O wicked one?” 'Abd Ar-Rahman replied: “It was the first calamity that Allah inflicted upon the people of polytheism. Inflicting heavy losses by killing the people of polytheism was dearer to me than preserving the men.” The battle ended with a crushing defeat for the polytheists and a clear victory for the Muslims. Fourteen men among the Muslims were martyred in this battle, six from the Muhajiroun and eight from the Ansar. As for the polytheists, they suffered heavy losses: seventy killed and seventy captured. Most of them were leaders, chiefs, and champions. When the war was over, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) came and stood over the killed and said: “What a bad tribe you were to your Prophet! You disbelieved me, while the people believed me; you abandoned me, while the people helped me; you drove me out, while the people gave me refuge.” Then he ordered them to be dragged to a well (Qalīb) in Badr. Mecca Receives the News of the Defeat: The polytheists fled from the field of Badr in a disorganized manner. They scattered in the valleys and ravines and headed towards Mecca, terrified, not knowing how to enter it out of shame. Ibn Ishaq said that the first to arrive with the news of Quraysh’s disaster was Al-Haysuman bin 'Abdullah Al-Khuza'i. They asked: “What is behind you?” He replied: “'Utbah bin Rabi'ah, Shaybah bin Rabi'ah, Abu Al-Hakam bin Hisham, and Umayyah bin Khalaf were killed, along with other leaders whom he named.” As he began to count the nobles of Quraysh, Safwan bin Umayyah, who was sitting in the sanctuary (Al-Hijr), said: “By Allah, this man is not sensible. Ask him about me.” They asked: “What happened to Safwan bin Umayyah?” He replied: “He is sitting right there in the sanctuary. By Allah, I saw his father and his brother being killed.” Abu Rafi' – the freed slave of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) – said: “I was a slave of Al-'Abbas, and Islam had entered our household. Al-'Abbas converted to Islam, Umm Al-Fadl converted, and I converted. Al-'Abbas kept his Islam a secret. Abu Lahab had stayed behind from Badr. When the news reached him, Allah afflicted him with grief and humiliation. We felt strength and pride within ourselves. I was a weak man who made cups, carving them in the chamber of Zamzam. By Allah, I was sitting there carving my cups, and Umm Al-Fadl was sitting beside me. We were overjoyed by the news that reached us, when Abu Lahab approached, dragging his feet with evil, and sat by the rope of the chamber, his back to mine. While he was sitting, the people said: ‘This is Abu Sufyan bin Al-Harith bin 'Abd Al-Muttalib who has arrived.’ Abu Lahab said to him: ‘Come here! By my life, you have the news!’” He said: “He sat with him, and the people were standing around them. [Abu Lahab] asked: ‘O my nephew, tell me what happened to the people.’ He replied: ‘As soon as we met the enemy, we turned our backs to them. They were killing us as they wished and capturing us as they wished.’ He added: ‘By Allah, despite that, I do not blame the people. We met white men on dappled horses between the sky and the earth. By Allah, they spared nothing, and nothing could stand against them.’ ” Abu Rafi' said: “I lifted the rope of the chamber with my hand and then said: ‘By Allah, those were the angels!’ Abu Lahab raised his hand and struck my face a severe blow. I wrestled with him, but he lifted me up, threw me to the ground, and then knelt on me, beating me. I was a weak man. Umm Al-Fadl stood up, took a pillar of the chamber, and struck him with it, inflicting a nasty wound on his head. She said: ‘You overpower him because his master is absent!’ He stood up, turning away in humiliation. By Allah, he lived only seven nights until Allah afflicted him with Al-'Adasah (a plague-like sore which the Arabs considered a bad omen) and it killed him. His sons abandoned him, and he remained for three days without anyone approaching his corpse or attempting to bury him.
