When they feared the disgrace of leaving him, they dug a pit for him, then pushed him into his grave with a stick, and pelted him with stones from a distance until they covered him up. The Jews and the hypocrites had spread alarm in Medina by circulating false rumors, even spreading the news of the killing of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). When one of the hypocrites saw Zayd bin Harithah riding Al-Qaswa' – the she-camel of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) – he said: “Muhammad has been killed, and this is his she-camel that we recognize, and this Zayd is so terrified he doesn't know what he is saying, and he came back alone.” When the two messengers arrived, the Muslims surrounded them and began to hear the news from them until the Muslims’ victory was confirmed. Joy and happiness spread, and the city resonated with Tahlil (saying 'La ilaha illa Allah') and Takbir (saying 'Allahu Akbar'). The leaders of the Muslims – who were in Medina – headed towards the road to Badr to congratulate the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) on this clear victory. Usamah bin Zayd said: “The news reached us when we were covering Ruqayyah, the daughter of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), with earth. She was the wife of 'Uthman bin 'Affan. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) had left me with 'Uthman to look after her.” __________________ The Issue of the Prisoners: When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) reached Medina, he consulted his companions about the prisoners. Abu Bakr said: “O Messenger of Allah, these are our cousins, our tribe, and our brothers. I suggest that you take ransom from them. What we take will be a source of strength for us against the disbelievers, and perhaps Allah will guide them, and they will become a support for us.” The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) asked: “What is your opinion, O Ibn Al-Khattab?” 'Umar said: “By Allah, I do not agree with Abu Bakr’s opinion. Rather, I think you should allow me to execute so-and-so – a relative of 'Umar – by striking his neck, and allow 'Ali to strike the neck of 'Aqil bin Abi Talib, and allow Hamzah to strike the neck of his brother so-and-so, so that Allah may know that there is no leniency in our hearts for the polytheists, and these are their champions, their leaders, and their commanders.” The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) preferred what Abu Bakr said and did not agree with what I said. He took ransom from them. The next day, 'Umar said: “I went to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and Abu Bakr, and they were weeping. I said: ‘O Messenger of Allah, tell me what makes you and your companion weep. If I find a reason to weep, I will weep, and if I do not find a reason, I will pretend to weep for your weeping.’ ” The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: “It is because of what your companions presented to me concerning taking the ransom. Their punishment was shown to me, closer than this tree – a nearby tree.” And Allah, the Almighty, revealed: “It is not for a Prophet to have captives until he has inflicted a great slaughter in the land. You desire the transient goods of this world, whereas Allah desires the Hereafter. And Allah is Exalted in Might and Wise. Had it not been for a prior decree from Allah, there would have touched you, for what you took, a great punishment.” [Al-Anfal: 67-68]. The matter was settled according to the opinion of As-Siddiq, and he took ransom from them. The ransom ranged from four thousand dirhams to three thousand dirhams, down to one thousand dirhams. The people of Mecca could write, but the people of Medina could not. Whoever did not have a ransom was entrusted with ten boys from the boys of Medina to teach. When they became proficient, that would be his ransom. [The Prophet] granted a favor to his son-in-law, Abu Al-'As, on the condition that he would release Zaynab. She had sent money for his ransom, which included a necklace that belonged to Khadijah and which she had given to him when she married her to Abu Al-'As. When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) saw it, he felt deep compassion for her and asked his companions for permission to release Abu Al-'As, which they did. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) stipulated to Abu Al-'As that he should release Zaynab, and he did. She emigrated, and the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) sent Zayd bin Harithah and a man from the Ansar, saying: “Wait in the valley of Ya'jaj until Zaynab passes by, and then accompany her.” They went out and returned with her. The story of her emigration is long and painful. Among the prisoners was Suhayl bin 'Amr, who was an eloquent orator. 'Umar said: “O Messenger of Allah, pull out the two front teeth of Suhayl bin 'Amr so that his tongue hangs out, and he will never be able to deliver a speech against you in any gathering.” However, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) refused this request, cautioning against mutilation and the retribution of Allah on the Day of Resurrection. In the second year of the Hijra, the fasting of Ramadan was made obligatory, as was Zakat Al-Fitr (charity of fast-breaking), and the shares of the other forms of Zakat were specified. The obligation of Zakat Al-Fitr and the detail of the other Zakat shares brought relief to many of the immigrant refugees who were poor and unable to travel and work the land. Among the best occasions and most marvelous coincidences was that the first 'Eid (festival) the Muslims celebrated in their lives was the 'Eid that occurred in Shawwal in the year 2 AH, following the clear victory they had achieved in the Battle of Badr. How splendid was this happy 'Eid that Allah brought them after crowning their heads with the diadem of victory and glory! And how magnificent was the sight of that prayer they performed after leaving their homes, raising their voices with Takbir (saying 'Allahu Akbar'), Tawhid (affirming the Oneness of Allah), and Tahmid (saying 'Alhamdulillah'), their hearts overflowing with yearning for Allah and longing for His mercy and satisfaction, after the favors He had bestowed upon them and the victory with which He had supported them, reminding them by saying: “And remember when you were few and oppressed in the land, fearing that people might abduct you, but He sheltered you and supported you with His victory and provided you with good things, that you might be grateful.” [Al-Anfal: 26] Battle of Uhud Quraysh Prepares for a Vengeful Battle: Mecca was burning with rage against the Muslims because of the tragedy of defeat and the killing of the champions and nobles it had suffered in the Battle of Badr. The desire for revenge and retaliation was surging within it, so much so that Quraysh had even forbidden weeping for their dead in Badr and prevented the hasty ransoming of prisoners so that the Muslims would not realize the extent of their tragedy and grief. Following the Battle of Badr, Quraysh agreed to wage a total war against the Muslims to quench its rage and satisfy its thirst for hatred. It began preparations to engage in such a battle. 'Ikrimah bin Abu Jahl, Safwan bin Umayyah, Abu Sufyan bin Harb, and 'Abdullah bin Rabi'ah were the most active and enthusiastic leaders of Quraysh in pursuing the battle. The first thing they did in this regard was to confiscate the caravan that Abu Sufyan had managed to save and which had been the cause of the Battle of Badr. They said to those whose property was in the caravan: “O people of Quraysh, Muhammad has victimized you and killed your best men. Help us with this wealth to fight him, so that we may perhaps take our revenge from him.” They agreed to this, and the caravan was sold. It contained a thousand camels, and the wealth was fifty thousand dinars. Concerning this, Allah, the Almighty, revealed: “Indeed, those who disbelieve spend their wealth to hinder [people] from the way of Allah. They will spend it; then it will be for them a source of regret; then they will be overcome.” [Al-Anfal: 36]. Then they opened the door to volunteering for all who wished to participate in the invasion of the Muslims, from the Ahabish, Kinanah, and the people of Tihamah. They employed various methods of incitement. Safwan bin Umayyah incited Abu 'Izzah the poet – who had been captured at Badr and whom the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) had granted favor and released without ransom, taking a pledge from him not to rise against him – to incite the tribes against the Muslims. He promised him that if he returned alive from the raid, he would enrich him, and if not, he would take care of his daughters. Abu 'Izzah proceeded to incite the tribes with his poems, which inflamed their grudges. They also chose another poet – Musafi' bin 'Abd Manaf Al-Jumahi – for the same task. Abu Sufyan was the most fervent inciter against the Muslims after returning disappointed from the Expedition of As-Suwayq, having failed to achieve his goal and having lost a large amount of his supplies in that expedition. What further complicated the matter – or fueled the fire – was the heavy loss that Quraysh had recently suffered in the expedition of Zayd bin Harithah, which broke the back of their economy and caused them immeasurable grief and anxiety. At that point, Quraysh accelerated its preparations to engage in a decisive battle against the Muslims. Composition and Command of the Quraysh Army: By the turn of the year, Mecca had completed its preparations. Three thousand polytheist fighters from Quraysh, its allies, and the Ahabish had gathered. The leaders of Quraysh decided to take their women with them so that it would be a greater incentive for the men to fight to the death to protect their honor and chastity. The number of these women was fifteen. The transport equipment for this army consisted of three thousand camels, and the cavalry consisted of two hundred horses, which they led alongside them for the entire journey. The protective gear included seven hundred suits of armor. The overall command was given to Abu Sufyan bin Harb, and the command of the cavalry to Khalid bin Al-Walid, assisted by 'Ikrimah bin Abu Jahl. The banner was entrusted to Banu 'Abd Ad-Dar. Mecca's Army Marches: After this complete preparation, the Meccan army marched towards Medina. The old blood feuds and the hidden rage were kindling hatred in hearts, revealing the bitterness of the coming fight. Prophetic Intelligence Uncovers the Enemy's Movement: Al-'Abbas bin 'Abd Al-Muttalib was monitoring the movements and military preparations of Quraysh. When this army set out, Al-'Abbas sent an urgent message to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) containing all the details of the army. Al-'Abbas's messenger hastened to deliver the message, traveling with determination, so much so that he covered the distance between Mecca and Medina – which is about five hundred kilometers – in three days. He delivered the message to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) while he was at the Quba Mosque. Ubayy bin Ka'b read the letter to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), who ordered him to keep it secret. [The Prophet] quickly returned to Medina and exchanged views with the leaders of the Muhajiroun and the Ansar. Muslim Preparation for Emergencies: Medina remained in a state of general alert. The men did not part with their weapons, even during prayer, in anticipation of emergencies. A detachment of the Ansar – including Sa'd bin Mu'adh, Usayd bin Hudayr, and Sa'd bin 'Ubadah – was assigned to guard the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). They spent the night at his door, armed. Detachments were stationed at the entrances and defiles of Medina to guard it, fearing that they might be taken by surprise. Muslim patrols – to discover the enemy's movements – roamed around the routes that the polytheists were likely to take to raid the Muslims. The Meccan Army Reaches Medina's Walls: The Meccan army continued its march on the usual main western road. When it reached Al-Abwa', Hind bint 'Utbah – the wife of Abu Sufyan – suggested digging up the grave of the Messenger of Allah's mother (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). However, the army commanders rejected this request and warned against the dire consequences that would befall them if they opened this door. Then the Meccan army continued its march until it approached Medina. It took the valley of Al-'Aqiq, then turned right until it camped near Mount Uhud in a place called 'Aynayn, in the salty bed of Qanat on the edge of the valley – which is north of Medina – and encamped there on Friday, the sixth of the month of Shawwal, in the third year of the Hijra. Continuation of the Battle of Uhud Organization of the Islamic Army and Departure to the Battlefield: Then the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) led the people in the Friday prayer. He exhorted them and commanded them to be diligent and hardworking. He informed them that victory would be theirs through their patience and ordered them to prepare for their enemy. The people were pleased with this. Then he led the people in the 'Asr (afternoon) prayer. They had gathered, and the people of Al-'Awali were present. Then he entered his house with his two companions, Abu Bakr and 'Umar. They helped him put on his turban and clothing. He fully armed himself, wearing a double coat of mail (i.e., wearing one armor over another) and strapping on his sword. Then he came out to the people. The people were waiting for his departure. Sa'd bin Mu'adh and Usayd bin Hudayr had told them: “Have you compelled the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to go out? Refer the matter back to him.” They all regretted what they had done. When he came out, they said to him: “O Messenger of Allah, it was not for us to disobey you. Do as you wish. If you prefer to stay in Medina, then do so.” The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: “It is not fitting for a Prophet, once he has put on his defensive gear (Lammatuhu – which is the armor), to take it off until Allah judges between him and his enemy.” The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) divided his army into three battalions: 1. The Battalion of the Muhajiroun (Emigrants). He gave its banner to Mus'ab bin 'Umayr Al-'Abdari. 2. The Battalion of the Aws (from the Ansar). He gave its banner to Usayd bin Hudayr. 3. The Battalion of the Khazraj (from the Ansar). He gave its banner to Al-Hubab bin Al-Mundhir. The army consisted of a thousand fighters, including a hundred in armor and fifty cavalrymen, although some said there were no cavalrymen. He appointed Ibn Umm Maktum to lead the prayer in Medina for those who remained there. The command to depart was given, and the army moved north. The two Sa'd (Sa'd bin Mu'adh and Sa'd bin 'Ubadah) ran ahead of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), both in armor. When he passed the pass of Ath-Thaniyyat Al-Wada', he saw a well-armed battalion separated from the main body of the army. He asked who they were. He was told they were Jews, allies of the Khazraj, who wished to participate in the fighting against the polytheists. He asked if they had embraced Islam. They replied: “No.” He refused to use the help of the people of disbelief against the people of polytheism. Reviewing the Army: When he reached a place called Ash-Shaykhan, he reviewed his army and sent back those he deemed too young or unable to fight. Among them were 'Abdullah bin 'Umar bin Al-Khattab, Usamah bin Zayd, Usayd bin Zuhayr, Zayd bin Thabit, Zayd bin Arqam, 'Arabah bin Aws, 'Amr bin Hazm, Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, Zayd bin Harithah Al-Ansari, and Sa'd bin Habbah. Al-Bara' bin 'Azib is mentioned among them, but his narration in Al-Bukhari indicates that he witnessed the fighting that day. He allowed Rafi' bin Khadij and Samurah bin Jundub to stay despite their young age. Rafi' bin Khadij was skilled in archery, so he permitted him. Samurah said: “I am stronger than Rafi', I can wrestle him down.” When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was informed of this, he ordered them to wrestle in front of him. They wrestled, and Samurah wrestled Rafi' down, so he also permitted him to stay. Spending the Night between Uhud and Medina: At this location, evening overtook them. He prayed the Maghrib prayer, then the Isha prayer, and spent the night there. He selected fifty men to guard the camp, patrolling around it. Their leader was Muhammad bin Maslamah Al-Ansari, the hero of the expedition of Ka'b bin Al-Ashraf. Dhakwan bin 'Abd Qays took on the special task of guarding the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). The Mutiny of 'Abdullah bin Ubayy and his Companions: A little before dawn, he set out and reached Ash-Shawth for the Fajr prayer. He was close to the enemy; he could see them, and they could see him. It was there that 'Abdullah bin Ubayy, the hypocrite, mutinied and withdrew with about a third of the army – three hundred fighters – saying: “We do not know why we should kill ourselves!” He outwardly protested that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) had abandoned his opinion and obeyed others. Undoubtedly, the reason for this isolation was not the Prophet's rejection of this hypocrite's opinion, otherwise, his marching with the Prophet's army to this location would have had no meaning. If that had been the reason, he would have isolated himself from the army from the beginning of the march. Rather, his primary goal in this mutiny – at that critical moment – was to cause confusion and disorder in the Muslim army, in the sight and hearing of their enemy. This was so that the majority of the army would abandon the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and the morale of those who remained with him would collapse, while the enemy would be encouraged, and their determination would increase upon seeing this sight. This would hasten the elimination of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and his sincere companions, thus clearing the way for the return of authority to this hypocrite and his followers. The hypocrite nearly succeeded in achieving some of his goals. Two factions – Banu Harithah from the Aws and Banu Salamah from the Khazraj – were about to waver, but Allah took them under His protection, and they stood firm after anxiety spread among them and they almost retreated and withdrew. Concerning them, Allah, the Almighty, says: “When two parties among you intended to lose heart, but Allah was their Protector. And upon Allah let the believers rely.” [Al-Imran: 122]. 'Abdullah bin Haram – the father of Jabir bin 'Abdullah – tried to remind these hypocrites of their duty in this critical situation. He followed them, rebuking them and urging them to return, saying: “Come and fight in the way of Allah or defend!” They replied: “If we knew there would be a fight, we would have followed you.” 'Abdullah bin Haram returned from them saying: “May Allah keep you away, O enemies of Allah! Allah will suffice His Prophet without you.” Concerning these hypocrites, Allah, the Almighty, says: “And that He might make evident those who are hypocrites, to whom it was said, 'Come, fight in the way of Allah or [at least] repel [the enemy].' They said, 'If we had known [there would be] fighting, we would have followed you.' They were that day nearer to disbelief than to faith. They say with their mouths what is not in their hearts. And Allah is most knowing of what they conceal.” [Al-Imran: 167] Continuation of the Battle of Uhud The Defense Plan: There, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) organized his army and prepared them in ranks for battle. He selected a detachment of fifty skilled archers, and entrusted their command to 'Abdullah bin Jubayr bin An-Nu'man Al-Ansari Al-Awsi Al-Badri. He ordered them to be stationed on a hill located on the southern bank of the Wadi Qanat – which later became known as the Mount of the Archers (Jabal Ar-Rumat) – southeast of the Muslim camp, about one hundred and fifty meters from the headquarters of the Islamic army. The purpose of this was what the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) made clear in his words to these archers. He said to their commander: “Ward off the cavalry from us with arrows, so they do not come at us from behind. Whether the battle is for us or against us, remain firm in your position; let us not be attacked from your side.” Then he said to the archers: “Protect our backs. If you see us being killed, do not come to our aid. And if you see us taking spoils, do not join us in taking them.” In Al-Bukhari's narration, he said: “If you see us being snatched by the birds, do not leave your place until I send for you. And if you see us defeating the people and overrunning them, do not leave until I send for you.” By assigning this detachment to the hill with these strict military orders, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) sealed the only breach through which the polytheist cavalry could have infiltrated the ranks of the Muslims, executed flanking maneuvers, and an encircling operation. As for the rest of the army, he placed Al-Mundhir bin 'Amr on the right flank and Az-Zubayr bin Al-'Awwam on the left flank, supported by Al-Miqdad bin Al-Aswad. Az-Zubayr had the task of standing firm against the cavalry of Khalid bin Al-Walid. He placed at the front of the ranks an excellent elite of brave Muslims and men renowned for their valor and bravery, whose value was equal to thousands. It was a very wise and precise plan, reflecting the genius of the Prophet's military leadership (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) – and that no commander, no matter how advanced his competence, could have devised a plan more precise and wiser than this. He occupied the best position on the battlefield, even though he arrived there after the enemy. He protected his back and his right side with the mountain's heights, and protected his left side and his back – when the fighting raged – by sealing the only breach that existed on the side of the Islamic army. He chose an elevated position for his camp, which he could retreat to – if defeat befell the Muslims – and not resort to flight, which would expose him to falling into the hands of the pursuing enemies and being captured. He would also inflict heavy losses on his enemies if they wished to occupy his camp and advanced towards it. He forced his enemies to accept a low position, which would make it very difficult for them to gain any benefits of victory if they were to dominate, and difficult for them to escape the pursuing Muslims if the domination was with the Muslims. He also compensated for the numerical shortage of his men by selecting an excellent elite of outstanding brave companions. Thus, the Prophet's army was mobilized on the morning of Saturday, the seventh of the month of Shawwal, in the 3rd year of the Hijra. The Messenger (PBUH) Instills the Spirit of Valor in the Army: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) forbade the people from engaging in combat until he ordered them. He wore a double coat of mail and exhorted his companions to fight, encouraging them to persevere and show bravery upon the encounter. He began to instill the spirit of enthusiasm and valor in his companions – to the extent that he brandished a sharp sword and called out to his companions: “Who will take this sword with its due right?” Men rose to take it – among them 'Ali bin Abi Talib, Az-Zubayr bin Al-'Awwam, and 'Umar bin Al-Khattab – until Abu Dujanah Simak bin Kharashah stood up and asked: “And what is its due right, O Messenger of Allah?” He replied: “That you strike the faces of the enemy with it until it bends.” He said: “I will take it with its due right, O Messenger of Allah.” So he gave it to him. Abu Dujanah was a brave man who walked with arrogance during war. He had a red headband, and when he wore it, people knew he would fight to the death. When he took the sword, he wrapped his head with that headband and began to stride proudly between the ranks. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) then said: “That is a walk which Allah detests, except in a situation like this.” The First Fuel of the Battle: The two armies approached, and the two factions drew near. The stages of fighting began. The first to fuel the battle was the standard-bearer of the polytheists, Talhah bin Abi Talhah Al-'Abdari. He was one of the bravest knights of Quraysh. The Muslims called him the ram of the battalion. He came out riding a camel, calling for a duel. People held back from him because of his extreme bravery. But Az-Zubayr advanced towards him and gave him no respite, leaping upon him like a lion until he was with him on his camel. Then he pushed him to the ground, threw him off, and slaughtered him with his sword. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) saw this magnificent struggle, pronounced the Takbir (Allahu Akbar), and the Muslims did the same. He praised Az-Zubayr and said concerning him: “Every Prophet has a disciple (Hawari), and the disciple (Hawari) is Az-Zubayr.” The Weight of the Battle Around the Banner and the Annihilation of its Bearers: Then the fires of the battle erupted, and the fighting intensified between the two sides at every point on the field. The weight of the battle revolved around the banner of the polytheists. The Banu 'Abd Ad-Dar took turns carrying the banner after their leader, Talhah bin Abi Talhah, was killed. His brother, Abu Shaybah 'Uthman bin Abi Talhah, carried it and advanced to fight, saying: “There is a duty upon the bearers of the banner To dye the spear-shaft with blood or to shatter it.” Hamzah bin 'Abd Al-Muttalib charged him and struck him on his shoulder with a blow that severed his hand along with his shoulder, reaching his navel, and exposing his lung. Then Abu Sa'd bin Abi Talhah raised the banner. Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas shot him with an arrow that hit his throat, making his tongue hang out. He died instantly. It is also said that Abu Sa'd came out calling for a duel. 'Ali bin Abi Talib advanced to him. They exchanged two blows, and 'Ali struck him and killed him. Then Musafi' bin Talhah bin Abi Talhah raised the banner. 'Asim bin Thabit bin Abi Al-Aflah shot him with an arrow and killed him. His brother Kullab bin Talhah bin Abi Talhah then carried the banner. Az-Zubayr bin Al-'Awwam swooped down on him and fought him until he killed him. Then their brother Al-Jallas bin Talhah bin Abi Talhah carried the banner. Talhah bin 'Ubaydullah stabbed him with a thrust that ended his life. It is also said that 'Asim bin Thabit bin Abi Al-Aflah shot him with an arrow and finished him off. These were six men from one house, the house of Abu Talhah 'Abdullah bin 'Uthman bin 'Abd Ad-Dar, all killed around the banner of the polytheists. Then Arta'ah bin Shurahbil from Banu 'Abd Ad-Dar carried it. 'Ali bin Abi Talib killed him. It is also said: Hamzah bin 'Abd Al-Muttalib. Then Shurayh bin Qarizh carried it. Quzman killed him – he was a hypocrite who fought with the Muslims out of tribal zeal, not for Islam. Then Abu Zayd 'Amr bin 'Abd Manaf Al-'Abdari carried it. Quzman also killed him. Then a son of Shurahbil bin Hashim Al-'Abdari carried it. Quzman also killed him. These were ten men from Banu 'Abd Ad-Dar – the bearers of the banner – who were annihilated to the last man. There was no one left to carry the banner. Then a young Abyssinian slave of theirs – named Sawab – came forward, carried the banner, and displayed a variety of bravery and steadfastness that surpassed his masters, the banner bearers who were killed before him. He fought until both his hands were cut off. He lay down on the banner with his chest and neck so that it would not fall until he was killed, saying: “O Allah, have I fulfilled my duty?” (meaning: Have I done all that I could?) After this slave – Sawab – was killed, the banner fell to the ground, and there was no one left to carry it. It remained fallen. Continuation of the Battle of Uhud The Martyrdom of Hamzah bin 'Abd Al-Muttalib, the Lion of Allah: Wahshi bin Harb, the killer of Hamzah, said: “I was a slave of Jubayr bin Mut'im, and his uncle, Tu'aymah bin 'Adiyy, had been killed on the Day of Badr. When Quraysh marched to Uhud, Jubayr said to me: ‘If you kill Hamzah, Muhammad's uncle, to avenge my uncle, you are free.’” He said: “I went out with the people – I was an Abyssinian who threw the spear as Abyssinians throw, seldom missing anything.” He said: “When the people met, I went out to watch Hamzah. I saw him in the midst of the people like a dark gray camel, cleaving through the people, with nothing standing up to him. By Allah, I was preparing for him, seeking him, concealing myself behind a tree or a rock so that he would come close to me, when Siba' bin 'Abd Al-'Uzza advanced towards him. When Hamzah saw him, he said to him: ‘Come to me, O son of the clitoris-cutter!’ (His mother was a circumciser). He said: “Hamzah struck him a blow that did not miss his head.” He said: “I shook my spear, and when I was satisfied with it, I thrust it at him. It struck his groin – his entrails – and came out between his legs. He tried to get up towards me but failed. I left him with it until he died. Then I came to him, took my spear, and returned to the camp. I sat there, having no need for anything else, for I had only killed him to be set free. When I reached Mecca, I was set free.” Maintaining Control of the Situation: Despite this heavy loss sustained by the Muslims with the martyrdom of Hamzah bin 'Abd Al-Muttalib, the Lion of Allah and the Lion of His Messenger, the Muslims maintained full control of the situation. Abu Bakr, 'Umar bin Al-Khattab, 'Ali bin Abi Talib, Az-Zubayr bin Al-'Awwam, Mus'ab bin 'Umayr, Talhah bin 'Ubaydullah, 'Abdullah bin Jahsh, Sa'd bin Mu'adh, Sa'd bin 'Ubadah, Sa'd bin Ar-Rabi', Anas bin An-Nadr, and their like, fought that day with a bravery that broke the resolve of the polytheists and weakened their limbs. From the Embrace of a Wife to the Clashing of Swords and Shields: Among the adventurous heroes that day was Hanzalah Al-Ghasil (The Washed by the Angels), who was Hanzalah bin Abi 'Amir. This Abu 'Amir is the monk who was nicknamed Al-Fasiq (the wicked one) and was mentioned recently. Hanzalah was newly married. When he heard the calls to war while he was with his wife, he broke free from her embrace and immediately went out for Jihad. When he met the polytheist army on the battlefield, he began to cleave through the ranks until he reached the commander of the polytheists, Abu Sufyan Sakhr bin Harb. He almost killed him, had it not been that Allah granted him martyrdom. He charged Abu Sufyan. As he overpowered him and gained control, Shaddad bin Al-Aswad saw him and struck him until he killed him. The Role of the Archers' Detachment in the Battle: The detachment that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) had appointed on the Mount of the Archers played a crucial role in directing the course of the battle in favor of the Islamic army. The Meccan cavalry, led by Khalid bin Al-Walid and assisted by Abu 'Amir Al-Fasiq, attacked three times to break the left flank of the Islamic army, so that they could infiltrate behind the Muslims, cause confusion and turmoil in their ranks, and inflict a crushing defeat upon them. However, these archers pelted them with arrows, causing all three of their attacks to fail. Defeat Befalls the Polytheists: Thus the grinding of the fierce war turned. The small Islamic army maintained complete control of the situation until the resolve of the polytheist champions weakened, and their ranks began to scatter right, left, front, and back, as if three thousand polytheists were facing thirty thousand Muslims, not a few hundred. The Muslims displayed the highest forms of bravery and certainty. After Quraysh exerted its utmost effort to repel the Muslim attack, it felt helplessness and weakness. Its resolve was broken – to the extent that no one dared to approach their banner, which had fallen after the killing of Sawab, to carry it and resume the fighting around it. They began to withdraw and resorted to flight, forgetting what they had been saying in their hearts about taking revenge, retaliation, and restoring their glory, majesty, and dignity. Ibn Ishaq said: “Then Allah sent down His victory upon the Muslims and fulfilled His promise to them. They were cutting them down with swords until they drove them away from the camp. There was no doubt about the defeat.” 'Abdullah bin Az-Zubayr narrated from his father that he said: “By Allah, I saw myself looking at the ankles – or calves – of Hind bint 'Utbah and her companions, fleeing, tucking up their garments, with their ankle bracelets visible.” etc. And in the hadith of Al-Bara' bin 'Azib in Al-Bukhari's Sahih: “When we met them, they fled until I saw the women running up the hill, lifting their legs so that their ankle bracelets became visible.” The Muslims pursued the polytheists, striking them with weapons and collecting the spoils. The Fatal Mistake of the Archers: While the small Islamic army was once again recording a crushing victory over Mecca, no less magnificent than the victory they had gained at Badr, the majority of the archers' detachment committed a fatal mistake that completely changed the situation, led to heavy losses for the Muslims, and nearly caused the killing of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). It left the worst impact on their reputation and the prestige they had enjoyed after Badr. We have already mentioned the texts of the strict orders issued by the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to these archers, commanding them to remain at their position on the hill in all circumstances, whether victory or defeat. However, despite these strict orders, when these archers saw the Muslims plundering the enemy's spoils, a trace of love for this world overcame them. Some of them said to others: “The spoils! The spoils! Your companions have prevailed, what are you waiting for?” As for their commander, 'Abdullah bin Jubayr, he reminded them of the Messenger of Allah's orders (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and said: “Have you forgotten what the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) told you?” But the overwhelming majority paid no attention to this reminder and said: “By Allah, we will go to the people and take our share of the spoils!” Forty men from these archers then abandoned their positions on the hill and joined the main body of the army to participate in collecting the spoils. Thus, the backs of the Muslims were exposed, and only Ibn Jubayr and nine of his companions remained, resolutely holding their positions. Khalid ibn al-Walid seized this golden opportunity, making a lightning-fast maneuver until he reached the rear of the Muslim army. He soon annihilated 'Abdullah ibn Jubayr and his companions, then swooped down upon the Muslims from behind. His horsemen raised a shout by which the defeated polytheists realized the new development and turned back upon the Muslims. A woman among them – 'Amra bint 'Alqamah al-Harithiyyah – rushed forward and raised the polytheists' banner that lay on the ground. The polytheists rallied around it and gathered to it, calling one another until they united against the Muslims and stood firm for combat. The Muslims were surrounded from the front and the rear, caught between the two millstones.\r \r ## The Prophet's Valiant Stance Against the Encirclement:\r \r The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him - PBSD) was then in a small detachment – nine men of his Companions – at the rear of the Muslims. He was observing the Muslims' fierce fighting and pursuit of the polytheists when he was completely taken by surprise by Khalid's cavalry. He had two paths before him: either to save himself and his nine Companions quickly to a safe refuge, leaving his surrounded army to its predetermined fate, or to risk his life by calling his Companions to gather around him, establishing a strong front with them to break a path for his surrounded army toward the hills of Uhud.\r \r It was there that the genius and unparalleled bravery of the Messenger (PBSD) were manifested. He raised his voice, calling his Companions: “O Servants of Allah!” – knowing that the polytheists would hear his voice before the Muslims. Yet, he called and invited them, risking his life in that critical moment.\r \r Indeed, the polytheists became aware of him and rushed to him before the Muslims could reach him.\r \r ## The Dispersion of the Muslims in the Situation:\r \r As for the Muslims, when they were encircled, a faction of them lost their composure, caring only for themselves. They took the path of flight and abandoned the battlefield, not knowing what lay behind them. Some of this faction fled to Medina until they entered it, and some darted up the mountain. Another faction returned and became intermixed with the polytheists, and the two armies were confused and indistinguishable, resulting in the killing of Muslims by one another. Al-Bukhari reported from 'Aisha, who said: “When it was the Day of Uhud, the polytheists were clearly defeated, then Iblis (Satan) shouted: 'O Servants of Allah! Your rear!' – meaning: beware of those behind you – so their vanguard returned and fought their rearguard. Hudhayfah looked and saw his father, Al-Yaman, and cried out: 'O Servants of Allah, my father, my father!' She said: By Allah, they did not desist from him until they killed him. Then Hudhayfah said: 'May Allah forgive you.' 'Urwah said: By Allah, a remnant of good remained in Hudhayfah until he met Allah.”\r \r Severe disarray and chaos spread within the ranks of this faction. Many of them were lost, not knowing where to turn. While they were in this state, they heard a shouter proclaim: “Muhammad has been killed!” The last of their composure vanished, and the morale of many individuals collapsed or almost collapsed. Those who stopped fighting threw down their weapons in resignation, while others considered contacting 'Abdullah ibn Ubayy – the head of the hypocrites – to secure safe passage for them from Abu Sufyan.\r \r Anas ibn an-Nadr passed by these men who had resigned themselves and asked: “What are you waiting for?” They replied: “The Messenger of Allah (PBSD) has been killed.” He said: “What will you do with life after him? Stand up and die upon what the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) died upon!” Then he said: “O Allah, I apologize to You for what these (Muslims) have done, and I disavow myself before You from what those (polytheists) have done.” Then he advanced and met Sa'd ibn Mu'adh, and asked: “Where, O Abu 'Umar?” Anas replied: “Ah, the scent of Paradise, O Sa'd! I find it below Uhud!” Then he went on and fought the people until he was killed. He was not recognized until his sister recognized him by his fingers after the battle ended. He had between eighty and eighty-nine wounds from stabs by a spear, strikes by a sword, and shots from an arrow.\r \r Thabit ibn ad-Dahdah called out to his people: “O company of the Ansar! If Muhammad has been killed, Allah is Living and never dies! Fight for your religion, for Allah will grant you victory and aid you!” A number of Ansars rose to him, and he led them in a charge against Khalid's cavalry. He kept fighting them until Khalid killed him with a spear, and his companions were also killed.\r \r A man from the Muhajirun passed by a man from the Ansar who was wallowing in his blood and said: “O so-and-so, did you hear that Muhammad has been killed?” The Ansari replied: “If Muhammad has been killed, he has already conveyed [the message], so fight for your religion!”\r \r With such bravery and encouragement, the moral spirit returned to the Muslim soldiers, and their good sense and composure came back to them. They abandoned the idea of surrender or contacting Ibn Ubayy, took up their weapons, and began attacking the streams of polytheists, trying to force a path to the command center. News reached them that the report of the Prophet's (PBSD) death was a fabricated lie, which added strength to their strength. They succeeded in escaping the encirclement and gathering around a fortified center after engaging in fierce fighting and battling with extreme ferocity.\r \r There was a third faction whose only concern was the Messenger of Allah (PBSD). This faction rallied to the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) at the very beginning of the encirclement. At the forefront of these were Abu Bakr as-Siddiq, 'Umar ibn al-Khattab, 'Ali ibn Abi Talib, and others (may Allah be pleased with them). They were at the forefront of the combatants, but when they sensed the danger to his noble person – (peace and prayers be upon him) – they became the forefront of the defenders.\r \r ## The Intensification of the Fighting Around the Messenger of Allah (PBSD):\r \r While those factions were enduring the grips of the encirclement, being ground between the two millstones of the polytheists, the struggle was intensifying around the Messenger of Allah (PBSD). We mentioned that when the polytheists began the encirclement, there were only nine men with the Messenger of Allah (PBSD). When he called out to the Muslims, “Come to me! I am the Messenger of Allah!” the polytheists heard his voice and recognized him. They rushed toward him, attacking him and moving toward him with their full weight before any of the Muslim army could return to him. A fierce struggle ensued between the polytheists and these nine Companions, in which rare examples of love, self-sacrifice, valor, and heroism emerged.\r \r Muslim reported from Anas ibn Malik that the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) was isolated on the Day of Uhud with seven men from the Ansar and two men from Quraysh. When they pressed hard upon him, he said: “Who will ward them off from us and be guaranteed Paradise? Or be my companion in Paradise?” A man from the Ansar advanced and fought until he was killed. Then they pressed hard upon him again, and it continued until all seven were killed. Then the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) said to his two companions – the two Qurayshites – “Our companions did not treat us justly.”\r \r The last of these seven was 'Umarah ibn Yazid ibn as-Sakan, who fought until he was rendered immobile by wounds and fell.\r \r ## The Most Critical Hour in the Prophet's Life (PBSD):\r \r After the fall of Ibn as-Sakan, the Messenger (PBSD) was left only with the two Qurayshites. It is reported in the two Sahih collections from Abu 'Uthman that he said: “There remained with the Prophet (PBSD) on some of those days when he was fighting only Talhah ibn 'Ubaydullah and Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas.” This was the most critical hour concerning the life of the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) and a golden opportunity for the polytheists. The polytheists did not hesitate to seize this opportunity. They focused their attack on the Prophet (PBSD) and hoped to eliminate him. 'Utbah ibn Abi Waqqas threw stones at him, causing him to fall on his side. His lower right incisor was broken, and his lower lip was wounded. 'Abdullah ibn Shihab az-Zuhri came forward and gashed his forehead. A stubborn horseman, 'Abdullah ibn Qami'ah, struck his shoulder with a fierce sword blow from which he complained for over a month, but he was unable to penetrate the two coats of mail. Then he struck his cheek (PBSD) with another fierce blow like the first, so that two links of the helmet's rings entered his cheek. He said: “Take that! I am Ibn Qami'ah!” The Messenger of Allah (PBSD), wiping the blood from his face, said: “May Allah abase you (O Ibn Qami'ah)!”\r \r It is reported in the Sahih that his incisor was broken and his head was gashed. He wiped the blood away and said: “How can a people prosper who gash the face of their Prophet and break his incisor while he calls them to Allah?” Then Allah, Exalted and Glorified be He, revealed: $$\{لَيْسَ لَكَ مِنَ الأَمْرِ شَيْءٌ أَوْ يَتُوبَ عَلَيْهِمْ أَوْ يُعَذِّبَهُمْ فَإِنَّهُمْ ظَالِمُونَ\}$$ (Al 'Imran: 128) - “Not for you is the decision (to condemn them or to forgive them), but (it is for Allah) to forgive them or to punish them; for indeed, they are wrongdoers.”\r \r In a narration by At-Tabarani, he said that day: “The wrath of Allah has intensified upon a people who bled the face of His Messenger.” Then he paused for a moment and said: “O Allah, forgive my people, for they do not know.” Likewise, in Sahih Muslim, he used to say: “My Lord, forgive my people, for they do not know.” And in *Ash-Shifa'* by Qadi 'Iyad, he said: “O Allah, guide my people, for they do not know.”\r \r There is no doubt that the polytheists aimed to put an end to the life of the Messenger of Allah (PBSD). However, the two Qurayshites, Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas and Talhah ibn 'Ubaydullah, displayed rare heroism and fought with unparalleled valor, ensuring that – though they were only two – there was no way for the polytheists to succeed in their goal. They were among the most skilled archers of the Arabs, and they shot arrows tirelessly until they drove the polytheist detachment away from the Messenger of Allah (PBSD).\r \r As for Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas, the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) handed him his quiver and said: “Shoot, may my father and my mother be ransomed for you!” The fact that the Prophet (PBSD) never combined his parents for anyone other than Sa'd indicates the extent of his competence.\r \r As for Talhah ibn 'Ubaydullah, An-Nasa'i reported from Jabir the story of the polytheists gathering around the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) while he was with a few men from the Ansar. Jabir said: “The polytheists caught up with the Messenger of Allah (PBSD). He said: 'Who will deal with them?' Talhah said: 'Me.'” Jabir then mentioned the advancement of the Ansar and their being killed one after the other, similar to the narration of Muslim. When all the Ansar were killed, Talhah advanced. Jabir said: “Then Talhah fought the fight of eleven men until his hand was struck and his fingers were cut off. He said: 'Hass (ouch).' The Prophet (PBSD) said: 'Had you said Bismillah (In the Name of Allah), the angels would have raised you up while people watched.' ” Jabir said: “Then Allah repelled the polytheists.” It is reported in *Al-Iklil* by Al-Hakim that he was wounded on the Day of Uhud with thirty-nine or thirty-five wounds, and his finger became paralyzed (the index and the one next to it).\r \r Al-Bukhari reported from Qays ibn Abi Hazim: “I saw Talhah's hand paralyzed; he had protected the Prophet (PBSD) with it on the Day of Uhud.”\r \r At-Tirmidhi reported that the Prophet (PBSD) said about him that day: “Whoever wishes to look at a martyr walking upon the face of the earth, let him look at Talhah ibn 'Ubaydullah.”\r \r Abu Dawud at-Tayalisi reported from 'Aisha: “When Abu Bakr mentioned the Day of Uhud, he would say: 'That entire day belonged to Talhah.' ”\r \r Abu Bakr also said about him:\r \r *“O Talhah ibn 'Ubaydullah, the Gardens have become incumbent upon you,\r And you have obtained the wide-eyed *Houris*.”*\r \r In that critical juncture and difficult hour, Allah sent down His unseen victory. In the two Sahih collections, Sa'd said: “I saw the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) on the Day of Uhud with two men fighting on his behalf, wearing white clothes, fighting with the fiercest intensity. I had never seen them before or after.” In one narration, they are identified as Jibril (Gabriel) and Mika'il (Michael).\r \r *\r \r ## The Battle of the Confederates (Al-Ahzab)\r \r Twenty men from the Jewish leaders and chiefs of Banu an-Nadir went out to Quraysh in Mecca, inciting them to invade the Messenger (PBSD) and promising them their support and victory. Quraysh responded favorably. Quraysh, having broken their promise to march out for Badr, saw this as an opportunity to save their reputation and fulfill their word.\r \r This delegation then went out to Ghatafan, inviting them to what they had invited Quraysh to, and they responded favorably. Then the delegation toured the Arab tribes, calling them to the same, and those who responded did so. Thus, the Jewish politicians and leaders succeeded in inciting the factions of disbelief (Al-Ahzab/the Confederates) against the Prophet (PBSD), his call, and the Muslims.\r \r Indeed, Quraysh, Kinanah, and their allies from Tihamah came out from the south – led by Abu Sufyan – with four thousand men. Banu Sulaym met them at Marr az-Zahran. From the east came the tribes of Ghatafan: Banu Fazara, led by 'Uyaynah ibn Hisn; Banu Murrah, led by al-Harith ibn 'Awf; and Banu Ashja', led by Mis'ar ibn Rukhaylah, as well as Banu Asad and others.\r \r These factions advanced and moved toward Medina, according to a pre-arranged agreement.\r \r After some days, a massive army of ten thousand fighters gathered around Medina. An army whose number perhaps exceeded all the women, children, youth, and elderly in Medina.\r \r If these mobilized and confederated armies had reached the walls of Medina suddenly, it would have posed the greatest danger to the existence of the Muslims, possibly leading to total eradication. However, the command of Medina was vigilant, keeping its fingers on the pulse, scouting the circumstances, and assessing the developments. No sooner had these armies moved from their positions than Medina's intelligence conveyed the news of this dangerous advance to its command.\r \r The Messenger of Allah (PBSD) quickly convened a Supreme Consultative Council to address the plan for the defense of Medina. After discussions between the leaders and the council members, they agreed upon a decision put forward by the noble Companion Salman al-Farisi (may Allah be pleased with him). Salman said: “O Messenger of Allah, when we were in the land of Persia, if we were besieged, we would dig a trench around us.” This was a wise strategy previously unknown to the Arabs.\r \r The Messenger of Allah (PBSD) hastened to implement this plan. He assigned every ten men to dig forty cubits of the trench.\r \r The Muslims worked with diligence and energy digging the trench, and the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) encouraged them and participated in their work. In Al-Bukhari, Sahl ibn Sa'd reported: “We were with the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) at the Trench, and they were digging, and we were carrying the soil on our shoulders. Then the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) said:\r \r 'O Allah! There is no life but the life of the Hereafter, so forgive the Emigrants and the Helpers.' ”\r \r The Muslims were working with this energy while enduring extreme hunger that broke their hearts. Anas said: “The people of the Trench were brought a handful of barley, which was prepared for them with hot fat and placed before the people, who were hungry. It was bitter in the throat and foul-smelling.”\r \r Abu Talhah said: “We complained to the Prophet (PBSD) about hunger and lifted our garments to show him a single stone tied to our bellies. Then the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) lifted his garment to show two stones tied to his belly.”\r \r On this occasion, signs of prophethood occurred during the digging of the trench. Jabir ibn 'Abdullah saw the intense hunger of the Prophet (PBSD). He slaughtered a small animal, and his wife ground a *sa'* of barley. He secretly requested the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) to come with a few of his Companions. The Prophet (PBSD) then stood up with all the people of the Trench, who were a thousand. They ate from that food and were satiated, yet the meat pot continued to bubble as it was, and the dough continued to be baked as it was. The sister of Nu'man ibn Bashir brought a handful of dates to the Trench for her father and uncle to eat. She passed by the Messenger of Allah (PBSD), who asked her for the dates and spread them over a cloth. Then he called the people of the Trench, and they began to eat from it. The dates kept increasing until the people of the Trench finished, and there were still dates falling from the edges of the cloth.\r \r Greater than these two events is what Al-Bukhari reported from Jabir, who said: “While we were digging the Trench, a very hard rock appeared. They came to the Prophet (PBSD) and said: 'This is a rock that has appeared in the Trench.' He said: 'I am going down.' Then he stood up, his belly tied with a stone – and we had remained for three days without tasting any food. – The Prophet (PBSD) took the pickaxe, struck it, and it turned into a heap of loose sand.”\r \r Al-Bara' said: “On the Day of the Trench, a rock appeared to us in a part of the trench that the pickaxes would not affect. We complained about this to the Messenger of Allah (PBSD). He came, took the pickaxe, and said: 'Bismillah' (In the Name of Allah). Then he struck a blow and said: 'Allahu Akbar (Allah is the Greatest)! I have been given the keys to Sham (Syria)! By Allah, I see its red palaces now!' Then he struck the second blow and cut off another part, and said: 'Allahu Akbar! I have been given Persia! By Allah, I see the white palace of Mada'in now!' Then he struck the third blow, cutting off the rest of the rock, and said: 'Allahu Akbar! I have been given the keys to Yemen! By Allah, I see the gates of San'a from my position!' ”\r \r Quraysh advanced with four thousand men until they camped at the confluence of the valleys of Rumah, between Al-Jurf and Za'abah. Ghatafan and their followers from Najd advanced with six thousand men until they camped at Dhanab Nuqmi, next to Uhud.\r \r $$\{وَلَمَّا رَأَى الْمُؤْمِنُونَ الأَحْزَابَ قَالُوا هَذَا مَا وَعَدَنَا اللَّهُ وَرَسُولُهُ وَصَدَقَ اللَّهُ وَرَسُولُهُ وَمَا زَادَهُمْ إِلا إِيمَانًا وَتَسْلِيمًا\}$$ (Al-Ahzab: 22)\r \r “And when the believers saw the Confederates, they said, 'This is what Allah and His Messenger had promised us, and Allah and His Messenger spoke the truth.' And it increased them only in faith and submission.”\r \r As for the hypocrites and the weak-hearted, their hearts were shaken by the sight of this army:\r \r $$\{وَإِذْ يَقُولُ الْمُنَافِقُونَ وَالَّذِينَ فِي قُلُوبِهِمْ مَرَضٌ مَا وَعَدَنَا اللَّهُ وَرَسُولُهُ إِلا غُرُورًا\}$$ (Al-Ahzab: 12)\r \r “And when the hypocrites and those in whose hearts is disease were saying, 'Allah and His Messenger did not promise us except delusion.'”\r \r The Messenger of Allah (PBSD) went out with three thousand Muslims, placing their backs toward Mount Sal', fortifying themselves there. The trench was between them and the disbelievers. Their battle cry was: “They shall not be victorious.” He appointed Ibn Umm Maktum as his deputy over Medina and commanded that the women and children be placed in the city's forts (*āṭām*).\r \r When the polytheists wanted to attack the Muslims and storm Medina, they found the wide trench separating them. They resorted to imposing a siege upon the Muslims, which they were unprepared for when they left their homes, as this plan – as they said – was a trick unknown to the Arabs. They had not considered it at all.\r \r The polytheists began circling the trench in anger, searching for a weak point to cross. The Muslims watched the movements of the polytheists, shooting arrows at them so that they would not dare to approach it, or be able to storm it, or pour earth into it to build a crossing.\r \r On some days, the polytheists made a considerable effort to storm the trench or build crossings in it, but the Muslims fought a glorious defense, shooting arrows at them and struggling fiercely until the polytheists failed in their attempts.\r \r Due to the engagement in this intense defense, some prayers were missed by the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) and the Muslims. In the two Sahih collections, Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) reported that 'Umar ibn al-Khattab came on the Day of the Trench and started cursing the disbelievers of Quraysh. He said: “O Messenger of Allah, I almost didn't pray until the sun was about to set!” The Prophet (PBSD) said: “And I, by Allah, have not prayed it either.” Then we descended with the Prophet (PBSD) to Buṭḥān, and he performed ablution for the prayer, and we did so too. He prayed 'Asr after the sun had set, and then prayed Maghrib after it.\r \r The Messenger of Allah (PBSD) was so distressed by the missed prayer that he invoked against the polytheists. In Al-Bukhari, 'Ali reported that the Prophet (PBSD) said on the Day of the Trench: “May Allah fill their houses and graves with fire, just as they kept us preoccupied from the middle prayer until the sun set.”\r \r In Musnad Ahmad and Ash-Shafi'i, it is reported that they kept him from the prayers of Dhuhr, 'Asr, Maghrib, and 'Isha, and he prayed them all together. An-Nawawi said: “The way to reconcile these narrations is that the battle of the Trench lasted several days, so this happened on some days, and that on others.”\r \r From this, it is understood that the polytheists' attempts to cross and the Muslims' continuous resistance lasted for several days. However, since the trench was a barrier between the two armies, there was no direct combat or bloody war between them; they confined themselves to shooting arrows and dueling.\r \r During this exchange of arrows, men were killed from both armies, counted on the fingers: six Muslims and ten polytheists, with only one or two of them being killed by the sword.\r \r In this exchange of arrows, Sa'd ibn Mu'adh (may Allah be pleased with him) was struck by an arrow that severed his median arm vein (*al-kaḥl*). The man who shot him was a Qurayshite named Ḥibbān ibn al-'Ariqah. Sa'd prayed: “O Allah, You know that there is no one more beloved to me to strive against for Your sake than a people who denied Your Messenger and expelled him. O Allah, I think You have ended the war between us and them. If any fighting with Quraysh remains, keep me alive for them so that I may strive against them for Your sake. But if You have ended the war, then let it burst forth and make my death in it.” At the end of his supplication, he said: “And do not let me die until my eyes are delighted by Banu Qurayzah.”\r \r ## The Treachery of Banu Qurayzah\r \r While the Muslims were facing these hardships on the battlefront, the serpents of intrigue and conspiracy were writhing in their holes, seeking to inject poison into their bodies. The chief criminal of Banu an-Nadir, Huyayy ibn Akhṭab, went to the dwellings of Banu Qurayzah and approached Ka'b ibn Asad al-Quraẓi – the chief of Banu Qurayzah, the guarantor of their covenant and pact. Ka'b had contracted with the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) to support him if war befell him, as previously mentioned. Huyayy knocked on Ka'b's door, and Ka'b shut it before him. Huyayy kept speaking to him until he opened his door. Huyayy said: “O Ka'b, I have brought you the glory of eternity and a surging sea. I have brought you Quraysh with all its leaders and chiefs, and I have settled them at the confluence of the valleys of Rumah. And Ghatafan with all its leaders and chiefs, and I have settled them at Dhanab Nuqmi, next to Uhud. They have covenanted and contracted with me that they will not depart until we eradicate Muhammad and those with him.”\r \r Ka'b replied to him: “By Allah, you have brought me the humiliation of eternity and a rainless cloud that has shed its water; it thunders and lightens, but there is nothing in it. Woe to you, O Huyayy! Leave me with my current state, for I have seen nothing from Muhammad but truthfulness and fidelity.”\r \r Huyayy persisted in persuading Ka'b until he consented, on the condition that Huyayy gave him a covenant and oath by Allah that if Quraysh and Ghatafan returned without having harmed Muhammad, he would enter his fortress with Ka'b, and whatever befell Ka'b would befall him. Ka'b ibn Asad then broke his covenant and disavowed what was between him and the Muslims, joining the polytheists in the war against the Muslims.\r \r This noble action by the Prophet's (PBSD) aunt had a deep effect on preserving the women and children of the Muslims. It seems the Jews thought that those forts were protected by the Muslim army – even though they were completely empty of them – so they did not dare to attempt such an action a second time. However, they began supplying provisions to the pagan invaders as practical evidence of their joining them against the Muslims, so much so that the Muslims seized twenty camels of their provisions.\r \r The news reached the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) and the Muslims. He hastened to verify it, so as to ascertain Qurayzah's stance and deal with it appropriately from a military perspective. To verify the news, he sent the two Sa'ds: Sa'd ibn Mu'adh and Sa'd ibn 'Ubadah, as well as 'Abdullah ibn Rawahah and Khawwat ibn Jubayr. He said: “Go and see whether what has reached us about these people is true or not. If it is true, give me an allusion that I can understand, and do not discourage the people. If they are faithful to their pact, announce it openly to the people.” When they drew near, they found them in the vilest possible state. They openly insulted and showed enmity towards them, and reviled the Messenger of Allah (PBSD). They said: “Who is the Messenger of Allah? There is no covenant or agreement between us and Muhammad!” They returned from them, and when they approached the Messenger of Allah (PBSD), they alluded to him, saying: “'Aḍal and Al-Qārah,” meaning that they had committed treachery, like the treachery of 'Aḍal and Al-Qārah against the Companions of Ar-Raji'.\r \r ## Continuation of the Battle of the Confederates\r \r This was the most critical situation the Muslims had faced. Nothing stood between them and Qurayzah to prevent them from striking from the rear, while before them was a massive army they could not leave. Their children and women were close to these traitors, without protection or guard. They were as Allah (Exalted be He) says: $$\{وَإِذْ زَاغَتْ الأَبْصَارُ وَبَلَغَتْ الْقُلُوبُ الْحَنَاجِرَ وَتَظُنُّونَ بِاللَّهِ الظُّنُونَ * هُنَالِكَ ابْتُلِيَ الْمُؤْمِنُونَ وَزُلْزِلُوا زِلْزَالا شَدِيدًا\}$$ (Al-Ahzab: 10-11) - “When eyes turned aside and hearts reached the throats, and you were thinking various thoughts about Allah. There the believers were tested and shaken with a severe shaking.”\r \r Hypocrisy emerged from some hypocrites, one of whom said: “Muhammad used to promise us that we would eat the treasures of Khosrow and Caesar, but today one of us is not safe to go to the toilet.” And another said in an assembly of his people's men: “Our houses are exposed to the enemy, so allow us to go out and return to our homes, for they are outside Medina.” Banu Salimah even intended to fail. It was about them that Allah (Exalted be He) revealed: $$\{وَإِذْ يَقُولُ الْمُنَافِقُونَ وَالَّذِينَ فِي قُلُوبِهِمْ مَرَضٌ مَا وَعَدَنَا اللَّهُ وَرَسُولُهُ إِلا غُرُورًا * وَإِذْ قَالَتْ طَائِفَةٌ مِنْهُمْ يَا أَهْلَ يَثْرِبَ لا مُقَامَ لَكُمْ فَارْجِعُوا وَيَسْتَأْذِنُ فَرِيقٌ مِنْهُمْ النَّبِيَّ يَقُولُونَ إِنَّ بُيُوتَنَا عَوْرَةٌ وَمَا هِيَ بِعَوْرَةٍ إِنْ يُرِيدُونَ إِلا فِرَارًا\}$$ (Al-Ahzab: 12-13) - “And when the hypocrites and those in whose hearts is disease were saying, 'Allah and His Messenger did not promise us except delusion.' And when a faction among them said, 'O people of Yathrib, there is no station for you, so return.' And a party of them asked the Prophet for permission, saying, 'Indeed, our houses are exposed,' while they were not exposed. They only intended to flee.”\r \r As for the Messenger of Allah (PBSD), he covered himself with his garment when the treachery of Qurayzah reached him. He lay down and remained for a long time until the distress intensified for the people. Then, the spirit of hope overcame him, and he stood up, saying: “Allahu Akbar! Rejoice, O company of Muslims, in the victory and aid of Allah!” He then began to plan how to confront the current situation. As part of this plan, he sent guards to Medina so that the children and women would not be taken by surprise. But a decisive step was necessary to lead to the breakdown of the Confederates. To achieve this, he wanted to make peace with 'Uyaynah ibn Ḥiṣn and al-Ḥārith ibn 'Awf, the two chiefs of Ghatafan, in exchange for one-third of Medina's dates, so that they would withdraw with their people, leaving the Muslims free to inflict a swift and overwhelming defeat upon Quraysh, whose strength and might they had tested repeatedly. Negotiations took place concerning this, and he consulted the two Sa'ds (ibn Mu'adh and ibn 'Ubadah). They said: “O Messenger of Allah, if Allah has commanded you this, then we hear and obey. But if it is something you are doing for our sake, we have no need of it. We and these people were in polytheism and idol worship, and they did not hope to eat any fruit from it except as guests or by purchase. Now that Allah has honored us with Islam, guided us to it, and empowered us through you, should we give them our wealth? By Allah, we will give them nothing but the sword!” He approved their view and said: “It is only something I am doing for you because I have seen the Arabs targeting you from a single bow.”\r \r Then Allah (Exalted and Glorified be He) – and to Him be all praise – brought about a matter from Himself by which He disgraced the enemy, routed their armies, and blunted their edge. Among what He prepared was a man from Ghatafan named Nu'aym ibn Mas'ud ibn 'Amir al-Ashja'i (may Allah be pleased with him) who came to the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) and said: “O Messenger of Allah, I have embraced Islam, but my people are unaware of my conversion. Command me as you wish.” The Messenger of Allah (PBSD) said: “You are but one man, so sow discord among them as much as you can, for war is deception.” He immediately went to Banu Qurayzah – with whom he had been a close friend in the *Jahiliyyah* (pre-Islamic era) – and entered upon them, saying: “You know my affection for you and the special bond between us.” They replied: “You speak the truth.” He said: “Quraysh is not like you. This is your country, where your wealth, children, and women are, and you cannot move from it to another place. As for Quraysh and Ghatafan, they have come to fight Muhammad and his Companions. Their country, wealth, and women are far away. If they find an opportunity, they will seize it; otherwise, they will return to their lands, leaving you alone with Muhammad, and he will take revenge on you.” They asked: “So what should we do, O Nu'aym?” He said: “Do not fight with them until they give you hostages.” They said: “You have given excellent advice.”\r \r Then Nu'aym continued on to Quraysh and said to them: “Do you know my affection and sincerity toward you?” They replied: “Yes.” He said: “The Jews have regretted what they did in breaking their pact with Muhammad and his Companions, and they have sent him a message that they will take hostages from you and hand them over to him, and then they will ally with him against you. If they ask you for hostages, do not give them any!” He then went to Ghatafan and told them the same thing.\r \r When it was the night of Saturday in Shawwal – year 5 AH – they sent to the Jews: “We are not in a land for prolonged stay, and the livestock are perishing. March out with us so that we may decisively engage Muhammad.” The Jews sent back: “Today is the Sabbath. You know what happened to those before us when they violated it. Furthermore, we will not fight with you until you send us hostages!” When their messengers returned with this, Quraysh and Ghatafan said: “By Allah, Nu'aym has spoken the truth to you!” They sent word to the Jews: “By Allah, we will not send anyone to you. Come out with us so that we may decisively engage Muhammad!” Qurayzah said: “By Allah, Nu'aym has spoken the truth to you!” The two parties lost trust in each other, division crept into their ranks, and their resolve weakened.\r \r The Muslims were praying to Allah (Exalted be He): “O Allah! Cover our defects and secure our fears!” The Messenger of Allah (PBSD) invoked against the Confederates, saying: “O Allah, Revealer of the Book, Swift in account! Defeat the Confederates! O Allah, defeat and shake them!”\r \r Allah heard the prayer of His Messenger and the Muslims. After division crept into the ranks of the polytheists and despair spread among them, Allah sent upon them an army of wind, which began to overturn their tents, did not leave a cooking pot but overturned it, and did not leave a tent-peg but uprooted it, giving them no rest. And He sent an army of angels to shake them and cast terror and fear into their hearts.\r \r On that cold, biting night, the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) sent Hudhayfah ibn al-Yaman to bring him news of them. He found them in this state, preparing to depart. He returned to the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) and informed him of the people's departure. The Messenger of Allah (PBSD) awoke, and Allah had repelled His enemy in their rage, without them achieving any good. Allah spared him their fight. He fulfilled His promise, granted victory to His army, aided His servant, and defeated the Confederates alone. He returned to Medina.\r \r The Battle of the Trench took place in Shawwal of the fifth year of the Hijra, according to the soundest opinion. The polytheists besieged the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) and the Muslims for a month or so. It appears, by combining the sources, that the siege began in Shawwal and ended in Dhu al-Qa'dah. According to Ibn Sa'd, the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) departed from the Trench on Wednesday, with seven nights remaining of Dhu al-Qa'dah.\r \r The Battle of the Confederates was not a battle of casualties but a war of nerves. No fierce fighting took place in it, yet it was one of the most decisive battles in the history of Islam. It resulted in the breakup of the polytheists and proved that no force among the Arabs could eradicate the small, growing power in Medina, because the Arabs could not gather a stronger army than they had in the Confederates. Therefore, the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) said when Allah drove away the Confederates: “Now we will invade them, and they will not invade us; we will go to them.”\r \r *\r \r ## The Campaign against Banu Qurayzah:\r \r On the very day the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) returned to Medina, Jibril (Angel Gabriel) (peace be upon him) came to him at noon while he was bathing in the house of Umm Salamah. He said: “Have you already laid down your weapons? The angels have not laid down their weapons, and I have only just returned from pursuing the people. Stand up with those who are with you and go to Banu Qurayzah! I shall march ahead of you, shaking their fortresses and casting terror into their hearts.” Jibril marched forth in a procession of angels.\r \r The Messenger of Allah (PBSD) commanded a muezzin to announce among the people: “Let whoever is obedient and submissive not pray 'Asr (Afternoon Prayer) except at Banu Qurayzah!” He appointed Ibn Umm Maktum as his deputy over Medina and gave the banner to 'Ali ibn Abi Talib, sending him ahead to Banu Qurayzah. 'Ali marched until, drawing near their fortresses, he heard from them offensive speech towards the Messenger of Allah (PBSD).\r \r The Messenger of Allah (PBSD) went out in his procession of the Emigrants and the Helpers until he camped at a well of Qurayzah called the Well of Ana'. The Muslims hastened to obey his command, rising immediately and moving toward Qurayzah. The 'Asr prayer overtook them on the way. Some said: “We will not pray it except at Banu Qurayzah, as he commanded us,” so some men prayed 'Asr after 'Isha (Night Prayer). Others said: “He did not mean that, but he meant for us to leave quickly,” and they prayed it on the way. He did not censure either of the two groups.\r \r The Muslim army thus moved toward Banu Qurayzah in successive groups until they joined the Prophet (PBSD). They were three thousand men, with thirty horses. They besieged the fortresses of Banu Qurayzah and imposed a blockade upon them.\r \r When the siege intensified, their chief, Ka'b ibn Asad, offered them three options: 1) Embrace Islam and enter the religion of Muhammad (PBSD), thus securing their lives, property, children, and women. He told them: “By Allah, it has become clear to you that he is a sent Prophet, and he is the one you find in your Book.” 2) Kill their children and women with their own hands, and then go out to the Prophet (PBSD) with drawn swords, fighting him until they were victorious or all killed. 3) Attack the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) and his Companions on the Sabbath, as they were safe from fighting on that day. They refused to accept any of these three options. Thereupon, their chief, Ka'b ibn Asad, said in distress and anger: “Not a single man among you has spent one night of his life being resolute since his mother gave birth to him!”\r \r After rejecting these three options, nothing remained for Qurayzah but to submit to the judgment of the Messenger of Allah (PBSD). However, they wanted to contact some of their Muslim allies to find out what would happen to them if they submitted to his judgment. They sent a message to the Messenger of Allah (PBSD): “Send us Abu Lubabah so that we may consult him.” He was their ally, and his wealth and children were in their area. When they saw him, the men rose toward him, and the women and children wept in his face, which moved him. They asked: “O Abu Lubabah, do you think we should submit to Muhammad's judgment?” He replied: “Yes,” and pointed with his hand to his throat, indicating slaughter. He immediately realized that he had betrayed Allah and His Messenger. He went on his way and did not return to the Messenger of Allah (PBSD), but went to the Prophet's Mosque in Medina, tied himself to a pillar of the Mosque, and swore that no one would untie him but the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) with his own hand, and that he would never enter the land of Banu Qurayzah again. When the news reached the Messenger of Allah (PBSD), who had found his return slow, he said: “Had he come to me, I would have prayed for his forgiveness. But since he has done what he has done, I am not the one to release him from his place until Allah accepts his repentance.”\r \r Despite Abu Lubabah's gesture, Qurayzah decided to submit to the judgment of the Messenger of Allah (PBSD). The Jews could have endured a long siege due to the availability of food supplies, water, wells, and the strength of their fortresses, and because the Muslims were suffering from bitter cold and severe hunger in the open, coupled with the intense fatigue from continuous military operations since the start of the Battle of the Confederates. However, the war against Qurayzah was a war of nerves: Allah cast terror into their hearts, and their morale began to collapse. This collapse reached its peak when 'Ali ibn Abi Talib and Az-Zubayr ibn al-'Awwam advanced, and 'Ali shouted: “O Battalion of Faith! By Allah, I will taste what Hamzah tasted, or I will open their fortress!”\r \r At that point, they hastened to submit to the judgment of the Messenger of Allah (PBSD). The Messenger of Allah (PBSD) ordered the arrest of the men. They were put in fetters under the supervision of Muḥammad ibn Maslamah al-Anṣāri. The women and children were kept separate from the men in one area. The Aws rose and came to the Messenger of Allah (PBSD), saying: “O Messenger of Allah, you dealt with Banu Qaynuqa' as you know, and they were the allies of our brothers, the Khazraj. These are our allies, so be good to them.” He asked: “Would you not be pleased if a man from amongst you judged their fate?” They replied: “Yes.” He said: “Then it is for Sa'd ibn Mu'adh.” They replied: “We are pleased.”\r \r They sent for Sa'd ibn Mu'adh, who was in Medina, having been unable to join them because of the wound that had severed his median arm vein during the Battle of the Confederates. He was mounted on a donkey and brought to the Messenger of Allah (PBSD). His relatives surrounding him began to say: “O Sa'd, be gentle with your allies, be good to them, for the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) has appointed you to judge them so that you may be good to them.” He remained silent, not replying to them. When they pressed him further, he said: “The time has come for Sa'd not to fear the blame of any blamer for the sake of Allah.” When they heard that from him, some of them returned to Medina to mourn the people to their kin.\r \r When Sa'd reached the Prophet (PBSD), he said to the Companions: “Stand up for your chief.” When they helped him dismount, they said: “O Sa'd, these people have agreed to abide by your judgment.” He asked: “Is my judgment binding on them?” They replied: “Yes.” He asked: “And on the Muslims?” They replied: “Yes.” He asked: “And on those here?” He turned his face and gestured toward the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) out of respect and reverence. They said: “Yes, and on you.” Sa'd then judged: “I rule that the men should be killed, the offspring be taken captive, and the wealth be divided.” The Messenger of Allah (PBSD) said: “You have judged concerning them with the judgment of Allah from above seven heavens.”\r \r Sa'd's judgment was utterly just and fair. For, in addition to the heinous treachery they had committed, Banu Qurayzah had gathered for the eradication of the Muslims: one thousand five hundred swords, two thousand spears, three hundred coats of mail, and five hundred shields and targets, which the Muslims obtained after the conquest of their homes.\r \r The Messenger of Allah (PBSD) ordered that Banu Qurayzah be confined in the house of Bint al-Harith, a woman from Banu an-Najjar, and trenches were dug for them in the market of Medina. Then he commanded that they be taken to the trenches in groups, where their necks were struck. Ka'b ibn Asad, their chief, asked those remaining in confinement: “What do you think he is doing with us?” He said: “Do you never reason? Don't you see that the caller does not stop, and those who depart from you do not return? By Allah, it is the slaughter!” They were between six hundred and seven hundred men, and their necks were struck.\r \r Thus, the serpents of treachery and perfidy were eradicated, those who had broken the firm covenant and aided the Confederates in the eradication of the Muslims at the most critical hour of their lives. By their action, they had become major war criminals deserving of trial and execution. The devil of Banu an-Nadir, and one of the great criminals of the Battle of the Confederates, Ḥuyayy ibn Akhṭab – the father of Safiyyah, the Mother of the Believers (may Allah be pleased with her) – was killed with them. He had entered Banu Qurayzah's fortress when Quraysh and Ghatafan withdrew, in fulfillment of the promise he had given to Ka'b ibn Asad when he came to incite him to treachery during the Campaign of the Confederates. When he was brought, he was wearing a robe that he had torn on all sides by the length of a fingertip so that it would not be taken from him, his hands tied to his neck with a rope. He said to the Messenger of Allah (PBSD): “By Allah, I have never blamed myself for being hostile to you, but whoever struggles against Allah is defeated.” Then he said: “O people, there is no harm in Allah's decree.
