It is a written decree, a destiny, and a slaughter that Allah has decreed for the Children of Israel.” Then he sat down, and his neck was struck.\r \r Only one woman was killed among their women, the one who had thrown the millstone upon Khallad ibn Suwayd and killed him. She was killed for that reason.\r \r The Messenger of Allah (PBSD) had ordered the killing of those who had reached puberty (those who had grown pubic hair) and the sparing of those who had not. Among those who had not reached puberty was 'Aṭiyyah al-Quraẓi, who was spared. He embraced Islam and became a Companion.\r \r Thābit ibn Qays requested the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) to grant him Az-Zubayr ibn Bāṭā, his family, and his wealth. Az-Zubayr had a favor with Thābit, so he granted them to him. Thābit ibn Qays said to Az-Zubayr: “The Messenger of Allah (PBSD) has granted you to me, and he has granted me your wealth and family, so they are yours.” Az-Zubayr, having learned of the killing of his people, said: “I ask you, by the favor I have with you, O Thābit, that you do not join me with my loved ones!” Thābit struck his neck, joining him with his loved ones among the Jews. Thābit spared Az-Zubayr ibn Bāṭā's son, 'Abd ar-Raḥmān ibn az-Zubayr, who embraced Islam and became a Companion. Umm al-Mundhir Salma bint Qays an-Najjāriyyah requested Rifā'ah ibn Samu'al al-Quraẓi, and he was granted to her. She spared him, he embraced Islam, and became a Companion.\r \r A few men among them embraced Islam that night before the surrender, and their lives, property, and children were secured. A man named 'Amr fled that night; he had not participated in Banu Qurayzah's treachery against the Messenger of Allah (PBSD). Muḥammad ibn Maslamah, the leader of the Prophetic Guard, saw him and let him go when he recognized him. It is unknown where he went.\r \r The Messenger of Allah (PBSD) divided the wealth of Banu Qurayzah after taking out the fifth (Khums). He allocated three shares to the cavalryman (two for the horse and one for the rider), and one share to the foot soldier. He sent a group of the captives to Najd under the supervision of Sa'd ibn Zayd al-Ansari, who exchanged them for horses and weapons.\r \r The Messenger of Allah (PBSD) chose for himself from the women Rayḥānah bint 'Amr ibn Khanāqah. She remained with him until his death while she was his property. This is what Ibn Ishaq said. Al-Kalbi said that he (PBSD) freed her and married her in 6 AH, and she died upon his return from the Farewell Pilgrimage and was buried in Al-Baqi'.\r \r When the matter of Qurayzah was concluded, the supplication of the righteous servant Sa'd ibn Mu'adh (may Allah be pleased with him), mentioned during the Battle of the Confederates, was answered. The Prophet (PBSD) had pitched a tent for him in the Mosque to visit him nearby. When the matter of Qurayzah was concluded, his wound burst open again. 'Aisha said: “It burst from his chest. While a tent of Banu Ghifār was in the Mosque, they were not startled until the blood flowed toward them. They asked: 'O people of the tent, what is this coming to us from your side?' ” It was Sa'd whose wound was profusely bleeding. He died from it.\r \r It is reported in the two Sahih collections from Jabir that the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) said: “The Throne of the Most Merciful shook at the death of Sa'd ibn Mu'adh.” At-Tirmidhi authenticated a Hadith from Anas who said: “When the funeral of Sa'd ibn Mu'adh was carried, the hypocrites said: 'How light his bier is!' The Messenger of Allah (PBSD) said: 'The angels were carrying it.' ”\r \r One man from the Muslims was killed during the siege of Banu Qurayzah, Khallād ibn Suwayd, upon whom the woman from Qurayzah threw the millstone. Abu Sinān ibn Miḥṣan, 'Ukāsha's brother, also died during the siege.\r \r As for Abu Lubabah, he remained tied to the pillar for six nights. His wife would come at the time of every prayer, untie him for the prayer, and then he would return and tie himself to the pillar. His repentance was revealed to the Messenger of Allah (PBSD) at dawn, while he was in the house of Umm Salamah. She stood at the door of her chamber and said to Abu Lubabah: “Rejoice! Allah has accepted your repentance!” The people rushed to release him, but he refused to be untied by anyone except the Messenger of Allah (PBSD). When the Prophet (PBSD) passed by on his way out for the Fajr (Dawn) prayer, he released him.\r \r This campaign took place in Dhu al-Qa'dah of the fifth year of the Hijra. The siege lasted twenty-five nights.\r \r Allah (Exalted be He) revealed verses from Surah Al-Ahzab concerning the Battle of the Confederates and Banu Qurayzah, commenting on the most important parts of the event, including the state of the believers and the hypocrites, the defeat of the Confederates, and the results of the treachery of the People of the Book.\r \r ## The Conquest of Mecca (Ghazuat Fatḥ Makkah) Ibn al-Qayyim said: "It is the Greatest Conquest (al-Fath al-A’dham), with which Allah honored His religion, His Messenger, His army, and His faithful party. Through it, He rescued His town and His House, which He made a guidance for all peoples, from the hands of the disbelievers and polytheists. It is the Conquest for which the inhabitants of the heavens rejoiced, whose tents of glory were pitched on the shoulders of the Gemini, by which people entered the religion of Allah in crowds, and by which the face of the earth shone with light and joy. " Cause of the Expedition We mentioned regarding the incident of Al-Hudaybiyyah that a clause of that treaty stipulated that whoever wished to enter into the covenant of Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) could do so, and whoever wished to enter into the covenant of Quraysh could do so. The tribe that joined either party was considered part of that faction, so any aggression against any of those tribes would be considered aggression against that faction. According to this clause, the tribe of Khuzā'ah entered into the covenant of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH), and Banū Bakr entered into the covenant of Quraysh. Both tribes were now safe from the other. Old enmity and tensions had existed between the two tribes in the Jāhiliyyah (pre-Islamic era). When Islam came, and this truce was concluded, and each party was safe from the other, Banū Bakr took advantage and wished to exact old revenge on Khuzā'ah. Nawfal ibn Mu'awiyah ad-Dīlī went out with a group of Banū Bakr in the month of Sha'bān in 8 AH, and they attacked Khuzā'ah at night while they were at a watering hole called al-Watīr. They killed some of their men, skirmished, and fought. Quraysh assisted Banū Bakr with weapons, and men from Quraysh fought alongside them, exploiting the darkness of the night, until they drove Khuzā'ah into the sacred precinct (al-Haram). When they reached it, Banū Bakr said: "O Nawfal, we have entered the Haram, fear your God! Fear your God! " He spoke a terrible word: "There is no God today, O Banū Bakr! Take your revenge! By my life, you steal in the Haram, so why not take your revenge in it? " When Khuzā'ah entered Makkah, they sought refuge in the house of Budayl ibn Warqā' al-Khuzā'ī and the house of one of their freedmen named Rāfi'. 'Amr ibn Sālim al-Khuzā'ī hastened to leave until he came to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) in Al-Madīnah, and stood before him while he was sitting in the Mosque among the people, and recited [verses of poetry asking for help]. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) then said: "You have been helped, O 'Amr ibn Sālim! " Then a cloud appeared in the sky, and he said: "This cloud is pouring forth rain in support of Banū Ka'b. " Then Budayl ibn Warqā' al-Khuzā'ī went out with a group of Khuzā'ah until they came to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) in Al-Madīnah. They informed him of those who had been killed among them and of the support Quraysh had given to Banū Bakr against them. Then they returned to Makkah. Abū Sufyān leaves for Al-Madīnah to renew the treaty There is no doubt that what Quraysh and its allies did was pure treachery and an explicit breach of the covenant, for which there was no justification. Therefore, Quraysh quickly realized their treachery, feared and sensed its dire consequences. They held a consultative council and decided to send their leader, Abū Sufyān, as their representative to renew the truce. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) had informed his Companions of what Quraysh would do following their treachery. He said: "It is as if you see Abū Sufyān coming to you to strengthen the treaty and extend the term. " Abū Sufyān left – as Quraysh had decided – and met Budayl ibn Warqā' at 'Usfān – who was returning from Al-Madīnah to Makkah. He asked: "Where have you come from, O Budayl? " – thinking he had gone to the Prophet (PBUH). Budayl replied: "I traveled with Khuzā'ah along this coast and in the bottom of this valley. " Abū Sufyān asked: "Did you not go to Muhammad? " He replied: "No. " When Budayl left for Makkah, Abū Sufyān said: "If he went to Al-Madīnah, he must have been fed dates there. " He went to his she-camel's resting place, took some of its droppings, crushed them, and saw date stones in them. He said: "I swear by Allah, Budayl has indeed been to see Muhammad. " Abū Sufyān arrived in Al-Madīnah and went to his daughter, Umm Habībah. When he went to sit on the bed of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH), she folded it away from him. He said: "O my daughter, have you kept this bed away from me, or have you kept me away from it? " She said: "Rather, it is the bed of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH), and you are a polytheist and impure man. " He said: "By Allah, something evil has afflicted you since I left. " He then went out until he came to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) and spoke to him, but he did not respond to anything. He then went to Abū Bakr and asked him to speak to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH), but Abū Bakr said: "I will not do it. " He then went to 'Umar ibn al-Khattāb and spoke to him, but 'Umar said: "Should I intercede for you with the Messenger of Allah (PBUH)? By Allah, if I had nothing but ants to fight you with, I would fight you with them! " Then he came and went in to 'Alī ibn Abī Tālib, and with him were Fātimah, and Hasan, a young boy crawling between them. He said: "O 'Alī, you are the closest person to me in kinship, and I have come for a need, so do not let me return disappointed as I came. Intercede for me with Muhammad. " 'Alī said: "Woe to you, O Abū Sufyān, the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) has decided on a matter about which we cannot speak to him. " He turned to Fātimah and said: "Would you command this son of yours to grant protection among the people, so that he may be the master of the Arabs until the end of time? " She said: "By Allah, my son has not reached the age to grant protection among the people, and no one grants protection against the Messenger of Allah (PBUH). " At this, the world darkened before Abū Sufyān's eyes. He said to 'Alī ibn Abī Tālib in distress, agitation, despair, and disappointment: "O Abū al-Hasan, I see that matters have become difficult for me, so advise me. " 'Alī said: "By Allah, I know nothing that will benefit you. However, you are the master of Banū Kinānah, so stand up and grant protection among the people, then return to your land. " Abū Sufyān asked: "Do you think that will benefit me at all? " 'Alī replied: "No, by Allah, I do not think so, but I have found nothing else for you. " Abū Sufyān then stood up in the Mosque and said: "O people, I have granted protection among the people! " Then he mounted his camel and departed. When he arrived back with Quraysh, they asked: "What is behind you? " He replied: "I went to Muhammad and spoke to him, but by Allah, he did not respond to anything. Then I went to the son of Abū Quhāfah (Abū Bakr) and found no good in him. Then I went to 'Umar ibn al-Khattāb, and I found him to be the nearest enemy. Then I went to 'Alī, and I found him to be the softest of the people. He advised me to do something, and by Allah, I do not know if it will benefit me or not. " They asked: "What did he command you to do? " He said: "He commanded me to grant protection among the people, and I did so. " They asked: "Did Muhammad approve of that? " He said: "No. " They said: "Woe to you, that man only played a trick on you. " He replied: "No, by Allah, I found nothing else. " Preparation for the Expedition and the attempt to conceal it The narration of At-Tabarānī reports that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) ordered 'Ā'ishah – three days before the news of the covenant breach reached him – to prepare him, without anyone knowing. Abū Bakr entered upon her and asked: "O my daughter, what is this preparation? " She said: "By Allah, I don't know. " He said: "By Allah, this is not the time for the expedition against Banū al-Asfar [the Byzantines]. Where does the Messenger of Allah intend to go? " She said: "By Allah, I have no knowledge. " On the morning of the third day, 'Amr ibn Sālim al-Khuzā'ī arrived with forty riders, and recited [verses of poetry]: "O Lord, I appeal to Muhammad... " [the verses]. Then the people learned about the breach of the covenant. After 'Amr came Budayl, then Abū Sufyān, and the news was confirmed to the people. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) then ordered them to prepare and informed them that he was heading to Makkah. He said: "O Allah, keep the eyes and news from Quraysh until we surprise them in their land. " To further concealment and deception, the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) sent a small detachment of eight men, led by Abū Qatādah ibn Rib'ī, to Bātn Idham, between Dhū Khashab and Dhū al-Marwah, three *burd* (about 36 miles) from Al-Madīnah, at the beginning of the month of Ramadān in 8 AH; so that people might think he was heading in that direction and for the news to spread accordingly. This detachment continued its march until, upon reaching their destination, they were informed that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) had set out for Makkah, and they marched toward him until they caught up. Hātib ibn Abī Balta'ah wrote a letter to Quraysh informing them of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH)'s march toward them. He gave it to a woman and promised her a reward to deliver it to Quraysh. She placed it in the braids of her hair and left with it. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) received news from the heavens about what Hātib had done. He sent 'Alī, al-Miqdād, az-Zubayr ibn al-'Awwām, and Abū Marthad al-Ghanawī, saying: "Go until you reach Rawdat Khākh, for there is a traveling woman there with a letter for Quraysh. " They set out, their horses racing, until they found the woman at that place. They made her dismount and said: "Do you have a letter? " She replied: "I have no letter. " They searched her baggage but found nothing. 'Alī said to her: "I swear by Allah, the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) has not lied, nor have we. By Allah, you will bring out the letter, or we will strip you! " When she saw his seriousness, she said: "Turn away. " He turned away, and she untied the braids of her hair and took out the letter. She handed it to them, and they brought it to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH). It read: "From Hātib ibn Abī Balta'ah to Quraysh, " informing them of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH)'s march. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) called Hātib and asked: "What is this, O Hātib? " He replied: "Do not be hasty with me, O Messenger of Allah. By Allah, I believe in Allah and His Messenger. I have neither apostatized nor changed, but I was a man attached to Quraysh; I am not one of their own people, and I have family, a clan, and a child among them, and no relatives to protect them. Whereas those with you have relatives who protect them. I loved, since I lacked that, to establish a favor with them by which they would protect my relatives. " 'Umar ibn al-Khattāb said: "Leave me, O Messenger of Allah, to strike his neck, for he has betrayed Allah and His Messenger, and he has been a hypocrite. " The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "He has witnessed Badr. And what makes you know, O 'Umar, that perhaps Allah looked at the people of Badr and said: 'Do what you wish, for I have forgiven you.' " 'Umar's eyes shed tears, and he said: "Allah and His Messenger know best. " Thus, Allah kept the eyes away, and no news of the Muslims' preparation and readiness for the march and battle reached Quraysh. The Muslim Army moves toward Makkah Ten days into the blessed month of Ramadān in 8 AH, the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) departed from Al-Madīnah, heading towards Makkah, with ten thousand Companions (may Allah be pleased with them). He left Abū Ruhm al-Ghifārī as his deputy in Al-Madīnah. When he was at Al-Juhfah – or just beyond – his uncle, Al-'Abbās ibn 'Abd al-Muttalib, met him. He had left with his family, immigrating as a Muslim. Then, when the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) was at Al-Abwā', his cousin, Abū Sufyān ibn al-Hārith, and his maternal cousin, 'Abdullāh ibn Abī Umayyah, met him. He turned away from them because of the intense harm and satire he had received from them. Umm Salamah said to him: "Do not let your cousin and the son of your aunt be the most wretched of people because of you. " 'Alī said to Abū Sufyān ibn al-Hārith: "Go to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) from the front and say to him what Joseph's brothers said to Joseph: {They said: 'By Allah! Allah has indeed preferred you over us, and we were certainly sinners.'} [Yūsuf: 91], for he will not be pleased that anyone has better words than him. " Abū Sufyān did this, and the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said to him: {He said: 'No reproach upon you this day. May Allah forgive you; He is the Most Merciful of the merciful.'} [Yūsuf: 92]. Abū Sufyān then recited some verses, [after which] the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) struck his chest and said: "Was it you who drove me out wherever I went? " The Muslim Army encamps at Marr adh-Dhahran The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) continued his journey while fasting, and the people were fasting, until he reached Al-Kudayd – a watering hole between 'Usfān and Qudayd – where he broke his fast, and the people broke theirs with him. He then continued his journey until he encamped at Marr adh-Dhahran (Wādī Fātimah), arriving in the evening. He ordered the army, and they lit fires. Ten thousand fires were lit. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) appointed 'Umar ibn al-Khattāb (may Allah be pleased with him) over the guard. Abū Sufyān before the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) Al-'Abbās – after the Muslims encamped at Marr adh-Dhahran – rode the white mule of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) and went out, searching, hoping to find some woodcutters or someone to inform Quraysh so that they would come out to ask the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) for amnesty before he entered [Makkah]. Allah had kept the news hidden from Quraysh, and they were in anxiety and anticipation. Abū Sufyān had gone out to spy for news; he had gone out with Hakīm ibn Hizām and Budayl ibn Warqā' to seek intelligence. Al-'Abbās said: "By Allah, I was riding it – meaning the Messenger of Allah (PBUH)'s mule – when I heard the speech of Abū Sufyān and Budayl ibn Warqā' as they were talking to each other. Abū Sufyān was saying: 'I have never seen fires or an army like tonight.' Budayl said: 'By Allah, this is Khuzā'ah, provoked by the war.' Abū Sufyān replied: 'Khuzā'ah is too few and too humble for these to be their fires and their army.' " Al-'Abbās said: "I recognized his voice and said: 'Abū Hanzalah?' He recognized my voice and said: 'Abū al-Fadl?' I said: 'Yes.' He asked: 'What is wrong with you? May my father and mother be your ransom!' I said: 'This is the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) with the people. By Allah, what a morning for Quraysh!' " Abū Sufyān asked: "What is the plan? May my father and mother be your ransom! " I replied: "By Allah, if he finds you, he will strike your neck. Ride behind me on this mule until I bring you to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) and ask him for amnesty for you. " He rode behind me, and his two companions returned. Al-'Abbās said: "I brought him, and whenever we passed by a fire of the Muslims, they would ask: 'Who is this?' When they saw the Messenger of Allah (PBUH)'s mule and me upon it, they would say: 'The Messenger of Allah (PBUH)'s uncle on his mule.' Until I passed by the fire of 'Umar ibn al-Khattāb. He asked: 'Who is this?' He stood up towards me, and when he saw Abū Sufyān on the back of the animal, he said: 'Abū Sufyān, the enemy of Allah? Praise be to Allah who has given us power over you without any treaty or covenant!' Then he rushed towards the Messenger of Allah (PBUH). I spurred the mule and rushed ahead. I jumped off the mule and entered upon the Messenger of Allah (PBUH). 'Umar entered upon him and said: 'O Messenger of Allah, this is Abū Sufyān! Let me strike his neck.' I said: 'O Messenger of Allah, I have granted him protection.' Then I sat next to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) and took hold of his head, saying: 'By Allah, no one will have a private conversation with him tonight besides me.' When 'Umar spoke much about him, I said: 'Be gentle, O 'Umar, by Allah, if he were from the men of Banū 'Adī ibn Ka'b, you would not say such a thing!' 'Umar replied: 'Be gentle, O 'Abbās, by Allah, your conversion to Islam was dearer to me than the conversion of Al-Khattāb (my father), if he had converted. And that is only because I know that your conversion was dearer to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) than the conversion of Al-Khattāb.' " The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Take him, O 'Abbās, to your tent, and when you wake up, bring him to me. " I went, and when I woke up, I brought him to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH). When he saw him, he said: "Woe to you, O Abū Sufyān, hasn't the time come for you to know that there is no god but Allah? " He replied: "May my father and mother be your ransom! How forbearing, generous, and kind you are! I thought that if there were a god other than Allah, he would certainly have helped me by now. " The Prophet said: "Woe to you, O Abū Sufyān, hasn't the time come for you to know that I am the Messenger of Allah? " He replied: "May my father and mother be your ransom! How forbearing, generous, and kind you are! As for this, there is still something in my soul until now. " Al-'Abbās said to him: "Woe to you! Accept Islam and testify that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, before your neck is struck! " So, he accepted Islam and bore the testimony of truth. Al-'Abbās said: "O Messenger of Allah, Abū Sufyān is a man who loves pride, so grant him something. " The Prophet said: "Yes, whoever enters the house of Abū Sufyān is safe, whoever locks his door upon himself is safe, and whoever enters the Sacred Mosque is safe. " The Muslim Army departs Marr adh-Dhahran for Makkah On that morning – the morning of Tuesday, the seventeenth of Ramadān, 8 AH – the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) departed from Marr adh-Dhahran for Makkah. He ordered Al-'Abbās to detain Abū Sufyān in the narrow pass of the valley near the mountain's nose, so that Allah's armies would pass by him, and he would see them. Al-'Abbās did so. The tribes passed by with their banners. Whenever a tribe passed by, Abū Sufyān would ask: "O 'Abbās, who are these? " He would say – for example –: "Sulaym. " Abū Sufyān would say: "What do I have to do with Sulaym? " Then another tribe would pass by, and he would say: "O 'Abbās, who are these? " He would say: "Muzaynah. " He would say: "What do I have to do with Muzaynah? " Thus, all the tribes passed. No tribe passed by but he asked Al-'Abbās about it, and when he informed him, he said: "What do I have to do with Banū so-and-so? " Until the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) passed by with his green phalanx, including the Emigrants and the Helpers, from whom nothing was visible but their eyes due to the iron [armor]. Abū Sufyān exclaimed: "Subhān Allāh! O 'Abbās, who are these? " Al-'Abbās replied: "This is the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) with the Emigrants and the Helpers. " Abū Sufyān said: "No one has the power or ability to stand against these. " Then he said: "By Allah, O Abū al-Fadl, your nephew's dominion has become immense today! " Al-'Abbās replied: "O Abū Sufyān, it is Prophethood! " Abū Sufyān said: "Yes, then it is. " The banner of the Helpers was with Sa'd ibn 'Ubādah. When he passed Abū Sufyān, he said to him: "Today is the day of massacre! Today, the sanctity [of the place] will be violated! Today, Allah has humbled Quraysh! " When Sa'd came near the Messenger of Allah (PBUH), Abū Sufyān said: "O Messenger of Allah, did you not hear what Sa'd said? " The Prophet asked: "And what did he say? " Abū Sufyān repeated his words. 'Uthmān and 'Abd ar-Rahmān ibn 'Awf said: "O Messenger of Allah, we do not feel safe that he may attack Quraysh. " The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Rather, today is the day the Ka'bah will be glorified! Today is the day Allah has honored Quraysh! " Then he sent for Sa'd, removed the standard from him, and gave it to his son, Qays, considering that the standard had not been taken from Sa'd. It is also said that he gave it to Az-Zubayr. Quraysh is surprised by the advance of the Muslim Army When the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) passed Abū Sufyān and proceeded, Al-'Abbās said to him: "Hurry to your people! " Abū Sufyān rushed until he entered Makkah and shouted at the top of his voice: "O people of Quraysh, this is Muhammad! He has come to you with what you cannot withstand! Whoever enters the house of Abū Sufyān is safe! " His wife, Hind bint 'Utbah, stood up, grabbed his mustache, and said: "Kill this inflated, obese man with thin shanks! What a wretched scout for a people! " Abū Sufyān said: "Woe to you, do not let this woman deceive you! He has come to you with what you cannot withstand. Whoever enters the house of Abū Sufyān is safe! " They said: "May Allah curse you! What good is your house to us? " He said: "Whoever locks his door upon himself is safe, and whoever enters the Mosque is safe. " The people dispersed to their homes and to the Mosque. Some lowlifes gathered and said: "Let us put these [the leaders] forward. If Quraysh succeeds, we will be with them. If they are defeated, we will give what is asked of us. " The fools and reckless ones of Quraysh gathered with 'Ikrimah ibn Abī Jahl, Safwān ibn Umayyah, and Suhayl ibn 'Amr at Al-Khandamah to fight the Muslims. Among them was a man from Banū Bakr – Himās ibn Qays – who had previously been preparing his weapons. His wife asked him: "Why are you preparing what I see? " He replied: "For Muhammad and his companions. " She said: "By Allah, nothing can stand against Muhammad and his companions. " He said: "By Allah, I hope to make some of them your servants. " Then he said [a poem]: *If they advance today, I have no excuse,* *This is a complete weapon and instrument,* *And a swift-sheathed, double-edged [sword].* This man was among those who gathered at Al-Khandamah. The Muslim Army at Dhū Tuwā As for the Messenger of Allah (PBUH), he proceeded until he reached Dhū Tuwā – and he was bowing his head in humility to Allah when he saw the honor of the Conquest Allah had granted him, to the extent that the hair of his beard almost touched the middle of his saddle. There, he divided his army. Khālid ibn al-Walīd was in charge of the right wing – which included Aslam, Sulaym, Ghifār, Muzaynah, Juhaynah, and tribes from the Arab tribes. He commanded him to enter Makkah from below, saying: "If anyone from Quraysh confronts you, reap them down unsparingly, until you meet me at As-Safā. " Az-Zubayr ibn al-'Awwām was in charge of the left wing, and he carried the banner of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH). He commanded him to enter Makkah from above – from Kadā' – and to plant his banner at Al-Hajūn, and not to leave until he came to him. Abū 'Ubaydah was in charge of the foot soldiers and the unarmed men. He commanded him to take the bottom of the valley until he settled facing Makkah before the Messenger of Allah (PBUH). The Muslim Army enters Makkah Each battalion of the Muslim army moved along the route assigned for its entry. As for Khālid and his companions, they did not meet anyone from the polytheists except that they overcame them. Two Muslims were killed among his companions: Kurz ibn Jābir al-Fihrī and Khunays ibn Khālid ibn Rabī'ah. They had strayed from the army and taken a different path, and were both killed. As for the fools of Quraysh, Khālid and his companions met them at Al-Khandamah and they engaged in some fighting. They killed twelve men from the polytheists. The polytheists fled, and Himās ibn Qays – who was preparing weapons to fight the Muslims – fled until he entered his house and said to his wife: "Lock the door behind me! " She said: "And what about what you were saying? " He replied [referencing his poem] : *And a swift-sheathed, double-edged [sword].* Khālid proceeded through Makkah until he met the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) at As-Safā. As for Az-Zubayr, he advanced until he planted the banner of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) at Al-Hajūn, near the Mosque of Al-Fath, and pitched a tent for him there. He did not move until the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) came to him. The Messenger (PBUH) enters the Sacred Mosque and purifies it of idols Then the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) arose, with the Emigrants and the Helpers before him, behind him, and around him, until he entered the Mosque. He went to the Black Stone (al-Hajar al-Aswad) and kissed it. Then he performed the circuit (Tawāf) around the House, holding a bow in his hand. There were three hundred and sixty idols around the House. He began to strike them with the bow and say: {The truth has come, and falsehood has vanished. Indeed, falsehood is ever bound to vanish.} [Al-Isrā’: 81], {Say: 'The truth has come, and falsehood can neither originate [anything] nor restore [what it has destroyed].'} [Sabā’: 49]. And the idols were falling on their faces. He performed his circuit on his riding animal, and he was not in a state of Ihrām (consecration) that day. He limited himself to the circuit. When he finished it, he called for 'Uthmān ibn Talhah, took the key of the Ka'bah from him, and ordered it to be opened. He entered it and saw images inside. He saw the images of Ibrāhīm and Ismā'īl (peace be upon them) seeking to know the unseen by drawing lots with arrows. He said: "May Allah fight them! By Allah, they never sought to know the unseen by drawing lots with them! " He saw a dove made of wood in the Ka'bah, broke it with his hand, and ordered the images to be erased. The Messenger (PBUH) prays in the Ka'bah and then addresses Quraysh Then he closed the door upon himself, Usāmah, and Bilāl. He faced the wall opposite the door until he was about three cubits away from it, where he stood, placing two pillars on his left, one pillar on his right, and three pillars behind him – the House had six pillars at that time – and then he prayed there. Then he went around the House, pronouncing the Takbīr (Allahu Akbar) in its corners and proclaiming the Oneness of Allah. Then he opened the door. Quraysh had filled the Mosque in rows, waiting to see what he would do. He took hold of the doorposts, and they were beneath him, and he said: "There is no god but Allah alone, without any partner. He fulfilled His promise, helped His servant, and defeated the Confederates alone. Listen! Every claim of pride, or wealth, or blood [from the pre-Islamic era] is under these two feet of mine, except the custodianship of the House (Sidānah) and the watering of the pilgrims (Siqāyah). Listen! As for the slaying by mistake or quasi-intentional – by the whip or the stick – the blood money (Diyyah) for it is aggravated: one hundred camels, forty of which have their young in their wombs. O people of Quraysh! Allah has removed from you the arrogance (nakhwah) of the Jāhiliyyah and the boasting of ancestors. People are all from Adam, and Adam is from dust. " Then he recited this verse: {O mankind, indeed We have created you from male and female and made you peoples and tribes that you may know one another. Indeed, the most noble of you in the sight of Allah is the most righteous of you. Indeed, Allah is Knowing and Acquainted.} No Reproach Upon You Today Then he said: "O people of Quraysh, what do you think I shall do with you? " They replied: "Good, a noble brother and the son of a noble brother. " He said: "Then I say to you what Joseph said to his brothers: {No reproach upon you this day.} Go, for you are the freed ones! (at-Tulaqā') " The Key of the House to its rightful keepers The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) then sat in the Mosque. 'Alī (may Allah be pleased with him) stood up with the key of the Ka'bah in his hand and said: "Combine the custodianship (Hijābah) with the watering (Siqāyah) for us, may Allah bless you. " – Another narration states that Al-'Abbās was the one who said this. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Where is 'Uthmān ibn Talhah? " He was called for, and the Prophet said to him: "Here is your key, O 'Uthmān. Today is a day of goodness and faithfulness. " In the narration of Ibn Sa'd in At-Tabaqāt, he said to him when handing him the key: "Take it, eternally, hereditarily. No one will take it from you except an oppressor. O 'Uthmān, Allah has entrusted you with His House, so eat equitably from what reaches you from this House. " Bilāl calls to prayer on the Ka'bah The time for prayer arrived. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) commanded Bilāl to ascend and call the prayer (Adhān) on the Ka'bah. Abū Sufyān ibn Harb, 'Attāb ibn Asīd, and Al-Hārith ibn Hishām were sitting in the courtyard of the Ka'bah. 'Attāb said: "Allah honored Usayd [his father] by making him not hear this, lest he hear what would enrage him. " Al-Hārith said: "By Allah, if I knew it was the truth, I would follow it. " Abū Sufyān said: "As for me, by Allah, I will say nothing. If I spoke, these gravel stones would inform [the Prophet] about me. " The Prophet (PBUH) then came out to them and said: "I have known what you said. " Then he mentioned it to them. Al-Hārith and 'Attāb said: "We bear witness that you are the Messenger of Allah. By Allah, no one who was with us knew this for us to say he informed you. " The Prayer of the Conquest (Salāt al-Fath) or Thanksgiving Prayer On that day, the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) entered the house of Umm Hāni' bint Abī Tālib. He performed a full ritual wash (*ghusl*) and prayed eight units of prayer (rak'āt) in her house – it was in the forenoon (*duhā*). Some people thought it was the Duhā prayer, but it was the Prayer of the Conquest. Umm Hāni' had granted protection to two of her brothers-in-law. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "We have granted protection to whomever you have granted protection, O Umm Hāni'. " Her brother, 'Alī ibn Abī Tālib, had intended to kill them. She had locked the door of her house upon them and had asked the Prophet (PBUH), who gave her that response. The Blood of Major Criminals is declared null On that day, the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) declared the blood of nine individuals among the major criminals to be null (i.e., ordered their execution) and commanded that they be killed even if they were found clinging to the curtains of the Ka'bah. They were: 'Abd al-'Uzzā ibn Khatal, 'Abdullāh ibn Sa'd ibn Abī Sarh, 'Ikrimah ibn Abī Jahl, Al-Hārith ibn Nufayl ibn Wahb, Maqīs ibn Sabābah, Hubbār ibn al-Aswad, two singing slave women belonging to Ibn al-Khatal who used to sing in satire of the Prophet (PBUH), and Sārah, a freedwoman of Banū 'Abd al-Muttalib, who was the woman with whom Hātib's letter was found. As for Ibn Abī Sarh, 'Uthmān brought him to the Prophet (PBUH) and interceded for him. His life was spared, and his Islam was accepted after the Prophet (PBUH) remained silent, hoping that one of the Companions would rise and kill him. He had previously accepted Islam and emigrated, then apostatized and returned to Makkah. As for 'Ikrimah ibn Abī Jahl, he fled to Yemen. His wife sought amnesty for him, and the Prophet (PBUH) granted it. She followed him, and he returned with her, accepted Islam, and his Islam became good. As for Ibn Khatal, he was clinging to the curtains of the Ka'bah. A man came to the Prophet (PBUH) and informed him, and he said: "Kill him, " and he was killed. As for Maqīs ibn Sabābah, he was killed by Numaylah ibn 'Abdillāh. Maqīs had accepted Islam previously, then assaulted a man from the Helpers and killed him, then apostatized and joined the polytheists. As for Al-Hārith, he had severely harmed the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) in Makkah, and 'Alī killed him. As for Hubbār ibn al-Aswad, he was the one who had attacked Zaynab bint Rasūlillāh (the Prophet's daughter, PBUH) when she emigrated, prodding her [with his spear] so that she fell onto a rock and aborted her fetus. Hubbār fled on the day of Makkah, then accepted Islam, and his Islam became good. As for the two singing women, one was killed, and amnesty was sought for the other, and she accepted Islam, just as amnesty was sought for Sārah, and she accepted Islam. Ibn Hajar mentioned that Abū Ma'shar included among those whose blood was declared null Al-Hārith ibn Talātil al-Khuzā'ī, who was killed by 'Alī. Al-Hākim also mentioned among those whose blood was declared null Ka'b ibn Zuhayr – whose story is famous; he came later, accepted Islam, and recited praise – Wahshī ibn Harb, and Hind bint 'Utbah (Abū Sufyān's wife), who accepted Islam. Arnab, Ibn Khatal's freedwoman, was also killed, and Umm Sa'd was killed, according to Ibn Ishāq, completing the number to eight men and six women. It is possible that Arnab and Umm Sa'd were the two singing women, with a difference in their names or honorifics. The Conversion of Safwān ibn Umayyah and Fadālah ibn 'Umayr Safwān was not one of those whose blood was declared null, but as a major leader of Quraysh, he feared for himself and fled. 'Umayr ibn Wahb al-Jumahī sought amnesty for him from the Messenger of Allah (PBUH), who granted it and gave 'Umayr the turban with which he had entered Makkah. 'Umayr caught up with him as he was about to take a ship from Jeddah to Yemen and brought him back. Safwān said to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH): "Grant me a choice of two months. " The Prophet said: "You have the choice of four months. " Safwān later accepted Islam. His wife had accepted Islam before him, and he kept them in their original marriage. Fadālah was a bold man who came to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) while he was performing the Tawāf, intending to kill him. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) informed him of what was in his heart, and he accepted Islam. The Messenger's Second Sermon after the Conquest On the day after the Conquest, the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) stood up to address the people. He praised Allah, extolled Him, and glorified Him as He deserves. Then he said: "O people, Allah made Makkah sacred the day He created the heavens and the earth, and it is sacred by the sacredness of Allah until the Day of Resurrection. It is not lawful for any man who believes in Allah and the Last Day to shed blood in it or to cut down any tree in it. If anyone offers the fighting of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) as an excuse, say: 'Allah granted permission to His Messenger, but He did not grant it to you.' It was made lawful for me for only one hour of a single day, and its sanctity has returned today as it was yesterday. Let the one present inform the one absent. " In another narration: "Its thorns are not to be cut, its game is not to be disturbed, its fallen property is not to be picked up except by one who announces it, and its fresh herbage is not to be cut. " Al-'Abbās said: "O Messenger of Allah, except the Idhkhir (aromatic grass), for it is for their artisans and their homes. " He said: "Except the Idhkhir. " That day, Khuzā'ah had killed a man from Banū Layth for revenge dating back to the Jāhiliyyah. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said in this regard: "O people of Khuzā'ah, withdraw your hands from killing. Killing has multiplied if it were beneficial. You have killed a man, and I will pay the blood money for him. Whoever kills after my standing here, his family has the choice of two options: either the blood of his killer, or the blood money (Diyyah). " In a narration: A man from Yemen called Shāh stood up and said: "Write [this speech] for me, O Messenger of Allah. " The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Write [it down] for Abū Shāh. " The Concern of the Helpers about the Messenger (PBUH) staying in Makkah When the Conquest of Makkah was completed for the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) – which was his city, his homeland, and his birthplace – the Helpers (Ansār) said among themselves: "Do you think the Messenger of Allah (PBUH), now that Allah has opened his land and his city to him, will remain there? " – He was supplicating on As-Safā, raising his hands. When he finished his supplication, he asked: "What did you say? " They replied: "Nothing, O Messenger of Allah. " He persisted until they informed him. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "I seek refuge in Allah! The life is your life, and the death is your death. " Taking the Allegiance (Bay'ah) When Allah opened Makkah to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) and the Muslims, the truth became clear to the people of Makkah. They knew that there was no way to success except through Islam. They submitted to it and gathered for the allegiance. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) sat on As-Safā, taking the allegiance of the people, with 'Umar ibn al-Khattāb sitting below him, taking the allegiance from the people. They pledged allegiance to him to listen and obey within their capability. In Al-Madārik, it is narrated that when the Prophet (PBUH) finished taking the allegiance from the men, he began taking the allegiance from the women while he was on As-Safā, and 'Umar was sitting below him, taking their allegiance on his behalf and conveying his words to them. Hind bint 'Utbah, Abū Sufyān's wife, came, disguised, fearing that the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) would recognize her because of what she had done to Hamzah. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "I take your allegiance that you will not associate anything with Allah. " 'Umar took the allegiance from the women that they would not associate anything with Allah. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) said: "Nor will you steal. " Hind said: "Abū Sufyān is a miserly man. Will I be committing a sin if I take some of his wealth to feed our family? " Abū Sufyān said: "Whatever you have taken is lawful for you. " The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) laughed and recognized her, saying: "And you are Hind? " She replied: "Yes. Forgive what has passed, O Prophet of Allah, may Allah forgive you. " The Prophet said: "Nor will you commit unlawful sexual intercourse. " She said: "Does a free woman commit unlawful sexual intercourse? " The Prophet said: "Nor will you kill your children. " She said: "We raised them small, and you killed them big – you and they know best. " – Her son, Hanzalah ibn Abī Sufyān, had been killed at Badr. 'Umar laughed until he lay on his back, and the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) smiled. The Prophet said: "Nor will you produce a slander. " She said: "By Allah, slander is an ugly thing, and you only command us to righteousness and noble manners. " The Prophet said: "Nor will you disobey me in what is right. " She said: "By Allah, we did not sit in this assembly with the intention of disobeying you. " When she returned, she began breaking her idol and saying: "We were in delusion because of you. " In the Sahīh: Hind bint 'Utbah came and said: "O Messenger of Allah, there was no people of a tent on the face of the earth whom I loved more to see humbled than the people of your tent, and today there is no people of a tent on the face of the earth whom I love more to see honored than the people of your tent. " The Prophet said: "And likewise, by Him in Whose Hand is my soul. " She said: "O Messenger of Allah, Abū Sufyān is a stingy man. Is there any blame on me for feeding our children from what belongs to him? " He said: "No, only what is reasonable (bil-ma'rūf). " The Messenger's Stay in Makkah and his work there The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) stayed in Makkah for nineteen days, renewing the landmarks of Islam and guiding the people to right guidance and piety. During these days, he commanded Abū Usayd al-Khuzā'ī to renew the boundary markers of the Sanctuary. He dispatched his detachments (*sarāyā*) to call people to Islam and to break the idols that were around Makkah. They were all broken. His caller announced in Makkah: "Whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day should not leave an idol in his house without breaking it. " The Detachments and Missions 1. After the Conquest, the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) sent Khālid ibn al-Walīd to Al-'Uzzā five nights before the end of Ramadān in 8 AH to demolish it. It was at Nakhlah and belonged to Quraysh and all Banū Kinānah; it was their greatest idol. Its custodians were the Banū Shaybān. Khālid went out to it with thirty horsemen until he reached it, and he demolished it. When he returned, the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) asked him: "Did you see anything? " He replied: "No. " The Prophet said: "Then you did not demolish it. Go back to it and demolish it. " Khālid returned, angry, drawing his sword. A naked black woman with disheveled hair came out to him. The custodian began to shout at her. Khālid struck her and cleaved her into two. Then he returned to inform the Messenger of Allah (PBUH), who said: "Yes, that was Al-'Uzzā. She has despaired of ever being worshipped in your land. " 2. Then, in the same month, he sent 'Amr ibn al-'Ās to demolish Suwā'. It was an idol of Hudhail at Ruhāt, about 150 km northeast of Makkah. When 'Amr reached it, its custodian asked him: "What do you want? " 'Amr replied: "The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) has commanded me to demolish it. " The custodian said: "You will not be able to do that. " 'Amr asked: "Why? " The custodian said: "It will prevent you. " 'Amr said: "Are you still in falsehood? Woe to you, does it hear or see? " Then he approached and broke it, and commanded his companions to demolish its treasury house, but they found nothing in it. He then said to the custodian: "How do you see it now? " The custodian replied: "I have submitted to Allah. " 3. In the same month, he sent Sa'd ibn Zayd al-Ashhalī with twenty horsemen to Manāt. It was at Al-Mushallal, near Qudayd, and belonged to the Aws, Khazraj, Ghassān, and others. When Sa'd reached it, its custodian asked him: "What do you want? " Sa'd replied: "To demolish Manāt. " The custodian said: "That is your affair. " Sa'd approached it, and a naked black woman with disheveled hair came out, wailing and beating her chest. The custodian said to her: "Manāt is before you! [Here are] some of your disobedient ones! " Sa'd struck and killed her, then he approached the idol, demolished it, and broke it. They found nothing in its treasury. 4. When Khālid ibn al-Walīd returned from demolishing Al-'Uzzā, the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) sent him in Shawwāl of the same year – 8 AH – to the Banū Judhaymah as a caller to Islam, not a fighter. He set out with three hundred and fifty men from the Emigrants, the Helpers, and Banū Sulaym. When he reached them, he invited them to Islam, but they did not know how to say: * "We have accepted Islam (Aslamnā), "* and they started saying: * "We have become Sābi'ūn (Saba'nā), we have become Sābi'ūn. "* Khālid began to kill and capture them. He assigned a captive to every man in his group. One day, he commanded every man to kill his captive, but Ibn 'Umar and his companions refused, until they came to the Prophet (PBUH) and informed him. The Prophet (PBUH) raised his hands and said: "O Allah, I disavow myself of what Khālid has done, " twice. It was the Banū Sulaym who killed their captives, not the Emigrants and the Helpers. The Messenger of Allah (PBUH) sent 'Alī to pay the blood money for their slain and what they had lost. A dispute and ill feeling arose about this between Khālid and 'Abd ar-Rahmān ibn 'Awf. When the news reached the Prophet (PBUH), he said: "Be gentle, O Khālid! Leave my companions! By Allah, if one of you had a mountain of gold and spent it in the way of Allah, you would not reach the merit of a mere morning or evening of a man from my companions. " That was the expedition of the Conquest of Makkah, the decisive battle and the Greatest Conquest that brought a definitive end to the existence of paganism and left no room or justification for its survival in the Arabian Peninsula. Most tribes were waiting to see what would result from the struggle and confrontation that was taking place between the Muslims and the pagans. Those tribes knew well that the Sanctuary (al-Haram) could only be controlled by one who was upon the truth. This firm belief had been confirmed to them half a century earlier when the People of the Elephant intended this House and were destroyed, made like pulverized straw. The Treaty of Al-Hudaybiyyah was a prelude and preparation for this Great Conquest. Through it, people felt safe, talked to each other, and debated Islam. The Muslims who had been hiding in Makkah were able to openly practice their religion, call to it, and debate it. Many people entered Islam because of it, so much so that the number of the Muslim army, which had not exceeded three thousand in previous expeditions, swelled to ten thousand in this expedition. This decisive expedition opened people's eyes and removed the last veils that separated them from Islam. With this Conquest, the Muslims gained total control over both the political and religious situation across the length and breadth of the Arabian Peninsula. Religious primacy and temporal leadership were transferred to them. The phase that had begun after the Treaty of Al-Hudaybiyyah, favorable to the Muslims, was completed and perfected by this Manifest Conquest. Another phase began after that, which was entirely in favor of the Muslims, giving them total control of the situation. All that remained for the Arab peoples was to come to the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) to embrace Islam and carry its call to the world, for which their readiness was completed in the next two years. The Farewell Pilgrimage (Hajjat al-Wada') The work of calling to Islam and conveying the message was complete, and a new society had been built on the foundation of affirming the sole Divinity of Allah and negating it for anyone else, and on the foundation of the message of Muhammad (PBUH). It was as if a hidden voice arose in the heart of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH), informing him that his time in this world was drawing to a close. Indeed, when he sent Mu'ādh to Yemen in 10 AH, he said to him – among other things –: "O Mu'ādh, it is likely that you will not meet me after this year of mine, and perhaps you will pass by this mosque of mine and my grave. " Mu'ādh wept, moved by the separation from the Messenger of Allah (PBUH). Allah willed for His Messenger (PBUH) to see the fruits of his call, for which he had endured various hardships for more than twenty years. Individuals and representatives of the Arab tribes gathered around Makkah. They received from him the laws and rulings of the religion, and he received from them the testimony that he had delivered the trust, conveyed the message, and advised the nation. The Prophet (PBUH) announced his intention for this accepted and witnessed pilgrimage. Many people came to Al-Madīnah, all seeking to follow the example of the Messenger of Allah (PBUH). On Saturday, five days before the end of Dhū al-Qa'dah, the Prophet (PBUH) prepared for the journey: he combed his hair, anointed himself with oil, put on his *izār* (lower garment) and *ridā'* (upper garment), marked his sacrificial animals (*budn*), and set out after noon, reaching Dhū al-Hulayfah before the 'Asr prayer. He prayed it as two units and stayed there overnight. In the morning, he said to his Companions: "A visitor from my Lord came to me last night and said: 'Pray in this blessed valley and say: an 'Umrah within a Hajj.' " Before he prayed the Zuhr prayer, he performed a full ritual wash (*ghusl*) for his Ihrām. 'Ā'ishah perfumed him with her hands with *dharīrah* (fragrant powder) and perfume containing musk, on his body and head, so much so that the glint of the perfume was visible in the parting of his hair and his beard. He kept it and did not wash it off. Then he put on his *izār* and *ridā'*, prayed the Zuhr in two units, and then declared his intention for Hajj and 'Umrah at his place of prayer, combining them (Qirān). Then he set out, rode Al-Qaswā', and declared his intention again, and then again when the mule stood up with him on Al-Baydā'. He continued his journey until he drew near Makkah. He spent the night at Dhū Tuwā, then entered Makkah after the Fajr prayer and performing *ghusl*, on the morning of Sunday, four nights into Dhū al-Hijjah in 10 AH – he had spent eight nights on the road, which is the average distance. When he entered the Sacred Mosque, he performed the circuit (Tawāf) around the House and the running (*Sa'y*) between As-Safā and Al-Marwah. He did not exit the Ihrām because he was performing Qirān and had brought his sacrificial animals (*Hady*) with him. He camped in the upper part of Makkah at Al-Hajūn and stayed there, not returning to perform any circuit other than the circuit of Hajj. He ordered those of his Companions who had not brought sacrificial animals (*Hady*) to make their Ihrām an 'Umrah, to perform the Tawāf around the House and the Sa'y between As-Safā and Al-Marwah, and then to exit the Ihrām completely. They hesitated, and he said: "If I could undo what I have done, I would not have brought the sacrificial animals, and if I did not have the Hady with me, I would have exited the Ihrām. " So, those who did not have the Hady exited the Ihrām, listening and obeying. On the eighth day of Dhū al-Hijjah – Yawm at-Tarwiyah – he proceeded to Minā. He prayed the Zuhr, 'Asr, Maghrib, 'Ishā', and Fajr prayers there – five prayers – and then stayed a short time.
source: Holy Quran and Prophetic Sunnah, Authentic Sirah Nabawiyyah (Prophetic Biography)
