texte_original: In this chapter, we speak about Lot, the Prophet of God and His Messenger. God, Blessed and Exalted, has linked the story of Lot with the story of Abraham in many places in His Noble Book, mentioning that Lot believed in Abraham and indicated that he migrated with him, as it says: “So Lot trusted in him.” [Al-Ankabut: 26]. As I mentioned earlier, Lot was sent to the people of Sodom and the surrounding areas of the Jordan, while the Friend of God (Abraham) remained in Palestine. The people of Sodom and its towns were among the most disbelieving and corrupt of God’s creation. They innovated in immorality in ways no one before them had done. They combined polytheism with corruption, cutting off the path, committing sins openly, and engaging in abominations in their gatherings. Lot came to them to call them to their Lord and to forbid them from their falsehood, but they did not respond and persisted in their sins, despite warnings of God’s punishment if they continued [Al-Qur’an: Al-Naml]. Some of them said to one another: “Expel Lot and his family from your city; they are people who purify themselves,” as if, because impurity had dominated their hearts, they considered purity a shameful act. [Al-Ankabut: 56]. They said to Lot: “We will punish you with God’s torment if you are among the truthful.” He said: “My Lord, help me against the corrupting people” [Al-Ankabut: 29]. When Lot despaired of them, God sent angels to Abraham to give him the glad tidings of Isaac, and after Isaac, Jacob. They were commanded to overturn the towns of Lot’s people after instructing Lot to leave his home. The angels came to Sodom in the form of men of the most handsome of God’s creation. The people of Lot came to them hastily, intending evil. Lot was alarmed and said to his people: “Fear God and do not disgrace my guests. Is there not among you a righteous man?” [Hud: 78]. “Your women are better for you and purer.” They said: “O Lot, you know our desire is for men, and we have no desire for women.” Lot’s anger intensified, and he said to them: “If only I had the strength against you” [Hud: 80], meaning to destroy you, “but I take refuge in God; whoever takes refuge in Him has taken refuge in a strong protector.” At that point, the guests revealed to him that they were angels, the messengers of God sent to destroy his people. It is mentioned that Gabriel, after reassuring Lot that they would not harm him, struck out the eyes of his people, blinding them. They said to Lot: “Do not fear, nor grieve; indeed, we will save you and your family, except your wife, she is among the doomed” [Al-Ankabut: 33]. They instructed him: “Take your family by night and follow them not” [Al-Hijr: 65]. They brought glad tidings that the rest of these people would be destroyed [Al-Hijr: 66]. Lot and his daughters departed, and God saved them from the painful punishment. The angels overturned the land of Lot’s people, sending a shower from above and a quake from beneath, and their land was turned over as their nature had been. God left a clear sign to this day, known to the people of the Arabian Peninsula when they visit or return from the Levant, as God says: “And indeed, you pass by them by morning and evening. Do you not reflect?” [As-Saffat: 137-138]. God made Lot’s wife an example for every disbeliever until the Day of Judgment, as He says: “God sets forth an example for those who disbelieve: the wife of Noah and the wife of Lot. They were under two of Our righteous servants, but they betrayed them. Nothing of God could benefit them, and it was said: Enter the Fire with those who enter” [At-Tahrim: 10]. As I explained earlier, the betrayal of Noah’s wife and Lot’s wife was not marital infidelity, but disbelief in God and opposition to His messengers, peace be upon them. God, Blessed and Exalted, narrated Lot’s story in several places in His Noble Book, as in Surah Al-A’raf: “Lot said to his people: ‘Do you commit such immorality as no one has preceded you with from among the worlds? Indeed, you approach men with desire instead of women. Rather, you are a transgressing people.’ The answer of his people was nothing but to say: ‘Expel them from your city; they are people who purify themselves.’ So We saved him and his family, except his wife, who was of the doomed. And We rained upon them a rain, and see how was the end of the criminals” [Al-A’raf: 80-84]. And in Surah Hud: “And Our messengers came to Abraham with the good news. They said, ‘Peace.’ He said, ‘Peace,’ and soon after they brought a roasted calf. When he saw their hands could not reach it, he was suspicious and feared them. They said: ‘Do not fear. We have been sent to a people of Lot, and his wife is doomed.’ She laughed, but We gave her glad tidings of Isaac, and after Isaac, Jacob. She said, ‘Woe to me! How shall I have a son, when I am old, and my husband is old?’ They said: ‘Do you marvel at God’s command? God’s mercy and blessings be upon you, O family! Indeed, it is something wondrous and praiseworthy.’ When the fear left Abraham and the glad tidings reached him, they spoke to us concerning Lot’s people. Abraham was forbearing, gentle, and patient. He said: ‘Turn away from this; indeed, your Lord’s command has come, and punishment is inevitable for them.’” [Hud: 69]. When Our messengers came to Lot, he was distressed and constrained by them. He said: “This is a difficult day.” His people rushed toward him, having previously committed evil deeds. He said: “O my people! These [women] are purer for you. So fear God and do not disgrace my guest. Is there not among you a wise man?” They said: “You know we have no right to your daughters, and you know what we desire.” He said: “If only I had strength against you or could take refuge in a strong protector.” They said: “O Lot, we are messengers of your Lord; they will not reach you. So take your family by night, and let no one of you look back, except your wife, who is doomed.” The command came at dawn, and We rained stones upon them, firmly marked by your Lord. They were not far from the wrongdoers [Hud: 69]. And in Surah Al-Hijr: “We told Our servants: I am the Forgiving, the Merciful, and My punishment is the painful punishment. When they came to Abraham, they said: ‘Peace.’ He said: ‘Indeed, we are wary of you.’ They said: ‘Do not fear. We bring you glad tidings of a knowledgeable boy.’ He said: ‘How can you bring me glad tidings in old age?’ They said: ‘We bring you the truth. Do not be among the despairing.’ He said: ‘Who despairs of the mercy of his Lord except the lost?’ They said: ‘We have been sent to a criminal people, except for Lot; We will save him and his family, except his wife, who is among the doomed.’ When Our messengers came to Lot, he was distressed by them and constrained. They said: ‘Do not fear nor grieve. We will save you and your family, except your wife, who is among the doomed. Indeed, We are sending upon the people of this town a punishment from the sky for what they were corrupting. And We have left a clear sign in it for a people who understand.’” [Al-Ankabut: 28-35]. And in Surah As-Saffat: “Indeed, Lot was among the messengers. When We saved him and his family, except his wife, We destroyed the others. Indeed, you pass by them by morning and evening. Do you not reflect?” [As-Saffat: 133-138]. And in Surah Adh-Dhariyat: “They asked: ‘What is your matter, O messengers?’ They said: ‘We have been sent to a criminal people to send upon them stones of clay, marked with your Lord, for the transgressors. We have brought out whoever was in it of the believers, leaving a clear sign for those who fear the painful punishment.’” [Adh-Dhariyat: 31-37]. And in Surah An-Najm: “And the immoral woman fell; what she fell into, she was covered by it.” [An-Najm: 30]. And in Surah Al-Qamar: “The people of Lot denied the warnings. We sent upon them a rain, except for Lot and his family, as a favor from Us. Thus, We reward the grateful. And We warned them, but they disputed the warnings. We blotted out their eyes; let them taste My punishment and warnings. In the morning, the punishment was settled; let them taste My punishment and warnings. And We have made the Qur’an easy for remembrance; is there any who will remember?” [Al-Qamar: 33-40]. Some people misunderstood Lot’s words: “Or I take refuge in a strong protector” [Hud: 80] to mean he sought protection in a powerful tribe. This is incorrect. In Sahih al-Bukhari, Abu Huraira reported that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: “God forgave Lot because he took refuge in a strong protector,” meaning God. When Lot took refuge in God, God protected him. The angels then said: “O Lot, indeed, We are messengers of your Lord; they will not reach you” [Hud: 81]. Many animals also avoid the act of approaching males. Abdul Malik ibn Marwan, the Umayyad Caliph, said: “If God had not mentioned it in the Qur’an, I would not have thought a male would approach another male.” The term “Lotite” became widespread for those committing this act, but this is incorrect. The act should not be attributed to Lot. Similarly, Abu Jahl and Abu Lahab are not called Muhammads, as they opposed Muhammad. Lot’s name represents righteousness, not this crime. God said about Lot: “Indeed, I am disgusted by your deeds” [Ash-Shu’ara: 168]. As for the story in Genesis 9 about Lot and his daughters, God cleared Lot and his daughters of any wrongdoing, peace be upon him

bio_naissance_annee: Date of birth unknown for both prophets
bio_lieu_naissance: Idris was born in Babylon, while Elias was sent to the people of Baalbek in Lebanon
bio_descendance: Idris AS was the 5th generation of Prophet Adam and had a son named Methuselah, grandfather of Nuh (AS). Elias, on the other hand, was a descendant of Harun (Aaron), the brother of Musa (AS).
texte_original: In this chapter, we speak about two honorable prophets of God, namely Idris and Elias (peace be upon them). Al-Bukhari, in his Sahih, indicated that Idris is Elias, saying: it is narrated from Ibn Mas‘ud and Ibn ‘Abbas that Elias is Idris. Al-Bukhari also noted that people differ regarding Idris’s lineage. In his Sahih, in the chapter mentioning Idris, it is said that he is the ancestor of the father of Noah, and some say he is the ancestor of Noah. However, Al-Bukhari did not assert any specific lineage for Idris, nor is there any authentic report from the Messenger of God (peace be upon him) confirming that Idris lived before Noah. The judge Abu Bakr Ibn al-Arabi held that Idris was not an ancestor of Noah, but rather belonged to the Children of Israel, based on the idea that Idris is Elias, and Elias is one of the prophets of the Children of Israel. This view is supported by what Al-Bukhari narrated in his Sahih regarding the Isra and Mi‘raj. When Gabriel passed by the Prophet with Idris, he said: “Welcome, righteous brother and righteous prophet.” The Prophet asked: “Who is this?” He was told: “This is Idris.” In another version via Qatada, it is said: he ascended until he reached the fourth heaven and asked: “Who is this?” Gabriel said: “Muhammad is with him.” They said: “Welcome to him, and what a good arrival!” The Prophet met Idris, returned his greeting, and Gabriel said: “Welcome, righteous brother and righteous prophet.” The term “righteous brother” indicates that the Prophet was not from his lineage. If Idris had been an ancestor of Noah, the Prophet would certainly have been from his lineage, and he would have been addressed as Adam and Abraham were in the Isra and Mi‘raj: “Welcome, righteous son and righteous prophet.” Whether Idris lived before or after Noah is not of great importance. Therefore, there is no specific report confirming the exact date or period of his mission. What matters is that he is a prophet of God, elevated to a high rank, and that he was truthful and a prophet. God says about him: "And mention Idris in the Book. Indeed, he was a truthful prophet. And We raised him to a high station." [Maryam: 56-57] And He also says: "And Ishmael, and Idris, and Dhul-Kifl: all were among the righteous. We admitted them into Our mercy; indeed, they were of the virtuous." [Al-Anbiya: 85-86] Many commentators and narrators have reported various legends about Idris. They claimed that he asked an angel to intercede with the Angel of Death to postpone taking his soul so he could continue his work. The angel carried him on his wings up to the sky. When he reached the fourth heaven, the Angel of Death met him and spoke to him. The Angel asked where Idris was; he replied: “He is on my back.” The angel was astonished and said: “I was told to take Idris’s soul in the fourth heaven; how can I do that while he is on earth?” Yet his soul was taken there. Many other “firsts” are attributed to Idris: he is said to be the first to write with a pen, the first to sew clothes, and the first to write in the sand. Ibn Kathir in Stories of the Prophets reports that many exegetes and scholars claim he was the first to speak on this matter and call him Hermes Trismegistus. They also falsely attributed many things to him, as they did with other prophets, scholars, wise men, and saints. As for Elias, the Quran clearly indicates that he is of the lineage of Noah. God says in Surah Al-An‘am: "We guided Noah before, and from his descendants, David, Solomon, Job, Joseph, Moses, Aaron, as well as the righteous, Zechariah, John, Jesus, and Elias: all were among the righteous." [Al-An‘am: 84-85] This indicates that Elias comes from Noah’s lineage, whether we say the pronoun “his descendants” refers to Noah or Abraham, since Abraham is from Noah’s lineage. Therefore, anyone from Abraham’s lineage is necessarily from Noah’s lineage. God mentions Elias in Surah Al-An‘am and recounts his story in Surah As-Saffat. This story illustrates his mission: calling to God, purifying worship, urging his people to piety, and warning them of the causes of God’s wrath. Only turning to God, following His commands, and avoiding His prohibitions protects them from His punishment. Elias condemned the worship of their idol Baal, showing them that it does not deserve sanctification or honor. God supported Elias in the truth and helped him against his disbelieving people. He left a good legacy and beautiful praise for himself and for those who believed in him, as well as for other prophets and nations until the Day of Judgment. God says: "And indeed, Elias was among the messengers. He said to his people: Do you not fear? Why do you call upon Baal and abandon the best Creator, God, your Lord and the Lord of your ancestors? They denied him, except for the sincere servants of God. We left peace upon him among the later generations. Peace be upon Elias! Thus do We reward the righteous; indeed, he was among Our believing servants." [As-Saffat: 123-132] This story strengthens the heart of the Messenger of God (peace be upon him) and serves as a lesson for the wise: a good outcome belongs to the righteous servants of God, while a bad outcome belongs to the deniers and the misguided. Elias is a Hebrew name, which can be given the suffix -in or -on, hence Eliasin, just as Idris becomes Idresin. Most of the seven principal reciters of the Quran say “Peace be upon Eliasin.” This could mean Elias alone with the added suffix, or Elias along with the believers with him. Ibn Kathir also mentions that some claimed that Elias and Al-Khidr meet every year in Jerusalem during Ramadan and drink from Zamzam water sufficient for the next year, but he clarifies that none of this is authentic and that evidence indicates that both Al-Khidr and Elias died.

bio_naissance_annee: No specific date, believed to have lived between the time of Prophet Lut and Prophet Musa (peace be upon them).
bio_lieu_naissance: The land of Madyan (located in the North-West of the Arabian Peninsula, near modern-day Tabuk) and the Dwellers of Al-Aykah.
bio_descendance: He is traced to the lineage of Ibrahim (peace be upon him). Some narrations state he was the father-in-law of Prophet Musa (Moses), the father of his wife.
texte_original: ## Chapter Thirty-Six: Stories of the Prophets: The True Narrative: Shu'aib We speak to you about Shu'aib, the Prophet and Messenger of Allah, who is described as the Orator of the Prophets (peace be upon them). Most scholars trace his lineage back to Ibrahim, the Friend of the All-Merciful (peace be upon them), while some mention that he was from the ancient Arabs (Al-'Aribah). Allah sent him to his people, Madyan (Midian), who lived in the land known by their name near Ma'an, on the outskirts of the Levant, close to the land of the Hijaz. This land was near the lake of the people of Lut, known as the Dead Sea, and lay on a route traveled by Arabs to the Levant, as well as a path used by travelers between Egypt, the Levant, and the Hijaz, close to the Gulf of Aqaba. It is apparent that they lived not long after the destruction of the people of Lut, as their land was not far from the villages of the people of Lut. The people of Madyan were disbelievers who cut off the way (highway robbers) and intimidated passersby. They worshipped deities besides Allah, including Al-Aykah, which was a tree or a dense grove. They were also among the worst in dealings and transgression against wealth, giving short measure and weight, defrauding people of their goods, and spreading corruption in the land after its reform. They took every crooked path and deviated from the straight path. Allah called them Madyan, after their tribe, and also described them as The Companions of the Wood (Ahl al-Aykah). The claim that Shu'aib was sent to two different nations is a refuted opinion and unsound understanding, for Madyan are the Companions of the Wood. Allah says (Al-A'raf, 7:85): "And to Madyan [We sent] their brother, Shu'aib, " and concerning the Companions of the Wood (Ash-Shu'ara, 26:177): "When Shu'aib said to them, " omitting 'their brother' because Shu'aib was not a part of their worship of Al-Aykah, though they are the same people. The total descriptions given of the people of Madyan are the same as those given of the Companions of the Wood. Allah sent Shu'aib to Madyan, the Companions of the Wood, and he was from a noble lineage. He called them to dedicate their worship solely to Allah, commanded them to give full measure and weight, not to defraud people of their goods, to abandon corruption in the land, not to cut off the road, and to adhere to justice, explaining that what is with Allah is better and more lasting. He clarified that he did not ask for any wage for conveying the Message. He warned them that if they denied him, they would be afflicted by the fate of the people of Nuh, or Hud, or Salih (Hud 11:89), reminding them of the people of Lut, whose destruction was recent and nearby. The Quran narrates the story of Madyan immediately after the story of Lut in Al-A'raf, Hud, Al-Hijr, and Ash-Shu'ara. Shu'aib reminded them of Allah’s favor in having increased their small numbers. The response of his people was only to mock him and his prayer. They said (Ash-Shu'ara 26:185-186): "You are only one of the bewitched, and you are only a human being like us. " They questioned: "O Shu'aib, does your prayer command you that we should abandon the worship of our ancestral idols? And does your prayer restrict our freedom to dispose of our wealth as we wish—by theft, usury, or short measure? " Shu'aib replied that Allah had guided him to this religion which leads to the straight path. "I am the first of the believers committed to this religion, and I do not intend to differ from you in that which I forbid you (Hud 11:88). I only desire reform as much as I am able. And my success is not but through Allah. Upon Him I have relied, and to Him I return " (Hud 11:88). Following his clear call, they said to him: "O Shu'aib, we do not understand much of what you say. We see you among us as weak, and were it not for your clan (Raht), we would have certainly stoned you. " Shu'aib asked them: "Is my clan more honored in your hearts than Allah? " A group believed, angering the disbelievers, who threatened to expel Shu'aib and the believers if they did not revert, saying (Al-A'raf 7:90): "If you follow Shu'aib, indeed, you will then be losers. " Shu'aib and the believers refused: "We would have invented a lie about Allah if we returned to your religion after Allah has saved us from it.... Our Lord encompasses all things in knowledge. Upon Allah we have relied. Our Lord, judge between us and our people in truth, and You are the best of those who give judgment " (Al-A'raf 7:89). The word 'returned' (Aada - عاد) here signifies 'to become' (Saara - صار). The people of Shu'aib hastened the punishment, demanding Shu'aib cause fragments of the sky to fall upon them if he was truthful. He explained that punishment was solely in Allah's hand. He then challenged them: "Act according to your position (exert your efforts); indeed, I am acting (doing my duty). You are going to know upon whom the humiliating punishment will descend and who is a liar. And wait; indeed, I am waiting with you " (Hud 11:93). When the Command of Allah came, He saved Shu'aib and the believers by His mercy. The disbelievers were seized by a Rajfah (quaking/earthquake), a Sayhah (loud cry/blast), and the Dhillah (shade/cloud) rained down Allah's torment. They became in their homes motionless corpses (Jathimeen), perished, as if they had never lived there. Ruin for Madyan, just as Thamud perished. Allah narrated Shu'aib's story in detail in Al-A'raf, Hud, and Ash-Shu'ara, and briefly in Al-Ankabut and Al-Hijr. --- ## Chapter Thirty-Seven: Shu'aib (Continued) Refutation of the Confusion with Musa's Father-in-Law Many scholars have erred by claiming that Shu'aib is the old man who gave his daughter in marriage to Musa (Moses) when Musa fled to Madyan (Al-Qasas 28:20-29). Shu'aib preceded Musa (peace be upon him) by many centuries and distant times. Musa's arrival in Madyan and his marriage to the daughter of a righteous old man does not necessitate that this man was Shu'aib. No authentic Prophetic report confirms this. Rather, the Quran indicates that Allah sent Musa many centuries after the destruction of Shu'aib's people (Al-A'raf 7:101-103; Al-Qasas 28:43). Shu'aib had told his people (Hud 11:89): "And the people of Lut are not far from you. " The nations of Lut were destroyed during the lifetime of Ibrahim, the Friend of the All-Merciful, separating them from Musa by many generations. The man who married Musa's daughter was a righteous believer, from the offspring of those believers whom Allah saved from Shu'aib's people. And Allah knows best. The context of the Quran's narrative indicates that the greatest crime of Shu'aib's people, after Shirk, was giving short measure and weight, serving as a severe warning against this transgression. Thus, Allah says (Al-Mutaffifin 83:1-6): "Woe to the defrauders [Al-Mutaffifin]! Those who, when they take a measure from people, take in full. But if they give by measure or by weight to them, they cause loss. Do those not think that they will be resurrected for a tremendous Day - The Day when mankind will stand before the Lord of the worlds? " To the next chapter, if Allah wills. Peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you.
source: Holy Quran and Prophetic Sunnah, Exegeses of Ahlus Sunnah Wal Jama'ah

bio_naissance_annee: Zechariah: No specific date, approximately 100 years before Christ. John: Born miraculously in his father's old age and his mother's barrenness.
bio_lieu_naissance: Jerusalem (or Sham/Levant region)
bio_descendance: Zechariah is the father of Yahya (John), and guardian of Maryam (Mary) daughter of Imran. John is the son of Zechariah and the maternal cousin of Isa (Jesus), peace be upon them.
texte_original: Zechariah and John We speak to you about two noble Messengers of God who hastened in good deeds, calling upon God with hope and fear, and who were humble before Him: Zechariah (Zakariyya) and John (Yahya). Allah the Almighty mentioned Zechariah and John in the Holy Quran a few years after the Prophet's mission (peace and blessings be upon him). Surah Maryam (Mary) begins with their narrative; it was revealed before the migration of Ja'far ibn Abi Talib and his companions to Abyssinia. Allah (Blessed and Exalted is He) also mentioned Zechariah and John in Surah Al-Anbiya (The Prophets), which is also Meccan, as well as in Surah Al-An'am (The Cattle) among the group of Messengers (also Meccan), and in Surah Al Imran (The Family of Imran), which is Medinan. The mention of them in Surahs Maryam, Al-Anbiya, and Al Imran serves to demonstrate Allah's Power over all things, that nothing in the heavens or on earth can frustrate Him. The laws of the universe operate by His Will, not by their own natures, for He is the Lord, Master, and Sovereign of all things, and the Overseer of His servants' affairs. He supports His allies, answers their prayers, grants them victory over their enemies, and ensures a good outcome for them, thus strengthening the heart of the Messenger of Allah and the believers with him. Indeed, He created Adam without a father or mother, Eve (Hawwa') without a mother, and Jesus (Isa) without a father. He granted a son to Abraham (Ibrahim) when he was an old man and his elderly wife had passed the age of menopause, a state in which women do not usually conceive. Similarly, He granted His righteous servant Zechariah his son John, when Zechariah had reached an advanced old age (i.e., his bones were weakened and his head was covered with grey hair), a manifestation of man's transformation from strength to weakness, as Allah states: *« Then, after strength, He appointed weakness and grey hair... »* [Surah Ar-Rum (30:54)]. Despite Zechariah reaching this advanced state of age, his wife was barren in her youth; she did not conceive in her younger years and had now become an old woman, combining two factors that conventionally prevent pregnancy. The context of the Noble Quran suggests that Zechariah was deeply concerned with the righteousness of the Children of Israel, that he witnessed their obstinacy (as was their custom) after the death of the Prophets and Messengers, and that he feared their deviation from the Straight Path would intensify. His bones were weak and he had reached an advanced age, and he saw no one among his people fit to carry the Message after him. Since his wife was barren, it was unconventional for a woman in her condition to give birth, which caused him great anxiety. His wife was the sister of Mary (Maryam) bint Imran, the mother of Jesus (Isa) son of Mary, or her maternal aunt. After Mary's father died, the Children of Israel disputed over who would be her guardian; they drew lots, and the lot fell to Zechariah. He took her under his guardianship and placed her in his sanctuary (Mihrab). He noticed that whenever he entered her place of worship, he found sustenance with her. He said: *« O Mary, from where is this for you? » She said: « It is from Allah. Indeed, Allah provides for whom He wills without reckoning. »* [Surah Al Imran (3:37]. The implications of this reality quickly arose in his heart, making him hope that God would bestow upon him a righteous son to govern the Children of Israel. Even though the conventional causes for his righteous wife to bear a son were absent—he was an old man and she was barren—the sustenance that God had granted Mary stirred hope in him that God would grant him a child despite the absence of normal means. So he called upon his Lord in a low voice, standing in prayer in his sanctuary (Mihrab). In his supplication, he said: *« My Lord, grant me from Yourself a good offspring. Indeed, You are the Hearer of supplication. »* He also said: *« My Lord, indeed my bones have weakened and my head is covered with grey hair, and never have I been wretched in my supplication to You, my Lord. And indeed, I fear my relatives after me (those who will inherit my responsibility); moreover, my wife was barren in her youth, yet You are powerful over all things. So grant me from Yourself an ally (a son) who will inherit me and inherit from the family of Jacob (Yaqub), and make him, my Lord, one with whom You are well-pleased. »* Then the angels called out to him while he was standing in prayer in the *Mihrab* (sanctuary), announcing that God gave him the good news of a boy whose name would be John (Yahya), for whom God had not made anyone similar before. He would be a confirmer of a Word from God, a chief (Sayyid), chaste (Hasoor), and a Prophet among the righteous. He asked, « How can I have a child when my wife and I are in this state? » The angel replied, « Thus it is; Allah creates what He wills. Indeed, He created you before when you were nothing – you came into your mother's womb as a fluid with no human form. » He then asked Allah for a sign by which he would know that the child was imminent. The answer was: « Your sign is that you will not be able to speak to people for three days, while perfectly sound (with no illness). » He emerged from his sanctuary to his people and indicated to them to glorify God morning and evening. God granted him John, who grew up quickly. Allah granted him wisdom and Judgment while yet a child (Hukm Sabiya), favored him with many gifts, and granted him Peace (Salam) on the day he was born, the day he dies, and the day he is raised alive. Concerning this, Allah says in Surah Maryam (19:1-15): *« Kãf-Hã-Yã-'Ayn-Sãd. A mention of the mercy of your Lord to His servant Zechariah. When he called upon his Lord in a secret invocation... »* until *« ... And peace be upon him the day he was born and the day he dies and the day he is raised alive. »* And He says in Surah Al-Anbiya (21:89-90): *« And (mention) Zechariah, when he cried out to his Lord, « My Lord, do not leave me solitary, and You are the best of inheritors. » So We responded to him, and We bestowed upon him John (Yahya), and We made his wife fit for him. Indeed, they used to hasten to good deeds and supplicate to Us with hope and fear, and they were humble before Us. »* And in Surah Al-An'am (6:85): *« And Zechariah and John and Jesus and Elias. All were among the righteous. »* And in Surah Al Imran (3:37-40): *« So her Lord accepted her with a good acceptance and made her grow in a good manner and entrusted her to the care of Zechariah. Every time Zechariah entered upon her in the sanctuary, he found with her provision. He said, « O Mary, from where is this for you? » She said, « It is from Allah. Indeed, Allah provides for whom He wills without reckoning. » At that, Zechariah called upon his Lord, saying, « My Lord, grant me from Yourself a good offspring. Indeed, You are the Hearer of supplication. » So the angels called him while he was standing praying in the sanctuary, « Allah gives you good tidings of John (Yahya), confirming a word from Allah and a chief (Sayyid) and chaste (Hasour) and a Prophet from among the righteous. » He said, « My Lord, how can I have a boy when old age has reached me and my wife is barren? » He said, « Thus [it will be]; Allah does what He wills. »* The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) mentioned that Zechariah was a carpenter (*Najjâr*), narrated by Muslim on the authority of Abu Hurayrah. The Messenger of Allah also described John and Jesus as being maternal cousins (*Ibnā Khālah*), narrated by Al-Bukhari and Muslim in the *Isrā'* (Night Journey) narrative: « Then he ascended until he reached the second heaven and asked for it to be opened. It was said, 'Who is this?' - 'Gabriel.' - 'And who is with you?' - 'Muhammad.' - 'Has a Message been sent for him?' - 'Yes.' - 'Welcome to him, and what an excellent coming he has come!' It was opened for us, and when I passed through, behold, there were John and Jesus, and they were maternal cousins. Gabriel said, 'These are John and Jesus, greet them.' I greeted them, and they returned the greeting, and then said, 'Welcome to the righteous brother and the righteous Prophet.' » As for the interpretation that John was incapable of sexual relations, derived from the term *« Hasoor »* [Surah Al Imran (3:39)], it is without proof and is not authentically established from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him). It is a flaw in manhood of which Allah purifies His Prophets. Moreover, the term *« Hasoor »* has many meanings: it refers to one who is incapable of approaching women, one who is narrow-chested, or one who protects himself from sins and impurities. This last meaning is the most appropriate for John. Until the next chapter, God willing, and may the peace, mercy, and blessings of God be upon you.
source: Holy Quran and Prophetic Sunnah, Exegeses of Ahlus Sunnah Wal Jama'ah

bio_naissance_annee: Born long before the people of ‘Ad
bio_lieu_naissance: Al-Ahqaf, Yemen, between Oman and Hadramaut
bio_descendance: Hud ibn Shalikh ibn Arfakhshad ibn Sam ibn Noah (PBUH)
texte_original: We speak to you about Hud, the first Arab prophet whose story Allah mentioned in the Qur’an. We have not found a reliable lineage for him in authentic reports, as historians differ on his genealogy. Some say he is Hud ibn Salih ibn Arfakhshad ibn Sam ibn Nuh, others say Hud is ‘Abir ibn Salih ibn Arfakhshad ibn Sam ibn Nuh, and others say he is Hud ibn Abdullah ibn Rabah ibn Al-Jarood or Jawar ibn ‘Ad ibn Aws ibn Iram ibn Sam ibn Nuh. None of these opinions can be relied upon because no authentic evidence supports them. Hud was sent to the people of ‘Ad after they had become a mighty nation. So how could he be directly linked to Sam ibn Nuh in the first and second accounts, or how could ‘Ad be his second-generation ancestor in the third account? Allah Almighty mentions that Hud was sent to ‘Ad, who lived in Al-Ahqaf, located in Yemen between Oman and Hadramout, overlooking the sea near Shukhr and extending to Al-Dahna. Their lands were among the most fertile and lush. Al-Ahqaf (plural of Haqf) refers to large sand dunes, either curved or rectangular. A chapter of the Qur’an is named Al-Ahqaf. The tribe of ‘Ad, to whom Hud was sent, were among the strongest and most formidable nations, with unmatched physiques. They are sometimes referred to as ‘Ad Iram, with the “first ‘Ad” referring to the earlier ‘Ad in history, as opposed to the second ‘Ad, which is Thamud, the people of Salih. The tribe of ‘Ad were pure Arabs. Many Qur’anic commentators note that they were the first nation after Noah’s people, based on the fact that Allah mentions Hud’s people after Noah’s in several chapters, such as Al-A’raf, Hud, and Ash-Shu’ara. However, mentioning Hud after Noah does not mean Hud came immediately after Noah, nor that his people were the first to commit shirk after the Flood. In Surah Al-Ahqaf, Allah says about Hud: "And mention ‘Ad, when We sent against them a messenger from among themselves, Hud. He said, 'O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. Will you not fear Him?'" [Al-Ahqaf: 21] And in Surah Fussilat: "If they turn away, say, 'I have warned you of a thunderbolt like the thunderbolt that struck ‘Ad and Thamud when the messengers came to them before.'" [Fussilat: 13–14] This clearly shows that Hud was one of the messengers sent by Allah. Not all messengers’ stories are mentioned in detail; Allah says: "Some of them We relate to you, and some of them We do not relate to you." [Ghafir: 78] The Qur’an situates Hud’s story after Noah to remind his people of the flood and indicate that the people of ‘Ad were aware of Noah’s story. Hud’s mission included guiding his people away from shirk and reminding them of Allah’s commands. In Surah Al-A’raf, Allah says: "And to ‘Ad [We sent] their brother Hud. He said: 'O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. Will you not fear Him?'" [Al-A’raf: 65] In Surah Hud: "And to ‘Ad [We sent] their brother Hud. He said: 'O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. You are only inventors [of falsehood].'" [Hud: 50] And in Al-Ahqaf: "And mention ‘Ad, when He warned their people in Al-Ahqaf, and the warners had passed away before him and after him, 'Do not worship anyone but Allah; indeed, I fear for you the punishment of a tremendous day.'" [Al-Ahqaf: 21] Hud emphasized to his people that he did not ask for a reward for delivering the message, as is the case with all messengers. Allah says in Surah Hud: "O my people, I do not ask you for any reward for it. My reward is only with the One who created me. Will you not understand?" [Hud: 51] And in Surah Ash-Shu’ara: "And I do not ask you for any reward for it. My reward is only with the Lord of the worlds." [Ash-Shu’ara: 180] Indeed, had they used their intellect, they would have believed, since Hud undertook this great mission without seeking any worldly reward. The messengers guided their people to what brings happiness in this world and the hereafter, reminding them to turn to Allah and avoid sins. In Surah Hud, Allah says: "And ask forgiveness of your Lord, then repent to Him. He will send the sky upon you in showers and increase you in strength to your strength. And do not turn away as criminals." [Hud: 52] Similar to the story of Noah: "Say, 'Ask forgiveness of your Lord. Indeed, He is ever Forgiving. He will send rain upon you in abundance and provide you with wealth and children and make gardens for you.'" [Noah: 10–12] Prophet Hud also showed that when the disbelievers could not counter his arguments, they would resort to saying he must be cursed by their gods. Allah says: "They said, 'O Hud, you have not brought us clear proof, and we are not abandoning our gods because of what you say, nor do we believe you.'" [Hud: 53] Hud replied: "I bear witness to Allah, and you bear witness that I am free from what you associate with Him. So plan against me all together, then do not give me respite; indeed, I rely upon Allah, my Lord and your Lord. There is no creature whose fate He does not hold. Indeed, my Lord is on a straight path." [Hud: 54–57] This stance resembles that of Noah and Abraham, who relied on Allah alone. Allah protected Hud and those who believed with him from severe punishment, while the disbelievers were destroyed for rejecting their Lord. The Qur’an mentions: "We saved Hud and those who believed with him by Our mercy and destroyed those who denied Our signs." [Hud: 50–60] The punishment for ‘Ad is described as a furious wind striking them for seven nights and eight days, leaving them lifeless like uprooted palm trees. The Qur’an says: "And as for ‘Ad, We destroyed them with a furious wind, which left nothing they possessed intact." [Al-Dhariyat: 41–242] "And We destroyed the first ‘Ad." [An-Najm: 50] "‘Ad denied the messengers. How terrible was My punishment." [Al-Qamar / Al-Haqqah / Al-Fajr: 6] Narrations from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) report that the Prophet (peace be upon him) never laughed loudly but smiled. When he saw clouds or wind, it would reflect on his face. Aisha asked about this, and he explained that the people often fear the punishment that Allah sends. Ibn Abbas reported that the Prophet said: "‘Ad were destroyed by the wind
