bio_lieu_naissance: Created in Paradise then sent to Earth
bio_descendance: Eve (his wife) and his children
texte_original: We are talking here about Adam in points covering his story: his creation, his composition from different types of soil, his height, the tree he was forbidden to eat from, the duration of his stay in Paradise, his descent from Paradise, the number of his children and the question of whether he named a son “Abd al-Harith,” the mention of passing on his life to David, what is said about his hair during the murder of his son, whether he built the Kaaba, his supplication to God through Muhammad, the Prophet Muhammad ﷺ seeing Adam during the Isra and Mi‘raj, then we talk about his death, the location of his burial, the debate between Moses and Adam about destiny, and finally his delay in interceding on the Day of Judgment. Regarding the story of his creation, Almighty God mentioned it in many places in the Holy Qur’an. He says in Surah Al-Baqara: “And when your Lord said to the angels: ‘I am going to place a vicegerent on earth,’ they said: ‘Will You place someone there who will spread corruption and shed blood, while we glorify and sanctify You?’ He said: ‘Indeed, I know what you do not know.’ And He taught Adam the names of all things, then presented them to the angels and said: ‘Inform Me of the names of these if you are truthful.’ They said: ‘Glory be to You! We have no knowledge except what You have taught us. Indeed, it is You the All-Knowing, the Wise.’” [Al-Baqara: 30-33] Almighty God mentioned that He created him from soil, clay, pottery-like clay, and sticky clay. It is said in Surah Al-Imran: “The likeness of Jesus before God is like that of Adam: He created him from dust, then said ‘Be!’ and he was.” [Al-Imran: 59] And in Surah Al-A‘raf: “We certainly created you, then shaped you, then We said to the angels: ‘Prostrate to Adam!’ They prostrated except Iblis; he refused and was not among those who prostrated. He said: ‘Why did You not prostrate to what You created from clay?’” [Al-A‘raf: 11] And in Surah Al-Hijr: “We created man from baked clay, then We breathed into him of Our spirit…” [Al-Hijr: 26-33] And in Surah As-Sajda: “He Who perfected His creation…” [As-Sajda: 7] And in Surah At-Tin: “We created man from the best clay…” [At-Tin: 4] The description of the process indicates that God took a handful of all the soils of the Earth and shaped it. Thus, the children of Adam come from all the colors of the earth. This handful of soil was moistened by God, became clay, and depending on its transformation, was called pottery. Baked clay is called pottery. Sticky clay is clay that has hardened but retains a particular smell. Solid black clay is called “hamâ’ masnûn.” Adam’s height was sixty cubits. God created him with His hands, shaped him, and made him beautiful and healthy. According to a hadith reported by Abu Huraira, the Prophet ﷺ said: “God created Adam sixty cubits tall, then He said to him: go greet these angels and listen to their response; that will be your greeting and that of your descendants.” The angels replied: “Peace be upon you,” and added: “and the mercy of God.” All men entering Paradise will have Adam’s form, and humanity’s size gradually decreased over time until today. Regarding the tree Adam was forbidden to eat from, some say it was wheat, others fig, others vine, but the Prophet ﷺ did not specify which tree it was. The important point is that Adam and his wife were warned by God not to eat from this tree. According to Surah Al-Baqara: “O Adam, dwell, you and your wife, in Paradise and eat freely wherever you wish, but do not approach this tree, lest you be of the wrongdoers.” [Al-Baqara: 35] Satan deceived them, they ate from the tree, and God caused them to descend to Earth: “Descend, enemies one to another, and you will find on earth a dwelling and enjoyment for a time.” [Al-Baqara: 36] As for the number of Adam’s children, there is no exact information from the Qur’an or the Prophet ﷺ. Some say Eve had 40 children in 20 pregnancies, others 120, each pregnancy producing a son and a daughter. Ibn Kathir reports that Adam died after seeing 400,000 descendants. The story that Adam named a son Abd al-Harith is considered unauthentic and comes from the Isra’iliyat. It is not attributable to Adam and Eve; the real meaning of the story is to warn against associating partners with God (shirk). Regarding passing on his life to David, a weak hadith mentions that Adam gave 40 years of his life to David, bringing the latter’s life to 100 years. This hadith is not authentic and cannot be applied to Adam. For the murder of his son by Cain, there is no authentic narration about Adam’s hair or any poems attributed to him, and he did not build the Kaaba. Stories about his supplication to God in the name of Muhammad ﷺ are also weak and unauthentic. During the Isra and Mi‘raj, the Prophet ﷺ saw Adam in the first heaven and greeted him. Adam acknowledged the prophecy and the lineage of the children. Adam’s age at death and burial location are not specified in authentic sources. Regarding the discussion between Moses and Adam about destiny, the Prophet ﷺ reported that Adam won the argument: Moses blamed Adam for bringing humans down from Paradise, and Adam replied that what was written by God would happen anyway. Finally, concerning intercession on the Day of Judgment, Adam was not late; it is recalled that the argument of destiny only applies to disasters or involuntary mistakes, not to sins committed voluntarily.

bio_naissance_annee: No specific date, lived in the period between Ibrahim (Abraham) and Musa (Moses) (approx. 1600 BCE).
bio_lieu_naissance: Canaan (Palestine) and Egypt.
bio_descendance: Son of Ya'qub (Israel) son of Ishaq. He had eleven half-brothers and one full brother, Binyamin (Benjamin). His sons include Ephraim and Manasseh.
texte_original: ## Yusuf the Truthful: From Trial to Sovereignty In this chapter, we discuss the Noble son of the Noble, son of the Noble, son of the Noble, Yusuf (Joseph) the Truthful (*As-Siddîq*), the Prophet and Messenger of Allah. We have previously mentioned some aspects of his story when discussing his fathers, Ibrahim, Ishaq, and Ya'qub (Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob), peace be upon them. Genealogists generally agree that he was born to Ya'qub by his wife Rachel. Most scholars hold that she died when he was young, leaving him a younger full brother, Benjamin. Ya'qub had ten other sons from other wives, one of whom was Rachel's elder sister. Allah granted Yusuf such beauty and grace that he became proverbial for it. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) described him as having been given 'half of all beauty.' Muslim narrated in his *Sahih*, in the story of the Night Journey and Ascension (Al-Isra wal-Mi'râj), from the Hadith of Anas ibn Malik, that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), in his account of his ascent to the highest heavens, said: "Then we were ascended to the third heaven. Gabriel requested entry. It was asked: 'Who are you?' He said: 'Gabriel.' It was asked: 'Who is with you?' He said: 'Muhammad.' It was asked: 'Has he been sent for?' He said: 'He has been sent for.' It was opened for us, and I saw Yusuf; he had been given half of all beauty... " (end of the Hadith). Allah the Blessed and Exalted mentioned concerning the women who criticized the wife of Al-Aziz (the Vizier) that when she tested them by arranging a banquet (or couches on which to recline) and giving each of them a knife, she told [Yusuf]: {Come out before them}. When they saw him, {they were greatly amazed (akbarnahû) and cut their hands, saying, 'Good Heavens! This is not a human being! This is none other than a noble angel!'} [Yusuf: 31]. His father Ya'qub loved him for the physical and inner beauty that Allah had bestowed upon him. His brothers noticed that their father loved Yusuf and Benjamin more than them, though their father knew their own character and conduct better than theirs. Since Yusuf's brothers were not infallible (*ma'sûmîn*) from sins and evil deeds (they were not Prophets, and though they were from the Tribes (*Al-Asbât*), they were not the specific *Asbât* whom Allah mentioned as receiving revelation, as in: {Indeed, We have revealed to you as We revealed to Noah and the Prophets after him. And We revealed to Abraham, Ishmael, Isaac, Jacob, and the Tribes (Al-Asbât)...} [An-Nisa: 163]), they held malice towards Yusuf. The term *Sabt* (Tribe) applies to the son's son, no matter how far down the line, as well as to the daughter's son. Allah the Blessed and Exalted dedicated an entire Surah of the Qur'an to Yusuf, narrating his story. He concluded Sūrat Hūd with His saying: {And all that We relate to you of the news of the Messengers is to strengthen your heart therewith...} [Hūd: 120]. Having mentioned the news of the Messengers in Sūrat Hūd and the harm the Prophets suffered from relatives and strangers, He mentioned in Sūrat Yusuf, who is one of the great Messengers, the harm he suffered from his own brothers. This was to inform Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) and strengthen the hearts of the believers by showing them the suffering of the Prophets from both relatives and strangers. The story of Yusuf contains sublime laws, wisdom, manners, rules of conduct, lessons about the lives of kings, the thinking of scholars, the planning of strategies to achieve righteous goals, setting beautiful means to attain lofty objectives, the cunning of women, their lack of patience regarding temptations, the demonstration of the excellent outcome for the pious and patient, the father's compassion, and the fact that a person's diligence in guarding his child from evil does not save him from the Decree of Allah. It shows that a righteous father may have a disobedient son, and that forgiveness when having power is a noble trait. It also establishes the prophethood and message of Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), the Seal of the Prophets, in addition to other indications and lessons that only Allah encompasses. Allah the Blessed and Exalted began Yusuf's story with the vision he saw when he was young, and concluded it with the fact that the honor and dignity he attained was the fulfillment of his vision. Concerning Yusuf's vision, Allah says: {When Joseph said to his father, 'O my father, indeed I saw eleven stars and the sun and the moon; I saw them prostrating to me'} [Yusuf: 4]. Ya'qub understood that this vision indicated that Yusuf was destined for something great: honor from Allah, exaltation of his status, and Allah's selection of him. He would complete His favor upon him and upon Ya'qub's family, just as He had completed it upon his two fathers, Ibrahim and Ishaq. Ya'qub asked Yusuf to keep this vision secret from his brothers, sensing their malice and hatred for him, and knowing that revealing the story of the vision would only increase their rancor and cause them to plot against him. On this matter, Allah says: {He said, 'O my son, do not relate your vision to your brothers, lest they plot against you a plot. Indeed, Satan is to man a clear enemy. And thus will your Lord choose you and teach you the interpretation of narratives and complete His favor upon you and upon the family of Jacob, as He completed it upon your fathers before, Abraham and Isaac. Indeed, your Lord is Knowing and Wise'} [Yusuf: 5-6]. Ya'qub also understood from this vision that his son Yusuf would be highly skilled in the interpretation of dreams, which implies a raised status, high rank, and authority on earth. The majority of exegetes agree that the eleven stars are Yusuf's brothers, and the sun and the moon are his father and his aunt, or his father and his mother. Allah described the affair of Yusuf and his brothers as Signs for those who ask, saying: {There were certainly in [the story of] Joseph and his brothers signs for those who ask} [Yusuf: 7]. Meaning, lessons, admonitions, wonders, and wisdom for those who seek knowledge, contemplate, and heed. They show the effect of envy on its possessor, the ultimate fate of the envious, the effects of patience, the praiseworthy outcome for the patient, a father's compassion, that a person's diligence in preserving his son from evil does not save him from the Decree of Allah, and that a righteous father may beget a disobedient son. They also show that forgiveness when having power is the character of the noble, and affirm the prophethood and message of Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), the Seal of the Prophets, as well as other indications and lessons that only Allah encompasses. The first sign of evil intent from Yusuf's brothers was their saying: {Joseph and his brother [Benjamin] are more beloved to our father than we} [Yusuf: 8]. His inclination toward them was greater, his tenderness towards them was more profound, and his affection for them was stronger. {While we are a cohesive group ('uṣbah)}, a strong, united company, which is more beneficial to our father. {Indeed, our father is in clear error [concerning this love]}, far from guidance and correctness. Some of them said to each other: We must turn Yusuf away from our father's attention. Some proposed killing him, others proposed throwing him in a distant land where wild beasts would devour him or where he would die, and then they would become righteous people. Others suggested getting him away from their father while trying to save him from immediate death by throwing him {into the bottom of the well} [Yusuf: 10] - the dark part of the well, similar to a modern well-pump chamber, so that a traveler might pick him up. They finally agreed to put him in a dark place in a well frequented by travelers going from Palestine to Egypt. When they started to execute the plan, they said to their father: {O our father, why do you not entrust us with Joseph while we are indeed to him sincere counselors? Send him with us tomorrow that he may enjoy himself and play, and indeed, we will be his guardians} [Yusuf: 11-12]. Ya'qub replied that he could not bear his absence, that his departure would grieve him, and that he feared the wolf might devour him while they were heedless and playing. They dismissed the fear of the wolf, arguing that they were an 'uṣbah (a strong group that supports one another). If a wolf were to reach him despite their strength and number, they would be worthless, ruined, incapable, and weak. They took him from his father, despite his caution, for caution does not avert the Divine Decree. They left Benjamin behind. They went to the well and threw him {into the bottom of the well} (*ghayabat al-jubb*). If they had thrown him into the middle of the well, he would have died. Allah cast tranquility into his heart, assuring him that he would not perish in this well, that he would see his envious brothers again, and that he would inform them of what they did to him at a time when he would be honored and they humbled. They had stripped him of his shirt before throwing him in the well and put false blood upon it (a fabricated lie, not Yusuf's blood). {And they came to their father at night, weeping} [Yusuf: 16]. They said to him: {O our father, indeed we went off racing and left Joseph with our belongings, and the wolf ate him. But you would not believe us, even if we were truthful} [Yusuf: 17]. Ya'qub did not believe them about the wolf or his death, for he was certain that Yusuf had a great destiny. Therefore, he said to them: {Rather, your souls have enticed you to [do] something. So patience is most fitting (ṣabrun jamîl). And Allah is the one sought for help against that which you describe} [Yusuf: 18]. To the next chapter, if Allah wills. Peace and Allah's mercy and blessings be upon you. --- ## Chapter Thirty-One: Continuation of Yusuf the Truthful In the previous chapter, I mentioned the actions of Yusuf's brothers, their plot against him, their trickery in taking him from their father, and throwing him into the well. Concerning this, Allah says: {There were certainly in [the story of] Joseph and his brothers signs for those who ask. When they said, 'Joseph and his brother are more beloved to our father than we, while we are a cohesive group. Indeed, our father is in clear error. Kill Joseph or cast him out to [some] land; the attention of your father will [then] be only for you, and thereafter you will be righteous people.' Said a speaker among them, 'Do not kill Joseph but throw him into the bottom of the well; some travelers will pick him up - that is, some passing travelers from the caravans - if you would do [something]'} [Yusuf: 7-10]. {They said, 'O our father, why do you not entrust us with Joseph while we are indeed to him sincere counselors? Send him with us tomorrow that he may enjoy himself and play, and indeed, we will be his guardians.' He said, 'Indeed, it grieves me that you should take him, and I fear that a wolf would eat him while you are of him unaware.' They said, 'If a wolf should eat him while we are a cohesive group, then [indeed] we would be losers.' So when they took him away and agreed to put him into the bottom of the well, We inspired to him, 'You will surely inform them of this affair of theirs while they do not perceive [who you are].' And they came to their father at night, weeping. They said, 'O our father, indeed we went off racing and left Joseph with our belongings, and the wolf ate him. But you would not believe us, even if we were truthful.' And they presented upon his shirt false blood. [Jacob] said, 'Rather, your souls have enticed you to [do] something. So patience is most fitting! And Allah is the one sought for help against that which you describe'} [Yusuf: 11-18]. Ya'qub's stance when his sons told him that the wolf had eaten their brother Yusuf, despite his certainty that his sons were lying and that Yusuf was facing a severe trial, was this noble stance of patience in the face of calamity, delegation of the matter to Allah, and lack of despair. This is an example for every righteous servant who is tried and tested. Thus, Al-Bukhari reported that 'Aishah, the Truthful daughter of the Truthful, the Mother of the Believers, the chaste and dignified, when she was accused of the slander (Al-Ifk), said: "By Allah, I find no example for you and me except the father of Yusuf when he said: {So patience is most fitting! And Allah is the one sought for help against that which you describe} [Yusuf: 18]. " Allah the Blessed and Exalted described what happened to Yusuf after his brothers cast him into the well, indicating that his time alone in the well was not long. Allah prepared for him a group of travelers who stopped near the well. They sent their water drawer (Wârid), a person who comes to the well to draw water for them. He let down his bucket into the well, and Yusuf clung to it. When the drawer sensed him, he pulled him out, exclaiming: "Oh, good news! This is a boy! " (Yâ buchrâ hâdhâ ghulâm). He secretly agreed with some of his companions to claim that he was a slave whom they had obtained to sell to wealthy people near the well in Egypt. It was as if Yusuf felt he could not refute their claim of his slavery, so he submitted. It was as if those who made him a commodity realized that they were facing a noble human being, one who should not be passed around among common people. They decided that it was only fitting to present him to the Vizier (Aziz), the chief minister of the King of Egypt, as an honor to him. As soon as they reached Egypt, they presented him to its Vizier and sold him for a nominal price: {for a meager price - a few counted dirhams} (a small number) [Yusuf: 20]. They were certain that this noble person was worthy of being settled in the Vizier's house in any case, and that they were not worthy of keeping him under their hands or the hands of anyone less than the Vizier. The stages of honoring, esteem, veneration, and exaltation began to unfold for Yusuf. The Vizier's joy in him was immense. He said to his wife: {Make his stay comfortable}, and lodge him in the best quarters: {Perhaps he will benefit us, or we will adopt him as a son} [Yusuf: 21]. Thus, a misfortune can sometimes be a blessing: he moved from the hardships of desert life to the greatest civilized palaces. His being thrown into the well became the reason for his arrival in Egypt and his progression through stages of dignity until he became its ruler. Allah showed mercy to the servants and the land through him, especially during the years of drought and famine, so much so that the blessings Allah conferred through him extended to his father and brothers. This served to strengthen the heart of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), informing him: 'I am aware of the harm your people inflict upon you, but the relief is near. I will grant you a good outcome and mastery over them.' And Allah did so: it was not long before the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) emigrated to Medina. A few years after Yusuf's separation from his father, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) conquered Mecca, and people entered the religion of Allah in crowds. It is reported that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) asked the people of Mecca who had harmed and expelled him: "What do you think I will do to you? " They replied: "You are noble, the son of a noble brother. " He said: {I will not say to you except what my brother Joseph said: 'No blame will there be upon you this day. May Allah forgive you; and He is the most merciful of the merciful'} [Yusuf: 92]. "Go, for you are free. " Allah the Blessed and Exalted described Yusuf's transfer to the house of the Vizier of Egypt as an establishment (Tamkîn) for him in the land. He reached his full strength (*ashuddah*), and Allah gave him wisdom (*ḥukm*) and knowledge (*'ilm*). In all this, Allah says: {And there came a caravan, and they sent their water drawer, and he let down his bucket. He said, 'Oh, good news! This is a boy.' And they concealed him [intending] as merchandise; and Allah was knowing of what they did. And they sold him - meaning: they sold him - for a meager price, a few counted dirhams, and they were among those who were indifferent concerning him - their indifference was one of reverence and respect, not disdain or contempt. And the one who bought him from Egypt said to his wife, 'Make his stay comfortable; perhaps he will benefit us, or we will adopt him as a son.' And thus, We established (makannâ) Joseph in the land, and that We might teach him the interpretation of narratives. And Allah is predominant over His affair, but most of the people do not know. And when he reached his full maturity, We gave him judgment and knowledge. And thus do We reward the doers of good} [Yusuf: 19-22]. Allah the Blessed and Exalted mentioned that the wife of the Vizier's heart became attached to Yusuf. {She was overcome by passion for him (qad shaghafahâ ḥubban)}, meaning his love penetrated the *shighâf* (cover or veil) of her heart, or its *suwaydâ* (innermost part). She felt as if he were a king and she his slave, offering everything she could to make him happy, honored, and respected. It reached a point where she contemplated intercourse with him. She used every kind of enticement before him, but he turned away, heedless of her actions. When she realized that her attempts at seduction did not turn his attention to her, she concluded, as it is said: * "Objectives are not attained by wishes, but the world is taken by might. "* Hinting had not benefited her, and she had to state her need clearly to Yusuf. {She closed the doors and said, 'Come to me (Hayta laka),' meaning: I have prepared and beautified myself for you, so come. {He said, 'I seek refuge in Allah!'} (Ma'âdha Allâh), meaning: I seek protection and shelter in Allah from committing the crime of Zina, which is the most heinous of crimes. Allah has been so kind to me, providing me with a good home and noble standing. How can I repay His goodness with disobedience? The wrongdoers do not succeed: {Indeed, the wrongdoers will not succeed}. The fornicators will not succeed, for Zina leads to the loss of blessings in this world and Allah's punishment in the Hereafter. Since the woman's impulsiveness and sexual fervor had reached its peak, she paid no heed to his refusal and chastity and rushed towards him. Had Allah not protected His Prophets and Messengers from evil, he might have succumbed. But the favors of Allah became manifest to Yusuf, and Allah turned away from him the evil and the immorality. He ran toward the door to escape her. She chased him and caught his shirt from behind, pulling it so that the shirt was torn {from the back (min dubur)}. He managed to reach the door, and the Vizier was there. She quickly moved to pin the blame on Yusuf and said to her husband: {What is the recompense for one who intended ill for your wife but that he should be imprisoned or undergo a painful punishment?} Yusuf defended himself and said to the Vizier: {It was she who sought to seduce me}. Allah caused a witness from her family to speak. He said to the Vizier: {If his shirt is torn from the front, then she has told the truth, and he is of the liars}, because she would have torn it while defending herself as he approached her. {But if his shirt is torn from the back, then she has lied, and he is of the truthful}, because she would have torn it as he tried to flee and she pursued him. When the Vizier saw that the shirt was torn from the back, he was convinced of Yusuf's innocence. It is noteworthy here that the witness began by considering the shirt being torn from the front, to make his attempt to prove her innocence more plausible, lest he be accused of favoring Yusuf, even though he was from her family. This would make his testimony more acceptable to them both. This is similar to what the believer from the people of Pharaoh said to Pharaoh and his people concerning Moses: {And if he is a liar, upon him will be [the consequence of] his lie; but if he should be truthful, there will strike you some of what he promises you. Indeed, Allah does not guide one who is a transgressor and a liar} [Ghafir: 28]. This believer began the hypothetical scenario with the possibility that he might be a liar, and followed it with the possibility that he might be truthful, to make his words more impactful on their hearts and closer to their acceptance of his advice. Allah the Blessed and Exalted did not name the Vizier's wife, nor did the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him). People call her Zulaikhâ' or Râ'îl. Since there was no great benefit in identifying her name, Allah did not name her for us. He only mentioned the important matter that points to Yusuf's high stature and purity: that he was in her house, that she closed the doors, that she said {Come to me}, and that she desired him (*hammat bih*). Yet, despite that, Allah turned away from him the evil and the immorality. Concerning all this, Allah says: {And she, in whose house he was, sought to seduce him. She closed the doors and said, 'Come to me.' He said, 'I seek refuge in Allah. Indeed, he is my master, who has made my residence comfortable. Indeed, the wrongdoers will not succeed.' And she certainly desired him, and he would have desired her had he not seen the proof of his Lord. Thus [it was] that We should avert from him evil and immorality. Indeed, he was one of Our selected servants. And they both raced to the door, and she tore his shirt from the back. And they found her master at the door. She said, 'What is the recompense for one who intended ill for your wife but that he should be imprisoned or undergo a painful punishment?' [Joseph] said, 'It was she who sought to seduce me.' And a witness from her family testified, 'If his shirt is torn from the front, then she has told the truth, and he is of the liars. But if his shirt is torn from the back, then she has lied, and he is of the truthful.' So when [the master] saw his shirt torn from the back, he said, 'Indeed, it is of the cunning of you women. Indeed, your cunning is great. Joseph, disregard this. And [you, woman], ask forgiveness for your sin. Indeed, you were of the sinful'} [Yusuf: 23-29]. To the next chapter, if Allah wills. Peace and Allah's mercy and blessings be upon you. --- ## Chapter Thirty-Two: Continuation of Yusuf the Truthful I mentioned at the end of the previous chapter what Allah disclosed regarding the Vizier's attempt to keep his wife's attempted seduction of Yusuf a secret, and how he asked her to seek Allah's forgiveness for her sin and that she was among the sinful, saying: {Joseph, disregard this. And [you, woman], ask forgiveness for your sin. Indeed, you were of the sinful} [Yusuf: 29]. However, the concealment of this incident did not succeed. It was circulated by tongues, and the women in the city (wives of princes and daughters of notables) spoke of it. They criticized and deplored the action of the Vizier's wife, severely condemning her for trying to seduce her young servant and for her intense love for him. They became eager to see him. When she heard their criticism, denigration, and blame for her love of her servant, realizing that they did not know that Yusuf's beauty could enchant those of sound mind, she wanted to present her excuse to them and show that a young man like him was unparalleled. She sent for them, gathered them at her house, prepared a feast, and included something to be cut with knives, like the citron (*utrujj*) or similar, and gave a knife to each one of them. When they began cutting what they held with the knives, she ordered Yusuf to come out before them. He emerged, undoubtedly more handsome than the full moon. When they saw him, they were greatly amazed (*akbarnahû*), revered him, were awestruck, and astonished at his sight. His beauty so overwhelmed them that they forgot themselves, and began cutting and carving their hands with the knives instead of cutting the fruit, without even feeling the wounds. They thought that one like him did not exist among the sons of Adam, and {they said, 'Good Heavens! This is not a human being! This is none other than a noble angel!'} [Yusuf: 31]. Meaning: May Allah forbid that this be from the sons of Adam. This is none other than a noble angel. The people of Egypt at that time, although idolaters, acknowledged the Lord of the heavens and the earth, like the polytheists of Quraysh and others, even if they worshipped others besides Allah. It was then that the Vizier's wife revealed the concealed passion and infatuation in her heart. {She said, 'That is the one about whom you blamed me!'} [Yusuf: 32]. She highlighted his chastity and complete innocence, saying: {And I did certainly seek to seduce him, but he firmly refused (fasta'ṣama). And if he does not do what I order him, he will surely be imprisoned and will be among the humiliated (aṣ-ṣâghirîn)} [Yusuf: 32]. There is no doubt that her infatuation and madness for him had reached the extent that she publicly declared this to the gathering of people. When Yusuf heard her threat of imprisonment and humiliation if he did not submit to her will, {He said, 'My Lord, prison is more to my liking than that to which they invite me. And if You do not avert from me their plan, I might incline toward them and be among the ignorant'} [Yusuf: 33]. Meaning: No one but You can turn away evil from me, O Most Merciful of the merciful. Do not entrust me to myself even for the blink of an eye, for if You entrust me to myself, You entrust me to weakness and incapability, and I possess no power to benefit or harm myself except what Allah wills. Protect me from evil, guard me from wickedness, and shield me with Your might and power, O Lord of the Worlds. {So his Lord responded to him and averted from him their plan. Indeed, He is the All-Hearing, the All-Knowing} [Yusuf: 34]. By this, Yusuf deserved to be at the head of the seven people whom Allah will shade with His Shade on the Day when there is no shade but His. One of them is 'a man who was invited by a woman of rank and beauty, but he said: Indeed, I fear Allah,' as the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) informed in the Hadith found in the two *Sahihs*. After Yusuf's innocence became widespread, the Vizier and his wife concluded that it was in their interest to imprison Yusuf to minimize public talk about the issue. They wanted to make it seem that he was the one who sought to seduce her and was imprisoned because of it. Thus, they imprisoned him unjustly and aggressively. However, prison was dearer to Yusuf than being among them, and it distanced him from their company and proximity. Concerning this, Allah says: {And [some] women in the city said, 'The wife of Al-Aziz is seeking to seduce her slave boy; he has definitely overcome her with love. Indeed, we see her in clear error.' So when she heard of their scheming, she sent to them and prepared for them a banquet and gave each one of them a knife and said [to Joseph], 'Come out before them.' And when they saw him, they were greatly amazed and cut their hands and said, 'Good Heavens! This is not a human being! This is none other than a noble angel!' She said, 'That is the one about whom you blamed me. And I certainly sought to seduce him, but he firmly refused. And if he does not do what I order him, he will surely be imprisoned and will be among the humiliated.' He said, 'My Lord, prison is more to my liking than that to which they invite me. And if You do not avert from me their plan, I might incline toward them and be among the ignorant.' So his Lord responded to him and averted from him their plan. Indeed, He is the All-Hearing, the All-Knowing. Then it appeared to them after they had seen the signs that they should surely imprison him for a time} [Yusuf: 30-35]. Allah the Blessed and Exalted ordained that two young men should enter the prison with Yusuf the Truthful. When they saw Yusuf in prison, they were impressed by his demeanor, his guidance, and the majesty and splendor that Allah had bestowed upon him. They observed his nobility, honor, abundant worship of Allah, and benevolence towards Allah's creation. His conduct was the most eloquent call to Allah, and their hearts became attached to him. Each of them had a dream, and they realized that the best interpreter was Yusuf the Truthful. They approached him, and each recounted his dream. One said: "Indeed, I saw myself pressing wine. " The other said: "Indeed, I saw myself carrying upon my head [some] bread, from which the birds were eating. " They said to him: "Inform us of its interpretation. Indeed, we see you to be of the doers of good. " Before interpreting their dreams, he took the opportunity of their sincere approach to invite them to Allah. However, before calling them directly to the unity of Allah, he began by introducing himself and the grace of Allah upon him and his fathers. He told them that he was knowledgeable in the interpretation of visions and dreams. "No meal of [daily] provision comes to you but that I inform you of its interpretation before it comes to you. That is from what my Lord has taught me. " He clarified that this knowledge was not from him, but from Allah who taught him. Before proceeding to the sheer call to the oneness of Allah, he used the most beautiful method of inviting to Allah by rejecting the worship of idols and statues, and stressing that no one should attach themselves to them. He said: {Indeed, I have left the religion of a people who do not believe in Allah, and they are, in regard to the Hereafter, disbelievers. And I have followed the religion of my fathers, Abraham and Isaac and Jacob. And it was not for us to associate anything with Allah. That is from the favor of Allah upon us and upon mankind, but most of the people are not grateful} [Yusuf: 37-38]. The greatest gift a servant can be given is the rejection of idol worship and the recognition of Allah's right. Having reached this point, he proceeded to call them directly to the oneness of Allah, saying: {O my two companions of prison, are separate lords better or Allah, the One, the Irresistible? You worship not besides Him except [mere] names you have named them, you and your fathers, for which Allah has sent down no authority} [Yusuf: 39-40]. He explained that all creation belongs to Allah, and all authority belongs to Allah, and that no one is permitted to seek judgment from other than Allah's Law, for to Allah belongs the creation and the command: {The judgment is only for Allah. He has commanded that you worship none but Him. That is the correct religion, but most of the people do not know} [Yusuf: 40]. After inviting them to Allah, he interpreted each of their dreams. The one who saw himself pressing wine would exit the prison and serve wine to his master. As for the other, who saw himself carrying bread on his head from which the birds were eating, he would be crucified, and the birds would eat from his head. He did not specify which one would be crucified, but only said: One of you will serve his master wine, and the other will be crucified and the birds will eat from his head. The matter concerning which they asked for interpretation was settled (*quḍiya al-amr*). The implication of the interpretation was: let the one decreed to be crucified be patient, and let the one who will be saved be thankful. {And he said to the one whom he knew would be saved among them, 'Mention me to your master' (dh-kurnî 'inda rabbika)} [Yusuf: 42], and mention that I am being wronged. (*Adh-Dhan* - thought - can mean certainty, as in Allah's saying: {I thought that I would meet my account} [Al-Hâqqa: 20], and {those who think that they will meet their Lord} [Al-Baqarah: 46], and {Do those not think that they will be resurrected for a tremendous Day?} [Al-Muṭaffifîn: 4-5]). Satan made the saved man forget to mention the wronged prisoner Yusuf to the king. So, Yusuf remained in prison for 'a few years' (*biḍ'a sinîn*), a number of years. *Al-Biḍ'* is said to be between three and nine years, or three to five, or four to nine, or seven. Allah the Blessed and Exalted narrated this in His Noble Book, saying: {And two young men entered the prison with him. One of them said, 'Indeed, I saw myself [in a dream] pressing wine.' And the other said, 'Indeed, I saw myself carrying upon my head [some] bread, from which the birds were eating. Inform us of its interpretation; indeed, we see you to be of the doers of good.' He said, 'No food will come to you as provision but that I will inform you of its interpretation before it comes to you. That is from what my Lord has taught me. Indeed, I have left the religion of a people who do not believe in Allah, and they are, in regard to the Hereafter, disbelievers. And I have followed the religion of my fathers, Abraham and Isaac and Jacob. And it was not for us to associate anything with Allah. That is from the favor of Allah upon us and upon mankind, but most of the people are not grateful. O my two companions of prison, are separate lords better or Allah, the One, the Irresistible? You worship not besides Him except [mere] names you have named them, you and your fathers, for which Allah has sent down no authority. The judgment is only for Allah. He has commanded that you worship none but Him. That is the correct religion, but most of the people do not know. O my two companions of prison, as for one of you, he will give his master wine to drink; but as for the other, he will be crucified, and the birds will eat from his head. The matter about which you have asked has been decreed.' And he said to the one whom he knew would be saved among them, 'Mention me to your master.' But Satan made him forget the mention [to] his master, and [consequently] Joseph remained in prison for a few years} [Yusuf: 36-42]. Yusuf's statement: {Mention me to your master} [Yusuf: 42] indicates that taking means (or causes) does not contradict reliance upon Allah (Tawakkul). Some people have claimed that the pronoun in {But Satan made him forget the mention [to] his master} [Yusuf: 42] refers to Yusuf, and that he was punished by the prolonged stay in prison for seeking relief from other than Allah. This is a lie against Allah and against Yusuf. As for what Ibn Jarîr mentioned in his *Tafsîr*, citing a narration attributed to the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) through Ibn 'Abbâs: "Had he - meaning Yusuf - not said the word he said, he would not have remained long in prison, as he sought relief from other than Allah, " this narration is not authentic from the Messenger of Allah. Ibn Kathîr said in his *Tafsîr*: "This Hadith is very weak... " To the next chapter, if Allah wills. Peace and Allah's mercy and blessings be upon you. --- ## Chapter Thirty-Three: Continuation of Yusuf the Truthful In the previous chapter, I pointed out the forgetfulness of the saved prison companion of Yusuf to mention Yusuf's situation to the king. Allah the Blessed and Exalted attributed this forgetting to Satan, saying: {But Satan made him forget the mention [to] his master} [Yusuf: 42]. This style, of attributing evil to Satan, has been repeated by Allah the Blessed and Exalted in the Noble Qur'an, such as in the story of Ayyub (Job): {When he called to his Lord, 'Indeed, Satan has touched me with hardship and torment'} [Sad: 41]. This is because every evil and harm that befalls a person is due to Satan, who caused our parents to be expelled from Paradise. This is a matter of etiquette (*adab*) towards Allah: attributing good to Him and evil to Satan and the soul that commands evil (*an-nafs al-ammârah bis-sû'*), while firmly believing that everything is by the Decree and Will of Allah, and that everything comes from Allah: {And that Allah may purify those who believe [through trials] and destroy the disbelievers} [Âl 'Imrân: 141]. When Allah the Blessed and Exalted willed to exalt Yusuf's rank and confirm his dignity in the hearts of the King of Egypt and his entire people, the King saw in his sleep seven fat cows being eaten by seven lean ones, as well as seven green ears of grain and seven others dry. The King was greatly concerned by his dream and asked the nobles of his people, and those whom he thought possessed knowledge of interpretation, to interpret and explain it to him, and to advise him on what the dream required. They said: {These are mixtures of false dreams (aḍghâth aḥlâm), and we are not learned in the interpretation of [such] dreams} [Yusuf: 44]. *Aḍ-Dighth* (mixture) is a handful of mixed grass, both dry and wet. Meaning: this is a confusing dream whose interpretation is invalid, and we are not capable of interpreting it. It was then that the saved prison companion remembered Yusuf after this long period and said: {I will inform you of its interpretation, so send me [to him]! [He said]: Joseph, O man of truth, explain to us about seven fat cows eaten by seven lean ones, and seven green ears of grain and [seven] others dry, that I may return to the people, perhaps they may know [the meaning]} [Yusuf: 45-46]. So they sent him to Yusuf. As soon as the dream was presented to him, he quickly interpreted it. He explained the seven fat cows and the seven green ears of grain as seven years of plentiful bounty and rich harvest. He interpreted the seven lean and scrawny cows and the seven dry ears of grain as seven years of famine and drought. He did not stop at this profound interpretation of the King's dream but provided them with a plan to overcome the hardship of the seven years of famine. He said: {You shall sow for seven years consecutively. And what you harvest, leave in its heads, except a little of which you will eat. Then will come after that seven hard [years] which will consume what you saved for them, except a little of that which you will store. Then will come after that a year in which the people will have relief (yughâth) and in which they will press [olives, etc.]} [Yusuf: 47-49]. Meaning: you should sow during the seven years, utilizing the opportunity of plenty and good harvest without wasting anything. When the grain is ripe, do not thresh it, but leave it in its ears, except for your necessary food consumption. Do not be extravagant in spending, and store everything you can during these fertile years so that you will have what you need during the seven years of famine. He gave them the glad tidings that Allah would send them rain (*yughâth*) in the first year after the seven lean years, the drought would end, and the oil presses and similar operations would resume their work as before these years. Undoubtedly, the advice of Yusuf the Truthful to preserve the grain in its ears is still admired and appreciated by agricultural scientists, ancient and modern, for keeping grain in its ears better protects it from weevils and decay and preserves it for a long time without the need for modern silos or the like. When the King heard this interpretation, Yusuf grew in his heart, and it became clear to him that he was in dire need of his presence. He said: {Bring him to me! (I'tûnî bih!)} [Yusuf: 50]. When the messenger came to him and informed him that the King was summoning him to honor and exalt him, he did not rush out of prison. Instead, he asked the messenger to return to the King and ask him about the affair of the women who had cut their hands. This was to make his innocence more apparent and his position more dignified, and to put an end to bad rumors. Allah is aware of all things. The majority of scholars hold that the meaning of the Messenger of Allah's (peace and blessings be upon him) saying in the authentic Hadith: "Had I remained in prison as long as Yusuf, I would have answered the caller " means: I would have rushed out of prison without hesitation, and would have responded to the King's messenger immediately. In any case, the purpose of this Hadith, as I mentioned in the story of Ibrahim and Lot, is to show Yusuf's high rank, not to suggest that he is superior to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him). It is unanimously agreed upon by the sensible that the humility of a high-ranking person toward those below him does not diminish his status. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) is the best of all of Allah's creation, the chief of the Messengers, and the Imam of the Prophets. He is the one with the highest degrees (*Darajât*), referred to in Allah's saying: {Those messengers - We preferred some of them over others. Among them were those to whom Allah spoke, and He raised some of them many degrees} [Al-Baqarah: 253]. The Messenger of Allah, Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), is among the Messengers a heaven that no other heaven has surpassed. The King asked the women who had cut their hands: {What was your situation when you sought to seduce Joseph?} [Yusuf: 51]. They said: {Good Heavens! We know of no evil committed by him}. The Vizier's wife said: {Now the truth has become manifest (ḥaṣḥaṣa al-ḥaqq)! It was I who sought to seduce him, and indeed, he is of the truthful} [Yusuf: 51]. {That is so he may know that I did not betray him in [his] absence} (I acknowledge his virtue even in his absence), {and that Allah does not guide the plot of betrayers}. And the Vizier's wife also said: {And I do not acquit myself. Indeed, the soul is a persistent evil-doer, except those upon which my Lord has mercy. Indeed, my Lord is Forgiving and Merciful} [Yusuf: 53]. When the King was certain that Yusuf had been unjustly imprisoned, and that he was a man of noble trustworthiness and great knowledge, the King could not bear to wait. He said: {Bring him to me, I will select him for myself!} [Yusuf: 54]. When Yusuf came and spoke with him, the King said to him: {Indeed, you are today, with us, established [in position] and trusted} [Yusuf: 54]. Yusuf, desiring to benefit the land and the servants, said to the King: {He said, 'Appoint me over the storehouses of the land (khazâ'in al-arḍ). Indeed, I am a knowledgeable guardian'} [Yusuf: 55]. So Allah established (makkana) Yusuf in the land of Egypt, allowing him to settle wherever he willed, free, noble, a master, and obeyed, by the favor of Allah upon him and upon all doers of good. This is in this world, {But the reward of the Hereafter is better for those who believed and were constantly conscious of Allah} [Yusuf: 57]. Concerning this, Allah says: {And [subsequently] the king said, 'Indeed, I have seen [in a dream] seven fat cows being eaten by seven lean ones and seven green ears of grain and [seven] others dry. O council, advise me concerning my vision, if you should interpret visions.' They said, 'It is a mixture of false dreams, and we are not learned in the interpretation of [such] dreams.' But the one of the two [prisoners] who was saved and remembered after a period of time said, 'I will inform you of its interpretation, so send me [to him].' [He said], 'Joseph, O man of truth, explain to us about seven fat cows eaten by seven lean ones and seven green ears of grain and [seven] others dry, that I may return to the people, perhaps they may know [the meaning].' He said, 'You shall sow for seven years consecutively. And what you harvest, leave in its heads, except a little of which you will eat. Then will come after that seven hard [years] which will consume what you saved for them, except a little of that which you will store. Then will come after that a year in which the people will have relief and in which they will press [olives, etc.].' And [subsequently] the king said, 'Bring him to me!'} [Yusuf: 43-50]. ## The Stories of the Prophets: The True Narration When the messenger came to him (Joseph), he said: “Go back to your master and ask him what was the case of the women who cut their hands? Indeed, my Lord is Knowing of their plot.” Meaning that my God, my Creator, my Master, the Lord of the heavens and the earth, is fully aware of the cunning and plotting of women which led me to the prison. (The King) said: “What was your business when you solicited Joseph for his person?” They said: “God forbid! We know no evil against him.” The wife of Al-Aziz said: “Now the truth has come to light. It was I who sought to seduce him, and he is indeed one of the truthful.” (Joseph said): “This is so that he may know that I did not betray him in his absence, and that God does not guide the plot of betrayers.” “And I do not acquit myself. Indeed, the soul is a persistent inciter of evil, except that upon which my Lord has mercy. Indeed, my Lord is Forgiving and Merciful.” The King said: “Bring him to me; I will reserve him for myself.” And when he had spoken to him, he said: “Indeed, you are today, with us, established in position and trusted.” (Joseph) said: “Appoint me over the treasuries of the land. Indeed, I am a knowing guardian.” And thus, We established Joseph in the land to settle therein wherever he willed. We bestow Our mercy upon whom We will, and We do not allow to be lost the reward of the doers of good. And the reward of the Hereafter is better for those who believed and used to fear God. [Yusuf: 43-57] Some commentators have reported here false traditions and rejected, baseless reports in the exegesis of some of these verses. Allah the Most High protects His Prophets and Messengers from what is narrated in these exegeses, such as what was narrated concerning His saying “and she certainly desired him, and he would have desired her,” [Yusuf: 24] that he untied his waist-tie, meaning the drawstring of his trousers, and sat with her in the manner of a man with his wife. This, praise be to God, is not established by any report from the Messenger of Allah. Rather, it is an interpolated statement from the Jews and the narrations of the Children of Israel. The explicit wording of the verse connects his desire to seeing the evidence of his Lord in the past tense, as if to say: Had he not seen the proof of his Lord, he would have desired her, but he did not desire her because he saw the proof of his Lord. The context of the verse contradicts their claims, such as the Almighty's saying about her: “And she certainly sought to seduce him from himself, but he sought refuge.” [Yusuf: 32], connected by the letter 'fa' which denotes immediate succession, meaning that as soon as she sought to seduce him, he sought refuge. This is apparent. Likewise, their interpretation of His saying: “Indeed, he has made my residence excellent,” [Yusuf: 23] as meaning that he referred to the governor (Al-Aziz) of Egypt. This, praise be to God, is not established by any authentic or even *Hasan* report from the Messenger of Allah. The context indicates that the one whose proof Joseph saw and who made his residence excellent is the Lord of the Worlds. They also claimed that His saying: “This is so that he may know that I did not betray him in his absence,” [Yusuf: 52] was a statement of Joseph to Al-Aziz's wife, and that Gabriel said to him: “Nor when you desired her,” or that Al-Aziz's wife said to him at that time: “Nor when you untied your trousers, O Joseph.” All of this is a fabrication against Joseph the Truthful. Allah protected and preserved him from every evil, just as He protected his brothers, the Prophets and Messengers. “Exalted is your Lord, the Lord of Might, above what they describe. And peace upon the Messengers. And praise be to God, Lord of the Worlds.” [As-Saffat: 180-182] To the next chapter, God willing, and peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you. * ## The Stories of the Prophets: The True Narration ### Continuation of (the story of) Joseph the Truthful After Allah had established Joseph and the King had decided to make him his *Aziz* (Minister/Governor), granting him freedom to manage the treasuries of the land, people near and far needed to obtain provisions from him. The regions adjacent to Egypt, especially the land of Canaan, were then in dire need of food. So they came to Joseph to procure provisions for themselves, their families, and their people. They brought with them to Egypt whatever goods and money they had. Joseph had decided that he would not give any of them more than a specific measure of grain in one turn, and they could return at a later time in the future to take another share, according to the method known in the modern era and in some parts of the world as the rationing system. And the brothers of Joseph came to procure provisions when they learned that the *Aziz* of Egypt was giving people food for its price. They took with them goods to exchange for food. Jacob had kept his son Benjamin with him. When they reached Joseph and entered upon him, he recognized them because they were grown men when they threw him into the pit, so their appearances had not changed. As for Joseph, he was young when he was thrown into the pit, and a young person, when he grows up and reaches his full strength, is hardly recognized by someone who only saw him in childhood, because his features generally change. Therefore, his brothers did not recognize him, and it did not occur to them that he was Joseph the Truthful. It appeared that Joseph began to ask them about their situation and their families to find assurance regarding the state of his father and his brother Benjamin. They informed him of their situation and that they had a brother from their father, and that their father was Jacob, son of Isaac, son of Abraham. Joseph honored them and showed them concern, ordered their provisions to be prepared, and gave them their full measure. It was then as if he said to them: You have made me long for your brother from your father, and I am eager to see him. You will not obtain any measure from me in the future turns unless you bring me your brother from your father. And as a token of my increased honor for you then, I will add to your measure the load of a camel and double your provisions. He instructed his servants to secretly place all the merchandise they had brought into their saddlebags, as a gesture of kindness and to maintain their family ties, and to keep their wealth with them so they might return to Joseph out of need. He did not openly put their merchandise in their bags because that might have led them to refuse to take it. The brothers said to Joseph: “We will strive with all our effort to bring our brother from our father with us next time, and we will try to persuade his father with all our power, and we will not fail in that.” When they returned to their father, they told him their story with the *Aziz* of Egypt, and that he had decided not to give them any measure in the future unless they brought their brother Benjamin with them. They pleaded with him to send him with them so they could obtain provisions, and they promised to guard him most strictly. Jacob said: “How can I trust you with him except as I trusted you with his brother Joseph before? You claimed you would guard him when you said about Joseph: 'Send him with us tomorrow to enjoy himself and play, and indeed, we will be his guardians' [Yusuf: 12]. But Allah Most High is the Guardian for him, and He is the Best of Guardians, and He is the Most Merciful of the merciful.” And when they opened their baggage, they found their merchandise returned to them. They said: “O our father! What more could we desire? Here are our goods returned to us. Send our brother with us next time so we may get food for our family, and we will guard our brother, and we will gain the measure of a camel load.” That generous gift was easy for this noble *Aziz*. Jacob then decided to send Benjamin with them on the condition that they give him an oath and a solemn covenant by Allah that they would guard him and not fail in his protection unless they were overwhelmed by something they could not repel or overcome. When they swore to him and confirmed their covenant, Jacob made Allah Most High a witness to their covenant and said: “Allah is a Trustee over what we say.” [Yusuf: 66] When their journey for provisions was settled, Jacob advised them not to enter through one gate, but to enter through separate gates. This was either out of fear of the evil eye (envy) upon them if they were all together and known to be the sons of one man, or out of fear that they would all be surrounded if evil was intended for them. However, Jacob made it clear that caution does not avert the decree, and his concern for their safety would not benefit them if Allah had intended harm for them. The decree of Allah is executed, and the judgment of Allah is dominant. Allah alone is the Judge, and upon Him I rely and trust. It is incumbent upon every believer that his reliance and trust be upon Allah alone; there is no god but Him, and no Lord besides Him. The caravan set off and reached Egypt. And when they entered from where their father had commanded them, through the separate gates, even though what Jacob had said was true (that it would not avail them against the will of Allah), for Allah alone is the Protector. But Allah the Blessed and Most High benefited them with what He inspired in their father, and what God taught him. Thus, Jacob's advice to his sons was a rightful piece of advice, “but most of the people do not know.” [Yusuf: 68]. The evil eye is real, as Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated in their *Sahihs* on the authority of Abu Hurayrah, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: “The evil eye is a reality.” Similarly, Muslim narrated on the authority of Ibn Abbas that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: “The evil eye is a reality. And if there were anything that could precede the decree, it would be the evil eye.” Allah the Blessed and Most High mentioned the coming of Joseph's brothers and their entering upon him, and what happened concerning the measure and the hiding of the merchandise in their vessels and bags, the request for their half-brother, their return to their father, his urging regarding Benjamin until he agreed to send him with them, their father's advice to them upon their entry, the confirmation that the entire matter belongs to Allah, that caution does not avert the decree, and the indication that the evil eye is real, by saying: “And the brothers of Joseph came and entered upon him, and he recognized them, while to him they were unrecognizable. And when he had furnished them with their provisions, he said: 'Bring me a brother of yours from your father. Do you not see that I give full measure and that I am the best of hosts? But if you do not bring him to me, no measure will you have with me, nor will you approach me.' They said: 'We will try to obtain him from his father, and indeed, we will do it.' And he said to his servants: 'Put their merchandise into their bags, so they may recognize it when they go back to their people, that they may return.' So when they returned to their father, they said: 'O our father! [Further] measure has been withheld from us. So send with us our brother that we may obtain measure, and indeed, we will be his guardians.' He said: 'Should I entrust you with him except as I entrusted you with his brother before? But Allah is the Best of Guardians, and He is the Most Merciful of the merciful.' And when they opened their baggage, they found their merchandise returned to them. They said: 'O our father! What more could we desire? This is our merchandise returned to us. We will get food for our family and guard our brother and receive an extra measure of a camel's load. That is an easy quantity.' He said: 'I will never send him with you until you give me a solemn covenant by Allah that you will bring him [back] to me, unless you are surrounded [by death].' And when they had given their solemn covenant, he said: 'Allah is a Trustee over what we say.' And he said: 'O my sons! Do not enter from one gate but enter from separate gates. But I cannot avail you against [the decree of] Allah at all. The [final] decision is only for Allah. Upon Him I have relied, and upon Him let those who would rely [indeed] rely.' And when they entered from where their father had commanded them, it did not avail them against [the decree of] Allah at all except [it was] a need in the soul of Jacob, which he satisfied. And indeed, he was possessed of knowledge because of what We had taught him, but most of the people do not know.” [Yusuf: 58-68] Allah the Blessed and Most High indicated that when Joseph's brothers entered upon him with their brother Benjamin, and Joseph welcomed them in a way that relieved their hearts and reassured their souls, he whispered to Benjamin and said: “Indeed, I am your brother, Joseph, so do not grieve over what they used to do.” [Yusuf: 69]. He commanded him not to inform them that this *Aziz* was their brother. He conspired with him to devise a ruse to keep him with him, and made him understand that the reunion of all the loved ones was near, due to the plan Joseph had devised and managed so that all his family, headed by his father Jacob, would come to him. When he had furnished them with their provisions and given them their full measure, along with an extra camel load, he placed the drinking cup, which was the “King's measuring bowl,” in his brother Benjamin's bag, without any of his servants or others seeing it. When Joseph's young men missed the cup and it was widely rumored that it had been stolen, a caller cried out: “O people of the caravan! Indeed, you are thieves!” [Yusuf: 70]. The people of the caravan, including Joseph's brothers, were alarmed and approached them, saying: “What is it you are missing?” They said: “We are missing the King's measuring bowl.” [Yusuf: 72]. It was not Joseph who called out, nor did he order the caller. Rather, the person responsible for safeguarding his property was the one who called out or ordered the caller. Let no one say: “How could it be appropriate for Joseph, despite his high rank and honorable position of Prophethood and Messengership, to accuse people of theft when they were innocent?” Because Joseph's action was limited to placing the cup in his brother's bag, which is not blameworthy. As for the caller or the one who ordered the call, it was not Joseph. The people of the caravan said to the one who called out the loss of the cup: “By Allah, you certainly know that we did not come to cause corruption in the land, and we have not been thieves.” [Yusuf: 73]. Like us, with our need for you, do not cause corruption in your land or steal from it. The officials responsible for safeguarding the grain and goods said: “Then what is its recompense, if you should be proved to have lied in your claim that the cup is not with you, and the King's cup is found in the bag of one of you?” They said: “The recompense is that the one in whose bag it is found—he himself shall be its recompense. Thus do we recompense the wrongdoers.” [Yusuf: 75]. It was then that Joseph began the search and inspection of their bags before the bag of his brother and his own vessel. If he had started with his brother's bag, it might have occurred to them that it was a trick to take their brother. So, he delayed the inspection of his brother's bag to dispel this thought from them, and then he took it out of his brother's bag. This is what Allah the Most High means by: “Thus did We plan for Joseph.” [Yusuf: 76]. That is, We inspired Joseph's brothers to decree that the one who stole the cup should be taken in recompense, just as We inspired Joseph to hide the cup in his brother's bag. This plot by Joseph was a desirable stratagem that Allah loves and approves. But Allah elevates in degrees whom He wills among His servants, and “over every possessor of knowledge is one [more] knowing.” [Yusuf: 76]. To the next chapter, God willing, and peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you. * ## The Stories of the Prophets: The True Narration ### Continuation of (the story of) Joseph the Truthful I mentioned at the end of the previous chapter Joseph's stratagem to keep his brother Benjamin with him. Concerning this, Allah says: “So when they entered upon Joseph, he took his brother aside to himself, saying, 'Indeed, I am your brother, so do not grieve over what they used to do.' And when he had furnished them with their provisions, he put the measuring bowl into the bag of his brother. Then an announcer proclaimed, 'O caravan, indeed you are thieves.' They turned back and said, 'What is it you are missing?' They said, 'We are missing the King's measuring bowl, and for he who brings it is the load of a camel, and I guarantee it.' They said, 'By Allah, you certainly know that we did not come to cause corruption in the land, and we have not been thieves.' They said, 'Then what is its recompense, if you should be proved to have lied?' They said, 'Its recompense is that the one in whose bag it is found—he himself shall be its recompense. Thus do we recompense the wrongdoers.' So he began [the search] with their bags before the bag of his brother; then he extracted it from his brother's bag. Thus did We plan for Joseph. He could not have taken his brother under the law of the king except that Allah willed. We raise in degrees whom We will, but over every possessor of knowledge is one [more] knowing.” [Yusuf: 69-76] When Joseph's brothers saw that the measuring bowl was found in Benjamin's bag, they began to speak ill of him and Joseph, saying: “If he has stolen, a brother of his stole before.” [Yusuf: 77]. They intended to imply that Joseph had stolen their father's heart from them, or that out of their hatred for Joseph due to their father's love for him, they insulted and blamed him, not ceasing to abuse him. Therefore, Joseph said to himself, secretly from his brothers: “You are in a worse position, and Allah is most knowing of what you describe.” [Yusuf: 77]. They said: “O Aziz! Indeed, he has a father, a very old man, who cannot bear his absence. So take one of us in his place. Indeed, we see you as a doer of good.” Joseph said: “God forbid that we should take other than him with whom we found our property. Indeed, we would then be wrongdoers.” [Yusuf: 79]. Joseph had no need for any of them except Benjamin. When they despaired of freeing their brother Benjamin, whom they had obligated themselves and promised their father to return to him, they withdrew to confer among themselves about what to do. The eldest of them said: “Do you not know that your father has taken upon you an oath by Allah?” [Yusuf: 80] to bring him back, unless you are surrounded. “So I will not leave this land until my father permits me or Allah decides for me, and He is the best of judges.” [Yusuf: 80]. Meaning until Allah decrees a judgment for me, either by my death or by the release of my brother, and Allah is the Best of Judges. He then commanded them to inform their father of what had happened so that they would have an excuse, saying to him: “Your son was accused of theft and taken because of it. And we did not testify except to what we knew and what was manifest to everyone around us from the people of the caravan and the village. And we were not guardians of the unseen. And ask the caravan which we came with and the town in which we were. And indeed, we are truthful.” [Yusuf: 82]. So they arrived at their father and informed him of what their eldest brother had advised them. Jacob replied to them as he had replied to them when they came with the false blood on Joseph's shirt. He said to them: “Rather, your souls have enticed you to [do] something. So, patience is most fitting.” [Yusuf: 83]. He hoped that Allah would bring Joseph, Benjamin, and their eldest brother back to him, and said: “Perhaps Allah will bring them to me all together. Indeed, it is He who is the Knowing, the Wise.” [Yusuf: 83]. Jacob turned away from them and said: “Oh, my sorrow over Joseph!” [Yusuf: 84]. His grief intensified until his eyes turned white from sorrow, as the grief for the latter two renewed the grief for Joseph. However, he contained his anger and refrained from complaining to anyone but Allah. Nevertheless, his grief for Joseph stirred up their hidden resentment. They said: “By Allah, you will not cease remembering Joseph until you become fatally ill (on the verge of death and ruin) or become among the perishing.” He said: “I only complain of my suffering (my great sorrow and grief) and my grief to Allah, and I know from Allah that which you do not know,” [Yusuf: 86] (that Joseph is alive and may be in Egypt). “O my sons, go and find out about Joseph and his brother and do not despair of the relief (mercy) of Allah. Indeed, no one despairs of the relief of Allah except the disbelieving people.” [Yusuf: 87]. So they set out once more for Egypt in search of Joseph, and to complain of the distress that had afflicted them to the *Aziz* of Egypt and to ask for provisions. When they entered upon Joseph, they said: “O Aziz, adversity has touched us and our family, and we have brought an inferior (bad quality) amount of merchandise. So give us full measure and be charitable to us. Indeed, Allah rewards the charitable.” [Yusuf: 88] Joseph said to them: “Do you know what you did to Joseph and his brother when you were ignorant?” [Yusuf: 89]. When they heard him mention what they had done to Joseph, they scrutinized him, and it occurred to them that he was Joseph. They said: “Are you indeed Joseph?” [Yusuf: 90]. He said: “I am Joseph, and this is my brother. Allah has certainly favored us with honor and esteem. Indeed, he who fears [Allah] and is patient—then indeed, Allah does not allow to be lost the reward of the doers of good.” [Yusuf: 90]. They then showed remorse for what they had done and said: “By Allah, truly Allah has preferred you over us, and indeed, we were sinful (wrongdoers) in what we did.” He said: “No blame will there be upon you this day. May Allah forgive you; and He is the Most Merciful of the merciful.” [Yusuf: 92]. Having learned that his father's eyes had turned white from grief, he said to his brothers: “Take this shirt of mine and cast it over the face of my father; he will become visual. And bring me your whole family.” [Yusuf: 93]. This indicates that grief affects and harms the eye, and joy affects the eye with health and well-being. That is why Al-Khansa' said about herself concerning Sakhr: > *Is it a mote in your eyes, or is there a disease in the eye? Or did it shed tears when the home became empty of its people?* As soon as the caravan departed from the land of Egypt with Joseph's shirt, Jacob perceived the scent (smell) of Joseph. He said to those of his sons and grandchildren who were present: “Indeed, I find the scent of Joseph, though you might deem me a simpleton (foolish and in my old obsession).” [Yusuf: 94]. They said: “By Allah, indeed you are in your old delusion (passion)!” [Yusuf: 95]. But when the bearer of good tidings arrived and cast it over his face, he returned [to his sight] as clear. He said: “Did I not tell you that I know from Allah that which you do not know?” [Yusuf: 96]. They said: “O our father, ask forgiveness for us for our sins. Indeed, we were sinners.” [Yusuf: 97]. He said: “I will ask forgiveness for you from my Lord. Indeed, it is He who is the Forgiving, the Merciful.” [Yusuf: 98]. Then they all set out for Egypt. Allah reunited their family. When they entered upon Joseph, he took his parents to himself (his father and his aunt, or his father and his mother, according to the opinion that she was alive until that time), and said: “Enter Egypt, if Allah wills, safely.” [Yusuf: 99]. He raised his parents upon the throne, and they all fell down prostrate before him in gratitude to Allah for His grace and for the honor He had bestowed upon Joseph. Joseph said to his father: “O my father, this is the interpretation of my vision of old. My Lord has made it reality. And He was certainly good to me when He took me out of prison and brought you from the desert after Satan had caused discord between me and my brothers. Indeed, my Lord is Subtle in what He wills. Indeed, it is He who is the Knowing, the Wise.” [Yusuf: 100]. He also said, when the favor upon Joseph was complete and Allah had given him sovereignty, and he was asking Allah to join him with the righteous: “My Lord, You have given me [a share] of sovereignty and taught me the interpretation of dreams. Creator of the heavens and the earth, You are my Protector in this world and in the Hereafter. Cause me to die in submission [to You] and join me with the righteous.” [Yusuf: 101]. “That is from the news of the unseen (Al-Ghayb) which We reveal to you, [O Muhammad]. And you were not with them when they put together their plan while they conspired.” [Yusuf: 102] To the next chapter, God willing, and peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you.
source: Holy Quran (Surah Yusuf primarily), Prophetic Sunnah, and Exegeses of Ahlus Sunnah Wal Jama'ah.
