texte_original: We speak of Noah (peace be upon him), one of the Ulu’l-Azm (resolute) messengers, and the first prophet to warn against polytheism and the worship of other than Allah. His nation was the first nation to engage in polytheism on Earth. Some may call Noah “the second Adam,” because, as God Almighty said, all those remaining on Earth are from his progeny: "And We made his offspring the survivors." [As-Saffat: 77] People have differed regarding the period between Adam and Noah (peace be upon them). According to the People of the Book, Noah was born a hundred and six years after Adam’s death. Ibn Jarir mentioned that Noah was born 126 years after Adam’s death, and they listed eight forefathers in his lineage back to Adam. All these narrations regarding the period between Adam and Noah, as well as his lineage, are unsupported and speculative. It is authentically reported in Sahih al-Bukhari from Ibn Abbas that: there were ten generations between Adam and Noah, all of them practicing Islam. If by “generation” a century is meant, then the period between Adam and Noah was about a thousand years. If “generation” refers to a people’s era, then it spans thousands of years, since people before Noah lived very long lives. The exact duration is known only to Allah. Ibn Abbas clarified that humanity went through ten generations following Adam, all worshiping Allah alone, without associating partners with Him, until Satan introduced polytheism and led them to various forms of worship of other than Allah. They worshiped idols, and to these polytheists, God sent Noah. Al-Bukhari narrated from Ibn Abbas in interpreting the verse: "And they said, 'We will not forsake our gods, nor will we abandon Wadd, nor Suwa’, nor Yaghuth, nor Ya’uq, nor Nasr.'" [Noah: 23] Ibn Abbas explained: these were names of righteous men from Noah’s people. When they died, Satan inspired their people to erect statues at the places where they used to sit and name the statues after them. They followed this until they themselves perished, after which the idols were worshiped. The five idols mentioned in this verse do not indicate that these were the only ones worshiped; Noah’s people worshiped many other idols. God indicated this in His words: "Nor will we forsake Wadd, nor Suwa’, nor Yaghuth, nor Ya’uq, nor Nasr." [Noah: 23] Amr ibn Lahi al-Khuza’i transported these idols to the Arabian Peninsula, keeping the names of Noah’s people’s idols, and called for their worship. For example, Banu ‘Adrah took Wadd and placed it in Dumat al-Jandal until Islam arrived and Khalid ibn al-Walid destroyed it. Similarly, Mudar ibn Nizar took Suwa’ and placed it in Batn Nakhlah, where Hudhail worshiped it until Islam came and destroyed it. Madh’hij took Yaghuth and set it on a hill in their land, until Islam came. Hamdan took Ya’uq and set it in a village called Khaywan, worshiped until Islam destroyed it. Himyar took Nasr and placed it in a location in Saba’, where it was worshiped until Islam arrived. God Almighty narrated Noah’s story in various chapters of the Qur’an: in Surah Al-A’raf, Yunus, Hud, Al-Anbiya, Al-Mu’minun, Ash-Shu’ara, Al-Ankabut, As-Saffat, and in the complete Surah of Noah. Noah is also mentioned among the messengers throughout the Qur’an. There is no doubt that he is one of the Ulu’l-Azm prophets. One of the main benefits of the stories of the prophets is to learn lessons and emulate them, and avoid what they warned against. God extended Noah’s story in two places in the Qur’an: in Surah Hud and Surah Noah. Studying the language and expressions of this story reveals unique and powerful methods of calling to Allah, guiding people, and exposing the opposition of the disbelievers and enemies of God. God began Noah’s story in Surah Hud with: "And indeed We sent Noah to his people, [saying], 'Indeed, I am to you a clear warner.'" [Hud: 25] This teaches that Muhammad (peace be upon him) is not a new messenger, nor the first warner; he followed the same path as the prophets before him. God highlighted this in Surah Hud regarding Hud: "And remember ‘Aad, when He warned their people in the Ahqaf, but the warners before them and after them said, 'Do not worship except Allah. Indeed, I fear for you the punishment of a tremendous Day.'" [Al-Ahqaf: 21] The sending of messengers is part of human nature, passed down through generations, so that people know that Allah sends messengers to guide His servants to happiness in this world and the next, and to prevent people from claiming, “No bringer of good tidings or warner has come to us.” After mentioning that Noah was a messenger, the Qur’an emphasizes the main mission of all messengers: calling people to the exclusive worship of Allah. "And indeed We sent Noah to his people, [saying], 'Indeed, I am to you a clear warner, that you not worship except Allah.'" [Hud: 25–26] This is the approach of all prophets: to call their people to monotheism, since worshiping Allah alone is the purpose for which He created the heavens and the earth, humans and jinn: "And I did not create the jinn and mankind except to worship Me. I do not want from them any provision, nor do I want them to feed Me. Indeed, Allah is the [one] Provider, the Possessor of Strength, the Firm." [Ad-Dhariyat: 56–58] After Noah called his people to worship Allah alone and warned them of the punishment in the Hereafter, the arrogant leaders of the earth presented three objections to divert people from his call. God refuted their arguments and exposed their falsehood, revealing the fate of the deniers. "And indeed We sent Noah to his people, [saying], 'Indeed, I am to you a clear warner that you not worship except Allah. Indeed, I fear for you the punishment of a painful day.'" The leaders of his people said: "We do not see you except as a man like us, and we do not see anyone following you except the weakest among us." [Hud: 27] These objections reflect arrogance, as the elite opposed Noah to protect their social positions from the new religion. Their objections were: Noah is only human. His followers are poor, and poverty is equated with weakness and ignorance. Noah and his followers have no physical or social superiority over others. God addressed such objections in multiple places in the Qur’an, emphasizing that messengers being human is not a weakness, because it allows them to communicate in the language of their people. If angels had been sent instead, people could not interact and benefit as they do with a human messenger. "And if there were angels walking on the earth, We would have sent down to them an angel." [Al-Isra’: 94–95] Even Gabriel came to the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) sometimes in human form so that people could interact naturally. Another objection of Noah’s people was that his followers were poor. The Qur’an emphasizes that wealth is not a measure of intellect or righteousness, and poverty does not equate to weakness of judgment: "And We see that you are followed only by those who are lowly and poor." [Hud: 27] Allah demonstrates that He provides wealth and knowledge according to His will. The companions of prophets were often among the poor, as confirmed in authentic hadiths, showing that true support of the messenger comes from piety, not wealth or social rank. The Qur’an recounts examples of the elite and leaders of Quraysh in the time of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), who rejected him and were arrogant, contrasting them with the believers, often from humble backgrounds, who were saved and rewarded. God Almighty has explained that the arrogant among Noah’s people opposed his message, as the powerful always begin by opposing the prophets, not because they reject the truth per se, but because they fear losing their positions and influence. Hence, it is said: “The eminent among those who disbelieved from his people said, ‘We do not see you except as a man like ourselves…’” [Hud: 27] The “eminent” here refers to the leaders and nobles of the people. It is remarkable that they denied his prophethood simply because he was human. This objection is the same that the enemies of all messengers have raised throughout history: whenever a messenger comes, people deny him on the grounds that he is only human. They fail to recognize that sending a human messenger is one of God’s greatest favors, because he speaks their language, understands their circumstances, and can guide them directly. Had God sent an angel instead, people would not have been able to interact with him in the same way. This is why God says in the Qur’an: “And what prevented the people from believing when guidance came to them except that they said, ‘Has Allah sent a human messenger?’” [Al-Isra: 94] If God had sent a messenger in the form of an angel, people could not have benefited from him, as humans are not prepared to accompany angels in worldly life. Likewise, Gabriel sometimes came to the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) in human form, such as the form of Dihya al-Kalbi or a man from the Bedouins, so people would not recognize him. The Prophet would inform them of his identity only after the revelation ended. It is narrated in Sahih Bukhari and Sahih Muslim from Umar ibn al-Khattab that Gabriel once came in a very white robe with very black hair, without any sign of travel. He asked the Prophet about Islam, faith, and Ihsan, and the Prophet answered. After the dialogue, Gabriel revealed his identity. This shows that messengers are specially prepared for interaction with angels, which ordinary humans could not handle. Similarly, in the Hereafter, only believers are ready to accompany angels. The angels who punish the disbelievers in Hell are strict and do not disobey God. When revelation descended upon the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), he would sweat even in cold weather due to the intensity of the experience, as Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) described. His neck would sweat like molten pearls, showing the immense burden of receiving divine revelation, for which God had prepared him. The second objection of the disbelievers of Noah’s people was that his followers were the poor. God mentions in the Qur’an: “And we do not see you followed except by the least among us…” [Hud: 27] This is a strange objection, based on the assumption that wealth indicates wisdom or intelligence. Yet there is no necessary link between wealth and intellect, knowledge, or piety; all provisions are granted by God to whomever He wills. Indeed, it is mentioned that the followers of the prophets are often among the poor, as in the example of the companions of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him): Suhaib, Ammar, Bilal, Jamil ibn Asraqa, and Khabbab. They were raised in status after faith and admitted to Paradise, while the leaders and nobles who disbelieved were condemned to Hell. God also mentions that the Qur’an was not revealed to a wealthy man from the tribes of Mecca or Ta’if, but to a man of average social standing, Muhammad (peace be upon him). The Qur’an rebukes those who preferred wealth and status over divine guidance: “Do they swear by the mercy of your Lord? We have apportioned their livelihood in this life and raised some above others in ranks that they may compete therein…” [Az-Zukhruf: 31] Thus, God clarifies the corrupt thinking of the disbelievers, emphasizing that His mercy is better than all worldly possessions. Noah’s people also rejected his message because of their arrogance and pride. They said: “We do not believe in you” [Hud: 27] Arrogance has always been the root cause of denial. People refuse guidance when it threatens their pride, power, or comfort. In the case of Noah’s people, they had built a society based on wealth, status, and oppression, so accepting Noah’s message of monotheism and justice would have overturned their social order. God responded to their rejection by warning them of His punishment. The Qur’an describes the events leading to the Flood: “So We sent upon them a flood of water, and We saved Noah and those with him in the ark, and We drowned the others…” [Al-Ankabut: 14] This illustrates God’s justice: those who deny His signs and continue in arrogance are punished, while the believers are protected. The story of Noah also teaches patience and steadfastness in the face of opposition. Noah preached for centuries, yet only a few followed him. His perseverance became a model for all prophets and believers. Furthermore, the story highlights the importance of taking action in accordance with divine guidance. Noah did not wait for all people to believe; he built the ark and prepared for the flood as God commanded. This shows that faith must be coupled with effort and preparation. God’s message through Noah also emphasizes the universal principle of accountability. Each person is responsible for their choices, and no one can bear the sins of another. Even the closest family members cannot save someone from divine judgment if they persist in disbelief. Finally, the story concludes with a reminder of mercy: even after the flood, God allowed humanity to continue through Noah’s family, showing that His punishment is measured and His mercy abundant. The cycle of warning, punishment, and mercy is repeated throughout the Qur’an to guide humanity

texte_original: In this chapter, we speak about Jacob, the Prophet of Allah, son of Isaac. In the previous chapter, it was mentioned that Allah, exalted be He, gave the glad tidings to His Prophet (peace be upon them). It was previously indicated in the Qur’an that Sarah was given the glad tidings of Isaac, and through Isaac came Jacob. Allah, in the narration, indicated that Jacob is the son of Isaac, as also confirmed by the Prophet, which is narrated in Al-Bukhari. Jacob is Israel, and all the tribes belong to him. The meaning of Israel in Hebrew is “the servant of God,” combining the words “Isra” (servant) and “El” (God). In many languages, this name exists, but the Arabs adapted it to classical Arabic as “Isma‘il” or “Isma‘ain,” by changing the “l” to “n,” as they did in other stories. Regarding the story of Jacob and his children, many accounts are mentioned in the Qur’an. Allah, exalted be He, spoke of his wife and the fact that Jacob married more than one wife. He spoke about Joseph, whom his brothers from the same father envied because Jacob had a strong affection for him. Joseph had a full brother, as indicated in the Qur’an: "From your father, Joseph." [Yusuf: 59] Jacob was very attached to Joseph and could hardly bear being away from him. Satan fueled the jealousy of Joseph’s brothers, and they plotted against him, intending either to kill him or to throw him into a distant place away from their father, so that they could have their father’s attention for themselves. They decided not to kill him but to throw him into a deep well so that passing travelers could take him to a distant land, claiming to their father that a wolf had devoured him: "Why would you not guard Joseph? Send him with us tomorrow; we will surely protect him." [Yusuf: 11-12] Jacob’s attachment to Joseph was evident; he feared for him from the wolf: "Indeed, it grieves me that you should take him, and I fear that the wolf will eat him while you are heedless of him." [Yusuf: 13-18] The Qur’an also mentions the story of Joseph’s brothers arriving in Egypt, not recognizing him, and Joseph asking them to bring their youngest brother from their father: "Send with us our brother so that we may protect him; indeed, we will be his guardians." [Yusuf: 63-64] Jacob replied: "I will not send him with you until you give me a promise in the name of Allah that you will be responsible for him." When they gave him their promise, he said: "Allah is sufficient as a guardian over what you say." And Allah instructed: "Do not enter by one gate, but enter through separate gates. Nothing will avail you from Allah except that which He wills. Upon Him, I rely, and upon Him let the reliant rely." [Yusuf: 66-68] When they entered as their father instructed, it did not benefit them except as part of a destined plan by Allah, which they did not perceive. Joseph, upon seeing his brothers, revealed himself: "I am your brother, so do not grieve over what they were doing." [Yusuf: 69] Joseph placed a drinking vessel in his brother’s bag as a pretext to detain him, and his brothers tried to substitute another brother in his place, but Joseph refused: "Do you not know that your father has taken a promise from Allah? Take one of us in his place; indeed, we are righteous." [Yusuf: 78] When they despaired of deceiving him, Joseph was freed. The eldest said: "Did you not know that your father has taken a promise from Allah and that previously you tried to wrong Joseph?" Jacob’s sons then returned to their father and said: "O our father, your son has stolen. We only testify to what we know, and we were not aware of the unseen. We bring back the caravan and the town as we found them; indeed, we speak the truth." [Yusuf: 80-82] Jacob said: "It was your own selves who planned this. So patience is beautiful; perhaps Allah will bring them all back to me. He is the Knowing, the Wise." He turned away from them, grieving for Joseph, and his eyes turned white from sorrow, holding deep sadness in his heart: "By Allah, you will keep mentioning Joseph until you become weary," said his sons. [Yusuf: 85] Jacob said: "I only complain of my sorrow and grief to Allah, and I know from Him that which you do not know. My sons, go and inquire about Joseph and his brother, and do not despair of Allah’s mercy; only the disbelieving despair of Allah’s mercy." [Yusuf: 86-87] When they entered to Joseph and explained the grief that had befallen their father over the separation from his son, Joseph revealed himself to them and instructed them to bring his shirt to place over his father’s face to remove his grief and restore his sight. He also instructed them to bring all their family. When the curtain was removed, Jacob said to his sons: "Indeed, I perceive the springtime of Joseph." When the bearer of good news brought Joseph’s shirt to his father, his sight was restored, and he said to his sons: "Did I not tell you that I know from Allah what you do not know?" They said: "O our father, ask forgiveness for us. Indeed, we have been sinners." He said: "I will ask forgiveness for you from my Lord; He is indeed the Forgiving, the Merciful." When they entered to Joseph, he embraced his father and his uncle (the mother of his siblings on his father’s side) or other close relatives, placing them in safety: "Enter Egypt in safety. We raised your parents on the throne, and they fell down in prostration." [Yusuf: 99-100] They prostrated to Allah in gratitude. Joseph said: "This is the interpretation of my two dreams from before; my Lord has made it true, and He has done well by me when He brought you to me after Satan sowed discord between me and my brothers. Indeed, my Lord is Subtle in what He wills; He is the Knowing, the Wise." [Yusuf: 101

texte_original: In this chapter, we talk about Ṣāliḥ, the prophet and messenger of Allah. He was the second Arab messenger after Hūd, may peace and blessings be upon them. Allah sent him to the Arabian Peninsula, specifically to his people, Thamūd. Scholars of genealogy have mentioned that he was Ṣāliḥ ibn ʿUbaid ibn Asīf ibn Māshikh or Māsiḥ ibn ʿUbaid ibn Ḥājir, or Ḥādir ibn Thamūd ibn ʿĀbir, or ʿĀthir ibn Iram ibn Sām ibn Nūḥ. His people lived in the region of Al-Ḥijr, known as Diyar Thamūd or Madā’in Ṣāliḥ, located about 380–400 km northwest of Medina. In the south of this region is today the city of Al-ʿUlā. Some of its wells still exist, notably the famous “Well of the She-Camel.” The remains of Thamūd, including houses and graves, are still present, especially the houses they carved into the mountains. The Thamūd lived peacefully in expansive, shaded gardens with abundant water sources, crops, and palm trees with plentiful dates. They built palaces in the plains and carved houses from the mountains with remarkable skill, craftsmanship, and decoration. Allah had provided them with the means for a prosperous life. They were one of the nations that came after the people of Hūd and were aware of their history, as well as the punishment Allah had inflicted on those who disbelieved and worshiped idols. However, despite the blessings, the Thamūd rejected Allah’s signs and denied His favors. So Allah sent to them a messenger from among themselves: Ṣāliḥ, peace be upon him. He called them to worship Allah alone, to recognize His oneness, acknowledge His Lordship, and affirm His perfect names and attributes. He reminded them of Allah’s favors and warned them of His punishment, indicating that persisting in shirk (associating partners with Allah) and denying blessings could bring upon them the same fate as the people of Hūd. The weak among them believed and turned to Allah, while the arrogant refused to submit and said: "Ṣāliḥ was among us a trustworthy man before this. Did he not forbid us from worshiping what our ancestors worshiped? And we are in doubt about what you call us to?" [Hūd: 62] They asked for a miracle. Allah produced a camel from the rock. Ṣāliḥ said to them: "This is Allah’s camel for you, a sign. Let it graze on Allah’s land and do not harm it, or a severe punishment will strike you soon." [Hūd: 64] One of the miracles of this camel was that it drank nearly all the water. Ṣāliḥ divided the water between the people and the camel: on some days, the camel drank alone, and on others, the people drank while the camel did not. Although this miracle was a clear proof of Ṣāliḥ’s truthfulness, the arrogant persisted in their rebellion and disbelief. They tried to prevent the believers from following Ṣāliḥ and spread doubts about his message. Allah withheld rain as a warning. The arrogant said: "Ṣāliḥ is the reason for the drought in our land, and his presence brings misfortune. Following the believers with him destroys the blessings of our land and water." Ṣāliḥ replied: "Your fate is with Allah." [An-Naml: 47] Allah’s messengers bring goodness and prosperity, guiding people to repentance and divine mercy. Allah says: "If you do not seek forgiveness from Allah, perhaps you will be shown mercy." [An-Naml: 46] But they did not respond, and they said to the believers: "Do you know that Ṣāliḥ is sent by his Lord?" [Al-Aʿrāf: 75] The arrogant replied: "We do not believe in what you believe." [Al-Aʿrāf: 76] They plotted to kill Ṣāliḥ and attacked the camel. Nine of them persisted in killing the camel and planned to murder Ṣāliḥ. Allah struck them with a violent cry and an earthquake, destroying them entirely, while Ṣāliḥ and the believers were saved by Allah’s mercy. The Qur’an states: "They plotted, but We planned against them, and their entire people was destroyed." [An-Naml: 50–51] "When Our command came, We saved Ṣāliḥ and those who believed with him by Our mercy. On the day of punishment, your Lord is mighty and invincible. The wrongdoers were seized in their homes." [Hūd: 66–68] They killed the camel and defied their Lord’s command. Allah struck them with a single scream, annihilating them in their houses, leaving only ruins behind. The Qur’an notes that Thamūd and Hūd are not mentioned in any Jewish or Christian scriptures, indicating an attempt to erase all memory of prophethood among the Arab people out of jealousy and aversion. The Qur’an also shows that the prophet Moses, peace be upon him, warned his people so that they would not suffer the same fate as the peoples of Hūd and Ṣāliḥ. In Surah Ibrāhīm: "And Moses said: If you and all those on earth disbelieve, Allah is Rich and Praiseworthy. Did the news of those who came before you not reach you: the people of Nūḥ, ʿĀd, and Thamūd…?" [Ibrāhīm: 10] Allah mentions Ṣāliḥ’s story in several parts of the Qur’an, each time suited to the context, often in connection with other prophets and messengers. In Surah Al-Aʿrāf: "And to Thamūd, their brother Ṣāliḥ said: O my people, worship Allah. Here is Allah’s camel for you, a sign. Let it graze on the land and do not harm it. Remember how Allah established you on earth and facilitated your prosperity, and do not cause corruption. The arrogant among them said: We do not believe in what the weak among them believe. They killed the camel and disobeyed their Lord’s command. Then the earthquake seized them, and they were destroyed in their homes." [Al-Aʿrāf: 73–79] In Surah Hūd: "And to Thamūd, their brother Ṣāliḥ said: O my people, worship Allah, who has made you prosperous on earth and facilitated your life. Repent and seek forgiveness from your Lord. But they said: Ṣāliḥ was among us a trustworthy man before this. We are in doubt about what you call us to." [Hūd: 61] Allah’s camel was a clear miracle. They killed it and faced a severe punishment. Allah saved Ṣāliḥ and the believers. The arrogant were annihilated, while the believers were protected. Surahs Al-Ḥijr, Al-Isrā’, Ash-Shu‘arā’, An-Naml, and Fuṣṣilat confirm this story, emphasizing the punishment of Thamūd, the truthfulness of Ṣāliḥ, and Allah’s power and mercy.

bio_naissance_annee: Approximately 2000 years before Christ. Born in the region of Babylon (modern-day Iraq) among a people who worshipped idols and celestial bodies.
bio_lieu_naissance: Babylon, then migrated to the Levant (Palestine) and Egypt, before settling in Mecca and building the Kaaba there.
bio_descendance: Father of the Prophets. His prophetic lineage passes through his sons Isma'il (from whom Muhammad descended) and Ishaq (from whom Jacob and the tribes of Israel descended).
texte_original: In this chapter, we speak to you about the Imam of the Monotheists (Hounafa), the Father of the Prophets, and the Intimate Friend of the Most Merciful (Khalil Al-Rahman), the one who most closely resembled Muhammad in his physical and moral nature, one of the great masters among the Messengers of Strong Will (Ulu Al-'Azm), the Nation (Ummah), the Devout (Qanit), the Monotheist (Hanif), the Suppliant (Awwah), the Forbearing (Halim): Ibrahim (Abraham). His father Azar was from the progeny of Sam, son of Noah. Ibrahim was born in the land of Babylon, known as the land of the Chaldeans. His father and his people worshipped idols and statues, prostrated to the seven planets (stars), and erected temples for them. So, Allah sent to them the Imam of the Monotheists, Ibrahim. He called them to the obligation of sincerely devoting worship to Allah alone, and in his call, he adopted methods of guidance that established the proof and removed any doubt. Allah, Blessed and Exalted is He, presented images of Ibrahim's methods of calling in his dialogue with his people, guiding them to Allah, Blessed and Exalted is He. Regarding this, He says: « And (mention) when Abraham said to Azar, his father, "Do you take idols as deities? Indeed, I see you and your people to be in manifest error. " And thus did We show Abraham the kingdom of the heavens and the earth, that he might be of those with certainty. » [Al-An'am: 74-75] (Meaning: We showed him the way to deduce from Allah's cosmic signs in the heavens and the earth that there is no deity except Allah) « that he might be of those with certainty. » « So when the night covered him [with darkness], he saw a star. He said, "This is my Lord. " » (Meaning: Is this fit to be a Lord to be worshipped?) « But when it set, he said, "I like not those that disappear. " » [Al-An'am: 76] This is a wise method for shaking the foundations of their falsehood. « And when he saw the moon rising (Bâzighan), he said, "This is my Lord. " » (Meaning: Is this fit to be a Lord to be worshipped?) « But when it set, he said, "Unless my Lord guides me, I will surely be among the misguided people. " » [Al-An'am: 77] By this saying, he intended to gradually lead his people and inform them of their ignorance and their error in venerating and worshipping these setting heavenly bodies, and that the destiny of creation is in the Hand of Allah alone, so whoever Allah does not guide has no guide. « And when he saw the sun rising, he said, "This is my Lord; this is greater. " But when it set, he said, "O my people, indeed I am free from what you associate with Allah. Indeed, I have turned my face toward Him who created (Fatara) the heavens and the earth, inclining toward truth (Hanîf) » [Al-An'am: 78-79] (Meaning: inclining towards the upright religion) « and I am not of the polytheists. " » [Al-An'am: 79] The omission of the interrogative particle in a phrase like: "This is my Lord? " is permissible and common in the (Arabic) language, and it is an interrogation of denial and reproach to his people, the star worshippers. The omission of the interrogative particle has occurred in various places in the Noble Qur'an, including His saying (Exalted is He): « If you die, will they live forever? » [Al-Anbiya: 34] (Meaning: Will they live forever?) The Great Qur'an also points to his people's reaction to this conclusive argument: when they were defeated (by argument), they resorted to intimidating him with the wrath of their deities. Regarding this, Allah says: « And his people argued with him. He said, "Do you argue with me concerning Allah while He has guided me? And I fear not what you associate with Him unless my Lord should will something. My Lord encompasses all things in knowledge; will you not then remember? And how should I fear what you have associated while you do not fear that you have associated with Allah that for which He has not sent down to you any authority? So which of the two parties is more deserving of [feeling] secure, if you should know? " » [Al-An'am: 80-81] « They who believe and do not mix their belief with injustice - those will have [security] and they are [rightly] guided. » [Al-An'am: 82] « And that was Our [conclusive] argument which We gave Abraham against his people. We raise in degrees whom We will. Indeed, your Lord is Wise and Knowing. » [Al-An'am: 83] Allah (Praise be to Him) mentions another instance of Ibrahim's explanation that Allah alone is worthy of worship and that their other deities neither hear nor benefit nor harm. He says: « And recite to them the news of Abraham. When he said to his father and his people, "What do you worship? " » [Ash-Shu'ara: 69-70] He asked them about their deities in order to build on their answer that these gods do not deserve any worship, thereby cutting off their misconception. « They said, "We worship idols and remain devoted to them. " He said, "Do they hear you when you supplicate? Or do they benefit or harm you? " They said, "But we found our fathers doing so. " He said, "Then do you see what you have been worshipping, you and your ancient fathers? Indeed, they are enemies to me, except the Lord of the worlds, who created me, and He [it is who] guides me. And it is He who feeds me and gives me drink. And when I am ill, it is He who cures me. And He who will cause me to die and then will bring me to life. And [it is] He for whom I aspire that He will forgive me my sin on the Day of Recompense. " » [Ash-Shu'ara: 71-82] « My Lord, grant me authority (Hukm) and join me with the righteous. And grant me a reputation of truth (a tongue of truth) among later generations. And make me one of the inheritors of the Garden of Pleasure. And forgive my father, for indeed, he has been of those astray. » [Ash-Shu'ara: 83-86] This was due to a promise Ibrahim made, from which he understood that his father was close to faith. But when it became clear to him that he was an enemy of Allah, he disassociated from him, as Allah (Exalted is He) said: « And the supplication of Abraham for his father for forgiveness was only because of a promise he had made to him. But when it became clear to him that his father was an enemy to Allah, he disassociated himself from him. Indeed, Abraham was one who was ever supplicating (Awwâh) and forbearing (Halîm). » [At-Tawbah: 114] Then Ibrahim continued his supplication to Allah and extended his call to his people, saying: « And disgrace me not on the Day they are resurrected - The Day when neither wealth nor sons will benefit - Except one who brings to Allah a sound heart. » [Ash-Shu'ara: 87-89] In a bright picture of how Ibrahim's call was presented and his position towards his people after his wife Sarah and Lot believed in him, Allah says: « There has already been for you an excellent pattern in Abraham and those with him, when they said to their people, "Indeed, we are disassociated from you and from whatever you worship other than Allah. We have denied you, and there has appeared between us and you animosity and hatred forever until you believe in Allah alone " » [Al-Mumtahanah: 4] (Meaning: So do not seek forgiveness for the polytheists, even if they are your close relatives) « - except for the saying of Abraham to his father, "I will surely ask forgiveness for you " » « but I possess not for you [the power to obtain] from Allah a thing. Our Lord, upon You we have relied, and to You we have returned, and to You is the destination. Our Lord, make us not a trial for those who have disbelieved, and forgive us, our Lord. Indeed, You are the Exalted in Might, the Wise. There has certainly been for you in them a good example for whoever would hope for Allah and the Last Day. And whoever turns away - then indeed, Allah is the Free of Need, the Praiseworthy. » [Al-Mumtahanah: 4-6] Allah, Blessed and Exalted is He, describes a radiant instance of Ibrahim's interactions with his father Azar, saying: « And mention in the Book [the story of] Abraham. Indeed, he was a man of truth and a prophet. [Mention] when he said to his father, "O my father, why do you worship that which neither hears nor sees nor avails you in anything? O my father, indeed there has come to me of knowledge that which has not come to you, so follow me; I will guide you to a straight path. O my father, do not worship Satan. Indeed, Satan has ever been, to the Most Merciful, disobedient. O my father, indeed I fear that there will touch you a punishment from the Most Merciful so you would become to Satan a companion [in Hell]. " [The father] said, "Are you turning away from my gods, O Abraham? If you do not desist, I will surely stone you, so leave me for a prolonged time. " [Abraham] said, "Peace be upon you. I will ask forgiveness for you of my Lord. Indeed, He has ever been to me gracious (Hafiyya - very kind to me, great in kindness). And I will leave you and that which you invoke other than Allah and will supplicate my Lord. It may be that I will not be deprived in [my] supplication to my Lord. " » [Maryam: 41-48] In another instance of Ibrahim's interactions with his father and his people, Allah says: « And We had certainly given Abraham his sound judgment before, and We were of him all-knowing. [Mention] when he said to his father and his people, "What are these statues to which you are devoted? " They said, "We found our fathers worshippers of them. " He said, "You have certainly been, you and your fathers, in manifest error. " They said, "Have you brought us the truth, or are you one of those who jest? " He said, "[No], rather, your Lord is the Lord of the heavens and the earth, who created them, and I, to that, am of those who testify. And [I swear] by Allah, I will surely plan against your idols after you have turned and gone away. " » [Al-Anbiya: 51-58] « So he made them into fragments, except a large one among them, that they might return to it [for inquiry]. They said, "Who has done this to our gods? Indeed, he is among the wrongdoers. " They said, "We heard a young man mention them [with contempt] (meaning: criticize them and curse them) who is called Abraham. " They said, "Then bring him before the eyes of the people that they may testify. " » [Al-Anbiya: 59-61] « They said, "Have you done this to our gods, O Abraham? " He said, "Rather, this - the largest of them - did it. So ask them, if they should [be able to] speak. " So they returned to [blaming] themselves and said, "Indeed, you yourselves are the wrongdoers. " Then they made him fall back on their heads [and said], "You certainly know that these do not speak! " He said, "Do you then worship instead of Allah that which does not benefit you at all or harm you? Uff to you and to what you worship instead of Allah! Then will you not use reason? " » [Al-Anbiya: 62-67] « They said, "Burn him and support your gods, if you are to act. " We said, "O fire, be coolness and safety upon Abraham! " And they intended for him a plot, but We made them the greatest losers. » [Al-Anbiya: 68-70] Allah recounts the story of the king of the Chaldeans in his interrogation of Ibrahim about his Lord. Ibrahim said: « My Lord is the one who gives life and causes death. » The king then presumed to say: "I give life and cause death. " Ibrahim then silenced him by saying: « Indeed, Allah brings up the sun from the east, so bring it up from the west. » This disbeliever was bewildered. Regarding this, Allah says: « Have you not considered the one who argued with Abraham concerning his Lord [merely] because Allah had given him kingship? When Abraham said, "My Lord is the one who gives life and causes death, " he said, "I give life and cause death. " Abraham said, "Then indeed, Allah brings up the sun from the east, so bring it up from the west. " So the disbeliever was overcome by astonishment. And Allah does not guide the wrongdoing people. » [Al-Baqarah: 258] Some commentators have mentioned that this debate between Ibrahim and the king took place when Ibrahim came asking him for food, and the king refused to give it to him. Ibrahim's sorrow intensified as he approached his family's home, wondering how he could enter upon Sarah and his son Isaac without food. He resorted to a dune of sand and filled his two bags with it to console his family. When he slept, the sand turned into pure white flour. When Sarah opened the bag, she found the flour and made food from it. When Ibrahim woke up and found the food, he asked, "Where did you get this? " She said, "From your bag. " etc. This is an evident lie and has no basis, praise be to Allah, and Isaac was only born in Ash-Sham (Syria). Until the next chapter, if Allah wills. And peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you. Chapter Twenty-one: Continuation of Abraham Chapter Twenty-one Continuation of Abraham In the previous chapter, I mentioned bright examples of Ibrahim's call, and at the end of it, I recalled the debate between the Intimate Friend (Al-Khalil) and the king of the Chaldeans who argued with Ibrahim about his Lord, and how Ibrahim established the crushing argument, so the disbeliever was confounded. Ibrahim continued to pursue his call to his people to Allah, seeking to bring them out of the darkness into the light. Regarding this, Allah says: « And [We sent] Abraham, when he said to his people, "Worship Allah and fear Him. That is better for you, if you should know. You only worship, besides Allah, idols, and you produce a falsehood. Indeed, those you worship besides Allah do not possess for you [the power of] provision. So seek provision from Allah and worship Him and be grateful to Him. To Him you will be returned. And if you deny [the message] - already have nations before you denied. And there is not upon the Messenger except [to deliver] the clear notification. " » [Al-'Ankabut: 16-18] « Do they not see how Allah begins creation and then repeats it? Indeed, that, for Allah, is easy. Say, [O Muhammad], "Travel through the land and observe how He began creation. Then Allah will produce the final creation. Indeed, Allah, over all things, is competent. " » [Al-'Ankabut: 19-20] « He punishes whom He wills and grants mercy to whom He wills, and to Him you will be returned. And you will not cause failure [to Allah] upon earth or in the heaven. And there is not for you besides Allah any protector or any helper. And those who disbelieve in the signs of Allah and the meeting with Him - those have despaired of My mercy, and for them will be a painful punishment. » [Al-'Ankabut: 21-23] « So the answer of his people was only that they said, "Kill him or burn him! " But Allah saved him from the fire. Indeed in that are signs for a people who believe. » [Al-'Ankabut: 24] « And [Abraham] said, "You have only taken, besides Allah, idols as [a bond of] affection between you in worldly life. Then on the Day of Resurrection, you will deny one another and curse one another, and your refuge will be the Fire, and you will not have any helpers. " » [Al-'Ankabut: 25-26] « So Lot believed in him. [Abraham] said, "Indeed, I will emigrate to [the service of] my Lord. Indeed, He is the Exalted in Might, the Wise. " » [Al-'Ankabut: 26] Ibrahim emigrated with his wife Sarah and Lot to Ash-Sham (Syria). Regarding this, Allah says: « They said, "Burn him and support your gods, if you are to act. " We said, "O fire, be coolness and safety upon Abraham! " And they intended for him a plot, but We made them the greatest losers. And We saved him and Lot [by taking them] to the land which We had blessed for the worlds. » [Al-Anbiya: 68-71] The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) pointed to the cooperation of the gecko/lizard (Wazagh) with Ibrahim's people in attempting to burn him, and that the gecko was blowing on Ibrahim (the fire). It is reported by Al-Bukhari and Muslim from the Hadith of Umm Sharik (may Allah be pleased with her) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) commanded the killing of the gecko. In Al-Bukhari's wording: "It was blowing on Ibrahim. " It is confirmed in the two Sahih collections (Al-Bukhari and Muslim) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "The Prophet Ibrahim was circumcised with an adze (Al-Qaddûm) when he was eighty years old. " Ibrahim (peace be upon him) settled in Ash-Sham, which is the land of the Canaanites, along with his wife Sarah and Lot. Allah then sent Lot to the people of Sodom and Gomorrah and their surrounding areas in the circle of Jordan. Ibrahim and Sarah traveled to Egypt. The king of Egypt was informed of the beauty of Ibrahim's wife and was tempted by her. Allah saved her from him and gave her Hagar as a servant. Sarah then gave her to Ibrahim, and Allah blessed him with Ishmael (Isma'il) through her. Ibrahim returned with his family to the Holy Land in Palestine. A certain disagreement arose between Sarah and Hagar, due to what Allah had decreed: that her son Ishmael would build the Sacred House in Mecca with his father. Hagar fled from Sarah, and Allah commanded Ibrahim to take Hagar and Ishmael to Mecca. Hagar took a belt to tie around her waist, letting the end trail behind her to erase her tracks from Sarah. Al-Bukhari reported in his Sahih from Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them both) who said: "The first woman to use the belt was the mother of Ishmael. She used a belt to erase her tracks from Sarah. " Then Ibrahim brought her and her son Ishmael, whom she was nursing, until he placed them near the House (Kaaba), by a large tree (Dawhah) above Zamzam in the upper part of the Mosque. There was no one in Mecca at that time, and there was no water. He placed them there and left a bag of dates and a water skin with them. Then Ibrahim turned away to leave. The mother of Ishmael followed him and said, "O Ibrahim, where are you going, leaving us in this valley where there is neither company nor anything? " She repeated this to him several times, but he did not turn to look at her. She asked him, "Did Allah command you to do this? " He said, "Yes. " She said, "Then He will not abandon us. " Then she returned. Ibrahim continued until he reached the pass where they could no longer see him. He turned his face towards the House (Kaaba) and made these supplications, raising his hands and saying: « Our Lord, I have settled some of my descendants in an uncultivated valley » [Ibrahim: 37] until he reached « ... that they may be grateful. » Ishmael's mother continued to nurse Ishmael and drink from that water. When the water in the skin was depleted, she became thirsty and her son became thirsty. She started looking at him twisting, or he said: writhing. She left, hating to look at him, and found As-Safa the nearest mountain to her on earth. She stood upon it and faced the valley, looking to see if she could see anyone, but she did not see anyone. She descended from As-Safa, and when she reached the valley, she lifted the edge of her garment and ran with the running of a person exhausted until she crossed the valley. Then she came to Al-Marwah, stood upon it, and looked to see if she could see anyone, but she did not see anyone. She did this seven times. Ibn Abbas said: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "That is the running (Sa'y) of the people between them. " When she was overlooking Al-Marwah, she heard a sound. She said: "Hush! " (meaning to herself), then she listened again and heard it again. She said, "I have heard you, if you have help. " Then she saw the Angel near the location of Zamzam. He dug with his heel, or he said: with his wing, until the water appeared. She began to encircle it with her hand and scoop water into her water skin, while the water was gushing after she scooped. Ibn Abbas said: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "May Allah have mercy on the mother of Ishmael. If she had left Zamzam (or he said: if she had not scooped from Zamzam), Zamzam would have been a flowing spring. " He said: She drank and nursed her child. The Angel said to her: "Do not fear abandonment, for here is a House of Allah which this boy and his father will build, and Allah does not abandon His people. " The House (Kaaba) was elevated from the ground like a hill, and the torrents would take from its right and left. She remained like this until a group from Jurhum, or a family from Jurhum, came along the Kadda road. They settled in the lower part of Mecca. They saw a bird circling (Ta'ifan) and said, "This bird is circling over water. We did not know of any water in this valley. " They sent one or two scouts (Jariyyan or Jariyayn) and found the water. They returned and informed them, and they came forward. Ishmael's mother was by the water. They said, "Do you permit us to settle with you? " She said, "Yes, but you have no right to the water. " They said, "Yes. " Ibn Abbas said: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "This pleased the mother of Ishmael, as she liked company. " So they settled and sent for their families, who settled with them. The boy grew up and learned Arabic from them, and they liked him and admired him when he came of age. When he reached maturity, they married him to a woman from their tribe. Ishmael's mother died. Ibrahim came after Ishmael got married to check on what he had left. He did not find Ishmael. He asked his wife about him, and she said, "He went out to seek provision for us " (and in another narration: "to hunt for us "). Then he asked her about their life and condition. She said, "We are in a bad state, in distress and hardship. " She complained to him. He said, "When your husband comes, convey my greetings to him and tell him to 'change the doorstep of his door.' " When Ishmael came, he sensed something (unusual). He asked, "Has anyone visited you? " She said, "Yes, an old man of such and such appearance came to us. He asked about you, and I informed him. He asked me how our life was, and I told him we were in hardship and distress. " He said, "Did he recommend anything to you? " She said, "Yes, he ordered me to convey his greetings to you and to tell you to 'change the doorstep of your door.' " He said, "That was my father, and he has commanded me to leave you. Go back to your family. " So he divorced her and married another woman from them. Ibrahim stayed away from them as long as Allah willed, then he came again and did not find him. He went in to his wife and asked her about him. She said, "He went out to seek provision for us. " He said, "How are you? " He asked her about their life and condition. She said, "We are in goodness and ease, " and she praised Allah. He asked, "What is your food? " She said, "Meat. " He asked, "What is your drink? " She said, "Water. " He said, "O Allah, bless them in meat and water. " The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "There was no grain for them then, and if there had been, he would have supplicated for them regarding it. " He said: "These two (meat and water) are not suitable for anyone outside Mecca who relies on them. " He said, "When your husband comes, convey my greetings to him and order him to keep the doorstep of his door. " When Ishmael came, he asked, "Has anyone visited you? " She said, "Yes, an old man of good appearance came to us, " and she praised him. "He asked about you, and I informed him. He asked me how our life was, and I told him we were in goodness. " He said, "Did he recommend anything to you? " She said, "Yes, he conveys greetings to you and orders you to keep the doorstep of your door. " He said, "That was my father, and you are the doorstep. He commanded me to keep you. " Then he stayed away from them as long as Allah willed. Then he came after that and found Ishmael sharpening his arrows under a large tree near Zamzam. When he saw him, he stood up and did as a father does with his son and a son with his father. He said, "O Ishmael, Allah has commanded me to do something. " He said, "Do what your Lord has commanded you. " He said, "And will you help me? " He said, "And I will help you. " He said, "Indeed, Allah has commanded me to build a House here, " and he pointed to a raised hill. At that moment, they raised the foundations of the House (Kaaba). Ishmael would bring the stones, and Ibrahim would build. When the building rose high, he brought that stone (Maqam Ibrahim) and placed it for him. He stood upon it to build, and Ishmael handed him the stones, and they both said: « Our Lord, accept [this] from us. Indeed, You are the Hearing, the Knowing. » [Al-Baqarah: 127] Until the next chapter, if Allah wills. And peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you. Chapter Twenty-Two: Continuation of Abraham Chapter Twenty-Two Continuation of Abraham In the previous chapter, I referred to the coming of Ibrahim with his son Ishmael and Hagar to Mecca. I mentioned what Al-Bukhari reported in his Sahih about this story, the upbringing of Ishmael, his relationship with the tribe of Jurhum, his learning of the Arabic language, and his helping his father Ibrahim in building the Sacred House (Al-Bayt Al-Haram). Allah, Blessed and Exalted is He, mentioned the story of the building of the Kaaba in His Noble Book, where He says: « And [mention] when We designated for Abraham the site of the House, [saying], "Do not associate anything with Me and purify My House for those who perform Tawaf and those who stand [in prayer] and those who bow and prostrate. And proclaim to the people the Hajj [pilgrimage]; they will come to you on foot and on every lean camel; they will come from every deep ravine - That they may witness benefits for themselves and mention the name of Allah on known days over what He has provided for them of [sacrificial] animals. So eat of them and feed the miserable and poor. Then let them end their untidiness and fulfill their vows and perform Tawaf around the ancient House (Al-Bayt Al-'Atiq). " » [Al-Hajj: 26-29] And He said: « And [mention] when Abraham was tried by his Lord with commands and he fulfilled them. [Allah] said, "Indeed, I will make you to the people an imam (leader). " [Abraham] said, "And of my descendants? " [Allah] said, "My covenant does not include the wrongdoers. " » [Al-Baqarah: 124] « And [mention] when We made the House a place of return for the people and [a place of] security. And take, [O believers], from the standing place of Abraham (Maqam Ibrahim) a place of prayer. And We charged Abraham and Ishmael, [saying], "Purify My House for those who perform Tawaf and those who are staying [there] for worship and those who bow and prostrate. " And [mention] when Abraham said, "My Lord, make this a secure city and provide its people with fruits - whoever of them believes in Allah and the Last Day. " [Allah] said, "And whoever disbelieves - I will grant him enjoyment for a little; then I will compel him to the punishment of the Fire, and wretched is the destination. " And [mention] when Abraham was raising the foundations of the House and [so was] Ishmael, [saying], "Our Lord, accept [this] from us. Indeed, You are the Hearing, the Knowing. Our Lord, and make us Muslims [in submission] to You and from our descendants a Muslim nation [in submission] to You. And show us our rites [of pilgrimage] and accept our repentance. Indeed, You are the Accepting of repentance, the Merciful. Our Lord, and send among them a messenger from themselves who will recite to them Your verses and teach them the Book and the Wisdom and purify them. Indeed, You are the Exalted in Might, the Wise. " » [Al-Baqarah: 124-129] Allah also referred to what Ibrahim did by placing Hagar and Ishmael near the site of the House, where He says: « Our Lord, I have settled some of my descendants in an uncultivated valley near Your Sacred House, our Lord, that they may establish prayer. So make hearts among the people incline toward them and provide them with fruits that they may be grateful. » [Ibrahim: 37] Allah (Exalted is He) answered Ibrahim's supplication and made this House a safe sanctuary, to which the fruits of everything are brought, as He said: « Have We not established for them a safe sanctuary, to which are brought the fruits of all things as provision from Us? But most of them do not know. » [Al-Qasas: 57] And as He said: « Do they not see that We have made [Makkah] a safe sanctuary, while people are being snatched away all around them? » [Al-'Ankabut: 67] Allah, Blessed and Exalted is He, also answered the supplication of His Intimate Friend, Ibrahim, by sending Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) from the descendants of Ishmael, the people of the Sacred House, to recite to them the verses of Allah, teach them the Book and the Wisdom, and purify them. That is why it is mentioned in the Hasan Hadith that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "I am the supplication of my father Ibrahim, and the glad tidings of Jesus about me. And my mother saw that a light came out from her, illuminating for her the palaces of Ash-Sham (Syria). " This is also found in the Musnad of Imam Ahmad from the Hadith of Abi Umamah and Al-'Irbad ibn Sariyah, the wording being that of Abi Umamah. Allah, Blessed and Exalted is He, also mentioned the story of Ibrahim's emigration, the glad tidings of Ishmael, and the story of his vision of sacrificing him. He said: « And indeed, among his type (of Noah's) was Abraham. When he came to his Lord with a sound heart. [When] he said to his father and his people, "What is it you worship? Is it falsehood - [as] deities besides Allah - that you want? Then what is your thought about the Lord of the worlds? " And he cast a [contemplative] look at the stars And said, "Indeed, I am sick. " » [As-Saffat: 83-89] It is as if he wanted them to disperse and move away from him so he could attend to destroying their idols by making them think he was ill so they would not touch him, especially after his look at the stars. His look at the stars was not meant to learn his condition from the star, just as his saying, « Indeed, I am sick, » was not meant to mean he was afflicted with a contagious disease, but rather he meant in himself that he was weak, and every son of Adam is weak, regardless of his health. Man was created weak. This is an example of Tawriyah (ambiguity/equivocation), and in Tawriyah there is a way out of lying (far be it from him to lie), although Tawriyah may be called a lie in consideration of the real intent, but it is not the blameworthy lie. It is like calling non-blameworthy envy (Ghibtah) jealousy (Hasad), as in the saying of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) reported by Al-Bukhari and Muslim from the Hadith of Ibn Mas'ud (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "There is no jealousy (Hasad) except in two [cases]: a man whom Allah has given wealth and he spends it rightfully, and a man whom Allah has given wisdom and he judges by it and teaches it. " The general body of scholars interpreted jealousy (Hasad) in this Hadith as Ghibtah (non-blameworthy envy), as the blameworthy jealousy is wishing for the removal of a blessing from others. There is no doubt among the people of knowledge that Ibrahim's saying (peace be upon him): « Indeed, I am sick, » as well as his saying: « Rather, this - the largest of them - did it, » [Al-Anbiya: 63] and his saying to the king of Egypt about Sarah: "She is my sister, " is not considered by the scholars to be a blameworthy lie, but rather a matter of Tawriyah and Ambiguity (Ma'arid). Then Allah (Exalted is He) said: « So they turned away from him, retreating. » [As-Saffat: 90-91] « Then he turned to their gods and said, "Do you not eat? " » (Because the disbelievers had placed food by their idols) « What is [wrong] with you that you do not speak? " So he proceeded to [lay] upon them a blow with [his] right hand. » [As-Saffat: 92-93] « Then [the polytheists] came toward him, hastening. » [As-Saffat: 94] « He said, "Do you worship that which you [yourselves] carve, While Allah created you and that which you do? " » [As-Saffat: 95-96] « They said, "Construct for him a furnace and throw him into the blazing fire. " » [As-Saffat: 97] « And they intended for him a plot, but We made them the lowest. » [As-Saffat: 98] « And [Abraham] said, "Indeed, I am going to [the service of] my Lord; He will guide me. " » [As-Saffat: 99] (Meaning: I am emigrating from the land of disbelief to the land which Allah has blessed for the worlds, and I hope that Allah (Exalted is He) will guide me to the path of goodness and what is right for my religion and my worldly life.) « My Lord, grant me [a child] from the righteous. So We gave him good tidings of a forbearing boy. » [As-Saffat: 100-101] « And when he reached with him [the age of] working, he said, "O my son, indeed I have seen in a dream that I [must] sacrifice you, so see what you think. " He said, "O my father, do what you are commanded. You will find me, if Allah wills, of the patient. " » [As-Saffat: 102] « And when they had both submitted (Aslamâ) » [As-Saffat: 103] (Meaning: They submitted to the command of Allah) « and he had put him down upon his forehead, We called to him, "O Abraham, You have fulfilled the vision. Indeed, We thus reward the doers of good. Indeed, this was the clear trial. " And We ransomed him with a great sacrifice, And We left for him [good commendation] among later generations: "Peace upon Abraham. " Indeed, We thus reward the doers of good. Indeed, he was of Our believing servants. » [As-Saffat: 103-111] « And We gave him good tidings of Isaac, a prophet from among the righteous. And We blessed him and Isaac. » [As-Saffat: 112-113] There is no doubt that the context of these noble verses indicates that the one to be sacrificed was Ishmael, not Isaac, because the glad tidings of Isaac are mentioned after the glad tidings of Ishmael, who is described as a forbearing boy (Ghulâm Halîm). Isaac, when given the glad tidings, is described as a knowing boy (Ghulâm 'Alîm). Another evidence that the one to be sacrificed was Ishmael, not Isaac, is that when the glad tidings of Isaac were given, Allah said: « ...and following Isaac, Jacob (Ya'qûb). » [Hud: 71] This implies that Isaac would live and have a son during his father's lifetime. How could he be commanded to sacrifice him when he was a youth who had not yet had a child, with the certainty that he would not die until Jacob was born to him? Ibn Ishaq reported from Muhammad ibn Ka'b Al-Qurazi that he told them: "The one whom Allah commanded Abraham to sacrifice of his two sons was Ishmael. We find that in the Book of Allah (Exalted is He). That is because when Allah (Exalted is He) finished the story of the one sacrificed from the sons of Abraham, He said: « And We gave him good tidings of Isaac, a prophet from among the righteous. » [As-Saffat: 112] And Allah (Exalted is He) says: « So We gave her good tidings of Isaac and following Isaac, Jacob. » [Hud: 71] (He says: a son and a grandson). He would not have commanded him to sacrifice Isaac when there was the promise he had been given about him. It was none other than Ishmael who was commanded to be sacrificed. " Ibn Ishaq said: "I heard him say that often. " Ibn Ishaq also reported from Muhammad ibn Ka'b Al-Qurazi that he told him that he mentioned this to Umar ibn Abd Al-Aziz (may Allah be pleased with him) while he was Caliph and was with him in Ash-Sham. Umar said to him, "This is something I had not considered, and I see it as you have said. " Then he sent for a man who was with him in Ash-Sham, who had been a Jew and had embraced Islam and whose Islam was good, and who was considered one of their scholars. Umar ibn Abd Al-Aziz (may Allah be pleased with him) asked him about this. Muhammad ibn Ka'b said, "I was with Umar ibn Abd Al-Aziz. " Umar asked the man, "Which of Abraham's two sons was commanded to be sacrificed? " He replied, "By Allah, O Commander of the Believers, it was Ishmael. The Jews know that, but they envy you, the Arabs, that your father (Ishmael) was the one involved in Allah's command and the virtue that Allah mentioned regarding his patience with the command. So they deny it and claim it was Isaac because Isaac is their father. " This is not the first denial from the Jews. They denied that Abraham built the Kaaba. Knowing what the Jews would do, Allah (Exalted is He) left the Standing Place of Abraham (Maqam Ibrahim) in the Sacred House to be a witness against them until the Day of Resurrection, with knowledge of it being inherited generation after generation. Regarding this, Allah says: « Indeed, the first House [of worship] established for mankind was that at Bakkah [Mecca] - blessed and a guidance for the worlds. In it are clear signs [such as] the standing place of Abraham (Maqam Ibrahim). » [Al 'Imran: 96-97] Until the next chapter, if Allah wills. And peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you. Chapter Twenty-Three: Continuation of Abraham Chapter Twenty-Three Continuation of Abraham In the previous chapter, I pointed out that Allah (Exalted is He) preserved the Standing Place of Abraham (Maqam Ibrahim) in the Sacred House to be a witness to Abraham's building of this House, knowing that the Jews would deny that Abraham was the one who built the Honored Kaaba in Mecca. He placed clear signs in it, as He says: « In it are clear signs [such as] the standing place of Abraham (Maqam Ibrahim). » [Al 'Imran: 97] And as He said: « And take, [O believers], from the standing place of Abraham (Maqam Ibrahim) a place of prayer. » [Al-Baqarah: 125] I highlighted that the Arabs have inherited the knowledge of the Standing Place of Abraham from generation to generation until the sending of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Regarding this, Abu Talib says in his famous Lamiyyah: "And the footprint of Abraham on the rock is fresh, of his feet, barefoot and not shod. " It is reported that a mat was spread for Abd Al-Muttalib, the grandfather of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), in the shade of the Kaaba. His sons would sit around his mat until he came out to it, and none of his sons would sit on it out of reverence for him. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) would come when he was less than five years old, and Abd Al-Muttalib would take him and seat him on his mat. A group from Bani Madlij came performing Tawaf (circumambulation) around the Kaaba. When they saw the foot of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), they looked intently at it, then they looked intently at the Standing Place of Abraham. Then they said to Abd Al-Muttalib, "Whose boy is this, O Sheikh? " He said, "This is Muhammad, my son. " They said, "We have never seen a foot resembling the one on the rock (Maqam Ibrahim) like the foot of your son. " It is confirmed that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) described Ibrahim the Intimate Friend as the person who most resembled him. Al-Bukhari and Muslim reported that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said, while speaking about the night of his Night Journey (Isra'): "I saw Moses, and he was a man of medium build (Darb) - meaning, not very fleshy - with smooth hair (Rajil) - meaning, his hair was well-kept and not curly - as if he was one of the men of Azd Shanu'ah. And I saw Jesus, and he was a man of medium height (Raba'ah), reddish, as if he had just come out of a bathhouse (Dîmâs). And I am the one who most resembles Abraham among his children. " Just as Allah joined Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and his father Ibrahim in physical resemblance, He also joined them in the quality of Intimate Friendship (Khullah). Allah took no intimate friend other than Muhammad and Ibrahim (peace and blessings of Allah be upon them). He also joined them in the prayer upon them, so we say in the Tashahhud: "O Allah, send prayers upon Muhammad and upon the family of Muhammad, as You sent prayers upon Ibrahim and upon the family of Ibrahim. And send blessings upon Muhammad and upon the family of Muhammad, as You sent blessings upon Ibrahim and upon the family of Ibrahim in the worlds. Indeed, You are Praiseworthy, Glorious. " The Jews were keen on cutting every link between the Arabs and Ishmael and Abraham, and they deleted from the Torah everything related to Ishmael after his father took him and left him and his mother in the wilderness of Paran, and they cut off all news of him after that. They were ignorant of or chose to ignore that the wilderness of Paran is the land of Mecca. Ibrahim settled in the Blessed Land of Palestine, but he continued to frequent Mecca to check on what he had left there and to perform Tawaf around the Ancient House (Al-Bayt Al-'Atiq). He supplicated for Mecca before the building of the House, saying: « My Lord, make this a secure city » [Al-Baqarah: 126] And during one of his visits to Mecca after the building of the House and the birth of Isaac, he said: « My Lord, make this city secure... » [Ibrahim: 35] Lot had suffered hardship and difficulty from his people. They called him a liar and called the Messengers liars. They committed immorality with men of the worlds. When Allah intended to destroy the people of Lot, He sent some angels to destroy them. He commanded them to pass by Ibrahim before the destruction of the towns of Lot's people to give him the glad tidings of Isaac, and following Isaac, Jacob. Allah (Exalted is He) recounted the story of the glad tidings of Isaac in several places in His Noble Book, where He says: « And already had Our messengers come to Abraham with good tidings. They said, "Peace. " He said, "Peace. " And he was not long in bringing [to them] a roasted calf. But when he saw their hands not reaching for it, he became wary of them and felt a fear of them. He said, "Will you not eat? " And he felt a fear of them. They said, "Fear not. " And they gave him good tidings of a knowing boy (‘Alîm). Then his wife came forward screaming and slapped her face and said, "[I am] an old barren woman! " They said, "Thus has said your Lord. Indeed, He is the Wise, the Knowing. " » [Adh-Dhariyat: 24-30] The Noble Qur'an explicitly states that Jacob was the son of Isaac, where Allah says: « Or were you witnesses when death approached Jacob, when he said to his sons, "What will you worship after me? " They said, "We will worship your God and the God of your fathers, Abraham and Ishmael and Isaac - one God. And we are in submission to Him. " » [Al-Baqarah: 133] (Abraham is the grandfather, Ishmael is the uncle, and Isaac is the father, and all are referred to as 'fathers'). Allah, Blessed and Exalted is He, described Abraham with [various] qualities, saying: « Indeed, Abraham was a [single] nation, obedient to Allah, inclining toward truth (Hanîf) » [An-Nahl: 120] And He said: « Indeed, Abraham was one who was ever supplicating (Awwâh) and forbearing (Halîm). » [At-Tawbah: 114] And He said: « And Allah took Abraham as an intimate friend (Khalîl). » [An-Nisa: 125] As for what Allah recounted concerning Abraham in His saying: « And [mention] when Abraham said, "My Lord, show me how You give life to the dead. " [Allah] said, "Have you not believed? " He said, "Yes, but [I ask] only that my heart may be satisfied. " [Allah] said, "Take four of the birds and draw them toward you.
