" » [Al-Baqarah: 260] This is explicit that when Abraham asked, he was certain of the Resurrection and of Allah's ability to bring the dead back to life, but he wanted to add the evidence of certainty ('Ayn Al-Yaqîn) to the knowledge of certainty ('Ilm Al-Yaqîn), and for this to be one of the perceptible, material proofs of Allah's ability to bring the dead back to life. Allah has recounted..." Stories of the Prophets: The True Narrative 3.1 In Sūrat Al-Baqarah (The Cow), the Most High mentions a set of examples concerning this. He mentions the story of the man killed among the Children of Israel and striking him with a part of the slaughtered cow, and He said: $Thus does Allah bring the dead to life and show you His signs that you might reason.$ [Al-Baqarah: 73]. And He said: $And [recall] when you said, «O Moses, we will not believe you until we see Allah outright»; so the thunderbolt struck you while you were looking on. Then We resurrected you after your death that you might be grateful.$ [Al-Baqarah: 55-56]. And He said: $Have you not considered those who left their homes in thousands, fearing death? Allah said to them, «Die»; then He restored them to life. Indeed, Allah is a Possessor of bounty for the people, but most of the people do not show gratitude.$ [Al-Baqarah: 243]. And He said: $Or [consider] the one who passed by a town while it was a ruin over its roofless walls. He said, «How will Allah bring this back to life after its death?» So Allah caused him to die for a hundred years; then He revived him. He said, «How long have you remained?» He said, «I have remained a day or part of a day.» He said, «Rather, you have remained one hundred years. Look at your food and your drink; it has not changed. And look at your donkey. And [We did this] that We might make you a sign for the people. Look at the bones, how We bring them together and then clothe them with flesh.» When it became clear to him, he said, «I know that Allah is over all things competent.»$ [Al-Baqarah: 259]. Immediately after this story, He quotes the saying of Abraham: $My Lord, show me how You give life to the dead.$ [Al-Baqarah: 260]. As for what Al-Bukhari narrated in his Ṣaḥīḥ from the Hadith of Abū Hurayrah, that the Messenger of Allah said: “We are more entitled to doubt than Abraham when he said: $My Lord, show me how You give life to the dead.$ [Allah] said: «Do you not believe?» He said: «Yes, but that my heart may be satisfied.»” [Al-Baqarah: 260]. May Allah have mercy on Lot! He indeed sought refuge in a strong support. And had I remained in prison for as long as Joseph remained, I would have answered the caller. The purpose of this is to praise these three Prophets and to show the loftiness of their status. If Abraham had been in doubt, I would have been more deserving of doubt than him. And since it has not crossed anyone's mind that Muhammad doubts Allah's power to revive the dead, the same applies to Abraham. This is one of the well-known rhetorical styles, known as ‘Confirming the Praise by what Resembles a Censure’ (Ta’kīd al-Madḥ bi-mā yushbihu al-Dhamm). The 'strong support' (Rukn Shadīd) in which Lot sought refuge is Allah, the Blessed and Most High. His saying in the verse: $...or seek refuge in a strong support.$ [Hūd: 80]. The word ‘or’ (aw) here means 'but' (bal), i.e., 'but I seek refuge in Allah'. Then follows the praise of Joseph for preserving himself from evil despite the harm and imprisonment he endured. And the saying of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: “Had I remained in prison for as long as Joseph remained, I would have answered the caller,” meaning, I would have hastened to respond to what the King's messenger called me to and would have left the prison. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ intended to draw attention to the high status attained by Joseph the Truthful (Aṣ-Ṣiddīq). Until the next chapter, God willing, and may the peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you. Chapter Twenty-Four Continuation on Abraham Stories of the Prophets: The True Narrative In the previous chapter, I referred to what Allah, the Blessed and Most High, recounted about Abraham, from his saying: $My Lord, show me how You give life to the dead$ ...to the end of the verse [Al-Baqarah: 260]. I explained the meaning of the Messenger of Allah’s statement: “We are more entitled to doubt than Abraham,” and clarified that what came from Abraham was not doubt, and that the intention of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was to praise Abraham and show the loftiness of his rank. I also explained that this came in the manner of the rhetorical style known as ‘Confirming the Praise by what Resembles a Censure’ (Ta’kīd al-Madḥ bi-mā yushbihu al-Dhamm), like the saying of the poet: “They have no fault except that their swords bear nicks from clashing against the battalions.” Allah commanded His Prophet to follow the example of Abraham. Concerning this: $Say, «Indeed, my Lord has guided me to a straight path—a religion of correctness—the creed of Abraham, inclining toward truth, and he was not of the polytheists.» Say, «Indeed, my prayer, my rites of sacrifice, my living and my dying are for Allah, Lord of the worlds. No partner has He. And this I have been commanded, and I am the first of the Muslims.»$ [Al-An'ām: 161-163]. He refuted the claim of the Jews and Christians that they loved Abraham and were upon his religion, saying: $Abraham was neither a Jew nor a Christian, but he was one inclining toward truth, a Muslim [submitting to Allah]. And he was not of the polytheists. Indeed, the most deserving of Abraham among the people are those who followed him [in his lifetime] and this Prophet [Muhammad] and those who have believed. And Allah is the protector of the believers.$ [Āl 'Imrān: 67-68]. And He said: $O People of the Scripture, why do you dispute about Abraham while the Torah and the Gospel were not revealed until after him? Then will you not reason?$ [Āl 'Imrān: 65]. And the Most High said: $And who would abandon the religion of Abraham except one who is foolish in mind? And We had chosen him in this world, and indeed, in the Hereafter he will be among the righteous. When his Lord said to him, «Submit,» he said, «I have submitted to the Lord of the worlds.» And Abraham instructed his sons [to do the same] and [likewise] Jacob, [saying], «O my sons, indeed Allah has chosen for you this religion, so do not die except as Muslims.»$ [Al-Baqarah: 130-132]. Allah the Most High described Abraham as 'one who fulfilled' (waffā), meaning he completed everything Allah commanded him to do. Concerning this, He says: $...and [of] Abraham, who fulfilled [his obligations].$ [An-Najm: 37]. And He says: $And [mention, O Muhammad], when Abraham was tried by his Lord with commands and he fulfilled them. [Allah] said, «Indeed, I will make you a leader for the people.» [Abraham] said, «And [make leaders] from my offspring?» [Allah] said, «My covenant does not reach the wrongdoers.»$ [Al-Baqarah: 124]. And as He said: $Indeed, Abraham was a [single] nation, obedient to Allah, inclining toward truth, and he was not of the polytheists. [He was] grateful for His favors; Allah chose him and guided him to a straight path. And We gave him good in this world, and indeed, in the Hereafter he will be among the righteous. Then We revealed to you, [O Muhammad], to follow the religion of Abraham, inclining toward truth; and he was not of the polytheists.$ [An-Naḥl: 120-123]. The polytheists used to claim that they were upon the religion of Abraham. They had painted images of Abraham and Ishmael and hung their images in the Kaaba with divining arrows (Azlām) in their hands, using them to seek omens. The Messenger of Allah swore that they never sought omens with the divining arrows, and he ordered the images to be erased. Al-Bukhari narrated in his Ṣaḥīḥ from the Hadith of Ibn 'Abbās that when the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, saw the images in the House, he did not enter until he ordered them to be erased. He saw Abraham and Ishmael with divining arrows in their hands and said: “May Allah fight them! By Allah, they never sought omens with the divining arrows.” In some of Al-Bukhari's narrations of this Hadith, he said: “May Allah fight them! They knew well that our ancestor never sought omens with them.” Allah the Most High took none of His creation as intimate friends (Khalīlayn) except Abraham and Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon them both). It is established in the two Ṣaḥīḥs (Al-Bukhari and Muslim) from the Hadith of Jundub Al-Bajali, 'Abdullah ibn 'Amr, and Ibn Mas'ūd, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: “O people, indeed Allah has taken me as an intimate friend (Khalīl).” Al-Bukhari also reported from the Hadith of Abū Sa'īd that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said in his last sermon: “O people, if I were to take an intimate friend (Khalīl) from the inhabitants of the earth, I would take Abū Bakr as an intimate friend, but your companion is the Intimate Friend (Khalīl) of Allah.” Al-Bukhari also reported in his Ṣaḥīḥ from the Hadith of 'Amr ibn Maymūn, who said: When Mu'ādh arrived in Yemen, he led them in the morning prayer and recited: $...and Allah took Abraham as an intimate friend.$ [An-Nisā: 125]. A man among the people said: “The eye of Abraham’s mother has been comforted.” Al-Bukhari and Muslim reported from the Hadith of Abū Hurayrah, who said: It was asked, “O Messenger of Allah, who is the most honorable of people?” He said: “The most honorable of them is the most righteous of them.” They said: “That is not what we ask you about.” He said: “Then the most honorable of people is Joseph, the Prophet of Allah, the son of the Prophet of Allah, the son of the Prophet of Allah, the son of the Intimate Friend of Allah (Abraham).” They said: “That is not what we ask you about.” He said: “Then you are asking me about the origins of the Arabs?” They said: “Yes.” He said: “The best of them in the time of ignorance (Jāhiliyyah) are the best of them in Islam, if they attain understanding of the religion (fiqh).” The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, informed that Abraham, the Intimate Friend of the Most Gracious (Khalīl Ar-Raḥmān), will be the first person to be clothed on the Day of Resurrection. Al-Bukhari and Muslim reported from the Hadith of Ibn 'Abbās, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: “The people will be gathered naked, uncircumcised. The first to be clothed will be Abraham.” Then he recited: $...As We began the first creation, We will repeat it.$ [Al-Anbiyā: 104]. And Allah the Most High made it part of Abraham's reward for building the Sacred Kaaba that He placed him leaning his back against the Bayt Al-Ma'mūr (the Frequented House) in the Seventh Heaven. This is mentioned in Ṣaḥīḥ Al-Bukhari in the Hadith of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, concerning the Night Journey (Isrā'), where he said: “Then we came to the Seventh Heaven. It was said: ‘Who is this?’ It was said: ‘Gabriel.’ It was said: ‘And who is with you?’ It was said: ‘Muhammad.’ It was said: ‘Has he been sent for?’ ‘Welcome to him, and what an excellent coming he has!’ Then I came to Abraham and greeted him. He said: ‘Welcome to you, my son and Prophet.’ In one narration: ‘Welcome to the righteous son and the righteous Prophet.’ And behold, he—meaning Abraham—was leaning his back against the Bayt Al-Ma'mūr, and seventy thousand angels enter it every day, never to return to it.” Despite this honor and high status of Abraham, the Intimate Friend of the Most Gracious, he could not benefit his father, who died in polytheism (Shirk). Al-Bukhari reported in his Ṣaḥīḥ from the Hadith of Abū Hurayrah that the Prophet ﷺ said: “Abraham will meet his father Azar on the Day of Resurrection, and over Azar's face will be dust and darkness. Abraham will say to him: ‘Did I not tell you not to disobey me?’ His father will say to him: ‘Today, I will not disobey you.’ Abraham will say: ‘O Lord, You promised me that You would not disgrace me on the Day they are resurrected. What disgrace is greater than my farthest father?’ Allah the Most High will say: ‘Indeed, I have forbidden Paradise to the disbelievers.’” Then it will be said: “O Abraham! What is beneath your feet?” He will look and see a filthy, smeared hyena, which will be seized by its legs and thrown into the Fire. This is in line with what the Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: “O Fāṭima, daughter of Muhammad, ask me for whatever you wish from my property, for I cannot avail you against Allah at all. And O 'Abbās, uncle of the Prophet, save your own soul, I cannot avail you against Allah at all.” And as He said to him: $Indeed, you do not guide whom you like, but Allah guides whom He wills. And He is most knowing of the [rightly] guided.$ [Al-Qaṣaṣ: 56]. And when the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said after the death of Abū Ṭālib: “I will ask for forgiveness for you as long as I am not forbidden to do so,” Allah revealed: $It is not for the Prophet and those who have believed to ask forgiveness for the polytheists, even if they were relatives, after it has become clear to them that they are companions of the Hellfire. And the request for forgiveness of Abraham for his father was only because of a promise he had made to him. But when it became clear to him that he was an enemy of Allah, he disassociated himself from him. Indeed, Abraham was one who frequently invoked [Allah] and was forbearing.$ [At-Tawbah: 113-114]. I have chosen to mention that Allah the Blessed and Most High brought together Abraham and Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon them both) in their physical and moral attributes. Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was the person who most resembled his father Abraham (peace and blessings be upon them both). Al-Bukhari reported from the Hadith of Ibn 'Abbās, who said: “$Sufficient for us is Allah, and [He is] the best Disposer of affairs.$ [Āl 'Imrān: 173] was said by Abraham when he was thrown into the fire. And it was said by Muhammad when it was said to him: $Indeed, the people have gathered against you, so fear them. But it [merely] increased them in faith, and they said, «Sufficient for us is Allah, and [He is] the best Disposer of affairs.» So they returned with favor from Allah and bounty, no harm having touched them. And they pursued the pleasure of Allah, and Allah is the Possessor of great bounty.$ [Āl 'Imrān: 173-174]. Al-Bukhari also reported in his Ṣaḥīḥ from the Hadith of Ibn 'Abbās, who said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ used to seek protection for Al-Ḥasan and Al-Ḥusayn and would say: “Indeed, your father (Abraham) used to seek protection for Ishmael and Isaac with it: $I seek refuge in the perfect words of Allah from every devil and every harmful pest, and from every evil eye.$” Allah confined the Prophethood and the Book to the descendants of Abraham after him, as He says: $And We had already sent Noah and Abraham and placed in their descendants prophethood and the Scripture.$ [Al-Ḥadīd: 26]. And as He said: $And We gave him Isaac and Jacob and placed in his descendants prophethood and the Scripture.$ [Al-'Ankabūt: 27]. Thus, every Book that Allah the Most High revealed to a Prophet after Abraham was in his descendants. From Isaac was born Jacob, who is Israel, and to him all their tribes (Asbāṭ) trace their lineage. Prophethood remained among them until it was sealed with Jesus, son of Mary, who is from the Children of Israel through his mother's lineage. As for the second branch of Abraham's progeny, it is Ishmael. And from his progeny came the Seal of the Prophets and the Master of the Messengers, who is the dazzling Jewel and the brilliant Pearl, and he is the possessor of the Praised Station (Maqām Maḥmūd) and the Visited Basin (Ḥawḍ Mawrūd) which the first and the last will envy on the Day of Resurrection. It is established in Ṣaḥīḥ Muslim from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, that he said: “I will stand at a station that all creatures will desire, even Abraham.” Until the next chapter, God willing, and may the peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you.
source: Holy Quran (Al-Baqarah 260, etc.), Sahih Al-Bukhari and Sahih Muslim, and the translated text above.
